column1: Among the Napa Valley's most crowning achievements in Cabernet, this vintage of Hillside Select is stunning, bright and beguiling in every way. Intensely layered, its interwoven flavors burst in black licorice, dark chocolate, pipe tobacco, gun smoke and garrigue. Spicy oak adds to the power and weight. Drinkable now, it will show even greater finesse in time; enjoy best 20232033 and possibly beyond.

Intoxicating scents of smoke, flint, dried mountain herb and woodland berry are just some of the multifaceted aromas you'll find on this dazzling Nebbiolo. It's extremely elegant, with a weightless intensity, delivering Marasca cherry, crushed strawberry, white pepper and tobacco framed in fine tannins. Vibrant acidity gives it impeccable balance while a flinty mineral vein energizes the finish. Some may find this almost too ethereal while lovers of finesse, complexity and balance will be enchanted. Drink through 2027.

Since the first vintage in 1991, this wine and its vineyard have travelled far. Now close to the top of the classification tree in Saint-milion, this vintage shows the impressive nature of this powerful wine. With a good balance between acidity and black fruits backed up by tannins, the wine is powerful and stylish. Drink from 2027.

Almost entirely Cabernet Franc, this single-vineyard wine has a wonderful perfumed character. Firm tannins are fully integrated into the fruit, giving a structured yet balanced feel. Ripe and elegant, it will age well. Drink from 2027.

Direct and concentrated, this wine is powered by tannins and a firm texture. Dense, it has the potential for plenty of fruit as it matures. That will take time, because this impressive wine is powered by its structure. Wait until 2028.

Always one of the great white wines of the world, this vintage continues that reputation. With its richness, density and layers of fruit and acidity, this wine is powerful and beautifully ripe. The wood aging is just a hint in background. Drink from 2024.

It's always a clich to compare wine to the nectar of the gods but there's little that comes closer than this. It's decadently sweet, offering layer upon layer of unctuous honey and stone-fruit nectar, yet exhilarating, fine and filigreed. The finish is endless and breathtaking. Delicious now but will hold for decades to come.

Starting with the 2008 vintage, the firm's flagship bottling is now made without added dosage. It opens with aromas of yellow stone fruit, brioche and crushed stone that carry over to the elegantly structured palate, along with tangy tangerine and bright acidity. A refined perlage gives it a weightless concentration while a savory mineral note lingers on the bone-dry finish. In a word, it's gorgeous.
This wine is packed with ripe black fruit and structured by a dense, mineral texture. Generous fruit tones and plenty of tannic grip translate to a wine worthy of the cellar. Drink from 2025.

This wine, rich and opulent, defines the terroir of this estate. It has a rich, dense character, powerful and concentrated. The juicy black fruits enhance the impression of generosity as well as concentration. Drink from 2027.
This wine is dense in expressive, dark fruit and solid tannins which give it a rich, enveloping feel. With its spicy score and crisp acidity, there is great potential for aging. Drink from 2025.

If any wine from the Douro has a Bordeaux influence, it is this wine. Produced as part of a joint venture between the Prats family of Bordeaux and the Symington family of the Douro, this wine shows great attention to tannins and structure while allowing the black fruits to shine. It is a stylish wine, powerful while wearing that power lightly. Drink this wine, from a very good year, from 2022.

This huge, dense and firmly structured bottling absolutely begs for time in the cellar to allow the primary characteristics to mellow and greater elegance and nuance to unfold. Currently, it's an absolute bruiser, with boatloads of plush, ripe black berry and plum characteristics that are coupled with seductive notes of campfire, vanilla bean, Thin Mint, woodspice and licorice root. The assertive tannins produce a bold, extremely firm texture that is in equal measure to the superbly rich and concentrated fruit. Secondary notes of pencil shavings, violets, pipe tobacco and char unfold beneath the fruit, and suggest even further evolution and grace to come with time. Drink 20262038.

While this wine is rich, it has a classical demeanor, with fine tannins that support but never dominate the ripe black fruits. Full of juicy acidity, it offers black currants and some fine, firm tannins at the end. This will take some time to mature, and the wine will not be ready to drink before 2027.

Full of black-currant flavor, this firm wine has structure and a rich texture. Its bolstering tannins and vibrant acidity mark out an age-worthy selection. Spice tones and a dry core set the stage for a slow development into an even more complex and fulfilling wine. Drink from 2025.

Sweet tangerine, pineapple and mango pulsate through this piercing, feather-light wine. It's an exhilarating sweet sip accented by savory nuances of musk and white truffles. Expansive yet thrilling and spry, the finish meanders endlessly. Drinks beautifully now but should hold gorgeously for decades to come.

While exceptionally sheer, almost diaphanous in texture, this sprightly, sumptuous Riesling offers penetrating layers of honey, melon and pineapple nuanced by spice, hay and crushed earth. It's a spine tingling, concentrated wine, with an endless, rippling finish. Delightful already but sure to hold for decades to come.
This beautifully golden-colored, oak-aged wine is bone dry, with the intense acidity working with an orange-marmalade character. Together they give a mature wine that is ready to drink.

Concentrated and with tight, mineral fruitiness, this wine is potentially ripe and rich, with citrus and orange peel crispness. The wine will be rich, rounded and packed with fruit, but it will take time. Drink from 2023.

Spice and ripe fruit aromas lead into a wine that has both richness and a crisp, fruity herbal character. Acidity shines through, giving the wine a tangy, mineral edginess. It will be a delicious fruity wine. Drink from 2023.

This dazzling sparkler hits all the right marks. It opens with heady aromas of citrus, bread crust and lemon pastry while the vibrant palate delivers juicy tangerine, Rennet apple and an energizing mineral note alongside an elegant, continuous perlage. Made from 60% Chardonnay and 40% Pinot Nero with no added dosage, it boasts a pristine quality and a pure, crisp finish.

Bottled in 2017, this wine aged in old oak for 60 years. It still has all the sweetness you would expect from a Bual Madeira while also having that old wood, almost golden character. Acidity balances the opulent fruit. Drink this wine now.

This is a rich style of white, in keeping with the rich vintage. Its acidity and tight texture are paired off with the apricot and ripe pear fruitiness. Spice from wood aging adds an attractive background. Drink from 2022.

Sturdy and structured, this wine offers beautiful tones of ripe blackberry and black cherry, with a dark streak of chocolate. It's primed and brightened by snappy acids, and flows gracefully into a pleasingly creamy finish highlighted by smoke and toast.

Demure notes of lemon and crushed mineral on the nose contrast an exuberant palate full of pink grapefruit and hibiscus nectar. It's a gorgeously silky, concentrated dry Riesling, with a firm mineral backbone and electric acidity that need time to meld. Hold until 2020 as it's likely to improve well through 2030.

First produced in 1991, this wine was a pioneer in the new generation of red wines from the Douro. It is firm with tannins and the strong minerality typical of the Douro. It has weight despite its low alcohol and tense fruitiness. Drink this complex wine with great aging potential from 2020.

The best bottle in a stellar lineup of the winery's first 2016 releases, this marries old-vine elegance to lush aromatics, with entwined notes of walnuts, raspberries, thyme, rosewater and citrus. It's a long-lasting, beautifully integrated wine, made with grapes from some of the oldest blocks in the vineyard.

This stunning sparkler is all about precision, finesse and purity. It opens with enticing scents of white spring flower, crushed stone, lemon pastry and hazelnut. The aromas carry over to the chiseled palate together with creamy yellow apple, tangerine zest, brioche and mineral notes alongside an elegant perlage. Vibrant acidity gives it balance and structure.

Balanced and fragrant, this impressive sparkler offers alluring scents of yellow stone fruit and an inviting whiff of brioche. A blend of 80% Chardonnay and 20% Pinot Nero, it's elegantly structured and focused, delivering flavors of yellow apple, white peach, bread crust and crushed stone framed in bright acidity and elegant perlage. A vanilla note lingers on the bone-dry finish. It's extremely well balanced and refined.

This excellent wine from a steep terraced vineyard offers beautiful aromas of lavender and violet that segue to a palate replete with black fruit, black pepper and anise tones. Each flavor seems especially well defined and they layer together harmoniously on a velvety texture that provides good support for all that concentration. Best after 2020.

The name of this release goes back to the first red wine made by Niepoort in 1990. The wine was made with long old-barrel aging and was not bottled until 2017. Tannins are important to this rich wine; so is the powerful black fruit. They offer an mineral- and fruit-driven wine that still needs to age. Drink from 2020.

This wine is ripe, rich and generous. It brings out the almost-sweet character of the fruit in this vintage. At the same time, the tannins are firm and support all this fruitiness. The wine will develop well. Drink from 2024.

This wine offers a compelling nose of pretty florals and spicy forest-floor aromas. Dense on entry, it lingers in flavors of orange, cherry and rhubarb, with textured tannins and an undercurrent of a stony, mineral character.

This wine is ripe, rich and generous. It brings out the almost-sweet character of the fruit in this vintage. At the same time, the tannins are firm and support all this fruitiness. The wine will develop well. Drink from 2024.

This wine offers a compelling nose of pretty florals and spicy forest-floor aromas. Dense on entry, it lingers in flavors of orange, cherry and rhubarb, with textured tannins and an undercurrent of a stony, mineral character.

Enticing scents of scorched earth, cassis, new leather, vanilla, truffle and Mediterranean brush abound on this classy red. The full-bodied youthfully austere palate is still tightly wound but already shows mature black cherry, raspberry preserve, licorice and grilled herb set against a backbone of firm fine-grained tannins. Give it time to fully develop. Drink 20222030.

Smoothly textured, this fruity wine offers acidity and ripe apricot flavors. The zesty, mineral texture will allow it to develop well, promising of great fruit and texture in the future. Wait until 2024.

This powerful wine has great structure, fine and elegant tannins, and ripe black fruits. It wears its heart on its sleeve. The concentration doesn't take away from the juicy fruit and wealth of complex flavors. A wine with a great future, it won't be ready to drink before 2026.

Perhaps the best vintage of Compostella to date, the 2015 vintage is a blend of 40% Cabernet Franc, 32% Cabernet Sauvignon, 13% Merlot, 11% Petit Verdot and 4% Malbec. It showcases a beautiful elegance and herbal edge in waves of cigar tobacco and blackcurrant leaf, with a grounded fruit core of blackberry, plum and cassis. Additional notes of leather and German chocolate cake lend depth and intrigue, while the finish exhibits a masterful evolution between all these components with each sip. Well-structured and superbly balanced, it boasts gripping tannins and ample acidity to frame the ripe fruit. A beauty that should mature masterfully, drink 20232033.

Justina is the top wine for this estate, a mellifluous melding of berries and cherries, with a hint of peach. The acids are ample but never intrusive, and bring a rather delicate flavor of lemon oil. Exemplary in every way, this is drinking beautifully but may be cellared for up to a decade.

Already with a wonderful old-gold color, this aromatic wine with its fruit, acidity and touch of spirit is bone dry, but presents a rich texture. The typical intense acidity is right there as well as lemon peel, wood, spice and concentration. This wine, aged in wood and bottled in 2017, is ready to drink.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this full-bodied red opens with aromas of wild berry, exotic spice, aromatic herb and a whiff of fragrant blue flower. It's elegant and structured, with a youthful tension that underscores juicy wild cherry, raspberry compote, cinnamon and a hint of pipe tobacco. Fresh acidity lends balance while fine-grained tannins provide polished support. It's already tempting but will develop even more complexity with cellaring. Drink 20182033.

This wine is dense with superripe tannins. It has rich black-plum and berry fruits along with an opulent texture typical of this wine in good vintages. Along with its power, the wine has great acidity to keep the aftertaste crisp and fruity. Drink from 2024.

Jim Barry's top wine and one of Clare Valley's most renowned, the 2012 doesn't disappoint. Enchanting, complex aromas of purple beets, mocha, strawberry leaf, raspberries, figs and dates continue on the palate, all cloaked in savory, powdery tannins and a structure that sets it up for many years of aging. Drink 20192037.

This is one of the top vineyard selections in this vintage, among a select group, notable for its outstanding focus and concentration. Still compact, its purple fruits are lightly spiced and deftly balanced; leaving little doubt that further improvement is just around the corner. Drink now through 2035.

The nose is intense and heady, combining unlikely but harmonized elements of white currant, fresh white mushroom, honey, pear and lemon zest. The palate then majors on fresh, pure and fluid pear juiciness. There is a textural element and overtones of beeswax reinforced by more lemon zestiness. A very complex, very alive and facinating wine. This is mouthfilling, long and intense, utterly full-flavored but resolutely dry.

This particular block selection is focused upon old-vine Pommard grapes, and the result is a layered and deeply focused wine that continually evolves once poured. It's a delicate explosion of textures and flavors, berry and cherry, wet stone, cola and caramel. Though it will surely age beautifully over a decade or longer, if you give it ample aeration and attention, it drinks quite nicely already.

The vineyard cannot be disclosed, but there's nothing mysterious about the flavor, which pins the meter on the yum factor. Juicy huckleberry flavors come wrapped in mineral-drenched acids. Made from 100% Pommard grapes, this marries Old World complexity to pretty purple fruits. As with many Patricia Green wines, the oak aging is a minor player, while the ripe fruits and individual terroirs are expressed in riveting fashion.

Wet river rocks and mineral oil juxtapose zesty tangerine, pomelo and grapefruit in this lavish yet composed dry Riesling. It's clingy and plush in mouthfeel yet vibrantly balanced in acidity, with an unctuous and rippling finish. It's stunning already for its youthful fruit and electric acidity, but sure to improve further through 2035.

Dried sagebursh, wild cherries, rose petals and baked soil aromas make for a compelling blend of savory and sweet on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard on the eastern side of the appellation. A chalky texture and front-to-back acidity presents flavors of ripe boysenberry and black raspberry as well as clove, black pepper and other intriguingly dark spices.

Long associated with the Graham's name, this quinta makes impressive Ports. This hugely tannic and equally hugely fruity Port has a dry backbone as well as potentially rich black fruits. Acidity and a dry edge give structure to this dense wine. Drink from 2028.
Tight and firm, this young wine has great potential. The richness, good acidity and minerality promise a great future. Densely textured, it is powerful and very rich. Drink from 2024.

Instantly gratifying, this wine starts off ripe, focused and compact, with raspberries and pie cherries galore on the nose. Let it breathe and it offers complex acid-driven tones of pineapple and orange peel. Barrel aging shows from start to finish, with rich, toasty aromas and streaks of butter and vanilla cookie. It's delicious from first sniff to last sip.

Made from the original 150 year-old vinesof which just 800 remainthis wine is made only in the best years. The 2012 is a heady mlange of blue and purple fruits, raspberry leaf, beets, coffee and wet leaves. The medium-bodied palate is approachable now with its silky, sexy tannins, plush fruit and a complex, superlong finish, but this will age beautifully for many years to come. Drink now2027.

Pretty blossom, guava and pink grapefruit notes abound in this gorgeously perfumed, dry Riesling. It's lively and fresh, but maintains a creamy lusciousness on the palate. Concentrated and zingy, it lingers through a long finish marked by murmurs of astringency. Drinks beautifully already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.

Demure notes of white blossom, pineapple and lemon amass power and ripeness on the palate of this dry, medium-bodied Riesling. Silken and finely textured, it offers penetrating pink-grapefruit and yellow-peach flavors highlighted by zippy streaks of lemon-lime acidity and a cool, crystalline finish.

Superrich and undeniably flavorful, this stand-out wine achieves fine balance despite the huge tannins. It has an utterly dark color that stains the glass, wonderful aromas of crushed raspberries and black cherries, and deep fruit flavors that weave through tones of dark chocolate and mint. The mouthfeel is notably dense but somehow gentle. Best from 20202030.

Fresh Asian pear, lemon blossoms and honeysuckle make for an enjoyable nose on this bottling from a very coastally influenced vineyard just east of Santa Maria. The acidity on the palate is super racy and vibrant, carrying flavors of chalk and lime pith that sizzle long and deep.

Truffle, flint and wild berry aromas mingle with pipe tobacco and a whiff of new leather on this radiant red. On the savory precise palate, licorice and white pepper underscore a juicy core of red cherry and cranberry alongside a flinty mineral vein. Polished tannins and fresh acidity provide impeccable balance. Drink through 2032.

Toasty blackberry and cassis aromas are classic for Ribera, while the firm, compact palate is structured but not fiercely tannic. Flavors of spiced blackberry, plum and fig finish with the right interplay between fruit and oak. Drink through 2028.

Big, potent and deeply concentrated, this holds nothing back with its rich, ripe black-cherry-compote flavor. Lavender overtones lead into more expressive layers of vanilla, black tea and Kahla. It is intense and lingering.

Fragrant blue flower, wild herb, pipe tobacco and black-plum aromas waft out of the glass. Elegant and concentrated, the smooth delicious palate delivers juicy black cherry, raspberry preserve and licorice offset by well-knit, velvety tannins. Drink through 2025.

Made entirely with Pinot Nero, this well-structured sparkler boasts enticing aromas of red berry, crushed herb and brioche. The bright tangy palate delivers Marasca cherry, pomegranate, juicy nectarine and bread crust alongside an elegant perlage. It's well balanced, with bright acidity.

This quinta, situated in the heart of the Port vineyards, always forms the backbone of Dow's Ports. It makes a densely textured wine, powerful and with immense dusty tannins. These are backed by ripe black fruits, a good balance between sweet and dry, with a good shot of acidity. This complex Port needs to age for many years. Drink from 2028.

This is winemaker Dianna Novy Lee's debut sparkling wine, blending 56% Chardonnay and 44% Pinot Noir and then aging the wine on the lees for three years before release. It impresses from first sip, showing acid-driven raciness and a core of green apple, lime zest and biscuit flavors that linger. It'll serve well as a delicious aperitif or fitting companion for the table.

Flowery, fragrant aromas of spring blossoms and pink grapefruit belie the power and intensity found on the palate of this bold, steel-touched Riesling. While dry and medium bodied in style, ripe citrus and crisp stone-fruit flavors penetrate deeply. The finish is long, marked by cool strikes of steel and lime acidity.

Deep and hearty aromas of black currant, caramel, lilac and a touch of roasted oak show on the dense nose of this wine. It is massive on the palate, but with appropriate balancing factors of entrenched acidity and chalky, sticky tannins that hold up the rich flavors of vanilla, black-plum skin and blackberry sauce.

Owned by the Wrights, this beautifully proportioned wine is supple and tasty, with berry, cherry and blue plum. The barrel aging adds a dusting of cocoa, and the tannins, ripe and still a bit stiff, add notes of ground coffee.

Rich tannins and concentration are driven both by ripe black fruits and a strongly mineral texture in this wine. The tannins have been smoothed by wood aging, but that's deceptive. Although the silkiness suggests early drinking, the firmer core suggests aging. Go for aging, because this will be an even more impressive wine from 2021.

Forward, pristine fruit and mineral intensity align in this penetrating, complex dry Riesling. It offers luminous yellow peach, nectarine and grapefruit flavors offset by dazzling lemon-lime acidity and a firm strike of steely minerality. The palate is creamy and expansive yet finishes with laser-edged precision. Beautiful already but should continue to improve through 2035 and hold further.

While pristine pink grapefruit, pineapple and peach flavors are crisp and concentrated, this lacy, textured auslese is more a showcase of intensely layered minerality. Invigorating and fresh, it offers deeply embedded veins of salt, dusty slate and smoke that reverberate through a long, honey-kissed finish. Drinks beautifully already but should improve from 2021.

Tight-grained tannins lie beneath a sleek, sophisticated structure of ageworthy complexity in this old-vine wine made from grapes planted in 1959. Intensely layered, it shows wisps of currant, pencil shavings and aniseseasonings for a lush backdrop of brambly blackberry. Enjoy 20232033.

Estate-grown fruitprincipally Pinot Noir with 8% Chardonnaygoes into this impressively complex sparkling wine from Trisaetum. It's rich and deep, showing both power and finesse. A fine bead and light details of cocoa, coconut and cream bring exceptional complexity.

Wild red berry, tilled soil, violet, new leather and a whiff of sandalwood slowly unfold on this fragrant red. The structured savory palate delivers dried black cherry, pomegranate, white pepper and clove framed in polished, fine-grained tannins. A hint of coffee lingers on the close. Drink 20202025.

A selection made both of grapes in the vineyard and wines in the winery, this rich wine has power and density as well as superb fruits. The well-judged oak aging melds well with the dark fruits and acidity, while the tannins give strength and aging potential. Drink from 2021

This is a well-made, small-production wine from the producer's home estate. Inviting in perfumed oak, pencil and cedar, it has brawny power that remains elegant in the glass, with persistent acidity and layers of cassis and cinnamon.

The style of Warre's Ports tends to dryness, and this fine quinta vintage is no exception. It's dry, but the rich fruit forms a great counterbalance. Dense, still young and bursting with perfumed blueberry fruits, the wine has great promise. Drink from 2027.

Dense tannins and rich black fruits mark out this ripe wine. Its tannins are cushioned by the concentrated but generous black fruits that were organically grown. The wine has great purity as well as structure. Drink from 2024.

This wine is dense, complex and with great tannins. It is powerful and rich, packed with black fruits. Good acidity gives the wine its freshness, its black-currant fruit and its potential longevity. Rich and with great aging potential, this is becoming a major wine in its own right rather than just a second wine of Cos d'Estournel. Drink from 2025.

Deep, brooding scents of black plum, cherry and cassis form the soul of this beautiful, richly concentrated wine. Plenty of licorice, cigar-box spice and bittersweet cocoa ride atop the fruit core, while notes of green peppercorn, leather and tobacco flesh out the midpalate and flourish on the finish. The crushed-velvet texture offers ample tannic grip and balancing acidity to keep everything in harmony. While it's hard to resist now, this should shine from 20232028.

Aromas of mature black-skinned berry, baked plum, mint and violet mix with whiffs of dark culinary spice. The ripe chewy palate doles out raspberry jam, fleshy black cherry and licorice set against firm, polished tannins. The juicy fruit flavors deftly support the hefty alcohol. Drink through 2022.

Musk and earthen complexities of smoke and struck flint meld into sun-kissed yellow cherry and tangerine in this seductive, complex kabinett. It's ethereal and sheer yet boldly penetrating, with a piercing lemon-lime finish. Delicious already but sure to improve through 2022 and hold well beyond.

This gorgeous, radiant sparkler opens with enticing aromas of ripe orchard fruit, pressed wild flowers and cream-filled brioche. Elegantly sparkling, the bright palate delivers Golden Delicious apple, tangy lemon drop, Alpine herbs and minerals alongside tiny continuous bubbles. Fresh acidity brightens the rich flavors and lends impeccable balance.

Just a shade off dry in style, this feather-light dynamo offers bold, concentrated stone fruit and blossom tones, enveloped in rich, penetrating swathes of smoke and earth. It's a gorgeously complex wine, with spine tingling acidity and a delicate, lilting mouthfeel that extends endlessly on the finish. Drinks beautifully already but concentrated and structured enough to improve well through 2030.

Bright red fruits, sappy acids and citrus highlights combine here. The supporting tannins are ripe and toasty, with a slightly grainy mouthfeel. Suggestions of coffee grounds add further interest to the finish, which expands gracefully as it breathes. This is a wine still pulling itself together and clearly built to expand and improve with further bottle age. Drink now through 2030.

Lovely black-cherry fruit is the highlight here, with aromatics that elevate the fruit with high-toned intensity. The wine is cloaked with chocolate from barrel aging, and detailed with coffee grounds, graphite and loam.

Hints of honey, caramelized sugar and ripe tangerine on the nose contrast a palate that's lean and bracingly mineral here. While light bodied and lean, zesty white grapefruit and tart pineapple flavors are piercing and persistent. Tasted in 2017, it's still a taut, nervous wine that needs time to meld. Hold till 2020.

This is an excellent example why so many go crazy for Pinot Noir. The wine exudes a nourishing warmth that transports you to a cozy country kitchen, with bouquets of drying flowers and currants hanging from the rafters, szechuan beef sizzling in the stir fry, earthy sumac in the spice bowl and smoke from the dying embers of a campfire wafting in through the windows. It's silky and open enough to drink now, but should continue to age well through 2025.

This is a lovely light-bodied wine with serious intent and sophistication. Pear puree and apple skin mingle effortlessly along a plane of gravelly rocky mineral complexity that will show well with a variety of meals.

Linear and elegant, this vibrancy of this sparkler belies its age. It opens with enticing scents of wild flower, orchard fruit, a hint of hazelnut and a whiff of pastry. The palate shows complexity, depth as well as freshness, delivering Golden Delicious apple, apricot, toasted bread crust and a hint of tangerine zest. Tangy acidity lifts the rich flavors while an elegant mousse lends finesse.

The terrific texture and wealth of detail makes this truly exceptional. Citrus, mineral, candied pineapple and a hint of honey all combine in a long, dense and bright-tasting wine. In the spirit of Oregon's finest Rieslings, it's both sweet and tart, with a lively inviting mouthfeel.

Lusty black-fruit aromas are earthy, oaky and smooth, exemplifying an excellent Ribera del Duero. A palate with pulsing acidity tempers rich flavors of blackberry, chocolate and vanilla. Creamy oak and some fire on the finish guarantee that this will evolve nicely through 2028.

The estate vineyard, now about 15-years-old, delivers spicy black-cherry fruit deftly set against dark toasty barrel flavors. Just one-quarter new French oak was used, but winemaker Mo Ayoub is a barrel master who mixes and matches the oak like a painter mixes his or her colors. There's a strong streak of coffee, and it finishes with light accents of forest mushrooms.

Produced close to Saint-Estphe, this Merlot-dominated wine is powerful and dense. Great black fruits and juicy acidity contrast with firm tannins and the ripe texture from wood aging. This rich wine will age well. Drink from 2024.

The rich wood and fruit of this wine already show good balance. The estate, owned by Bordeaux negociant Dourthe, is now on excellent form with this structured wine offering concentration and long-term aging. The tannins and the dry core from roughly equal proportions of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot and a pinch of Petit Verdot promise great potential. Drink from 2025.

The fifth vintage from this estate since its purchase by the Barton family of Loville Barton in Saint-Julien, this is a generous, structured wine. It has ripe black fruits in profusion that are held together by the serious layer of tannins. Rich and concentrated, the wine will age for many years. Drink from 2024.

The second wine of Chteau Valandraud, this is rich, spicy with great fruit and firm tannins. The wood aging is still showing but it will soon integrate better with the ripeness of the rich fruit. This wine has weight, plenty of black fruit and acidity. Drink from 2022.

A closed nose offers a hint of cherry. The palate follows with a balance of pure cherry, firm tannin and bright freshness graced with a touch of dark peony. This is understated, light-bodied but wonderfully elegant and has a habit of growing on you slowly and stealthily. This has a long and lovely resonance.

This higher-end, elegantly packaged bottling delivers depth, starting with a well-woven, unique nose of baked strawberry, cinnamon, juniper, peppercorns and tobacco. Those elements converge on the palate alongside sandalwood, Montmorency cherry and vanilla, bolstered by a soft but steady acidity.

There's a lifted, vibrant impression to the nose of this impressive, well-crafted wine. It's a pleasant surprise, as it lends levity and definition to the notes of black cherry, crushed purple flowers, licorice root and earth. The mouthfeel is plush and mouthfilling, yet not oppressively so, with ample acidity and structured but velvety tannins. The rich, ripe and robust palate leads into a long finish. It promises a long life of beautiful evolution ahead, maturing to reveal greater nuance and elegance, so cellar through 2030.

The 2013 Attunga expresses aromas of blueberries, baking spices, coffee and tarragon. It's currently very youthful, with rich, plush fruit and big fine-grained tannins, but structurally it's set up for a long and beautiful life. Drink 20202037.

Bright and fresh aromas of pomelo pith, grapefruit flesh, guava skins and tangerine souffle show on the nose of this top-tier Chardonnay by veteran Rick Longoria. Clean and crisp flavors of mandarin pith and a crushed marble minerality give backbone to the richer touches of macadamia nut, cashew and the slightest kiss of buttercream.

Batuta, named after the baton used by an orchestral conductor to blend various musical instruments together, has splendid structure and fruit. It is richly textured with dense tannins as well as layers of black fruits. It holds fruit from three north-facing vineyards on the south bank of the Douro, giving the wine elegance and potential. Drink from 2020.

This monumental wine is one for the agesor at least for 15 years. A deep color is followed by gorgeous aromas of rose, dark chocolate and blackberry syrup. The mouthfilling, ripe fruit flavors are concentrated, bolstered by thick, powerful tannins that give it a mouth-puckering astringency. The firmness sets this wine up for a long life. Best from 20222032.

The new sparkling wine project from Trisaetum is off to a spectacular start. This 100% Chardonnay sparkler is refined and detailed. It keeps a lid on the excessive fruitiness and brings in the minerality, toast and overall finesse of the finest Old World examples.

The Weber vineyard, originally planted in 1978, shows well with bold bright black-cherry fruit, amplified with lemony acids and flavors of lemon meringue. The lingering midpalate leads gracefully into a smooth, lusciously fruity finish.

Aromas of struck matches and smoke are pronounced initially but dissipate into elegant mineral complexities on the palate of this intensely fruity kabinett. Juicy tangerine and grapefruit flavors are sweet and zesty, edged by a bracing fringe of astringency on the finish.

A beautifully pure topnote of black cherry sings on the nose, followed by peony and cinnamon. The palate is luminous in a dark cherry flavor. This wine is profound and concentrated but nothing weighs it down. Drink 20182028.

This shows beatutifully aromatic notes of fresh Cox Orange Pippin apple, jasmine and rose. The palate brims with these same notions, made bolder by pure, lively lemon freshness. The streamlined palate has a pithy, zesty edge that makes you want to drink more. This is a lovely, concentrated, grown-up Muscat of unusual power. The finish is bone-dry, a little salty and lingering.

Soft and alluring, this wine opens in bursts of rose petal and black tea, with plenty of baking spices accenting its core of cherry, blueberry and rhubarb. As the wine mellows on the finish, it show a velvety texture of round, supple tannins.
A whiff of white flowers, then a crush of ripe fruit, and the wine opens with tangy lemon, grapefruit and peach flavors. Notes of citrus rind add depth and the acids strike just the right chord.

This 11-acre property, centered on an ultramodern winery, is the most northerly estate in Margaux. The wine, with its blend of dark tannins and juicy black-currant fruit, is rich, with impressive concentration and minerality. With weight and a firm core, the wine will age well. Drink from 2025.

This is a structured wine, beautifully perfumed with richly tannic black fruits. It comes from a large 111-acre estate in the village of the same name. Made to age with firm tannins and layers of sumptuous fruit over firm wood aging, the wine will mature slowly. Drink from 2024.

This dense and impressively ripe wine comes from a Sorge family estate in the northern part of the Margaux appellation. With black fruits and generous tannins, it is a big wine with considerable richness. This complex wine will age. Drink from 2025.

This wine comes from a 50-acre crus bourgeois estate in the middle of some of the greatest crus classs estates. The terroir is impressive, giving a rich, structured wine with good concentration, ripe tannins and a sumptuous bed of black fruits. The wine is likely to age well; drink from 2025.

A touch of orange zest, honeysuckle and rose petals make for a gently aromatic opening. On the palate it is the sheer concentration of flavor that hits you, there seems to be a force of life straining to break free, which swishes across the dry palate in rich flavors of orange zest and florals. This is a vivid, arresting wine which is lovely now but sure has mileage. Drink 20182028.

Stark, electric acidity bolsters this intensely steely yet deeply fruity off-dry Riesling. It's a cutting, spine tingling wine pulsating with staccato hits of white grapefruit, stone fruit and citrus flavors. The finish is gossamer and sheer yet endless.

Made with the traditional blend of Sangiovese, Colorino and Canaiolo, this opens with aromas of pressed violet, woodland berry, menthol and dark culinary spice. The supple full-bodied palate delivers juicy morello cherry, black raspberry and star anise accompanied by fresh acidity and polished tannins. Drink through 2023.

The Carter is a complex, even rugged wine, replete with layered flavors of herb, black cherry, cola and a touch of molasses. The tannins are as smooth as river rock, with appealing mineral and rock flavors following right behind.

Far from simply fruity, this is a complex and sophisticated wine that shows how distinctive the grape variety can be. It relies on savory, minerally flavors that have wonderful subtlety and reserve. With each sip it settles a little deeper on the palate, lingering for a long finish buoyed by underlying acidity.

This new offering from John Kinney's tiny, consistently high-performing winery is big and muscularvery ripe and full bodied, generously laced with butter, toasted oak and almond flavors on a particularly creamy texture but not going over the top. Only about six barrels were made so it's rare, but worth a search.

Coming from the Rocks District, this offers expressive aromas of potpourri, fresh chopped parsley, orange peel, green olive, smoked meat, fresh flower and wet stone. These lead to plush, palate-coating fruit and savory flavors. Olive and charcuterie notes linger on the finish.

The result of a joint venture between the Bergqvist family of Quinta de la Rosa and winemaker Jorge Moreira, this wine comes from vines in the Douro Superior region. Rich and dense with black fruits, it is structured and still young. Its intensity and ripe fruits show the warm, dry nature of the vineyards in the region. Drink this concentrated wine from 2019.

A striking wine, this brand has long been an advocate for Cab Franc in South Africa, and the skill and experience of winemaker Bruwer Raats absolutely shines here. Plush and attractive, yet well defined, it opens with herbal aromas of green peppercorn, tobacco leaf, bark and a touch of pressed iris that weave throughout the ripe blackberry, cherry and currant fruit. Medium-plus in weight, it boasts a crushed-velvet texture and slightly creamy impression, framed by structured tannins and superb acidity to balance. The long finish offers an exercise of evolution, from ripe fruit to fresh earthy tones and finally dried ash and spice. It's hard to resist now, in all its complex, layered glory, but this will mature well through 2028.

This deep ruby wine offers a bouquet of blackberry, cassis and a slight touch of bell pepper. The full palate is bolstered by opulent tannins, offering flavors of black cherry, black currant and vanilla, with fennel, black pepper and a hint of spice on the finish.

Extremely light in color in the glass, this bottling of a 40-year-old vineyard block is an old vine masterpiece, starting with aromas of crisp, underripe raspberry, tart carnation and orange rind aromas. It's fresh, light, lovely and very quaffable on the palate, where pomegranate juice is sprinkled with dried oregano and a pinch vanilla dust. The acidity is clean and balanced.

There's a purity to the black fruit, cocoa, espresso and wisteria aromas on the nose of this bottling from a small dry-farmed vineyard 2,100-feet up in the mountains. The zesty palate throws potpourri and white pepper together with fresh boysenberry and elderberry, making for a uniquely flavored wine, redolent with dried purple flowers.

This is half barrel fermented and half fermented in stainless steel. It's gritty and expansive on the luxurious palate and well-made, offering layers of apple, pear and melon with a tease of anise on the lengthy full-bodied finish.

This is a sexy, elegant, light-on-its-feet beauty from one of Tasmania's most highly respected producers. The nose is a heady blend of cinnamon bark, bright red berries, salt and garrigue, while the palate is crunchy and sappy. A picture of drinkability combined with complexity and superb winemaking.

Wakefield's top wine offers enchanting aromas of mocha, milky coffee, vanilla, licorice and sun-ripened raspberries and blackberries. It's texturally plush, with a fair amount of richness, silky tannins and well integrated oak. This should age with exceptional grace. Drink 20192027.

This is a stunning example of a wine that's fresh and light yet loaded with flavor. Buoyant aromas of black raspberry juice, dried fennel and wet slate lead onto a palate of snappy, slightly sour pomegranate, white pepper and sumac. The texture is equally complex, while the finish brings additional flavors of candied cherry and strawberry.

There's a very prominent gamy quality throughout this wine, which starts with aromas of roasted lamb, charcoal, creosote and animal pelt. The palate takes that feral quality even deeper, with hints of Worcestershire sauce, dried lamb and peppery spice. Great for Northern Rhne lovers.

Rose petal, wild berry, graphite and crushed aromatic herb lead the way. Reflecting the nose, the fresh linear palate offers strawberry, sour cherry, white pepper and a savory saline note. Bright acidity and polished tannins provide graceful support. Drink through 2027.

Initial cola and root-beer aromas precede floral berry scents. A strict palate is firm but avoids crushing weight. Narrow plum, currant and berry flavors are focused and framed by roaring tannins. This is still young and tough, but with great potential; drink from 20192035.

A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah and Petit Verdot, this offers enticing scents of red and black-skinned berry, fragrant purple flower and a whiff of Mediterranean scrub. On the fresh, elegant palate, polished tannins support cassis, plum and raspberry alongside culinary spice notes.

This wine comes from a 10-acre estate that is run by the same team as the much larger Chteau Larose Trintaudon, helping explain its quality and the richness. It has broad tannins, ripe blackberry fruit and a generous, succulent character. It should be aged further so drink from 2024.

Owner Philippe Raoux has created both a major sculpture park and a series of impressive vintages at this estate at the western end of Margaux. This vintage is one of the best yet, rich and vibrant with great fruits and solid tannins. It needs serious aging, so drink from 2025.

This wine is light and fruity, with attractive acidity and a crisp texture. Black-currant flavors and balanced tannins keep it elegant and delicious. It is crisp, fresh and likely to develop over the medium term. Drink from 2023.

While each of Dalrymple's Pinots are distinctly different, they're all equally delicious. The Coal River will appeal to those funk lovers, with notes of earth, horse saddle, wet leaves, dried currants, orange rind and bitters. The medium-bodied palate is less funky, offering soft tannins and no harsh edges.

This wine is equal parts Grenache and Mourvdre (co-fermented), finished off with Syrah and aged in neutral French-oak puncheons. The aromas are fascinating, with notes of fresh savory herbs, capers, sea salt, white pepper, bacon fat and mixed fruit. The flavors are plump and appealing, mixing fruity and savory tones that lead to a pepper and olive finish. It's a standout interpretation of this vineyard.

The top wine from De Ponte, this gets 60% new French oak and a full 15 months in barrel prior to bottling. Those flavors come up quickly, putting a lush vein of butterscotch right down the center. The tangy marionberry fruit is a perfect complement, keeping it fresh and luscious, and suggesting that it will drink optimally for the next decade.

Charred hickory and cured bacon waft from the glass, overriding but not completely overpowering the lush, fruity center. Waves of velvety tannins brush across the palate, lending structure to the ripe black cherry, blackberry and mashed plum-flesh flavors. Final hints of tree bark, licorice root and black tea unfold on the medium-length finish. It's delicious now, but should evolve well from 20212028.

This starts out dense and tight, with compact seams of smoke, char, espresso and cacao, sprinkled with dashes of sea salt. It moves into a thick core of mulberry, red currant and black cherry fruit, set in a frame of polished tannins, hitting a faintly green note as it fades.

This black wine is rich, earthy and chocolaty on the nose, with fully toasted aromas of blackberry and cassis. A massive palate with tannins as heavy as cinderblocks features saturated flavors of blackberry, black coffee and chocolate. A malty, smoky, woody finish is anything but shy. Drink from 20202030.

With a slight nose of noble reduction, this seductive wine offers a wealth of balanced flavor and body, shining in tones of nuts, fennel, vanilla and mango. The oak is measured and supportive, never getting in the way, allowing the acidity to pierce through the fruit.

Deep ruby to the eye, this wine has a nose of dark plum, bramble fruit and thyme. A sense of brightness is ever-present on the palate, with flavors of cherry, cassis, butterscotch, fennel and white pepper. Smooth tannins play on the tongue and then linger just beyond the black-cherry finish, with a touch of caramel.

This young wine comes up quickly with strawberry fruit, ripe and dotted with white pepper. There are hints of parsley, and impressive midpalate concentration. With all of Ken Wright's wines, which are released quite young, the odds strongly favor additional development and improved complexity with another few years of bottle age.

Vineyard-designated wines from this appellation are rare, and this wine shows the promise of this site. There's no mistaking the variety, with its enchanting aromas of fragrant flower, smoked meat, chopped parsley, green olive and purple fruit. Flavors are supremely fresh and bright, showing a mixture of fruit and savory, with assorted herb notes intertwined throughout. An extended finish, filled with notes of olive, caps it off. It's beautiful on its own but should sing at the dinner table. Give it time to open up.

You'll find enticing aromas of black-skinned berry, graphite and Mediterranean brush on this blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 40% Syrah and 10% Teroldego. On the intense palate, notes of tobacco, black pepper and a touch of cocoa add depth to a core of black currant. Velvety tannins provide elegant support. Enjoy through 2026.

Aromas of red berry, dark culinary spice, wild mint and a whiff of new leather are textbook mountain Nebbiolo. The savory racy palate is loaded with finesse, delivering crushed raspberry, Marasca cherry, star anise and tobacco set against taut ultrafine tannins. A mineral note closes the finish while vibrant acidity gives it energy and balance.

Vineyard-designated wines from this appellation are rare, and this wine shows the promise of this site. There's no mistaking the variety, with its enchanting aromas of fragrant flower, smoked meat, chopped parsley, green olive and purple fruit. Flavors are supremely fresh and bright, showing a mixture of fruit and savory, with assorted herb notes intertwined throughout. An extended finish, filled with notes of olive, caps it off. It's beautiful on its own but should sing at the dinner table. Give it time to open up.

You'll find enticing aromas of black-skinned berry, graphite and Mediterranean brush on this blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 40% Syrah and 10% Teroldego. On the intense palate, notes of tobacco, black pepper and a touch of cocoa add depth to a core of black currant. Velvety tannins provide elegant support. Enjoy through 2026.

Aromas of red berry, dark culinary spice, wild mint and a whiff of new leather are textbook mountain Nebbiolo. The savory racy palate is loaded with finesse, delivering crushed raspberry, Marasca cherry, star anise and tobacco set against taut ultrafine tannins. A mineral note closes the finish while vibrant acidity gives it energy and balance.

There's impressive aromatic depth to the nose of this winery's top-tier bottling, with black cherry, olive, wisteria, wet wood, juniper and bay leaf all present. These elements converge on the sip, where black plum, light licorice and loamy earth flavors are enhanced by hints of truffle, nutmeg and vanilla. The tannic texture is upright yet not sticky or in the way.

Made from organically grown grapes, this wine comes from the plateau north of the Douro river itself. It is a limited-edition wine, rich and tannic at this stage. Alongside all this structure, the wine also has ripe black fruits that are about to burst out, juicy, rich and with final acidity. Drink this wine from 2019.

This thoroughly delicious wine offers a lush mix of raspberry compote, cherry pie and a touch of lemon curd. The tannins are supple and generous, and the wine glides effortlessly through a yummy midpalate and on into a satisfying finish with a lick of buttery caramel.

Winemaker Dominic O'Reilly worked for years under Ojai Vineyard Syrah master Adam Tolmach, so it makes sense that his take on this historic property would be so excellent. Aromas of deep black plum fruit are cut by game, tar and wild herbs. The palate shows fresh purple fruit and violets alongside cracked pepper, held up by a strong tannic backbone.

Made with Chardonnay and Pinot Nero, this offers delicate scents of wildflowers, orchard fruit and a whiff of baking spice. Racy, linear and refreshing, the crisp dry palate delivers Rennet apple, nectarine and a hint of ginger, while a graphite note adds depth. It's elegant, with small, continuous bubbles.

Distinct tones of cherry pit and cinnamon-clove define the aromatics of this wine. It's a relatively full-bodied style of the variety from the east side of the appellation. Succulent and fleshy, it offers an array of salty, savory notes and is appealing in its velvety texture and roundness. Cola, warm baking spices and orange peel add to the complexity.

This wine explores the gamy, cool-climate side of Syrah, sourced from the winery's estate vineyard just outside of the Santa Lucia Highlands. Roasted coffee, burnt toast, charred lamb, powdered cocoa and elderberry jam show on the nose, while a gamy flavor comes through even stronger on the firmly structured palate.

Those who like their Pinot on the savory and earthy side will enjoy this wine. Leading with the aroma of charred, salted meat, notes of bright red fruits and herbal bitters quickly follow along. The light-bodied palate is beautifully composed, offering a wealth of fruit and floral flavors, and a long, savory finish. Drink now2025.

From a consistently great producer, the 2015 Pipers River offers a wealth of aromas: sunbaked earth, dried leaves, sea spray, cocoa nibs and just-picked forest fruit. The palate is light and elegant, with soft but structured tannins and a cinnamon spice tone. It's totally approachable now but could age another five to seven years if you can bear to wait that long. Drink 20232025.

Lifted, succulent tones of mango, peach and melon abound in this lip-smacking yet complex auslese. It's boldly concentrated in fruit but exceptionally fine and filigreed on the palate and shaded by nuances of crushed slate, blossom and salt. The finish is piercing and long marked by spine tingling lime acidity.

Plumes of smoke and dark earth intensify tonic, lime and salty mineral notes in this nimble-footed auslese. It's a bracing, revitalizing wine, balanced by sweet-tart yellow peach and tangerine flavors that pierce through a long, nervous finish.

Vanilla, sea salt, red berries, florals, smoke and orange zest all swirl together in this silky smooth Pinot. The palate is simultaneously salty and tangy, with flavors of sea spray and dried cranberries and raspberries.
This wine is a riot of strawberry preserves on the nose, while the palate is full bodied and detailed. It comes with a touch of lemon custard, hints of barrel toast, and an elegant texture.

Pretty cherry candy flavors hold your attention here, balanced with perfectly ripened tannins. There's a light wash of milk chocolate and it finishes with cinnamon spice. In a stellar lineup of single-vineyard selections, the Shea is always surefire.

Layers of sweet, sun-kissed honeydew, grapefruit and tangerine flood the palate of this forward yet nuanced wine. There's a delightful cling of honey and nectar on the midpalate but it's counterbalanced neatly by strikes of lemon-lime acidity and an earthen minerality that lingers long on the finish. Drinks beautifully already but should improve further through 2035.

Derived from an assortment of Dundee Hills vineyards, this pays tribute to the Jory soils of the AVA. Strong mineral accents keep a tight focus on brambly cherry flavors. The barrel aging, which was minimal given the wine's early release, adds just a touch of caramel.

Across the river from the small town of Pinho and some of the finest Port vineyards, this estate is well situated. This wine comes from 100-year-old vines and boasts great concentration and richness. It is dense and full of black fruits, ripe from a fine year in the Douro. It will age well; drink after 2021.

This wine comes from an estate owned by the Amorim cork family. Powerful, perfumed tannins and dense texture from the old-vine Touriga Nacional give a rich character to the wine. Big, bold red fruits are laced with acidity and packed with concentration. Drink this wine from 2021.

This quinta, named after its cypress trees, has produced a firm and structured wine in this vintage. Tannins and a dry core give a great possibility for aging. It is rich and the black fruits will come through the structure. Drink this wine from 2021.

While lithe and lean in style, this dry Riesling builds in mineral intensity on the palate. Lime, lemon and green apple flavors are vivaciously fresh, fringed by hints of candlewax and blossom. The finish is long, steely and linear.

Roasted aromas of wet campfire, black pepper and roasted lamb crust meet with a pickled boysenberry scent on the nose of this bottling, the first time that this winery has made two estate Syrahs. (Hillside is the other.) The palate shows a strong lift from tarragon and mint, but the gamy quality is powerful as well as is the spice, with Szechuan peppercorn and kung pao beef flavors.

Mossy forest floor, pine needle, juniper and black pepper aromas show against a backdrop of elderberry on the extremely compelling nose of this bottling by Ernst Storm from a vineyard to the northwest of the Sta. Rita Hills. The palate shows much more of that foresty spice, as well as tapenade, wild berries, bay leaf and thyme.

In most years, Alabaster blows you away with its power, concentration and depth of flavors. In 2014, a mediocre year in much of Northern Spain, this is still excellent. Blackberry, cassis and creosote aromas are toasty, while this is flush in feel and severely tannic. Blackberry, mocha and coffee flavors finish with creamy oak and chocolate notes along with meaty tannins. Only 100 cases produced; drink through 2030.

Very pure notes of red cherry fill the nose. The same pure fruit is framed by bright, luminous freshness on the palate, which echoes in flavors of cherry, pepper and licorice. An aromatic, fresh and vivid Pinot made with a light touch.

Light in color, this wine offers beguiling aromas with notes of fire pit, flower, stem, potpourri, black raspberry and smoked meat. Ethereally light and enchanting, it's texturally rich and flavorful, with a warm finisha delicious example of this site and variety.

Beautifully inviting in aromas of caramelized biscuit, vanilla wafer and baked apple, this is a creamy and lush white wine, full bodied and highly ripe in style. A lovely hit of tangerine-laced acidity keeps it fresh and fleshy.

Drake Whitcraft is becoming a master at weaving a wide array of sensory experiences into very light wines. This starts with candied pomegranate, fennel bulb and cracked white pepper on the nose, then hits the palate with bright snappy red fruits, heavy peppery spice and a penetratingly bright acid profile. It goes down easy, but with complexity.

This is a blockbuster wine, full bodied and ripe, yet able to hold its considerable power in check. Its well-integrated oak and sizable structure give it weight and breadth, as well as age-worthy intrigue. Red currant, cedar and cigar box mark the flavor profile. Enjoy best 20242034.

Winemaker Sabrine Rodems manages to tame the richness of this vineyard while retaining its hedonistic joy. Aromas of rose, pomegranate, hibiscus, rhubarb and dark spice lead into pillowy flavors of strawberry, raspberry and clove. This wine feels light and racy yet full of body and flavor.

This sappy, sensational effort is bursting with an ultraripe flavor of crushed blueberry. Dusty tannins and a sprinkling of coffee grounds amplify the finish, with excellent texture and length, ending on a flourish of butterfat.

Pristine aromas of white melon, green plum, apple blossom and lemon leaf open the nose of this gorgeous white, with touches of fresh fynbos and almond skin for added depth. The palate offers a pithy, lightly astringent texture that supports the soft fruit flavors. This is more about structure, balance and feel than overt fruit tones, with the overall harmony and complexity to continue to evolve well through 2030. The palate is very well balanced with fine acidity, more a textural delight than overt flavors with sublime orange pith, walnut and saline notes on the ethereal finish.

This is a complex and delicious wine that's completely inviting now, but should continue to hold well for another 510 years. Earthy, herbal notes of tobacco leaf, leather, cigar box and crushed violets open the bouquet, grounded by a core of lush, ripe blackberry, currant, raspberry sauce and blueberry crumble. The mouthfeel is full and robust, yet structured by fine but present tannins and bold spicy tones that carry through to the enduring finish. Drink now2022.

Wild berry, rose petal, smoke, new leather and alpine-herb aromas make for a delicate bouquet. Focused and savory, the bright, elegant palate delivers cranberry, pomegranate, white pepper and black tea framed in taut refined tannins and bright acidity. A tangy saline note lingers on the close. While some may find this almost too austere, if you love finesse you'll be captivated. Drink through 2027.

This complex and engaging wine threads together equal portions of red fruits, leather, coffee, chocolate and toasted coconut. The tannins retain some palate-clinging astringency, and the aging in one-quarter new French oak puts a wreath of light smoke around the finish.

Enticing scents of white spring blossom, orchard fruit and a whiff of pastry take center stage on this elegant sparkler. Made entirely with Chardonnay, the graceful palate doles out white peach, yellow apple, lemon and a hint of brioche alongside bright acidity and a silky perlage.

Toasted aromas of brioche and hazelnut meld with whiffs of yellow stone fruit. On the structured palate, a lively elegant perlage underscores Golden Delicious apple, bread crust, white peach and nectarine drop. Bright acidity lifts the rich flavors.

This is dense and concentrated, reflecting the character of Haut-Brion itself. It has weight, firm tannins and power alongside juicy black fruits and acidity that will give great pleasure as they develop. Drink from 2023.

This is the Pauillac-appellation portion of a larger vineyard, Chteau Peyrabon, which is in the Haut-Mdoc. The wine is rich, perfumed and likely to age very well. Juicy acidity and firm texture go with the black-currant fruit in a wine that will become balanced and elegant. Drink from 2024.

The small vineyard in Soussans in the northern part of the Margaux appellation has produced this richly structured wine. Dark tannins and layers of wood aging are accompanied by black-currant fruits as well as dark-chocolate flavor. This wine needs to age, and will be best from 2023.

With Michel Rolland as consultant and the Cuvelier family, also owners of Loville Poyferr in Saint-Julien, in charge, no wonder this is an impressive wine. It has put on weight since it was tasted at en primeur. Packed with tannins, dark fruits and potential, it is a wine for aging. Solid tannins march along with the black fruit, acidity and spice from wood aging. The wine will take its time and will not be ready before 2025.

This is the luxury cuve from vineyards in the Seze family since 1918. With its perfumed fruits and firm tannins it is serious as well as sumptuous. It has weight and a dry texture that will soften into the blackberry fruits and generous structure. This wine, with its still-firm texture, needs to age, so drink from 2022.

A blend of 85% Chardonnay and 15% Pinot Nero, this offers enticing scents of brioche and yellow stone fruit. The elegant, focused palate delivers golden apple, bread crust, pomegranate and a mineral note alongside a refined perlage and vibrant acidity.

Paso Robles winemaker Tyler Russell applies that region's rich style to Sta. Rita Hills fruit for massive effect, great for lovers of ripeness and density. Aromas of baked vanilla cake, black cherry, loamy soil and star anise leap from the glass. Then the palate delivers loads of blackberry compote, licorice and clove, letting it all hang out yet bolstered by bright acidity and firm lavish tannins.

Pomegranate, carnation, dried cranberry, potpourri, baked earth and vanilla cookie all come to the fore on the nose of this light but expressive wine from the historic vineyard. Stewed red cherry and cranberry arise on the palate alongside thyme, peppercorn and the slightest hint of game.

This deep violet-red colored wine has a nose of cassis, lavender and anise. It is surprisingly soft on first sip, with tannins that gradually increase in power while showcasing flavors of black cherry, dark plum, cranberry, fennel bulb and a touch of mint. The slightly grippy finish offers pronounced notes of cherry and orange zest.

This flagship bottling is still a whopper of a wine. This vintage, a blend of 73% Cabernet Sauvignon, 15% Cabernet Franc and 12% Merlot, offers barely ripe black cherry, green peppercorn and charred fennel on the nose. The palate is loaded with both savory and ripe flavors, from roasted black plums and charred beef to oregano and dill. Very complex and chalky in texture.

Firm and focused, this young wine has miles to go. It opens with bright raspberry and cherry fruit, then puts on bulk in the midpalate, adding lovely orange-peel highlights. Drinking well this young, it has the structure and depth to add many more layers over the next decade or longer. Drink now through 2030 and beyond.

There is a certain high-toned intensity to many of Ken Wright's 2015s, which amps up the young fruit. Here the dominant flavors are ripe strawberry, vivid and layered against firm ripe tannins. There's a touch of coffee and dark chocolate running through the finish. For reasons unknown, this new cuve bears the old Ken Wright label design.

This radiant savory mountain Nebbiolo opens with enticing scents of wild berry, flint, smoke and a whiff of alpine herb. It's elegant and focused, delivering crushed raspberry, Marasca cherry, tobacco and star anise alongside taut refined tannins and bright acidity. It's already tempting but will develop even more complexity over the next several years or more. Drink 20202032.

Enticing scents of yellow stone fruit, acacia and brioche show this wine's Chardonnay pedigree. A refined beading and tangy acidity lend elegance and balance to flavors of creamy yellow pear, apple and lemon. A hint of fennel graces the finish.

Concentrated tangerine and candied lemon-peel flavors are juxtaposed by complexities of savory earth and smoked nuts. While off dry and sprightly, there's a lusciousness that builds on the midpalate that extends into a long, lavishly fruity finish.

Deep and dark in the glass, this Petite Sirah-dominant blend offers aromas of pure blackberry jam on the nose with hints of dried wild fennel and charred plum. It's rich and dense on the palate, but vivacious with fresh black-fruit energy and lifted by clove and purple-flower flavors. The acidity is bright, and tannins are firm but set in the background.

A stunning wine, this opens with scents of golden straw, honeydew rind, firm nectarine and fresh honeycomb that all carry through to the medium-weight mouth. The palate boasts a flinty, mineral texture and bright acidity that lends verve and precision to the notes of toasted apple, spiced orange rind and pressed yellow flowers. Hints of fresh herbs and minty fynbos grace the enduring finish. It sure is delicious now, but try this stunner from 20202028.

Aromas suggesting steeped prune, dark culinary spice, new leather, tobacco and balsamic notes lead the nose. The aromas follow over to the firmly structured palate along with raisin and licorice, while tightly knit fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity provide the austere framework. A smoky mineral note lingers on the finish. Drink 20192026.

This new release, a limited production wine from this estate, is named after Tim Bergqvist, the patriarch of the family that owns this property. The wood aging has given richness, almost creamy sweetness to the ripe fruits. The attractive slight oxidation adds complexity to what is already a fine wine. Drink from 2019.

Almost black in color, this rich, unctuous wine at first seems smooth. Ripe black-plum and jammy berry fruits are ripe and dense. Behind that generous exterior, firm tannins and a dense structure will allow the wine to age well. Drink after 2026.

This wine is richly layered, offering a density of brick, toasty char and dusty rock flavors and aromasa muscular showing from a warm vintage. Black pepper, leather and dried herbs provide additional complexity around a full-bodied core.

Lots of herbs, dried red currants and cranberry compote aromas show on the nose of this bottling, which has an earthy, gamy undercurrent. The palate tastes like it has more age on it, which is a good thing for now, with flavors of charred wood, damp forest floor, dried fruit and allspice, all riding a squeaky texture.

Tangy, savory and elegant, this bright, silky sparkler offers inviting aromas and flavors of Golden Delicious apple, tangy tangerine drop, white peach, mineral and herb. A creamy mousse lends even more finesse while cream-filled brioche lingers on the finish.

The ??? Pinots from Ayoub are made with fruit sourced from such excellent sources as Arcus, Renegade Ridge and Winderlea. Here, as elsewhere, the barrel management is as important as the fruit, putting a concise frame of toast around tight well-defined red-berry and black-cherry flavors. Streaks of cola and coffee add further interest through a lingering finish. Drink now to 2030.

A very intriguing hint of nettle plays along with the orange and mandarine zest aromas, creating a perfumed whiff of utter freshness. On the palate it is apple and orange ripeness that create a sort of dry, juicy richness and concentration. This is an unusual but utterly seductive Muscat.

This rich, dense vintage Port is produced by Niepoort. It has immense tannins as well as layers of ripe fruit. The concentrated texture, powerful dry core and the richness of the wine promise good aging. Drink from 2028.

One of the properties owned by the Chanfreau family of nearby Fonraud, this 14-acre estate has produced a structured, toasty wine. Its high proportion of Cabernet Sauvignon gives it plenty of juicy black currants as well as fruit tannins. The wine needs to age and should be drunk from 2025.

Biodynamically grown, the grapes from this estate offer structure, concentration and a delicious balance between fruit and tannins. The wine has a serious side, with its dense texture and a straight line of pure black fruits. Drink from 2025.

This is a rich wine with generous tannins and, more importantly, generous black fruits. It has a soft texture, the tannins fine and well integrated into the juiciness. It will be a delicious, fruity wine. Drink from 2022.

Produced from a Domaines Fabre parcel of old vines, this wine is rich, firm and concentrated. Wood aging has left its mark of toast and spice without losing the generous fruits. It is an elegant wine, full in the mouth and with great balance between all its elements. Drink from 2022.

From the southern part of the Haut-Mdoc, this Tessandier family wine is a richly structured blend with Cabernet Sauvignon dominant. It has a dry, firm and densely tannic structure along with ripe and potentially generous blackberry fruit. The combination will allow this dark, firm wine to age well. Drink from 2024.

From a grand estate, whose owners also have vines in Margaux and Moulis, this wine is well proportioned and dense. Rich tannins and concentration are just part of what will become a generous, full wine. With great black-currant fruit and acidity to match, this structured wine will need to age. Drink from 2024,

This deep garnet colored wine has aromas of strawberry, black cherry and fennel. Opulent tannins offer a rich mouthfeel, providing a backdrop for flavors of black cherry, black currant, mocha, pencil lead and lavender that wrap up in a cranberry finish.

Aged in neutral French oak, this has aromas that start out brooding but intriguing, with notes of raw meat, mineral, dried herb, crushed flower and huckleberry. The palate is earth-shaking in its richness and intensity, coating the palate with waves of fruit flavors. It hits the gong hard but maintains a lovely sense of balance.

This wine erupts from the glass, with aromas of brown sugar, candied pineapple, dried orange rind and flower. Flavors are viscous, intense and rich, with a mango-filled finish that sails. It's the perfect end to any evening.

Dark violet in the glass, this wine has aromas of blackberry, black cherry and vanilla. Flavors of black plum, blueberry, vanilla, clove and pipe tobacco are set into a framework of silky tannins that reed into a smooth cherry finish.

Thrilling lime acidity and smoky, savory mineral tones meld beautifully in this delicately off-dry feinherb kabinett. It's finely textured and nimble but crisp yellow peach and apricot flavors penetrate firmly on the palate. The finish is lingering and silky, marked by hints of spice, struck flint and pollen. A fascinating wine that's likely to improve. Drink from 2020.

The faintest touch of mocha and vanilla play enticingly on the dark-cherry nose. The palate is full of ripe red cherry, has a glossy, luscious sheen of oak, but handles it very well. A more international style but still with all the hallmark freshness and brightness of Alsace. Drink 20182025.

This is a densely packed, powerful and ripe wine from a tremendous site in the heart of the appellation. Black cherry, dark chocolate and coconut shavings make for a rich impression on the velvety palate, with plenty of toasted oak for support. This wine will do well in the cellar. Enjoy from 20242034.

Grenache (69%) takes the lead on this wine, followed by Mourvdre (26%) and a pinch of Syrah. Aged in neutral French oak, it offers aromas that aren't yet ready to reveal their charms on first pour. Notes of spice, herb and black pepper evolve into smoked meat and raspberry accents over time. The palate is swoon-worthy, with soft, supple fruit and savory flavors that lead to a persistent finish. The sense of purity dazzles.

The merest hint of mandarin peel plays on the nose. This is heightened on the slender, dry palate which seems to have a pithy depth of citrus peel and the airy lightness of a cloud of mandarin. There is ample freshness here as well as elegance and persistence. The finish is off-dry and long.

At first, this wine smells a bit burnt. But airing allows this gran reserva to show mature aromas of grilled beef, dry leaves and spice. Hard tannins make for a rubbery mouthfeel, but savory flavors of leafy plum and berry fruits bring it around. A finish with baked fruit and chocolate flavors concludes this classical Rioja. Drink through 2025.

Blackberry aromas are deep and ripe, with woodsy side notes. A powerful palate is sinewy but not overly rugged or tannic. Blackberry and toasty flavors of chocolate and brown sugar smolder across a strident finish; drink through 2022.

Tangs of lime and salt penetrate through delicately sweet layers of grapefruit and tangerine in this pristine, laser-edged Riesling. It's spine tingling yet honeyed by a long, intensely mineral finish.

Aromas of black-skinned berry, cedar and underbrush lead the nose on this savory blend of Merlot, Syrah, Cabernet and Sangiovese. The chewy palate delivers black-currant jam, mocha and star anise alongside polished, velvety tannins. Drink through 2027.

Rounded black currants and a hint of prune mix with chocolate and black pepper on the nose of this very rich and powerful bottling from Paso Robles. The palate is thick and gooey with pepper spice cutting through the black-plum-cake flavors. Firm tannins and enduring acidity hold everything in check.

Blackberry and prune aromas are smoky and suggest hoisin or barbecue sauce. This Monastrell-Garnacha blend is a bit drawing and wiry on the palate, while flavors of toasty oak, blueberry and savory plum are bold. Oak character dominates a clampy, grating finish. Drink through 2023.

Full body and lots of toasted oak character give this reserve-style wine plenty of impact in the aroma, flavor and finish. Tempting scents of toasted almonds, vanilla and grilled baguette lead to concentrated pear, butter and cream on the palate, while the texture is powerful and velvety.

Red cherry, rust, cinnamon, vanilla and wet herbs make for a crisp and compelling nose on this bottling by winemaker Tim Slater, who manages to elicit cooler climate properties from a warmer region. A wide array of herbs, including thyme, oregano, marjoram and sage, decorate the firmly structured hibiscus, red currant and cranberry backdrop. The acid goes deep into the finish.

This is a mouthwatering, succulent kabinett chock full of sweet-tart guava and white grapefruit flavors. It's silken and sweet yet elegantly spry and mineral. Delightful now but likely to hold well through 2026.

Chewy and intensely herbal, this bold, powerfully built wine is bittersweet in tobacco and cigar box elements. The fruit leans into dark cherry and cassis, with a dusting of cocoa powder seasoned seductively throughout.

Made entirely with Chardonnay, this opens with aromas of yellow stone fruit, Spanish broom, toasted nut and a whiff of sage. The aromas follow over to the palate along with mature golden apple, bread crust, ginger and dried citrus zest alongside an elegant, persistent perlage. Fresh acidity lifts the dry finish.

Exhibiting all that one could hope from a coastal site, this wine offers earthy rose petal aromas around a tightly wound core of forest and tea. Structured tannin provide a framework for secondary characteristics to develop in the glass, from cranberry and orange peel to Asian five spice.

This is a light, ethereal and hugely satisfying wine, delicately layered and soft in texture. Huckleberry, Asian five spice and forest floor figure prominently along a succulent persistence of acidity and salty freshness.

This single-vineyard wine is rock solid, with punchy black-cherry fruit, a streak of mineral and a sprinkling of coffee grounds. Clean earth and graphite add more complexity, and the tanninsripe and sturdyprovide a perfect foundation. The wine was aged for 17 months in one-third new French oak, and should drink well into 2028.

This is an inaugural blend of 75% Merlot and 25% Cabernet Franc made by Dan Petroski of Larkmead for the new producer. The grapes come from vineyards located near the winery in Oak Knoll. Dried herb de Provence aromas invite one in to mingle with aspects of cedar, pencil and red currant, the style subdued and soft. Layers of quiet power and oak lie beneath the fruit.

Candied black cherry, rosebuds, violets and a minty tobacco quality all show on the nose of this countywide blend by Bruno D'Alfonso. It commands attention on the palate, showing black currant, blueberry, black-pepper-crusted beef and candied violet flavors, balanced by strong acidity.

Roasted cocoa, espresso cream and caramel provide richness to the nose of this Cabernet Sauvignon-led blend, but there's also bright black raspberry fruit and hints of pepper and fennel to give complexity. The palate starts with a zip, which dissipates into flavors of lilac, blueberry and anise seed.

The 70% of Merlot in the blend of this wine gives it richness and ripe red-berry fruits. The tannins, dusty and spicy, are a blend of the wood aging and the structure of the Cabernet Sauvignon. Ripe and juicy, the wine is packed with fruit and likely to age well. Drink from 2022.

Ripe, and densely textured, this wine shows an impressive, rich balance between fruit and tannins, with a dry core and broad black fruits that have great intensity. This wine, with 12 months in wood, conveys spice, concentration and excellent potential. Drink from 2024.

Run by the Nony family, this 17-acre estate has produced a generous, rounded wine dominated by black fruits. The barrel aging has enhanced the black-currant flavors and the acidity. All these elements are coming together in a full wine that will age well. Drink from 2024.

This rich wine comes from a historic estate in Listrac, dating to the 18th century. It offers tannins and a dry core as well as dark black fruits and acidity, giving the wine its structure and potential longevity. The wine will develop slowly and will be ready to drink from 2025.

Old vines on the estate, close to the ancient city walls of Saint-milion, produce this smoothly ripe wine. It is broad, generously rich with black fruits. The toast from wood aging will integrate with time. Wait until 2024 for this impressive wine to be ready to drink.

Aromas reminiscent of bread crust, nut and orchard fruit carry over to the vibrant linear palate along with pomegranate and citrus zest notes. Bright acidity and a lively elegant perlage provide support and energy.

Woodland berry, dark culinary spice, tilled earth and new leather aromas combine with whiffs of aromatic herb on this fragrant graceful red. The vibrant palate is all about balance and finesse, offering strawberry, red cherry, star anise and a hint of white pepper balanced by bright acidity and polished tannins. If you love extreme elegance, this is for you. Drink through 2024.

A robust and flavorful Chardonnay, this exhibits superb balance between the ripe fruit, woodspice and vibrant acidity. Notes of baked apple, clove-spiked orange, toasted hazelnut and peach pit abound on the nose and palate, with added hits of citrus pith, honeysuckle and lemon verbena that add grace and elegance.
