It's medium in weight, with a lightly textured grip and lively acidity that lifts the sweet-spiced finish. It's hard to resist now, but should mature well through 2023.

This wine has a classic nose of pencil shavings, cedar and ripe black plum, following through on the palate in similar fashion. Full bodied and highly concentrated, it layers in flavors of cherry compote and dark chocolate.

From the winery's Mountain Terrace Vineyard 1,700-feet up, this is a floral, subdued and brightly woven red wine. Vanilla and milk chocolate flavors provide a richness and likability, with a pronounced bite of oak and tannin on the finish.

This wine has inviting caramel-apple aromatics, which follow along a subdued palate of ripe texture and oak. A brightness of orange blossom and tangerine add freshness and vibrancy to the lush fig-filled surroundings, dotted in nutmeg.

Heady aromas of sun-kissed mango, peach and melon are cut by blades of steel and stone in this captivating kabinett. It's delightfully spry in texture, offering loads of crisp-tart yellow peach and nectarine flavors highlighted against streaks of lime acidity. The finish is fresh and mineral-laden.

This reserve-level best-barrel blend spent 16 months in 40% new oak. It's dark, chewy and toasty, with black cherry, black coffee and dark chocolate all in the mix of flavors. A solid and substantial wine, it drinks well young and may best be consumed over the next five years.

Ripe berry aromas with a touch of root beer are lush and soft. That is not the case on the palate, which is tight in the middle and scratchy along the edges. Blueberry and black-currant flavors are a touch minty, while this wine displays chocolate and lemon-peel notes on a tough, pulling finish. Drink through 2030.

This is a stainless steel bottling done right. Citrusy aromas of lime peel, orange pith, just-ripe Asian pear and a flash of sweet butter show on the nose. The texture is phenomenally grippy on the sip, where flavors of crushed chalk meet with yuzu zest, nectarine and white peach, remain brisk throughout. Pink-grapefruit zest carries the finish.

This is based upon a single Dijon 115 clone, and delivers potent ripe black-cherry flavors. It's a full-throttle bottle, textural and lightly touched with dried seaweed. The barrel aging adds a welcome touch of chocolate to the powerful tannic finish.

This bright, big and mouthfilling wine was fermented with wild yeast, which seems to infuse it with a dollop of mystery. Ultraripe lemon and grapefruit come with a hint of marshmallow and plenty of toasted-peanut flavors. It finds a smooth runway and coasts gently to a gliding stop, with those toasty flavors still resonating.

Based at Quinta de Roriz in the Douro, this wine is produced by a joint venture between the Prats family of Bordeaux and the Symington family of the Douro. Made as a second wine to Chryseia, it is soft and rich, with great tannins and ripe fruit. Black currants and acidity go together with a young, dry core. Drink from 2020.
Based on old Tinta Roriz vines, this elegant wine is ripe and densely structured, with good balance between red fruits and juicy acidity. It is a wine to age for several more years. Drink from 2021.

Exhibiting all that one could hope from a coastal site, this wine offers earthy rose petal aromas around a tightly wound core of forest and tea. Structured tannin provide a framework for secondary characteristics to develop in the glass, from cranberry and orange peel to Asian five spice.

This is a light, ethereal and hugely satisfying wine, delicately layered and soft in texture. Huckleberry, Asian five spice and forest floor figure prominently along a succulent persistence of acidity and salty freshness.

This single-vineyard wine is rock solid, with punchy black-cherry fruit, a streak of mineral and a sprinkling of coffee grounds. Clean earth and graphite add more complexity, and the tanninsripe and sturdyprovide a perfect foundation. The wine was aged for 17 months in one-third new French oak, and should drink well into 2028.

New leather, baked plum, truffle and fruitcake aromas rise up from the glass. It's rounded and full bodied, with velvety tannins that underscore fig, steeped prune, cinnamon, graphite and chewing tobacco. Fresh acidity lifts the rich flavors. Drink through 2023.

Yellow flower, bread crust, ripe orchard fruit and graphite scents mingle together in the glass. It's loaded with finesse, offering Golden Delicious apple, peach and tangerine zest balanced by bright acidity and a refined perlage.

All Dijon clones from the Alloro vineyard, this tightly wound effort mixes tree-fruit flesh and skin flavors in a compact balanced wine with some good years of life ahead. There's a pleasing nuttiness resonating through the finish, from a small percentage that was fermented in new French oak. Give it an extra year or two in bottle and it should open up nicely.

This lovely wine shows its dark side throughout, mixing black fruits with strong flavors of black coffee. Barrel aging, just under a year in one-quarter new French oak, brings up flavors of dark chocolate and chicory. It's delicious and substantial, ready for drinking over the next half decade or longer.

Demeter-certified biodynamic grapes go into the making of this light and delicate winea fine example of coastal cooling. Layered in earthy rose petal and cardamom, it shows length and breadth around a quiet core of tart rhubarb and pomegranate.

A blend of 90% Chardonnay and 10% Pinot Nero, this refined sparkler opens with heady aromas of white wild flower, citrus and a whiff of bread crust. On the lively palate, fresh acidity brightens creamy white peach, Golden Delicious apple and lemon drop. A brioche note wraps up the finish.

Bright and savory, this refreshing, polished sparkler boasts alluring aromas of juicy raspberry, wild cherry, baking spice and a whiff of bread crust. The inviting aromas follow over to the vibrant palate along with a continuous refined perlage. A tangy candied nectarine note closes the finish.

Coming from one of the state's top Syrah vineyards, this offers high-toned aromas of potpourri, red and blue fruit, sage, bacon fat, iron and spice. These lead to supple, restrained smoked meat and red-fruit flavors, stretching out on the finish. It brings a sense of elegance, taking some time to get going before strutting its stuff.

Bright and delicately scented, this elegant sparkler evokes aromas of spring wild flower, white stone fruit and crushed herb. The bright palate offers Rennet apple, Anjou pear, pastry cream and tangy lemon drop. It's balanced with fresh acidity while a silky mousse lends finesse.

Exotic spice, pressed violet and woodland-berry aromas create an inviting bouquet. The linear elegant palate delivers tart cherry, strawberry, licorice and white pepper while bright acidity and firm refined tannins provide balance and support. A note of orange zest closes the finish. It's still young so give it time to fully blossom. Drink 20192028.

In the opulent, concentrated school of thought this wonderful luxurious-tasting wine is shaped by very ripe fruit flavors and generous helpings of suave oak. Flavors run from marzipan to honeysuckle and poached pears, and a nicely viscous texture fills the mouth and helps the finish linger.

Close to some of the top Margaux vineyards, this estate regularly produces some fine wines. This bottling is beautifully structured, firm with tannins and also generous with black fruits. A high percentage of Merlot gives a particularly ripe and juicy wine that will age over the medium-term. Drink from 2022.

From vineyards surrounding the medieval moated castle, this wine is well balanced, rich and yet structured. It has great blackberry fruit and dry tannins for aging and it's coming together well. Drink from 2022.

Ripe and densely textured, this is a plush, full-bodied wine. With swathes of rich black fruits and some firm tannins, it has good potential. The richness contrasts with the black-currant acidity that gives this otherwise dense wine a bright, crisp aftertaste. Drink from 2024.

Purchased by Olivier Decelle, who also owns property in Saint-milion and a negociant business in Burgundy, this estate is producing impressive wines. This bottling is richly structured while preserving all the ripe blackberry fruits and intense acidity. Drink this wine from 2023.

This wine, full of dusty dry tannins as well as ripe black-currant fruit, blends equal proportions of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot. Its richness comes from the full fruitiness as well as the dry core that will allow the wine to age. It needs time and should not be drunk before 2024.

Dark and dense, this wine has good aging potential, with black fruits as well as a dry core of tannins. Minerality shows through in the texture of the wine. It is rich and generous, reflecting the vintage. Drink from 2024.

Made with organically grown Pinot Nero, this vibrant sparkler has subtle aromas of wild berry, crushed herb and an apple orchard in bloom. Structured and elegant, the savory palate delivers tart red cherry, raspberry compote, baking spice and a hint of brioche set against bright acidity. Small continuous bubbles provide the refined perlage.

Showing its age well, this pure expression of Negroamaro immediately engages the nose with aromas of concentrated berries, wild herbs and a hint of hoisin sauce. Round in feel, with structured acidity and supportive, fine-grained tannins, the palate offers a wealth of vitality in fresh red cherry, cranberry and streaks of granite. Savory herbs and earth tones linger on the finish. This is in a sweet spot now, so drink soon.

The nose is very shy but gives the slightest promise of ripe, red fruit. Red cherry appears in full splendor on the palate, edged by racy, exciting freshness and superfine but crunchy tannins. The body remains slender but there is a sensuous, warm core of ripe fruit. Lovely now but will develop over the coming five years. Drink 20182025.

This is fresh, aromatic and primary in cherry aromas. The same luscious, generous fruit also dominates the juicy palate. There is freshness to balance this abundance but this is hedonistic and fruit driven to the core, with a cinnamon undertone. Drink 20182025.

The nose offers lovely touches of stone, fern and white pepper, with the freshness of green apple. There is something pristine about this wine, something light, clear and utterly moreish. The finish is clean and dry.

While feather light and ethereal in texture, there's an abundance of plump, juicy yellow cherry, guava and even strawberry fruitiness here. It's unabashedly forward and fruity yet racy and fresh. The finish lingers on a lovely floral tone.

Hints of caramelized sugar, pollen and orange peel glaze this succulent, lip-smacking Riesling. Its delicate sweetness is bolstered by sunny squirts of orange and yellow peach, but balanced neatly against a solid backbone of lime acidity. A deeply penetrating sptlese with a long burnt-sugar finish.

A cool, steely undertone intensifies crisp, yellow stone fruit and lime on the nose and palate. With electric, sweet-tart darts of honey and nectar, this is a piercing, concentrated wine that has a long lime-pith finish.

Intoxicating notes of exotic spice, smoke and crushed earth intensify flavors of pristine white grapefruit and peach in this tantalizing kabinett. Deeply penetrating in fruit and vibrantly balanced in acidity, it finishes with a long, crystalline finish.

Dusty earth and smoke tones are predominant on first whiff but open gradually, offering a succession of ripening fruits from fresh lime and gooseberry to crunchy peach and pink grapefruit. It's a spry, taut wine, with scintillating acidity and a long crystalline finish.

This wine is a blend of 49% Syrah, 38% Grenache and a whopping 13% Viognier, with the latter expressing itself on both the aromas and palate. The wine pops, with notes of freshly peeled orange, stargazer lilly, gravel, olive, smoked meat, blueberry and boysenberry. Soft and sumptuous, the palate shows a lot of elegance and expression along with an extended finish.

Pronounced aromas of struck match and flint belie the intensity of fresh grapefruit and lemon at the core of this delicately off-dry wine. It's more earth and herbs than forward or fruity but there's a savory intensity here that's beguiling. It's a wine that should improve with some cellaring, try after 2020.

This is the top cuve from the winery, and just a single barrel was produced. It's packed with baking spices, vanilla, black tea and cardamom. These are more than highlights: they are a substantial element, along with ripe black fruits. This was all whole-cluster fermented, and aged for 18 months in barrel.

This typifies the best wines from this AVA, with well-matched components. Ripe sweet red berries are at the core, with accents of dried herbs and a whiff of cannabis. Everything is smoothly integrated and works well as a seamless whole.

There are the typical rich aromas of blackberry pastry and black plum on the nose of this Zinfandel, but also a flowery elegance and savory hints of char. The palate is quite interesting, with powerful cracked pepper, dried herb and charred wood decorating the pure black plum backdrop and a long caramelized finish. A compelling take on Zin.

This wine is super dark in hue and packed full of blackberry, wood smoke and black pepper flavors. It brings a relatively light (for the varietal) mouthfeel considering that it does have a wealth of fine-grained tannins and elevated alcohol. Drink now with a steak or chop, or cellar until 2025 for more maturity and nuance.

This is in its infancy now, but it's remarkably refined and nuanced, showing great promise for evolution and development. Notes of melon rind, orange peel, lemon verbena and fresh fynbos fill the bouquet, while the palate offers more pithy citrus and green melon characters. It's well-balanced, with vibrant acidity and a fresh wet-stone minerality that endures through the long finish. It's hard to resist now, but it will continue to mature and hold well through 2024.

While initially offering more earth than fruit, this sprightly kabinett amasses bold white peach, grapefruit and gooseberry flavors as it opens and melds. Vivacious acidity and lingering undertones of crushed earth and clay lend structure and depth. Drinks well already but should improve through 2030.

This barrel selection is still tight and tannic, with compact, yet substantial cranberry, raspberry and pie-cherry fruit. It's got muscle and depth, and opens up nicely with aeration, displaying ripe and polished tannins through a long finish.

There's strong oak, vanilla and spice cake on the nose of this rich bottling from Paso Robles vineyards as well as sugar plums and wet soil aromas. There's an earthy minerality of turned loam to the palate, with hints of forest moss, pine oil and cracked pepper.

Utilizing Pommard clones planted in 1990, this exceptional wine has a nose-tickling funky note, providing a rich composty accent to juice loaded with raspberry and cherry fruit. It's detailed and textural, a truly engaging wine which goes well beyond the fruit to add the sort of complexity not often found in this price range.

Thick, firm tannin is pronounced in this reserve-level wine. Coconut and vanilla-seasoned oak rides along a roadway of dried herb, clove and blackberry as the texture softens and teases in complexity.
This impressive single-quinta wine is packed with fruit and plenty of the firm tannins. Ripe, perfumed and with touches of sweetness, it will age well. Drink from 2027.

With its north-facing aspect, this vineyard is just right for red wines rather than Port. A cool character comes through even in ageworthy wines such as this. Firm tannins mix in with the juicy red fruits and crisp aftertaste. Wood aging adds spice and rounds out the wine. Drink from 2021.

Cool, intensely mineral tones of slate and river rock permeate from nose to finish. It's dry on the palate but elegantly fruity, offering notes of crisp stone fruit, tangerine and lime. Piercing acidity leads a long, thrilling finish. It's a lovely wine already but likely to show even better from 2019.

Tasty, spicy oak nuances give a great lift to this frankly heavy, massively built wine that is very full bodied and has a thick layer of chewy tannins. Hints of toasted walnuts, cinnamon and nutmeg weave through dark chocolate, blackberry and espresso flavors that are concentrated and deep.

Bright and forward on the nose, this leads with attractive scents of lemon custard, verbena and grilled pineapple. The palate is plush and round, yet not overdone, boasting lush flavors of toasted apple and citrus oil that linger on the close. Bright acidity keeps the weight in check and lends a mouthwatering sensation on the finish. Time will encourage added depth and complexity, so consider drinking 20202024.

Again in 2015 this offers reserve-level density and extra complexity, with the added bonus that it's the winery's biggest production Pinot. Winemaker Tony Rynders loads it with appealing cinnamon, caramel and milk chocolate components from aging in half new French oak. This is all nicely integrated into a base of fresh raspberry fruit. Tasty and ready for near-term drinking.
Dusty mineral tones juxtapose pristine lime and lemon in this zesty, steely wine. While dry and light footed, it has an expansive, juicy richness that's satisfying through a long finish.

A little reserved at first, with time this opens up to reveal notes of pressed fynbos, dandelion, fresh straw, apple blossom and crushed mineral that grace the just-ripe apple and green-melon core. Surprisingly round and mouth-filling, that weight is countered by a stunningly vibrant seam of citrusy acidity and spiced tones of allspice and nutmeg. Final notes of grilled apple skin and pie crust dance on the lingering finish. Drink now2026.

This is an intensely youthful blend of 48% Cabernet Sauvignon, 21% Syrah, 21% Cabernet Franc and 10% Malbec. Concentrated flavors of black cherry, blackberry, cured meat and black licorice are well wrapped within a cocoon of toasted oak and firm tannins. Enjoy 20252030.

Z'IVO's Pinot Blanc is an obscure clone called Gouges, after the Burgundy winery that first isolated it. It's exceptionally dense, textural and racy, with scents and mouthfeel close to Chablis, with the same underlying minerality. Oyster shells and sea-breeze accents come with tart melon fruit and a touch of lime zest.

All Dijon clones from the Alloro vineyard, this tightly wound effort mixes tree-fruit flesh and skin flavors in a compact balanced wine with some good years of life ahead. There's a pleasing nuttiness resonating through the finish, from a small percentage that was fermented in new French oak. Give it an extra year or two in bottle and it should open up nicely.

Blackberry, leather and plum aromas are inviting. This wine is full and lush on the palate, with grippy tannins. Oaky berry flavors are accented by spice and chocolate notes, while the finish brings pronounced coffee and mocha flavors. Drink through 2025.

This reserve has the same detail and overall finesse as the regular estate bottling, but here there's an extra dollop of black fruits. Overall, the 12-barrel select is a bit bigger and fruitier, but much in the same style.

Rich, ripe and downright succulent, this offers pinpoint fruit flavors of grapefruit, apple and melon, with a broad streak of vanilla cream. The length is a bit surprising, sneaking up as the wine breathes open. Though just 10% was aged in new barrels, there is a pleasing toasty frame around the finish.

A must-get for those attracted to obscure grapes, this cool vintage bottling of a northern Italian variety by Marisa Beverly (assistant winemaker at Au Bon Climat, and Jim Clendenen's niece) shows cranberry, strawberry, dried plum, baked earth and sumac-cinnamon spice on the nose. The palate offers strong loamy minerality right away, then settles into dried sage, peppery spice and tangy but dense dark fruits.

This wine, under the same ownership as Margaux estate Mongravey, is a well-structured blend with 70% Cabernet Sauvignon. The 100% new-wood aging gives the wine an intensely toasty, dry character at this young stage. But the great black-currant and berry fruit is developing as well. Drink this rich wine from 2024.

Packed with black fruits and dense tannins, this is a rich wine with a fine future. This is full bodied and structured in feel, with a dry, spicy core of tannins. With its deep concentration, this wine will do well with time in the cellar. Drink from 2025.

This is an impressively structured and balanced wine from Patrick Meynard. Rich black fruits are nourished by the spice and toast of wood aging for 14 to 18 months.Dense and juicy, this ripe wine likely will age well. Drink from 2024.

Produced under the same management as Chteau Larose Trintaudon, this wine is rich, smoky and packed with blackberry fruits. Its warm, ripe character contrasts with the juicy fruitiness and firm backdrop of tannins, giving a wine with potential. Drink from 2024.

This estate, based in the Gironde port village of Lamarque, has produced a richly textured, chocolate and bitter-cocoa-flavored wine. That is only a problem at the moment, because ripe black-currant fruits are developing under the structure to give density, concentration and a serious wine as it ages. Drink from 2021.

Big, ripe and packed with tannins, this is a dense wine. The concentration is palpable, rich with black plum and berry fruits. This powerful wine with its great tannins and fruit needs to age. Drink from 2025.

Generous in its ripe Merlot, this wine is sumptuous and full bodied. Although there are plenty of tannins, they give just the right structure to this wine. From a 74-acre property that is named after the small village of Pez, the wine is rich and will age well. Drink from 2025.

A classic blend of 80% Sangiovese, 10% Canaiolo and 10% Colorino, this fragrant, almost ethereal wine is all about finesse. It opens with earthy aromas of woodland berry, tilled soil, truffle, violet and new leather while the elegant palate delivers succulent Marasca cherry, crushed strawberry and baking spice. Bright acidity and polished tannins provide balance and refined support. Drink through 2028.

This is a whopper of a Pinot Noir, seen through the eyes of a Paso Robles winemaker. Dark and thick in the glass, it shows black cherry, clove and allspice on the nose. The massive palate offers blackberry and boysenberry flavors, with spicy gingersnap notes giving balance.

This Grenache is a little older than the typical release, and that gives it some extra depth. Aromas of cranberry sauce, baking spice, rose petals, hibiscus and carnations are nose-tickling. The palate is loaded with spice cake, gingerbread and rounded, slightly sour red-cherry flavors, altogether soft and pleasing.

Fragrant woodland berry, blue flower and cake spice aromas mingle with a balsamic menthol note. The concentrated but almost weightless palate offers juicy raspberry, fleshy black cherry, espresso and star anise alongside polished supple tannins.

Smooth and showing primary bready flavors, this has a concentrated core of apple and quince, with plenty of barrel flavors. Roasted peanuts, lemon zest and a touch of salted caramel come up, but this young wine really needs another year or two in bottle to show its best.

Zesty, aromatic notes of lemon and tangerine carry the nose. The palate then bursts forth with ripe citrus: tangerine, orange and mandarin. This off-dry version of Sylvaner may be unusual but it is a triumph of balance. The concentrated, zesty freshness of citrus is countered by the ripeness of the fruit on a very light, fresh, concentrated and compelling palate. This is intriguing and irresistible.

Dominated by dark-colored, dense Alicante Bouschet, this is a rich wine. Its tannins are still up front, although watch for the rich black fruits as they develop. Aged in wood, it has vanilla and spice flavors that enhance the ripe fruit of the wine. Drink from 2019.

This is a small-production wine from a former French soccer player. It is soft, with great fruit and a rounded texture. Generous while also dense, it's powered by firm tannins. Drink this ripe wine from 2025.

This wine is all Cinsault from Olsen Vineyard. Aged in neutral French oak, it's resplendent with aromas of raspberry jam, potpourri, plum, flower and garrigue. The palate is transparent in style with elegant but rich red-fruit and plum flavors that lead to a lengthy, warm finish.

Dense aromas of strawberry, mace and vanilla combine for an alluringly rich experience on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. Notes of clove, allspice and gingerbread rise on the palate, where the background tones of mulberry and elderberry jam prove elegant and interesting.

This wine is spicy, savory and densea full-bodied wine from the sparkling wine producer which farms throughout the appellation. Buzzing acidity lies beneath a hearty helping of black cherry, strawberry and cola.

Plush and candied aromas of red cherry compote, rum butter, vanilla and mulling spice show on the nose of this bottling. Opulent cherry and rhubarb flavors mix with dark spice, bay leaf and tarragon on the palate, all riding a compelling texture with sizzling acidity.

Blackberry, leather and plum aromas are inviting. This wine is full and lush on the palate, with grippy tannins. Oaky berry flavors are accented by spice and chocolate notes, while the finish brings pronounced coffee and mocha flavors. Drink through 2025.

This reserve has the same detail and overall finesse as the regular estate bottling, but here there's an extra dollop of black fruits. Overall, the 12-barrel select is a bit bigger and fruitier, but much in the same style.

Rich, ripe and downright succulent, this offers pinpoint fruit flavors of grapefruit, apple and melon, with a broad streak of vanilla cream. The length is a bit surprising, sneaking up as the wine breathes open. Though just 10% was aged in new barrels, there is a pleasing toasty frame around the finish.

A must-get for those attracted to obscure grapes, this cool vintage bottling of a northern Italian variety by Marisa Beverly (assistant winemaker at Au Bon Climat, and Jim Clendenen's niece) shows cranberry, strawberry, dried plum, baked earth and sumac-cinnamon spice on the nose. The palate offers strong loamy minerality right away, then settles into dried sage, peppery spice and tangy but dense dark fruits.

This wine, under the same ownership as Margaux estate Mongravey, is a well-structured blend with 70% Cabernet Sauvignon. The 100% new-wood aging gives the wine an intensely toasty, dry character at this young stage. But the great black-currant and berry fruit is developing as well. Drink this rich wine from 2024.

Packed with black fruits and dense tannins, this is a rich wine with a fine future. This is full bodied and structured in feel, with a dry, spicy core of tannins. With its deep concentration, this wine will do well with time in the cellar. Drink from 2025.

This is an impressively structured and balanced wine from Patrick Meynard. Rich black fruits are nourished by the spice and toast of wood aging for 14 to 18 months.Dense and juicy, this ripe wine likely will age well. Drink from 2024.

Produced under the same management as Chteau Larose Trintaudon, this wine is rich, smoky and packed with blackberry fruits. Its warm, ripe character contrasts with the juicy fruitiness and firm backdrop of tannins, giving a wine with potential. Drink from 2024.

This estate, based in the Gironde port village of Lamarque, has produced a richly textured, chocolate and bitter-cocoa-flavored wine. That is only a problem at the moment, because ripe black-currant fruits are developing under the structure to give density, concentration and a serious wine as it ages. Drink from 2021.

This is a dense wine, packed with black fruits and rich tannins. The dominance of Cabernet Sauvignon gives the wine its ripe, juicy black-currant flavors and good acidity. This 56-acre estate has made a wine that will age well. Drink from 2025.

This wine comes from an historic 700-acre estate in the southern Mdoc that's home to vines, forests and stallions. The wine is ripe and full of black currants from its majority of Cabernet Sauvignon. Rich and packed with generous fruit, the wine shows the progress the property has made in recent years. It still holds plenty of tannins, so age further and drink from 2023.

The estate recalls the Pontac family, once one of the largest landowners in Bordeaux, who built this grand 16th-century hunting lodge. Today's wine is well balanced with ripe tannins, juicy red fruits and acidity. The 60% Merlot gives a full, generous character, although the tannins need time to soften. Drink from 2024.

This is a supple and sexy version of a notoriously tannic wine. It has a deep dark color, enticing dark chocolate and blackberry aromas and a thick layer of berries and black cherries on the palate. Tightly meshed tannins give it plenty of pucker power, and mean that this wine can age for quite a while. Best from 2020 to 2025.

Clean aromas of cinnamon, dried rose petals and tight raspberry fruit make for a very pretty nose on this lighter delicate style of Grenache. The palate is quite fresh, with cherry, cranberry, orange rind, dried ginger, cracker pepper and sumac flavorings combining for a very refreshing, elegant bottling.

This wine exhibits a beautifully pristine, precise and elegant character. It opens with delicate scents of apple flesh, orange blossom, saline and just a hint of toasted, earthy spice. That briny, mineral seam continues to shine on the palate, dancing through the fresh fruit flavors and leaving a lip-smacking kiss on the finish. A stunner now, this will continue to evolve and mature well through 2022.

This wine offers aromas of black, cherry, raspberry and violet. The tannins are barely noticeable at first, slowly building as flavors of cherry, cassis, violet and chocolate-covered espresso bean make their way across the palate. Hints of spice and cherry are evident throughout the prolonged finish.

Clean aromas of cinnamon, dried rose petals and tight raspberry fruit make for a very pretty nose on this lighter delicate style of Grenache. The palate is quite fresh, with cherry, cranberry, orange rind, dried ginger, cracker pepper and sumac flavorings combining for a very refreshing, elegant bottling.

This wine exhibits a beautifully pristine, precise and elegant character. It opens with delicate scents of apple flesh, orange blossom, saline and just a hint of toasted, earthy spice. That briny, mineral seam continues to shine on the palate, dancing through the fresh fruit flavors and leaving a lip-smacking kiss on the finish. A stunner now, this will continue to evolve and mature well through 2022.

This wine offers aromas of black, cherry, raspberry and violet. The tannins are barely noticeable at first, slowly building as flavors of cherry, cassis, violet and chocolate-covered espresso bean make their way across the palate. Hints of spice and cherry are evident throughout the prolonged finish.

This wine sees 40% French oak and is a reserve-level barrel selection. Soft and smooth, the pretty berry and plum fruit has a touch of mocha, but not too much. It's had ample bottle time to be ready to enjoy immediately.

Coming from one of the state's premier Syrah vineyards, the aromas pop, with notes of boysenberry, bacon fat, orange peel, herb and spice. The palate is dense and rich, packed with ultraripe blue- and black-fruit flavors. It delivers a lot of hedonistic appeal. For those looking for a big, bold, warm vintage Syrah, this one's for you.
This wine is delightfully fruit-forward in cherry cola and strawberry jam, balancing the strong well-defined flavors against a backdrop of powerful tannin and oak.

Savory and vibrant, this bright polished sparkler delivers aromas and flavors of red cherry, crushed raspberry, Rennet apple, tangy nectarine and bread crust. Refreshing acidity and a lively, refined perlage lift the finish.

Aromas of cherry, raspberry and coffee bean set the stage for flavors of black cherry, blackberry, apple peel, white chocolate and baking spice. Opulent tannins coat palate, making way for a juicy, blueberry pie flavored finish.

The Latchkey vineyard is shared with Cody Wright (of Purple Hands). Spicy cranberry, strawberry and raspberry fruit shines here, young and fresh and vibrant. It's snappy and sappy, with good grip and supporting acidity. It should drink best in the early 2020s.
There's a dusty character to the tannins, which complement the tart pomegranate and raspberry fruit. It's already quite smooth, lightly toasty and finished with a dollop of cinnamon.

This shows power and richness with a bit of finesse as well. Accompanying a deep, dark hue are equally dense aromas of black cherry and blackberry, cola, cocoa and a hint of dried herbs. The palate comes with chewy tannins and more plush fruit, but this well-structured wine should come into its own with great dignity soon enough. Drink 20202032.
This is a terrific wine from a classic estate which sits at 2,700 in the Sierra Foothills. It offers rich vanilla and cream aromas, with abundant pear and nutmeg flavor balanced by subtle acidity.

Leeuwin's characteristic elegance and approachability, combined with ageability, are in full force here. Trademark pencil lead, eucalyptus and red currant characters mingle with dried flowers, herbs and furniture polish. The tannins are dusty and tight-grained, with an herbaceous currant flavor continuing throughout. Drink now2032.

This wine from Matchbook has been improving steadily over recent vintages and now it's taken a big step toward more finesse and less flash. A very soothing mouthfeel and generous, but not overt, flavors make a great combination in this creamy, yummy and full-bodied wine. It has everything from toasty oak and lemon curd to mild marzipan nuances that interlace with good acidity for a balanced palate and a lingering finish.

Tinta Negra is a hybrid grape that takes on the characteristics of other Madeira grapes. To taste, this oak-aged wine could almost be a Bual. Smooth and rich, it has a sweet toffee and caramel character to go alongside the intense acidity. Drink now.

Delicately wood aged, this wine is beautifully structured and balanced. Ripe apple and quince fruits are cut with acidity and a clean, clear minerality. The wine needs to age for a while and will be ready to drink from 2019.

Black fruits dominate this full-bodied block selection. The alcohol is pulled back a half step from the previous vintage, and there's a pleasing minerality to the foundation. A hint of caraway comes up as it winds down through the chocolatey finish.

Blue flower, Asian spice and wild berry aromas mingle with a whiff of espresso. The rounded generous palate offers baked plum, fleshy blackberry, licorice and a hint of mocha alongside supple tannins. Drink through 2023.

Seriously wood aged, this reserva is meant to be matured over several years. Firm tannins, rich black fruits and concentration provide the aging potential. It's a rich, dense wine, still with its dry core. Give this ripe wine until 2020.

While the nose is intensely honeyed and floral, there's a steely mineral intensity on the palate of this elegant, dry Riesling. Pristine white grapefruit, lime and gooseberry flavors are invigorating and tart but fall on the palate in creamy, expansive layers. It's an impeccably balanced wine with a long, honed finish.

Hints of smoke and pencil shavings accent fragrant cherry blossom and pink grapefruit notes in this feather-light kabinett. It's a juicy, unctuously fruity wine but structured keenly by laser-light acidity and earthy nuances that linger long on the finish.

Named after the Son of Apulia, Frederick II of Swabiathe 13th century Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire who made his summer home the Castel del Monte, for which the DOCG is now namedthis is a pure expression of the Nero di Troia variety. Aromas of dark cherries, spiced bramble berries, old leather and anise permeate the nose and carry through to a tightly woven, grippy palate. There's wonderful tension, depth and complexity to this medium-bodied wine which needs a few years to soften its tannic edge. Drink from 2020.

Plumes of ripe peach, apricot and mango are exuberant on the nose, while the fruit profile on the palate is markedly demure, offering crisp but penetrating hits of gooseberry, green plum and lime. It's taut and nervous on the palate, with a firm mineral undertone. While elegant already, this should meld its fruit and mineral intensities after a few years in the cellar. Hold till 2019.

It's at least the third excellent vintage in a row from Ruby Hill, which is a historic name in Livermore Valley. Rich, concentrated and oaky, this is a no-holds-barred wine that layers toasted, smoky, spicy aromas overripe pear and nutmeg flavors. The body is full and the texture is mouth-filling.

Deeply concentrated lemon and pineapple meld seamlessly into earthier complexities of crushed earth and flint in this vivacious sptlese. It's deft and dancing on the palate, with a piercing honey-struck finish. Drinks well already but should improve further through 2025.

A rich style of Paso Cab, this bottling starts with aromas of rich black-cherry cream, vanilla, nutmeg, gravel and cinnamon. The palate is full of caramel, French toast and kirsch flavors at first, but then the chalky, still somewhat stiff tannins add a mouth-coating texture.

Toasty dark-fruit aromas are compact. In the mouth, this wine is more screechy, tannic and taut. Oaky and berry flavors are balanced and integrated on a long finish with driving acidity. Drink this strong-boned Tempranillo from a lesser vintage through 2028.

Lilacs and plump blackberry fruit meet with dried sage, fennel and a hint of green peppercorn on the lively fresh nose of this bottling by second generation vintner Drake Whitcraft. The palate is peppery, fresh and light, with cracked black pepper, rounded purple fruits and a strong acidity proving easy to quaff.

This full-bodied wine makes no apologies for its assertive oaky profile and matches the power of the smoky spicy elements deftly with ripe pear and hazelnut flavors. It has excellent concentration and a sense of layering, plus a long, delicious finish.

Focused and elegantly structured, this sparkling blend has enticing scents of orchard fruit, citrus and brioche. The vibrant, precise palate evokes white cherry, peach and tangerine zest framed in bright acidity and a refined lively mousse. A mineral note closes the dry finish.

A fifty-fifty blend of Chardonnay and Pinot Nero, this opens with enticing scents of brioche, white stone fruit, citrus and red berry. Mirroring the nose, the vibrant palate offers tart sour cherry, pomegranate, bread dough and tangerine zest alongside a refined perlage and tangy acidity. A bitter almond note marks the close.

Berry, apple and pastry aromas delicately swirl in the glass while the vibrant palate offers white peach, tangy tangerine zest and white cherry. An elegant, persistent perlage and bright acidity provide elegance and energy while a ginger note wraps around the finish.

There's a pleasant earthy, spicy character right off the bat on the nose of this wine, opening with pronounced scents of Dr. Pepper, cherry cola, red plum, chicory root and church incense. The medium-weight palate offers structured tannins that lend surprising grip, yet bright acidity keeps the mouthfeel lifted. The stalky, tight red-berry flavors on the palate return to spicy abundance on the medium-length finish. Drink 20202025.
This juicy bottle bursts open with pomegranate, cherry and orange zest. Hints of Dr. Pepper streak through, but overall it's an elegant and detailed wine, showing more finesse than sheer power.

A shift from the 2005, this is one-third Pinot Noir and two-thirds Chardonnay, disgorged in July of 2017. It's tasty and surprisingly young, with tart apple and peach flavors dominant, along with light custard and some lovely toast. This may be enjoyed now or cellared for up to five years.

A blend of 80% Pinot Noir and 20% Chardonnay, this vibrant sparkler offers fresh aromas of red berry and citrus. On the palate, a lively perlage underscores pomegranate, red grapefruit and a hint of baking spice. It's well balanced, with crisp acidity.

Exuberantly blossomy, this perfumed kabinett offers loads of pristine white peach and pineapple flavors off set by layers of cool minerals. It's a juicy yet revitalizing wine, with a long crystalline finish.

Initially this wine is charred and smoky-smelling, with accents of graphite and cola. A tight, juicy palate is bolstered by bold core acidity, while ripe blackberry and currant flavors capture both the black and red sides of the flavor spectrum. A dry, tannic finish with peppery flavors is intense. Drink through 2026.

It's rare to find a Portuguese white wine this old still available. While it does taste mature, it has wonderful nutty flavors and acidity, giving an old gold, yeasty character. This is a food wine, with its structure and mineral aftertaste. Drink now.

Spicy, structured and with a smoky character, this rich wine will develop power. It has a dense texture, layers of tannins that are integrating with the blackberry fruits. This will be a good wine as it matures. Drink from 2024.

This rich, juicy wine has 90% Merlot in the blend giving it vibrancy, rich tannins and great black-plum and spice flavors. It is a ripe wine, powerful and dense with intense youthful acidity that will soften. Drink this balanced, firm wine from 2022.

Made with 100% Pinot Nero, this offers inviting aromas of cherry, acacia, bread dough and a whiff of hazelnut. On the bright structured palate, fresh acidity lifts toasted nut, brioche and pomegranate alongside a lively refined perlage.

The nose on this ultimately zesty wine starts off on the richer side, with baked apple, yellow melon, cherimoya and orange peel. On the palate, the acidity is immediate and tremendously persistent, with flavors of apple blossom, pear syrup and tangerine spray riding the chalky texture.

Enticing, fruity aromas of red cherry and brambly berry set the stage for layers of cola, baking spice and cocoa. The medium-weight palate offers a texture like crushed satin, smooth yet defined, with ample acidity to keep the structure and ripe-fruit flavors from feeling overly dense. The spice returns on the finish and continues alongside a hint of peppery warmth. Drink now2023.

Sourced from a vineyard on the western edge of the valley, this sports lovely aromatics introducing matching flavors of black cherry and a dash of pepper. There's a pleasing minerality, like a lick of granite, and a whiff of dried thyme also.

A blend of 29% Roussanne, 23% Chardonnay, 22% Chenin Blanc, 18% Grenache Blanc and 8% Viognier, this opens with delicate aromas of pink apple, orange blossom, strawberry hull and white melon. The medium-weight palate offers just enough fruity weight to ground the precise cut of the vibrant acidity. Harmonious and well-balanced, this is one to enjoy now2022.

There is a slight hint of lime zest and fern on the nose. The palate is more expressive but in a slender, subtle way, offering a lime zest flavor countered by white pepper and a streak of green fern. Citrus freshness tingles everywhere and even has a pithy, textural element to it.

Dusty mineral and zesty lime aromas are contrasted by plump, summer-sweet peach and tangerine on the palate. It's a spry, frisky kabinett, with lip-smacking sweetness balanced neatly by streaks of spine tingling acidity.

There's a buzz of electric acidity that hits the midpalate here, softened by tones of luscious peach, pineapple and guava. It's delicate and thrilling on the palate but lavishly floral and fruity through a long, reverberating finish.

Fruit for this wine comes from the state's original Syrah vineyard. Expressive aromas of dried herb, dark raspberry, huckleberry, spice and licorice lead to ripe, full fruit flavors that glide on the finish. It's not shy, bringing a lot of richness and appeal.

Intensely earthen tones of smoke and slate abound in this profoundly mineral sptlese. The midpalate brings forth sweeter, sunnier tones of fresh lemon and lime, along with a pleasantly bracing astringency that lends structure to the finish. It's a savory but complex sptlese that needs time to meld. Hold till at least 2020 but its likely to improve for at least a decade beyond that.

Just a handful of Oregon wineries produce this varietal wine, and one hopes more will follow. Fresh, leesy and rich, with mineral-soaked flavors, this broadens out in the mouth with apple-flavored fruit. There's an appealing note of toasted cracker, peanut shells and a whiff of sea breeze. It's a fascinating wine.

A delicious bottle of Pinot Gris from Iris is as certain as a sunrise. This lightly tawny wine brings scents of lemon oil, white flowers and lemon verbena. The lovely fruit pulls in apple, pear, kiwi and a touch of banana, all in perfect balance. In short, this is a thoroughly engaging and versatile white wine.

This exceptional site was planted back in the 1970s, and winemaker Jay Somers pulls some of that old-vine depth and nuance out of his first release from Medici. Bursting with ripe cherry fruit, it's got a base of clean earth, with highlights of coffee grinds and dark chocolate.

This is tight and reserved at first, needing time to open and reveal notes of green apple, lemon-lime citrus, yellow plum and underripe mango. Given those tight, bright aromas, it's surprising to encounter the medium-weight, round mouthfeel, with low acidity and ripe tones of guava and white grapefruit that carry through to the close.

This remains tightly wound, but the deep flavors of black cherry and cassis suggest that once it unwraps it will add muscle and mass. Highlights of coffee and charred wood lead into an astringent finish with drying tannins.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of oak, coconut, forest floor and plum cake that carry over to the chewy palate along with juicy black cherry, mocha and vanilla. Soft rounded tannins provide supple support.

Pure and very appetizing notes of baked pear and fresh, yellow apple play on the nose. The palate reprises these flavors with juicy, fruity abundance and balances them with vibrant freshness. There is concentration and depth of pear and apple flavors. The finish is just off dry but full of that glorious fruit.

There's a lot to like about this refreshing, savory sparkler. It opens with inviting aromas of baked bread, baking spice, white stone fruit and a whiff of lemon pastry cream. The vibrant elegant palate delivers ripe Gala apple, white peach, candied tangerine drop and hazelnut alongside tangy acidity. A lively perlage provides the backdrop.

This tightly wound, still very young bottling from Rick Longoria's estate vineyard needs a little time to open up, but when it does, there are grapefruit pith, candied lemon rind and freeze-dried honeydew aromas to enjoy. The texture is tremendously chalky, delivering flavors of lime skin, apple rind and orange candies.

This wine shows a heady, toasty nose of black-fruit aromas, along with maple, spice and heat notes. Spiced blackberry and cassis flavors are typical of this Tinta de Toro, however a palate that's rough as sandpaper makes this a tough go. Drink through 2025.

Smooth and toasty, this cuve pushes pretty barrel flavors front and center, well-defined and framing crisp fruit flavors of raspberry and cherry. There's a dash of orange marmalade that seals the finish. The wine spent 16 months in barrel, 40% new and 60% once-used.
This medium-bodied Pinot offers aromas of tree bark, vanilla, dried leaves, cherry cola and a hint of licorice. The palate is supersmooth, with silky tannins and a tart cherry finish.

A blend of 51% Petit Verdot, 42% Cabernet Sauvignon and 7% Carmenre, this opens with floral tones of crushed violets and carnation alongside brambly berry, chocolate-covered cherry and sweet spice. The plush, velvety palate showcases a solid tannic structure and a fruity berry-preserve flavor, while final notes of tree bark, wood spice and cocoa powder linger long on the close. Drink now2023.

Lightly wood aged, this ripe wine was fermented initially in open tanks, giving the wine its rich black-fruit character and open texture. Spice from wood aging mixes with generous fruits to make a richly textured wine that will be ready to drink from 2019.

This is a ripe wine full of broad black fruits. Smoothed by the wood aging and with plenty of acidity to balance, it is rich and structured. The tannins in this wine from the de la Rosa estate are already enmeshed in the fruit. This wine could be drunk now for its fruit, although it will be better from 2019.

This is a well-balanced and attractive pour, with scents of orange blossom, lemon verbena, quinine and lime that frame the just-ripe peach and melon fruit core. A pithy astringency provides a subtle texture to the palate and lends some lingering grip to the finish, coupled with a vibrant acidity that leaves you read for more. Drink now2022.

While subdued on the nose, there's a deep concentration of sweet-tart tangerine and grapefruit flavors on the palate of this lushly textured Riesling. It's bold in mouthfeel for a kabinett but zesty acidity and a flinty mineral undertone keeps it invigorating.

Subdued red apple and lemon on the nose ripen into sweeter, honeyed tones of mango, peach and nectarine on the palate. Surprisingly lavish and deeply concentrated, it's an unctuously fruity yet elegantly balanced wine, with a vivacious lemon-lime finish.

Scintillating acidity highlights crisp yellow peach and apple in this racy, light-footed kabinett. It's a delicately honeyed but penetrating wine that's approachable now but concentrated enough to hold well through 2025.

Reflecting a warm, dry vintage, this wine smells ripe and balsamic, with notes of cheese blending with raw wood, cowhide, coconut and cassis aromas. A bipolar palate features creamy oak and lemony acidity. Deep berry-fruit flavors are pushed by perky acidity towards a finish with toast and chocolate notes. Drink from 20192030.

A blend of 70% Nero di Troia and 30% Montepulciano, this is an enticingly savory and earthy wine with lots of appeal. Aromas of spiced red cherry, cured meat, peppery tobacco and anise meld seamlessly on the nose. The aromas are echoed on the mouthwatering and engaging palate of medium weight, lingering on a sanguine note. Currently grippy and structured with grainy tannins, this will soften with time in bottle, giving way to its wealth of complexities. Enjoy from 2020.

Here's a savory red with surprising depth for the cool wet vintage. Dark wild cherry, licorice, violet, juicy plum, tilled earth and truffle aromas all follow through to the buffed palate. Fresh acidity and supple polished tannins lend brightness and give it a smooth, rounded texture.

Red berry, bread dough and toasted nut aromas emerge on this elegant, structured sparkler. On the palate, bright acidity underscores Rennet apple, pomegranate and nectarine alongside a refined perlage.

A gorgeous bouquet of apple skin, grilled pineapple, beeswax and a touch of baking spice sets the stage in this easy-to-like wine. The medium-weight body offers a superb balance of richness and freshness, with ripe, spicy fruit tones that harmonize with bright, lingering acidity, resulting in a fine overall texture. Drink now2021.

Pommard and Wdenswil are the clones, and the wine spent 18 months in roughly two-thirds new French oak. It's luscious and loaded with blueberry, cherry and chocolate flavors, gliding into a finish with moderate tannins, a whiff of coffee and a streak of caramel.

Earthy plum and berry aromas open this firm gran reserva from a cold vintage. This wine is chunky on the palate, with scraping tannins. Rooty, meaty berry and cinnamon flavors are slightly stewed, while this is long but hollow on the finish. Drink through 2026.

While sunny tangerine and yellow peach flavors abound, deeply embedded layers of smoke, struck flint, fennel and pollen lend savory complexities to this kabinett. It's luscious yet spry, with racy streaks of acidity and a lingering, spicy finish. Drinks well already but should improve through 2025.

The debut of Napa native winemaker and entrepreneur Josh Phelps' own label, this is a blend of 73% Cabernet Sauvignon, 8% Malbec, 7% Cabernet Franc, 6% Merlot and 6% Petit Verdot. It delivers tremendous value for the quality, a mix of chocolate-covered cherry, blueberry and vanilla cola wrapped in smooth, seductive layers of robust elegance. Tobacco, pencil shavings and cigar box add alluring seasoning.

Spicy bramble berry aromas are lifted and pure on the nose of this wine, riding over an earthy core of pressed violets and Mediterranean scrub. There's energy to the moderately full palate, with vibrant acidity cutting through juicy red and black berry flavors. Orange rind and tense granite tones provide further intrigue, with soft, integrated tannins giving structure.

This unique blend of 44% Mourvdre, 33% Zinfandel, 20% Grenache and 3% Counoise starts with dried alpine strawberry, pomegranate, wild chaparral spice, crushed pepper and bay leaf on the elegantly woven nose. A strong sagebrush character ensues on the palate, giving nuance to the saucy plum fruit. The acidity and tannins are well primed and ready to drink.

This blend of 42% Carignan, 29% Cinsault and 29% Grenache is full and concentrated, but not overly done. There's a mentholated and slightly liquorous edge to the ripe black plum, cherry and boysenberry fruit, as well as subtle hints of cocoa powder and pressed violets. Medium weight, the texture is like crushed velvet, with structure and finesse to frame the fruity palate. Final notes of charred sweet spice, black pepper and tea grace the lingering finish. Drink now2022.

Toasty lemon peel and spiced orange rind set up a spicy, citrusy welcome on the nose of this wine. At the core are rich notes of lemon custard, pear flesh and melon, all cut by superb acidity and a fresh, steely minerality. It's driven and focused, with clear precision on the palate and a medium-length finish that evolves from fruit flesh to rind and finally a kiss of earthy spice. Drink now2022.

This wine offers aromas of scorched earth, pipe tobacco, mature black-skinned berry and a hint of leather. The rounded, generous palate doles out juicy black cherry, fleshy raspberry, star anise and a hint of cinnamon alongside chewy tannins. Drink through 2022.

A tiny production of lightly oaked wine from primarily Pommard clones, this wine presents as thick and tannic at first, with a touch of reduction. Its intensity and density mellow in the glass to show a greater sense of elegance and fresh acid-driven flavor, built around pomegranate, strawberry and wild lavender.

White flower, yellow orchard fruit and brioche aromas carry through to the elegantly sparkling palate together with yellow apple, white peach and tangerine zest. Tangy acidity lifts the rich flavors while a creamy mousse gives it a silky texture.

Aromas of black plum and coffee bean set the scene for flavors of blackberry and black cherry that are quickly joined by stronger flavors of smoked meat and espresso bean. Rich tannins coat the mouth, receding into a smoke-filled finish.

Drenched with melted butter and vanilla flavors, but not blatantly oaky, this full-bodied Chardonnay is so lush that it's almost sweet. It seems to expand on the palate, brimming with delicious Fuji apple and Bosc pear notes that don't quit but last through a lingering finish.

Clear varietal character comes out in this wine, with solid black-cherry fruit and highlights of licorice, espresso, vanilla and black tea. The concentration and balance are impressive, and it lingers with a late show of power. This winery does far better with its red wines than its whites.

A solid effort, this brings plum and blueberry, black cherry and baking spices together in a substantial, even muscular style. Earthy tannins form a strong base, and the overall sturdy character, along with the balance and texture, suggest that this will age nicely over the next decade. Drink now through the late 2020s.

Fresh pressed boysenberry, fennel bulb, white pepper dust and Italian herbs show on the nose of this blend of 40% Cabernet Sauvignon, 35% Syrah and 25% Zinfandel. The leathery tannins grab hold of the palate rather quickly, and still need some time to smooth out, yet provide solid structure from which to hang the black plum and mulberry flavors.

The particulars of this estate-grown blend change annually, but it remains smooth and deeply-fruited, a tasty riot of loganberries, marionberries, blackberries and more. Juicy and fresh, with spot-on tannins, it's flat-out delicious and a stunning value.
The top selection of the 2015 vintage, this estate-grown wine has a lovely mix of strawberries, raspberries and plums. Tangy citrus brightens the acids, and a dusting of cocoa amplifies the finish.
The Nicholas reserve sees 40% new French oak yet isn't at all oaky. Rather, it's fruit-powered, smooth and supple. Blue plum and black cherry come with pastry spices and a dash of sassafras.

Hints of vanilla and woodsmoke combine with subtle red cherry on the nose. The body is gentle, translucent and light, handled with a welcome, light touch. This is an earthy, elegant Pinot which shows a lovely warmth but vivid freshness in cherry fruit at its core.

Intriguing aromas of boysenberry syrup, plum, sweet herb and barrel spice lead to exquisitely balanced, somewhat elegantly styled fruit and savory flavors. It's a very understated, very pretty expression of this warm vintage and growing region.

Earthy plum and cherry aromas are typical of Rioja gran reserva. A full, grabby palate is not silky-smooth, while this wine tastes of fig and chocolaty berry fruits that are on the cusp of cooked. It loses steam on a finish with raisiny notes. Drink through 2022.

Heady aromas suggesting grilled herb, sea breeze, wild berry and eucalyptus lead the nose. Made with Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah and Petit Verdot, the tightly knit palate offers dried black cherry, red currant, white pepper and star anise framed in taut, fine-grained tannins.

Under the same management as Chteau la Dominique in Saint-milion, this wine, dominated by ripe Merlot, is full, open and developing quickly. There's a rich edge to the black fruits as well as some powerful tannins that will need to soften. It is an open, generous wine, full of fruit and richly structured. Drink from 2023.

Dating to before the French Revolution, this estate produces some rich, generous wines. This vintage is in that mold, with its rounded black fruits, crisp acidity and solid core of dry tannins. The structure will allow the wine to age, giving great potential. Drink from 2024.

Under the same ownership as Chteau Cissac, this ancient estate, dating to the 6th century, is producing some fine wines. This rich vintage is well structured, dense and with classic black-currant Cabernet Sauvignon flavors. Ripe Merlot adds its rich jamminess to a wine that is still young. Drink from 2024.

With over 80% Cabernet Sauvignon in the this Kopp family blend, this wine is packed with black currants, ripe tannins and a smoky backdrop from the wood aging. It is structured, dry and juicy at the same time. With this firm core, the wine will need aging, so drink from 2024.

Aged for a year in wood, this wine has a toasty character. At the same time, it also has good fruit, plenty of black-currant flavors and acidity. A well-wrought wine, it melds the tannins and fruit into a balanced whole. Drink from 2024.

Owned by the Pags family, this rich wine is dense and structured. It has layers of dusty tannins and full black-currant fruit from the 60% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. Drink this firm wine with great fruit from 2023.

This ripe, impressively textured wine is going to be rich and generous. Not just yet, because the tannins need to soften and integrate. That said, the blackberry fruits are juicy, with balanced acidity and a full texture. Drink this wine from 2022.

Just to the north of Saint-Estphe, this 44-acre estate regularly produces good, structured wines. In this vintage, the structure is right there along with layers of rich blackberry fruits. This is a solid, dense wine, ripe and ready to age well. Drink from 2023.

Rich black cherry, clove, gingerbread and nose-tickling Christmas spices show on the rich nose of this appellation blend. It's also rich on the tip of the sip, with dried black cherry and more clove, but there is a black plum skin tang that holds it in check.

Bright and focused raspberry fruit comes buttressed by a firm streak of Mediterranean herbs. Hints of iron thread through the finish. This is a taut substantial wine that will require some breathing time to show its best.

This lush and lovely wine, a New World version of Muscadet, is tangy and loaded with bright apple and pear flavors. Amplified by hints of citrus rind, it opens up even further once it warms in the glass, showing unexpected and quite impressive depth and detail.

A very gentle touch of summer blossom is joined by fresh, bright lemon on the nose. The palate has a creamy element that enriches the bright lemon palate without adding heaviness. This is sprightly and light, but also creamy and mellow. A dry, fresh and totally convincing wine with a clean, long finish.
Aromas of baking spice, blackberry and cherry draw you into the glass. The palate is chock full of cherry and dark-chocolate flavors, with the tannins giving a light squeeze.

The aromas pop, with notes of clarified butter, pineapple, candlewax, corn silk, apricot and mango. The palate is full of stone and tropical fruit flavors that bring a big yum factor. Aromas and flavors are ripe, like the vintage this wine comes from.

This is a velvety thick, delightfully lush and seductive wine, savory in pine forest and clove, with layered highlights of orange peel, cinnamon and black tea. Dark cherry cobbler provides rich flavor that remains balanced in the glass.

Plump with ripe black-plum and cherry flavors, this single-vineyard wine offers a greater density of fruit than the producer's entry-level Pinot Noir. Still, it shares a ghostly elegance marked by faded whiffs of dried violet and lavender, dusty spice-box and earth notes. Vibrant acidity lends finesse to the palate along with a meandering finish of fine grained, bitter tannins.

This wine features a bouquet of raspberry, black cherry and violet. It is smooth on the palate, with flavors of blackberry, cherry, pomegranate, vanilla and almond blossom. Cool minty notes come into play towards the finish, followed by lingering brightness.

Excellent concentration and pinpoint focus are hallmarks at this property. Tart cranberry and raspberry fruit comes with a streak of dark chocolate and polished tannins. The focus and detail are exceptional.
Shades of subtle oak, fig and lemongrass are framed by tightly wound acidity on the palate. Light in feel, this is a bright, exotic Chardonnay with loads of energy.

A gentle mix of red berry, red plum and cherry carries some of the lightly earthy tones of the AVA. Soft and accessible, there's a hint of Dr. Pepper running through the flavors also. It's drinking right about at its prime and should hold through the early 2020s.

Here is a tasty chewy full-flavored effort, loaded with black-cherry fruit. There are notes of cola and brown sugar, along with a finishing hint of coffee. It was aged for 11 months in just 7% new French oak.

This showcases a nice balance between ripe-fruit notes, toasty warmth and ample acidity. Aromas of lemon custard, creamed pear and baked apple set the stage, framed by scents of toasted walnuts and clover honey. The palate offers a bit more restraint and verve, with notes of orange and lime peel that refresh the sip. Drink now2023.
Young, big and pleasantly chunky, this flavorful wine is loaded with green apple, tart melon and enough acidity to conjure up gooseberries. Enjoy it now for its exceptional fruit and freshness.

Fruity aromas of red berry unite with dark culinary spice and fragrant blue flower. On the soft juicy palate, supple tannins lithely support fleshy Marasca cherry, crushed blackberry and ground pepper. Drink through 2021.

This opens with aromas of dark-skinned berry, violet and leather. The savory balanced palate doles out raspberry jam, black cherry, tobacco and black pepper alongside fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. Enjoy through 2027.

Savory, mossy plum and currant aromas are mature and woodsy. High acidity is the lifeblood of this gran reserva that tastes of reedy, leafy currant and herbs. The finish is dry, with a note of tobacco. Drink through 2026.

Earthy black-fruit aromas open this fully built crianza. A tannic palate with cutting lemony acidity gives this a ton of energy. Berry and cassis flavors are equaled by oaky vanilla and caf-mocha notes, while a coconut flavor and heat come up on the finish. Drink through 2026.

It's no surprise that this appropriately named blend of 76% Petite Sirah, 20% Tannat and 4% Petit Verdot is dense and dark, starting with aromas of crushed asphalt, elderberry jam, white pepper and baked goods. The palate is equally unctuous, showing concentrated purple flowers, tar, more elderberry and a judicious hint of wild mints.

This wine exhibits superb interplay between just-ripe fruit character and earthy, spicy tones. Notes of tree bark, fresh turned soil, cocoa nib and olive mingle harmoniously with fruity tones of black cherry and plum. A sanguine accent dances across the silky, medium-bodied palate, while a peppery kick unfolds on the lingering close. Drink now2023.

Dirk Niepoort's venture into the Bairrada region at Quinta de Baixo blossoms in this wine. Rich fruit gives the wine both firm tannins and a ripe, crisply textured character. It is balanced with acidity, full of juicy fruit and perfumed with mint. Drink this wine from 2019.

Toast, underbrush, tobacco leaf and cassis aromas lead the nose. Reflecting the cool wet vintage, the palate is austere and lighter bodied than usual but still elegant, offering raw cherry, pomegranate, licorice and ground pepper alongside tight close-grained tannins. Give the tannins several more years to unwind.

Two clones and two vineyards combine here, with 18 months in French oak pulling it all together. It's a tasty mix of fruit, spice and barrel, with pomegranate and red-plum flavors at the core. Baking spices suggest buttered cinnamon toast, with a touch of cocoa powder adding the coup de grce.

This vineyard emphasizes rather steely mineral-driven flavors. The fruit is ripened in an austere mode, firm and sculpted, with flavors of wild mountain berry. A whiff of tobacco follows through, with a similar vein in the finish. It's a dense wine that will reward aggressive decanting.

Savory tones of smoke and crushed earth permeate from nose to finish, suggesting a complex auslese that's more mineral than fruit. Still, vibrant lemon-lime acidity and silken streaks of honey penetrate the midpalate and extend through a long, invigorating finish. It drinks well now but should show even better from 2021.

Formerly the property of one of Napoleon's generals, this estate is now performing impressively after renovations. This wine is richly structured and packed with black fruits. Dark tannins vie with black currants and ripe spice in this wine that will age well. Drink from 2024.

This is a fruity wine with lovely acidity and a firm background of tannins. The black-currant and berry flavors are up front, giving delicious acidity and a crisp aftertaste. Drink this fruity wine from 2023.

Earthy berry aromas are sweetened by notes of raisin, creamy oak and root beer. This gran reserva is more easygoing, plump and chunky than what you'd expect from a great vintage like 2010, with flavors of tobacco, woodspice, vanilla, cherry and berry fruit. Cocoa is a prime flavor on the finish. Drink now through 2023.

Veteran vintners Bruno D'Alfonso and Kris Curran manage to tease out uniquely fresh aromas and flavors from this Syrah, starting with the nose, which is full of cola, root beer, beet juice and Mission fig scents. The medium-bodied palate shows lots of flowery purple fruit and candied purple-fruit flavors, with a hint of licorice spice.

An abundance of spicy smoky oak aromas meets equally abundant flavors of dark chocolate, cocoa and raspberry in this full-bodied and heavily tannic wine. The color is about as dark as it gets, the mouthfeel is massive and yet the flavors are so big they balance out the huge structure. That it was aged for 30 months in 80% new French barrels explains the alluring spiciness.

From one of the state's top Syrah vineyards, this offers aromas of dried and fresh herb, violet and black cherry that lead to full-bodied, extremely pure dark-fruit flavors. Aged in three- to five-year old-oak, it has a purity and mouthfeel that add to the appeal. It should show well on the dinner table.

Plump yellow cherry, peach and apricot abound in this juicy, deeply concentrated kabinett. It's an intensely sun-kissed, almost tropical wine but light as a feather on the palate and deftly balanced by spine tingling acidity.

While smoky and earthen on the nose, the palate of this light-footed auslese is plush, almost fleshy, with unctuous yellow-peach, mango and tangerine flavors. Racy lime acidity revitalizes the midpalate, leading to a long, clean finish. Drink now through 2025.

This is an expressive yet well-balanced wine, with wonderful interplay between the dense black-fruit characteristics. Brambly boysenberry, blackberry and cherry meld seamlessly with notes of sweet spice, purple violets, game and white pepper. The palate's slightly creamy texture is countered by framing tannins that lend grip and structure through the finish. Drink now2023.

Named after the latin name of the Ionian sea (Jonio), this single-variety Negroamaro has a dense, permeating nose of jammy red and black berries, tobacco leaf, crushed cocoa nibs and graphite. Firmly medium in weight, the palate shows a vibrant force of tart berries and game that turns richer and riper come the midpalate, translating as a lingering red cherry note on the finish. Sandy tannins offer plenty of grip, yet the bright acidity and pervasive fruit tones keep everything in check.

Made primarily with Vermentino, this opens with delicate scents of white spring flower, yellow stone fruit, citrus and a whiff of honey. Mirroring the nose, the fresh enveloping palate doles out dried apricot, juicy nectarine drop and a honeyed mineral note alongside tangy acidity. Hold for even more complexity. Drink through 2021.
Plum, sweet cinnamon and cardamom are gracefully threaded through the core of brambly berry fruit. Aged for 11 months in barrel, it finishes with a streak of vanilla.

Firm tannins are well integrated with the black-currant fruits in this dense, ripe and very fruity wine. It is juicy and perfumed with a generous texture and good freshness. The Merlot sings in this wine, bright and structured. Drink from 2021.

There's strong woody spice on the nose of this appellation blend with sandalwood and lacquer aromas meeting with stewed plums, mulberries and candied flowers. Those same fruit flavors show on the sip, alongside a pine-needle lift. It is a quite rich expression.

This 100% varietal wine is a blend of fruit from top sites Klipsun (60%) and Dioynsus. Baking spice, herb, cocoa, tobacco, espresso and cherry aromas lead to suave, silky cherry and cocoa flavors. Like the vintage it came from, it holds nothing back. The oak (65% new French) is a bit up front at present but should integrate with additional time in bottle. Best after 2020.

The vanilla and wood scent of new oak is evident on the nose. On the palate this is more integrated, the fine wood notes intertwining with the ripe cherry fruit. The tannin structure is fine and firm, supported by vivid freshness. This is lovely now but will mellow over the coming years. Drink 20182025.

Plump aromas of poached pear, Meyer lemon pith, honeysuckle and an underlying slate-like minerality hit the nose on this bottling. There's a roundness to the palate of Asian pear, but the sip is all about grippy texture and sizzling citrus energy that carries deep into the finish.

This is a well-made version of the variety, 100% in this case. Earthy tobacco, clove and dusty oak ride along seamless tannin structure and plenty of length and breadth. Balanced within a full-bodied sense of powerful weight and presence, it softens on the finish to reveal lighter touches of pencil shavings and clove.

A rich and toasty wine, this opens with abundant aromas of baked apple, honey-roasted nuts, lemon oil and ginger-clove orange peel. The medium-weight palate is round and mouthfilling, but with superb acidity to balance, lifting the ripe fruit flavors and lending a saline lift to the finish. Drink this well-balanced beauty now2024.

This opens with aromas of woodland berry, alpine herb, menthol and whiffs of oak-driven spice. The elegant precise palate delivers sour cherry, cranberry, star anise and a hint of salty mineral set against a backbone of fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. It's still youthfully austere and needs time to fully develop. Drink 20212031.

This dark garnet colored wine has aromas of black cherry and a faint touch of green bell pepper. Sleek tannins coat the palate as flavors of black cherry, raspberry, smoke, black pepper and eucalyptus cavort towards a lasting, smoky finish.

Brioche, toasted nut, acacia honey and dried apricot aromas follow through to the dry vibrant palate along with yellow apple, nectarine and hint of exotic spice. Bright acidity and a refined perlage provide the backbone while a bitter-almond note marks the close.

Orange blossoms and crushed mineral tones perfume this delicately off-dry Riesling. Light bodied and spry, the palate is taut, with deeply penetrating high-toned acidity and crunchy peach, tangerine and lemon flavors. Finishes long on notes of lemon zest, fennel and crushed earth.

Perfumed lavender opens the way to a softly layered, structured wine that's medium bodied and restrained in tone. Cassis and red cherry are matched by bright, lingering acidity that provides a welcome succulence throughout.

A typical yet classy example of Margaret River, this wine dishes up notes of dark cherry, currant, tobacco, mocha, eucalyptus and dried green herbs. The medium-bodied palate has soft but chewy tannins, with some apparent oak components and a dark-cherry and green-tinged finish. It's elegant and soft enough to drink now but will age well through 2028.

Quite pronounced in tropical fruit and floral aromas, this opens with attractive scents of pressed buttercup, honeysuckle and lime lead that frame the guava, pineapple rind and red apple fruit core. Those ripe-fruit tones carry through to the medium-weight palate, with bright, orange-laced acidity to lift. A final note of delicate sweet spice on the way back of the close. Drink now2022.

This red embraces its main variety's ancestral home, blending in 12% Syrah, 10% Grenache and a pinch of other Rhne reds. Peppery and tannic, it shines in blueberry, cedar, dried herb and cinnamon, begging for more time in the bottle. Enjoy best 2019 through 2029.

Lemon butter and plump pineapple aromas are cut by crushed gravel and an edgy citrus peel character on the nose of this blend of 55% Roussanne, 28% Grenache Blanc and 17% Picpoul Blanc. The Roussanne provides a rich midpalate, full of fleshy but not overripe baked apple flavors, dusted with baking spice and leveled by buoyant acidity.

Hits of exotic spice and salt accent rich, ripe streaks of peach, yellow cherry and tangerine in this decadent sptlese. Despite its lavish ripeness, it's a sprightly, revitalizing wine, with zesty acidity and a cool, mineral finish. Drink now through 2025.

This small-production wine (just 22 cases) is a blend of 53% Malbec, 42% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Merlot that spent 32 months in 35% new French oak. Aromas of caramel, chocolate cake and black cherry are cut by a minty lift. The palate shows similar weight and richness, with flavors of baked strawberry, cinnamon and caramel sauce. It's soft on the palate and chalky in texture, boasting a butterscotch finish.

Red and purple flowers meet with crushed slate, turned soil and plump cherry fruits on the nose of this bottling. It's a solid, down-the-middle expression of the grape, with red and black plums, clove and tarragon lifts to the palate.

Delicate hints of clay and crushed earth lend savory complexity to this otherwise wildly fruity sptlese. It's unctuously ripe offering loads of summery peach and nectarine flavors but balanced by a spine tingling lemon-lime finish. Drink now through 2025.

Rounded and ripe aromas of baked strawberry, red plum, dried rose petal and anise show on the nose of this bottling by theater tech-turned-winemaker Sabrine Rodems. The complex texture is still a bit stiff and sticky on the palate, and the flavors are strong and straightforward, with cranberry and sandalwood. It's clean and refreshing overall, but it could use more time.

This Chenin Blanc-based wine, with 14% Smillon, is complex, layered and evolving, expressing different waves of flavor and texture with each sip. Initial scents of lanolin and waxy pink apple transition into earthy notes of dried yellow flowers and grass, while the medium-weight palate evokes tart, refreshing flavors of lime leaf, lemon peel and white melon rind. It's zippy and bright in feel, with lively, briny acidity, and the finish shows fantastic evolution that ends on a earthy, forest-foliage note. Drink now2025.

Violets and black cherries perfume this lavish, intensely fruity Pinot Noir. Concentrated in lush black plum and berry flavors, it's a full-bodied and fleshy wine but fringed by soft tannins and a long granite finish. Drink now through 2030.

A blend of three vineyards from across the Central Coast, this bottling shows lively aromas of violet and lavender along with black-plum skins and lamb meat. The palate has rosewater, candied rose petals, red plum and a slight maraschino cherry quality.

Wild berry, dark culinary spice, purple flower and a whiff of aromatic herb are some of the aromas you'll find on this vibrant red. The elegant medium-bodied palate shows pomegranate, tart cherry, clove and star anise alongside bright acidity and polished tannins. Drink over the next several years.

Orchard fruit, bread crust and a whiff of wild herb lead the nose. On the racy linear palate, firm acidity and a lively perlage underscore yellow apple, Bartlett pear and lemon zest before the crisp dry finish.

Inviting aromas of black-skinned berry, underbrush and a whiff of ginger lead the nose on this savory blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot. The structured, juicy palate offers ripe black currant, licorice and black pepper alongside polished tannins. Enjoy through 2024.
