Gamy, savory plum and berry aromas recall asphalt, tree bark and wildness. This blend offering Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Monastrell is clampy and tannic. Oaky savory berry flavors finish choppy, with a hint of clove.
Crisp, cool Sria gives this wine a bright and refreshing character. Minerality and apple and citrus flavors are delicious and very direct. Lightly textured and fruity, the wine is ready to drink.

This is a chunky wine with fruit leaning to the green (but still ripe) side of flavors. Apple, lime and grapefruit are in play, with a touch of bitter skin flavors also. It's balanced and persistent, with the structure to accompany poultry seasoned with fresh herbs.

This single-variety Malvasia Nera is dense in purple-fruit aromas, with accents of violets, anise and menthol. The fruity, soft palate offers plenty of ripe dark-fruit flavors, balanced by fresh acidity and black plum-skin tannins.

Spicy, dense aromas of tobacco leaf, briar berries and tilled earth make for an engaging nose. The palate is a bit more primary in ripe dark fruit flavors, yet solidly balanced by fresh acidity and savory, medium-grained tannins.

This remains stiffly compact, showing blue and purple fruits with a seam of chocolate mint. It was barrel aged entirely in neutral oak, and the tannins are smooth and polished. A bit of aeration would help to open it up.

This wine is surprisingly dense and dark in aromatic character, with brooding notes of black cherry, cassis and blackberry that set the stage for an equally concentrated palate. The astringent tannins lend good grip, framing the plush, ripe fruit. Final hints of tree bark, chicory and char spice up the close.

Syrah makes up half of this wine, with the rest equal parts Grenache and Mourvdre. Aromas of marionberry, herb, smoked meat and spice lead to a well-balanced palate that glides on the baking-spice-filled finish. The oak plays a bit prominently at times but overall it works.

This is an unctuous tale on Chardonnay, very much in line with the classic Californian style. Aromas of baked Asian pear, oak, butterscotch and caramel show on the nose, leading into a broad, buttery and viscous palate of lemon balm and coconut cream.
Inviting aromas of cherry cordial, dried herb and chalk lead to generous, well-fashioned fruit flavors. Light tannins provide support.

The barrel influence is primarily aromatical with notes of nougat, vanilla and sweet spices out in front of cherry and red apple. The fruit vies with the oak for attention on the palate as well, although the latter shows a pleasing supple feel as well as excellent concentration. There's impressive fruit here, but the oak unfortunately gets in the way of it.

There's a strong flavor of grilled fruits, especially peaches, and the red fruits are tangy and concentrated, like raspberry compote. A charred smoky streak runs through the tannins. All in all, though a bit heavy handed, this brings lots of potent flavors. Drink now through 2020.

Principally Riesling, with 8% Muscat blended in, this touches the borders of off dry, but has enough acid to keep it food-friendly. Ripe lemon and pink grapefruit, peaches and apples come through most pleasantly. It's well made and well balanced.
Toast, underbrush, licorice and charred-earth aromas carry over to the palate along with prune, blackberry extract, coconut and a confectionary note. Dusty tannins give it a rather grainy finish.

A mix of 60% Chardonnay, 15% Moscatello Selvatico, 15% Minutolo and 10% Passulara, this unusual white blend is perfumed in grapefruit, tangerine zest, papaya and lemon balm aromas. Medium in weight, with a pleasing roundness, rich melon and exuberant floral flavors are lifted by clementine acidity and a light mineral dusting.

The 1,500-foot elevation of the vineyards close to mountains gives this wine its crisp, bright character, allowing the acidity, the citrus and the zingy texture to shine. The wine is all tight fruit balanced by a creamy texture. Drink now.
Notes of wet stone, Pilsner and yeast meet with fresher elements of lemon, white pepper and honeydew in this Chardonnay. Sprightly acidity lends itself well to the long, energetic finish.

Though well made and easy drinking, this has an overall lightness that seems almost too thin. Flavors conjure up snippets of lemon rind, pineapple and honeydew melonfruity but lacking concentration. It's balanced with mineral acidity, and should be enjoyed while at its most fresh.

Vibrant aromas of blue fruit, dried herb and potpourri lead to light, soft, tart fruit and barrel flavors. Blue-fruit flavors linger on the finish. It seems compact right now but good things are going on.

This Chardonnay opens with alluring aromas of vanilla, lemon curd, dried apricot and pie crust. Lemon-lime acidity pulls together flavors of ripe peach and vanilla, with a hint of wood spice. Lime peel and spice linger on the fruity finish.
Confident saline and citrus aromas are a good entry to this clean, fairly lean brut. Lime and tangerine flavors are racy and not too sweet, while this is fresh and well made on the finish.

There's a surprising intensity to the aromas of fresh blackberries, turned earth and violets. The palate mirrors the nose in a package of grippy tannins and crisp acidity. While enjoyably straightforward in nature, the concentration is rather light, so enjoy for its immediate appeal.

The best of Airlie's current white wine releases, this is bright and fruity, with cucumber and green apple in the mix. The mouthfeel is lively, and the flavors show a bit of residual sugar, resulting in an impression not entirely unlike vinous Gatorade.
As the low alcohol suggests, this is a light and just barely ripe ros, a salmon shade with a blush of cherry red. Tart flavors of strawberry and rhubarb are dusted with a dash of Thai spices.

A gold color and resiny aromas of nutty oak and oxidized white fruits capture the essence of aged white Rioja. A round, oily palate is dominated by oak, tasting of spiced apple, almond skins and woodspice. Flavors of peanut, dried apricot and stone-fruit pits provide for a good finish.

Intense aromas of smoke, crushed earth and pollen permeate through sweet-tart lemon and lime flavors. It's savory yet invigorating, offering penetrating streaks of acidity that linger through a long finish.

This blend of three vineyards, including one in Santa Barbara County, offers intriguing sweet-and-sour aromas of dried sage, bay leaf, forest floor and olive tapenade. Dried berry fruit shows on the sip alongside chaparral, and it tastes much older than its young age.

Produced by Niepoort for the importer, this dense wine is rich in prunes and ripe black plums. Poised between sweet and dry, it has tannins as well as generous fruitiness and a liquorous, smooth aftertaste.

This is a solid-quality wine that tastes good and fruity, has a nice blend of acidity and richness and a rather full body that coats the palate. It's enjoyable to drink and seems to have everything in good proportions.

Aromas of cedar, dark-skinned fruit and baking spice lead the nose on this 70% Sangiovese and 30% Merlot blend. The firm palate offers black plum, clove and toast with tight assertive tannins. Drink 20192023.
Earthy, buttery aromas join good fruity ones in this medium-bodied and mineral-tinged wine. It has firm acidity and a slightly astringent texture that give it a lean, bracing quality.

This is the first vintage of this estate under the ownership of the Bouey family, which has a Bordeaux negociant business. The wine is dry, anchored in tannins at this stage although the juicy black fruits will come through over time. Wait for this wine until 2022.

This is one of the most northerly of the Mdoc estates, only six miles from the ocean. That gives a cool feel to the wine, emphasizing fruit rather than structure. Plenty of juicy acidity gives the wine a lift. Drink from 2022.

This northern Mdoc estate has produced a wine that has both structure and fruit. The tannins are certainly present, giving a burnt character from the wood aging. However, black currant flavors are there as well. Put the two together as they integrate, and the wine will be juicy and attractive. Drink from 2020.
Pure, rich ripe Touriga Nacional gives a perfumed wine, rich in tannins and with a stylish character from the bright red fruits. The wine is juicy, balanced, and certain to age well. Drink from 2019.

Dense soil aromas, leather, olive, charred beef, roasted wood and crushed asphalt make for a very dry and savory nose on this bottling. There's a tarry character to the palate that shadows the black fruit, allowing the black olive and black pepper to take the lead.
Aromas seem unsettled, with notes of dust, herb and cherry. The flavors are plush and ripe, delivering plenty of enjoyment.

This full, fleshy and affordable wine gets treated to small-lot ferments in neutral oak barrels. The fruit seems young and freshGamay-like, with bright and spicy berry flavors. Drink this over the next couple of years while that freshness remains in full force.

Breezy and fresh, this light-footed Riesling offers a crush of pristine white grapefruit, apple and nectarine flavors. Delicately sweet in style, it's refreshing and quaffable, with a delicately mineral finish. Drink now.
Made with organically farmed Vermentino grapes, this offers aromas of nectarine, yellow peach and a whiff of Mediterranean scrub. The aromas carry over to the crisp palate alongside firm acidity.

This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Syrah opens with aromas of blackberry, ginger and sandalwood. The medium-bodied palate has black-currant jam, cedar and vanilla alongside smooth tannins.

Though it's a bit astringent, the medium-bodied fruit is clean and juicy, with raspberry and cherry flavors. It seems to spread out across the palate, then winds down gracefully as it flattens into a drying astringent finish.

This tasty little Pinot introduces a well-made lineup from this producer. The pretty cherry fruit might seem delicate, but it's nonetheless persuasive. There's no thinness here; it's spot-on varietal and balanced throughout.

This wine exhibits hearty oak and ripe black cherry, cranberry and plum. Blended with 15% Cabernet Sauvignon, its grapes from Coombsville primarily, it's high-strung in supportive acidity and dried herb and tobacco.

This three-acre site, planted to Dijon 114 Pinot, comes up with strong aromatics loaded with baking spices. Those sweet flavors continue around standard medium-ripe berry fruit. The acids finish a bit chalky, and the effect is to dry out the flavors a bit too quickly.

This Cabernet Sauvignon expresses classic aromas and flavors of blackberry leaf, cassis, bramble, black pepper and eucalyptus. There is lovely oak integration that adds notes of clove and cedar. The tannic structure soft which make the finish feel shorter and more fruit forward.

This wine carries pronounced tones of black currant, cassis, bramble, juniper and oak spice. The tannins are full but well integrated and hold up to the weight of this wine. The finish is long and woody.
Notes of very ripe pear dominate the nose. The palate shows more freshness to aid the spicy pear fruit on the midpalate. This is dry and fresh, with a slightly lemony finish. Drink soon.

Vibrant and fun, this opens with zesty aromas of tangerine zest, white wildflower, white cherry and apple. The crisp savory palate offers Gala apple, crushed herb and orange slice. Tangy acidity and a vivacious perlage provide the backdrop.

A blend of Negroamaro and Malvasia Nera, this is red-fruit driven on the nose, with shades of tobacco and rubber. The palate brings a bit more depth in flavors of blackberry, cranberry and leather, yet ultimately this is light in feel from racy acidity and soft, sandy tannins. A slightly bitter dusting of cocoa powder marks the close.
A rather neutral nose offers glimpses of pear and lemon. The palate is also reticent but the pear fruit it shows is fresh, clean and edged with zesty lemon. This is light, dry and fresh.
Tropical fruit and apple aromas are ripe and nice. This wine is fruity but imprecise on the tongue, with bold orange and apple flavors that are juicy, bright and fairly potent. Drink now.

This biodynamic grower and producer makes distinctive wines that require a bit of a palate adjustment for some tasters. Here, there are some funky earthy aromas suggesting compost and barnyard, with flavors following. There is little of the fresh bright fruit flavors one might associate more commonly with Oregon Pinots, but plenty of complexity, length and a light touch of new French oak.

Lovely spicy fruit stands out here and sets this apart from many of the winery's offerings. Concentrated ripe cranberry and plum flavors come with some bite to them, in a good way. The supporting acids have a citrus character, and the clean fruit continues on through a satisfying finish.

Aromas of truffle, crushed herb, celery and wild berry slowly take shape on this. The medium-bodied elegant palate offers red cherry and baking spice notes alongside polished tannins and fresh acidity. Drink through 2019.

The Baga grape, a specialty of the Bairrada region, is traditionally known for its tannins. Here, in the hands of Dirk Niepoort from the Douro, it reveals a rounded, smoother character. The tannins are there although in a supporting role for the black fruits. Crisp, light and juicy, it's ready to drink from 2020
A rather closed nose hints at lemon. The palate has lemon freshness but lacks a little focus. Nonetheless this is fresh and clean, with an appetizing citrus note on the dry finish.

A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and 15% Petit Verdot, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, green olive and a whiff of pencil shaving. The straightforward palate offers black-currant jam, vanilla and a whiff of tobacco alongside round tannins.
Orange and other citrus aromas are a touch creamy and yeasty. A medium-bodied palate is average in feel, while touches of spice and smoke accent mild orange flavors. The finish is simple.

A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc, this has delicate aromas of black plum and baking spice. The dense palate offers prune, espresso and cedar alongside close-grained, rather astringent tannins.

Made entirely with Alicante, this presents aromas suggesting red-skinned berry, white pepper and leather. The easygoing palate offers cranberry, clove and exotic spice alongside smooth tannins. Enjoy soon.

This is Riesling for acid lovers; it screams out for freshly shucked oysters. Bone dry, quite tart, it's right on the edge of sour, with freshly squeezed lemon flavors in abundance. When matched to the right food, it should be a home run.

This Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Merlot, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc blend offers aromas of ripe blackberry and baking spice. The round, soft palate evokes black cherry jam, vanilla and star anise alongside lithe tannins.
This is a soft, juicy and approachable wine, in full grasp of grapey cherry flavors that veer overtly fruity. Medium bodied, it's a nice choice for the table, indoors or out.
This is a soft, juicy and approachable wine, in full grasp of grapey cherry flavors that veer overtly fruity. Medium bodied, it's a nice choice for the table, indoors or out.

This is the winery's first release of Chardonnay, an extreme rarity in this appellation. It comes from the upper Mill Creek area. Delicate, intriguing aromas of cut pear, yellow apple, straw, melon, candle wax and flower lead to full-feeling, lightly creamy banana and pineapple flavors.
Aromas of red plum, ground pepper and a whiff of Mediterranean scrub lead the nose. The savory straightforward palate offers ripe black cherry, fig and licorice alongside firm tannins.

Made with 80% Merlot, 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5% Cabernet Franc and 5% Petit Verdot, this has aromas of ripe black plum, vanilla and a touch of caramel. The dense palate offers black-currant jam, sweet exotic spice and a hint of licorice alongside round tannins.

Cranberry and wild strawberry aromas lead on the nose of this Rosato. Creamy in feel, with a healthy vein of acidity, the palate brings flavors of herbs and watermelon. Soft tannins offer support and help extend the finish.

This is a clonal mixPommard, Wdenswil, Dijon 115 and 777with leathery aromas around candied-fruit flavors. Ginger cookies and intense baking spices dominate, although the leathery character somewhat diminishes the fruit and dampens down the finish.

Sticking closely with the winery's style of forward fruity spicy wines, this has a burst of strawberry and raspberry flavors, backed with juicy acids and baking spices. There's a slightly chalky quality to the finish.
The closed nose has an earthy tint. On the palate this gives way to a pithy note of lemon and a bright, sunny freshness. This is light, fresh and has a superclean, dry finish.

This rich wine is juicy with black-currant fruit and crisp with acidity. The wood aging is just on the right side of too much, but shows in the wine's spicy, dry character. The fresh fruit should come through strongly as the wine matures. Drink from 2023.

This wine comes from a sector of the Entre-deux-Mers that is particularly suited to white wines. It shows in this ripe, lightly mineral-textured wine with apple, citrus and touches of spice. Drink this attractive wine from mid-2018.

There are dramatic views from this estate's vineyards over the Garonne river. The setting gives the chance to produce a fine wine from a privileged location. Rich and juicy, this black-fruit-flavored wine is made from organically grown grapes. Drink this ripe wine from late 2018.

This fruity wine is soft, rounded and already shows a good balance between fruit and tannins. It has a lightly dry core but the red-berry flavors and acidity are up front and give this wine its immediate attraction. Drink from 2019.
This wine comes from the lower vineyards of Chteau Quintus. It is fruity, soft and with balanced black fruits and tannins. Spice and hints of wood aging add extra flavor to the wine. Drink from 2019.

You'll find aromas of yellow stone fruit, bread crust and dried chamomile on this vibrant sparkler. The rich linear palate offers Golden Delicious apple and fennel set against bright acidity and a lively perlage. Bitter walnut signals the close.
This crisp, savory riserva offers light aromas of racy cherry and spiced game. The palate is lithe in feel, with soft tannins wrapped around a tart red-plum flavor. A sanguine note marks the close.
From vines close to Fronsac, this wine comes from Thunevin family vines. It is soft, with attractive black-currant fruit and spicy wood and tannins. It will be ready to drink from mid-2018.

This unusual wine is a bright strawberry shade and offers intense aromatics and flavors of strawberries and ripe cherries. It was fermented on the skins for 14 days, and one-quarter of the total was whole cluster. This is a tasty wine with some citrus snap to the finish.

Dark strawberry, black plum, fennel pollen, tarragon and a hint of caramel show on the nose of the solid second vintage for this memorably labeled bottle. Ripe purple fruit meets with minty spices on the palate, where the richness is cut by directed acidity.

While the nose is ripe and borderline over-the-top in aromas of candied melon, tropical fruit and butter, the palate is unexpectedly fresher, with bright acidity ensconced in a cloak of grainy, textural weight and oak flavors throughout.

This is a very good, moderate rendering of the varietal, blending good blackberry aromas with lightly smoky peppery flavors and medium to full body. It's firmly tannic and will taste great with juicy meats and indulgent cheesy pastas.

This is a pretty concentrated fruit-driven wine that shows focused red and black-cherry flavors and an elegant texture. It sips very smoothly, feels light to medium bodied and has a fresh fruity finish.

Deep red-violet to the eye, this wine has aromas of dark plum, cherry and juniper. It might be a little too restrained for some, with flavors of black cherry and Red Delicious apple, joined by strong notes of eucalyptus, spearmint and anise. Smooth tannins fill the palate right into a cool mint finish.

Invigorating freshness abounds in this dry, medium-bodied Grauburgunder, or Pinot Gris. Pristine lemon, apple and pear flavors are cutting and bright, marked by fresh acidity and a delicately textured mouthfeel. It's an easy going quaffer to enjoy now.

A touch of bruised apple peel fills the nose. The very light palate counters this with bright notions of fresh lemon on a dry, slender palate. This is clean-cut and refreshing, with a lovely lemon finish.

A fresh, clean nose of peeled Conference pear leads onto a palate where a yeasty, rounded tone joins this fruity notion. The palate is light and has the merest hint of savoriness, akin to soy. The finish is yeasty, fresh and dry.

Aromas of ripe red berry and dried Alpine herb follow through to the racy, rather slender palate together with a note of tangy nectarine zest. Vibrant acidity and a lively perlage give it an invigorating finish.

Pristine tones of peach, melon and grapefruit are tinged by earth and crushed stone in this light-bodied dry Riesling. Silken on the palate but boasting cutting lemon-lime acidity, it finishes moderately long and citrusy.
Appetizing, fruity notes of pear drop dominate the nose. The palate shows fresh notes of green and yellow pear on a lemony, fresh body. The finish is dry and superclean. Drink soon.

This easygoing blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Syrah offers aromas of black-skinned berry and cooking spice. The savory palate evokes black currant, clove and white pepper alongside polished tannins.

A luscious bouquet of rose petal and ripe peach on the nose is very convincing and not overblown. The fluid palate shows and edge of pleasant bitterness, countered by an off-dry finish. A lovely aperitif style. Drink soon.
Red cherry notes on the nose hint at ripeness. The palate presents this ripe fruit with simplicity and freshness. There could be more focus but this is juicy and easy.

Made almost entirely with Chardonnay, this opens with aromas of chamomile, yellow stone fruit and a whiff of alpine herb. The lively palate mirrors the nose, offering yellow Bartlett pear, Golden Delicious apple and a hint of pastry dough. A vibrant perlage provide the sparkle.

Aromas suggesting toast, bread crust and whiff of nut meld together. The aromas carry on to the soft palate together with ripe yellow apple and a hint of citrus alongside a light mousse. Bitter walnut is there at the end.

This dramatic, hefty wine has strong oaky, spicy aromas, a rich and honeyed fruit flavor and a texture that's almost thick, making it cling to the sides of the mouth. A touch of sweetness registers on the finish.

Raspberry, violet and new leather aromas lead the nose. The lithe, rather light-bodied palate offers sour cherry, strawberry and a hint of white pepper. It's easygoing, with supple tannins and firm acidity. Enjoy soon.

The delicate nose suggests wild berry and a whiff of culinary spice that carry over to the fresh easygoing palate along with crushed strawberry and white pepper. It's already approachable, with bright acidity and lithe tannins. Drink soon.

Sharp, racy and precise, this particular clone of Pinot Blanc is a rarity anywhere, especially in Oregon. Brisk apple and white-peach fruit comes with a scent of lemon verbena. The finishing tannins have a grainy expression. This would tuck in well with foods usually accompanied by a Loire Valley dry white wine.

This youthful wine pulls from several vineyards across the appellation, offering strong floral aromas of rose, geranium and lavender. Sizable tannins add to a feeling of full-bodied richness, highlighted in black tea, forest and clove.

Aromas of cocoa and maple syrup lead to lush, lightly sweet fruit flavors that have plenty of oak spice to dress them up. This wine tastes very ripe and full bodied, oozing with jammy flavors but it also has enough of a tannic backbone to keep it fresh on the palate.
Crisp tangerine, yellow apple and grapefruit abound in this juicy, delicately sweet Riesling. Easy going yet elegantly balanced, it's a dependable everyday wine with wide appeal.

For this white Pinot Noir, the grapes were quickly pressed and barrel fermented, yielding a wine whose scent, color and flavor are virtually indistinguishable from a young Pino Blanc. It's tart and light, with Meyer lemon, grapefruit and a dot of butter.

Taking its name from the Bordeaux estate owned by this negociant firm, this wine is soft, rich and ready to drink. Blackberries and damsons are laced with acidity and hint of spice from wood aging. Drink now.

Aromas of underbrush, toast, oak and espresso take the forefront. On the approachable palate, close-grained tannins give flexible support to fleshy black cherry, mature plum, coffee and nutmeg. Enjoy soon to capture the remaining freshness and fruit.
This racy wine was pressed whole cluster and aged sur lie in neutral oak for nine months. It's textural and fresh, with flavors of bright apple set against a mineral base.
Ripe blackberry, raisin and cassis aromas border on syrupy. This extracted wine is soupy in feel, with hard tannins. Toasty black-fruit flavors end with burnt oak notes on a saturated finish.

Rich, ripe yellow-apple, pear and grapefruit flavors are delicate in concentration but bright and invigorating in this dry, full-bodied Riesling. It's a vibrantly composed wine, with fresh lemon-lime acidity and a moderately long finish accented by hints of honey and pine nut.

This wine is all Chardonnay. Bright aromas of candied apple, crayon and melon lead to broad, dry fruit flavors that show a touch of bitterness on the finish. It's a pleasing, very cleanly made offering of this variety.

This young, tart and focused wine mixes fresh green herbs, citrus rind, celery and apple components. It's balanced and refreshing, and not notably different, other than slightly cheaper, from the winery's regular bottling of Pinot Gris.
A pretty shade of strawberry pink, this light tasty undemanding wine has strawberry fruit and a touch of white pepper. It was briefly barreled in a mix of stainless and neutral wood.

Tannic and oaky, this is a big, powerful wine with a lot of extraction and density to it. Intense notions of blackberry, black licorice and cedar meet accents of cigar box and pencil, finishing with a robust richness.
Leathery oak dominates in this medium-bodied wine from the mountain appellation. Green, dried herb emphasizes its varietal character, as thick tannins wrap tightly on the palate.

Made with organically grown Chardonnay, this opens with scents of dried stone fruit, acacia honey, chamomile and toast. The aromas follow through to the foaming palate along with candied lemon slice, vanilla and dried apricot alongside a soft mousse. A bitter walnut note marks the close.

Aged in older French oak, with a third whole-cluster, this offers aromas of peeled apple skin, black raspberry and black licorice that lead to palate-coating black-fruit flavors that drop off on the finish. There's no mistaking the warm vintage and warm region it comes from.

This is an unusual red that is light in color and extract and has a good grippy texture to carry the light spice, raspberry and earth flavors. It's nicely balanced and makes a refreshing change of pace from bigger bolder wines.

An aromatic hint of Williams pear plays on the nose. The palate is fresh, clean and vivid, with the pear fruit highlighted by fresh lemon. This is a dry, appetizing and refreshing wine with a slender body.
Subtle hints of yellow pear appear on the nose and lead to a very fruity palate where ripe and juicy pear flavors are boosted by lemon freshness. An easy-drinking, fruity number to drink soon.

Fresh aromas of dark strawberry, red plums, dark chocolate and brown spices show on the nose of this bottling by the legendary Gary Eberle. Crisp and buoyant purple fruits pop on the palate, set against a backdrop of dried lilacs and chalky tannins.

Elton is a new label under the Willamette Valley Vineyards umbrella, though the vineyard has been a favored designate for the past decade. This latest release offers pretty scents of red fruits. Along with those flavors come some bitter stem components, and a whiff of compost. The tannins at this age remain stiff and hard.

The scents are simple and grapey, like grape candy, and the fruit flavors leave a little bit of a hole in the middle. But it fills in quickly with tart strawberry, ample acids, good balance and some stiff, drying tannins.

This wine offers a bouquet of cassis, black plum and licorice. It is smooth and bright on the palate, with flavors of blackberry, pomegranate, vanilla, black pepper and clove that lead into a prolonged fruit-filled finish.

Aromas of black currant, vanilla and violet pave the way for flavors of tart cherry, strawberry, lavender and vanilla. Soft tannins lay a groundwork for bright fruit flavors that work their way across the entire palate, leading into a zippy cranberry finish.

Made entirely from Verdeca, a white grape of unknown origins which finds its home in parts of Southern Italy, this wine is delicately floral on the nose in notes of orchard blossoms and sweet dried hay. Pithy green apple and pear take center stage on the palate, which shows some textural weight and vibrant acidity.

Aromas lean into the green, with notes of savory garden herb along with dark raspberry and plum. The plum flavors are plump with a lightly scratchy feel to the tannins. There's intrigue but it seems a bit underripe and leafy.

This wine has aromas and flavors of black currant, cassis, fennel, cedar, dark chocolate and forest floor. A welcome barnyard note goves it a hint of rusticity. Decent acidity and velvety tannins make way for a long and woody finish.

This wine blends Cabernet Sauvignon (41%), Cabernet Franc, (28%), Malbec (28%) and Petit Verdot. Smoke, woodspice and cedar aromas are in front of fresh-chopped herb, green pepper and black raspberry, with green-olive notes lurking in the background. The palate is light but juicy, with coffee and cherry flavors that bring a slight sense of astringency. Citric acidity lingers on the finish.

Lightly scented, this has subtle aromas evoking bread crust, wild flower and white stone fruit. On the palate, a lively mousse and fresh acidity offset yellow apple, white peach and a drop of vanilla.

Aromas of ripe strawberry, iris and baking spice lead the nose on this Sangiovese and Alicante blend. Made with organically farmed grapes and without added sulfites, the lively palate doles out red cherry, raspberry jam and a touch of star anise alongside smooth tannins.

Abundant aromas of sweet spicethink cinnamon, nutmeg, allspiceset the stage in this bright, vivacious wine, grounded by notes of red currant and brambly berry. Medium in weight, it offers fine tannins and ample acidity to produce a clean and well-balanced package. Refreshing and so easy to like, drink now2020.

Deep and dark black currant, black plum, prune, dried sage and licorice spice show on the nose of this bottling. The dark dried fruit meets with a minty lift on the palate, proving relatively light in texture but with a strong, somewhat leathery tannic backbone.

With its cherry notes on the nose a little muddled, the palate nonetheless is bright fresh and vivid in a crunchy red-cherry note. This is simple and a little rustic, and would also work as a lightly chilled red.

A rather earthy nose leads onto the fresh, slender and balanced palate. The body has a kind of rustic simplicity, with honest, clean red-cherry fruit. This is easy and fresh and would be ideal for a country-style lunch. Drink soon.

Fully 70% was fermented whole cluster in neutral oak, yielding a wine with bright cranberry and raspberry fruit, juicy acids, and a touch of citrus. The wine avoids excessive stemmy flavors, though a bit of cardboard comes out in the tannins.

Earthy, herbal aromas are a bit murky and reflect a marginal Toro vintage in 2014. A grabby, overextracted palate delivers rock-hard tannins along with gummy flavors of blackberry and blueberry. On the finish, creamy oak takes on a clove-like flavor.

This Merlot brings a lot of aromas and flavors to the table, with tones of baked red and black fruits, nutmeg, clove and balsamic. The tannins are silky and the acidity gives a fresh lift to the feel.

This clean, grassy wine is a pure and pleasing example of varietal character, from a cool-climate region on the northern Oregon border. Lemon and lime rind and grapefruit flesh combine with plenty of lip-tingling acidity. It's not a big wine, but well done, lively and refreshing.
A pinched, rubbery nose hints at volatility. In the mouth, this single-vineyard Menca is wiry, tough and high in tartaric acidity. Savory, saucy plum and berry flavors are salty on a dense finish.

A blend of Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon, this easygoing red has aromas of iris, underbrush band and Mediterranean scrub. The juicy palate delivers Marasca cherry, white pepper and tobacco alongside velvety tannins. It's made to be drunk young so enjoy soon.

Light aromas of cherry, currant and wild herbs carry the nose. Medium in weight, with vibrant acidity countering sandy tannins, crunchy red fruit flavors dominate the palate, yet are restrained by a core of granite and crushed herbs.

Lightly spiced plum aromas are minerally and come with a hint of nutmeg. A flush, bouncy palate is made tougher by rubbery tannins, while spicy plum and blueberry flavors are solid through the back end. The blend offers Grenache, Syrah, Carignan and Cabernet Sauvignon.

This second wine from Quinta de Roriz is ready to drink young, with warm red fruits, soft tannins and juicy acidity. It has structure as well, which will allow it to develop further although it is already delicious and juicy. Drink now or wait until 2019.

The second wine of this great Douro quinta is generous and warm, made to be drunk young. Its rich tannins are equalled by the licorice and ripe black-fruit flavors, smooth structure and good acidity. Drink this wine from late 2018.

The vineyards on the south bank of the Douro face north, giving respite from the sun and producing an elegant style of wine. This is perfumed, fruity and concentrated from the old vines used in the blend. Drink this juicy wine from 2019.
Delicate aromas of baking spice and red plum come together on this. Made entirely with Sangiovese, the palate delivers wild cherry, vanilla and a touch of coconut alongside round tannins.

Dense dark fruit aromas blend with sweet tobacco leaf and anise on the nose. Solidly built with grippy tannins and structured acidity, the palate offers a good concentration of more dark fruit, invigorated by accents of spice and crushed herbs.
Aromas of white flower, beeswax and stone fruit mingle in the glass. The lively palate delivers Bartlett pear, white peach and a touch of ginger alongside fresh acidity.

This is principally Syrah and Merlot, with smaller amounts of other Bordeaux grapes in the mix. It's fruity, fresh and flavorful, with berries and cherries in abundance, along with scents and flavors of smoke and roasted coffee. Call it a fine, gulpable, everyday red.

There's a decent serving of thyme and sagebrush on the nose of this affordable bottling alongside the piquant raspberry and cranberry fruit, with a touch of wet earth in the background. The decently weighted palate shows cranberry and more dried herbs, gaining complexity toward the finish.

Pinot Noir is most often done in a rounder fruitier style in Southern Oregon, and this pins the tail on that characteristic. It's a sturdy, blocky and tasty winea bit tannic, with flavors of black cherry, dried herbs and a lick of espresso.

The price and special designation suggest that this is considered a reserve-level cuve. It seems quite dry, even astringent, with tea-flavored tannins around thin berry fruit. There are hints of mint, wintergreen and chocolate, but the wine doesn't show much depth. Perhaps more bottle age is needed. Two bottles were tasted with comparable notes.

Red cherry and blackberry aromas meld with snippets of baking spice and menthol on the nose. The medium-bodied palate is firm, with structured tannins and crisp acidity, housing juicy berry flavors dotted with red floral tones. Dark plum rounds out the finish.

A blend of 45% Sangiovese, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Petit Verdot, this has delicate aromas of tilled soil and black-skinned berry. The firm palate offers black-currant jam, tobacco and leather alongside closed-grained tannins.
Just a touch of red cherry fruit show on the nose. The palate is light and slender but fresh in feel, with smooth, unobtrusive tannins. This will work well chilled. Drink soon.
The nose offers lemon zest and green pear, two tones that also dominate the light, fresh and dry body which has a pithy textural side. Wonderfully clean and refreshing.

The name identifies this as the winery's Internet-only cuve, and it has much the same character as the Uncarved Block Pinot. Rhubarb and tart strawberry fruit, low alcohol, and an overall balance emulate the lighter style of Pinot.

Gamy, roasted aromas of berry fruits and black olive are less than stellar for a great year like 2010. A stewed, tomatoey palate is drawing in feel, while this Tempranillo from a single estate in Navarra tastes of olive and herbal black fruits. A severely tannic finish is rough and drying.

While the nose on this dry Riesling is lavish, marked by plumes of white blossom and grapefruit zest, the palate is surprisingly restrained. Taut with lemon-lime acidity and a firm, steely backbone, it's a refreshing, spry wine with a moderately long finish.

Broad black cherry aromas meet with soft touches of rosewater, star anise and hibiscus on this rather light bottling. It's very fresh on the palate, with lively pomegranate and berry flavors, though not much of the dark spice or tannic depth expected of the grape.
A touch of pear peel is joined by a fresh lemon aroma on the nose. The palate offers a crisp lemon flavor that brightens the light, dry and easy-drinking body. Drink soon.

The high proportion of Cabernet Sauvignon in this wine brings out both tannins and black-currant fruit. It is firm and structured with layers of acidity and judicious wood-aging flavors. It is likely to age well, and should be ready to drink from 2023.

From vines in the Entre-deux-Mers region, this ripe wine, with its 80% Merlot, is young with firm tannins that need to soften. It has plenty of ripe berry fruits laced with acidity and a dry core of tannins. Drink from 2019.

This offers delicate scents of spring blossom, white stone fruit and a whiff of bread crust. On the vivacious palate, vigorous bubbles and bright acidity frame yellow apple, chopped herb and tangerine zest.

This blend of three local grapes including Albario opens with briny core aromas surrounded by white-fruit notes. The palate hits with a piercing shot of acidity but then turns thicker and more syrupy. Flavors of passion fruit and nectarine are slightly briny and finish plump.
The nose isn't very expressive but the palate offers mature yellow apple, bread crust and citrus alongside a note of honeyed nut. Bright acidity and small bubbles refresh the finish.

In the village of Arcins, in the heart of the Haut-Mdoc, this estate belongs to the Castel family, one of the largest drinks companies in France. This wine, with its generous tannins and ripe blackberry fruit, is easy, generous and likely to age well and quickly. Its tannic structure is fully integrated into the fruitiness. Drink this wine from 2023.

This wine from an 11-acre property is soft and ripe, with plenty of ripe berry fruits. Hints of the 18 months in wood are still there although they are not at all obtrusive. It is an easy wine just touched by spice, and will be ready to drink by 2018.

Vineyards in the Press family's 450-acre estate surround one of the Mdoc's grand chateaus owned by Bordeaux elite over centuries. The wine from 155 planted acres has been spiced with 12 months in wood, giving a toasty character to the juicy black-currant fruit. It is a structured wine, ripe and with good potential. Drink from 2022.

The 39-acre estate is under the same ownership as Chteau les Trois Manoirs. This wine has a generous use of wood that has nicely stopped short of smothering the fruit. While the wine offers plenty of spice and toast, it also offers juicy black currants and acidity. The two elements are coming together and the wine will be ready from 2023.

This estate in the northern vineyards of Bordeaux is planted to a blend of 75% Merlot and the two Cabernets. The wine has structure as well as rich berry fruits. Its tannins mark it out as still young, and this potentially ripe, warm wine should be drunk from 2019.
This spicy, toasty has the potential for bright berry fruits. With acidity as well as a dry structure, it will need aging. This family estate dates back to the 19th century. Drink from 2023.

This light, fruity wine already has a good balance between bright fruits and the wood-aging. With black-currant flavors from the 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and spice from the 12 months wood aging, this wine is still structured and will be best from 2021.

This spicy, juicy wine has black-currant fruitiness from 60% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. It is rich, the wood aging still showing in the toasty edge. With its lively fruit and soft tannins, it will develop well over the medium term. Drink from 2020.

Owned by the Cruse family, one of Bordeaux's major negociants, this estate was their original purchase in Bordeaux. With more than 60% of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend, this wine is packed with black currants and tannins in equal measure. As the wine softens, it will broaden out to emphasize its richness and the warm fruit. Drink from 2023.

A blend holding 55% Cabernet Sauvignon gives plenty of black currant fruit and provides the tannins that form the background to this richly juicy wine. Merlot adds weight to this perfumed, ripe wine that will be ready to drink from 2019.

This wine is generous, with red-berry and red-currant fruitiness. Its tannins still show some firmness although they are integrating well with the fruit and acidity. The wine will be ready to drink by mid-2018.

This estate lies in the far western reaches of the Mdoc close to the forest, giving a cool character to the wine. It obviously been wood-aged, although with room left for the blackberry fruits. Spice and toast flavors are already integrating well, indicating the wine's potential. Drink from 2023.

This structured wine comes from an estate that has records going back to the 13th century. A blend of half-and-half Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, it is firm and tannic at this young stage. The juicy black currant fruit is beginning to develop, bringing with it plenty of crisp acidity. Drink this wine from 2023.
Yellow wildflower, bread crust and chamomile aromas lead the way. The bright foaming palate offers mature yellow apple, orange rind and toasted walnut alongside a fun lively mousse.

A perfumed cloud of rose petals hovers over the glass and beneath that is a touch of earthiness. The palate is surprisingly light and translucent but utterly rose-scented. This is off-dry but finishes a little short.

A rather neutral nose merely hints at some citrus and pear. The palate is more forthcoming with fresh, lively lemon that frames ripe pear. This is juicy, balanced and refreshing, with a dry and fruity finish. Drink soon.
A hint of ripe pear can be discerned on the closed nose. The palate is clean and fresh, with just a little texture. This is an easy, light and dry wine. Enjoy soon.

A blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot, this opens with subtle aromas of black-skinned fruit and underbrush. The firm palate offers black plum, vanilla and cocoa alongside velvety tannins.

Smoke and caramel accent fresh peach, lime and lemon in this sweet-tart kabinett. Light in body and offering a delicate concentration, it's a spry, racy wine with a refreshing finish. Drink now through 2020.

Warmly fruity, this is among the most immediately satisfying of the winery's 2015 Pinots. The berry and cherry flavors carry a light streak of cola, and the tight acids bring a hint of orange juice. Drink now through the early 2020s.

An opulent nose of cabbage, ginger and buttery oak aromas sets up for a palate that is slightly less in your face. It boasts bright acidity but is nevertheless rich and creamy, with a rather large smudge of oak. One for the full-bodied Chard lovers.
Sanguine and bitter in dried herb, this is a thick dense wine, explosive on the palate in juicy black cherry and berry. The finish is a tad harsh in tannin.

All of Helioterra's white wines are immaculate, fresh and framed with crisp, clean acids. This brings tightly-focused flavors of lemon and star fruit, with a sprinkling of caraway through the persistent finish.
A rather neutral nose just hints at freshness. The dry palate is light in feel, with lemon and pear flavors. Overall this is light, off-dry and fruity.

This is a giant of a wine, from the heady, dried-fruit aromas to the flavors soaked in espresso and blackberry syrup to the thick blanket of tannin that wraps it all up. It is very full bodied, feels warm on the palate and leaves an astringent aftertaste.

Johan grows biodynamically farmed grapes, and generally employs such techniques as native yeast and minimal intervention. The wines, as is the case here, tend to be quite low in alcohol. This offers precise flavors of wild berry, accented with allspice and a toasty note from aging in 30% new French oak.

A touch of ripe, red cherry on the nose becomes fully expressed on the palate where it is met with freshness and a conifer tone. The tannins are fine and have the slightest crunch, while the body is light and translucent. This is fresh-faced, honest and clean.
Aged in neutral French oak, this offers intriguing, slightly funky aromas of lemon verbena, green-apple skin and mineral that lead to sleek green- and red-apple flavors backed by racy acidity.

The nose offers intense aromas of orange peel, dried apricot, marmalade and ginger, which carries to the palate along with fresh brioche. It feels creamy and round, with a supple body lending itself to a long, opulent finish.

A tart but aromatic tone of cranberry hovers on the nose and then continues to fill the palate with its tart, appetizing purity. This is a very light, slender wine that offers ample freshness. Drink soon.

Oily, briny, waxy aromas reflect aging and extended time on lees, both of which this wine has been through. Piercing acidity keeps things in balance, while oxidized flavors of corn and salted peach finish strong and slightly bitter. This unique style of Albario is not for everyone.

Aromas of French oak, coconut and baked plum lead the nose. The chewy palate offers raspberry compote, prune, licorice, grilled sage and oak-driven flavors alongside close-grained tannins that leave a tongue-drying finish. You'll also notice the warmth of evident alcohol.

Aromas of moist soil, underbrush, leather and a whiff of eucalyptus take shape on this. Taut and racy, the linear palate offers sour cherry, cranberry, powdered sage and a hint of clove set against vibrant acidity. Tight, rather grainy tannins grip the close.

Grassy and herbaceous, as befits this variety, you'll want to drink this zesty, lively wine while it's at its freshest. Peppery and pungent, it's a good stand-in for an inexpensive Loire Valley Sauv Blanc.

From a property owned by the Bouey family since 1998, this wine is generous, ripe and offers attractive black-currant fruitiness. A blend led by 70% Merlot, it is soft and rounded, with a core of tannins for a bit of aging. Drink from 2021.

Raspberry and pomegranate rise above aromas of white pepper and herbs. Tart cranberry, cedar and vanilla flavors are supported by chalky tannins and a vibrant vein of acidity, finishing on notes of cedar and raspberry.
Perfumed in black cherry and smoky oak, this is a robust, richly ripe red, meaty and brawny in leather and blackberry jam.

This is a value wine, thick in resolved tannin and a density of tart cassis and red and black currant. Dried herb and earthy graphite elements give it varietal character and a brightness against the weight.

This wine is soft, gently textured and ripely fruity. Citrus and apple flavors are lifted by attractive acidity and the wine ready to drink young. The aftertaste has spice and fresh acidity. Drink now.
Named for a parcel of vines in the Sbio vineyard, this wine is perfumed, with aromatic fruit and a zesty texture. Lychees and spice are an important part of this ripe, rounded wine. Drink now.

A saturated, grapy nose with jammy black-fruit aromas is massive but not exact. A blocky, clumsy palate is weighty and a touch stewed. Blackened berry flavors show every bit of this Garnacha-based wine's 15% abv. Notes of fig and chocolate are up front on a heavy finish.

Correctly labeled medium sweet, this low alcohol, fruit-driven wine shows honeysuckle and apricot flavors principally, with a touch of tea. The sugar is offset with ample acidity, maintaining balance and precision, and keeping it in the ballpark to pair with spicy noodle dishes.
Vibrant in aromas of peach, guava and watermelon, these notes carry to a creamy palate that boasts lively acidity to balance. A crushed mineral note offers further levity on the finish.

Light in color, this offers faint aromas that give up almost nothing on first pour, except notes of spice. Still young, the palate is more revealing, showing elegant flavors of raspberry and plum. If the aromas open up it could move up a notch.

Bold and oaky, this full-bodied wine layers wood smoke and butter aromas over baked pear and almond flavors, while hints of new oak run through it. The wine has a mouth-coating texture and tastes warm and spicy on the finish.

This opens with earthy aromas suggesting forest floor, toast, scorched soil and a whiff of game. The palate shows dried black cherry, licorice and powdered sage alongside assertive, grainy tannins that grip the finish.

There's a nice vitality to the nose of this wine, with aromas of lemon and grapefruit rinds alongside ripe tones of pear and apple. The palate shows equalthe same verve in ripe yellow apple flavors struck against a core of tangerine and chalk.

While quiet on the nose, the palate of this juicy, easy drinking sptlese offers loads of ripe tangerine, pineapple and yellow-apple flavors. It's not a complex wine but revitalizing and crisp, with a pleasant hint of astringency lending structure to the finish. Drink now through 2020.
Fresh and floral on the nose, the palate is ripe in red berry flavors, balanced by streaks of granite. Vibrant acidity helps cut through some of the fruit weight. This is simplistic but easy to glug.

Oaky, rubbery aromas are stewy and include notes of clove and cinnamon. A raw, pulling palate is defined by rubbery tannins, while this wine is toasty on top of tart plum and black-currant flavors. A firm, tough finish holds leftover clove, toast and licorice flavors.

Berry and tomato aromas are basic. Typical of Garnacha, this is grabby and chewy on the palate. Flavors of grape skins, black plum and herbal berry fruits are peppery and show a hint of oak-based clove on the finish.
Aromas of toasted bread crust and walnut follow through to the palate along with mature yellow apple skin and a hint of ripe lemon zest. An almond note gives it a bitter finish.
Aromas of creamed corn, spice and baked apple lead to light, pleasant fruit flavors in this straightforward wine.

On first take, this smells oaky, with notes of animal fur and earthy berry fruits. A tight palate shows tomatoey acidity, while a narrow field of flavors includes plum and herbs. Drawing tannins and a minty flavor drive the finish on this basic but positive Rioja.

Pure and fresh notes of freshly cut Conference pear are immediately apparent. The same light, pure, fresh fruit plays on the slender, dry palate. This is an crowd-pleaser of a wine, with lovely balance.
The nose is ripe in aromas of red cherry and berry tones, while the palate is less expressive but presents a juicy, easy freshness on a light body. This will also work chilled. Drink soon.
This wine features a bouquet of white peach and pink grapefruit. It offers a nice balance of fruit and floral flavors, with grapefruit, lemon and jasmine.
This opens with aromas of black-skinned fruit, scorched soil and a hint of game. The firm palate offers black-currant jam, licorice and star anise alongside polished tannins.

A blend of 60% Verdeca, 35% Bianco d'Alessano and 5% Minutolo, this is a snappy, enjoyable wine, with aromas of ripe apple, pear and dried hay that echo on the palate. This shows a waxy feel that is cut by lively acidity on the midpalate. Enjoy with white fish or ceviche.

This wine shows a perfumed nose of lemon, rose water and orange zest. On the palate pithy citrus counters the rose petal softness. There is just the slightest edge of bitterness on the light and resolutely dry palate.

This Cabernet Franc is abundant in aromasvacillating from greener notes of tomato leaf and spearmint to jammy red currant, black plum and violets. The racy acidity is much needed to match the full body. Smooth tannins are well integrated and the finish is long and mouthwatering.

This blend of 45% Cabernet Sauvignon, 35% Shiraz, 11% Merlot and 9% Petit Verdot offers massive black-plum character throughout the nose and mouth, as well as accents of black cherry, cassis, tobacco and woodspice. The medium tannins lend good grip to the palate, but resolve fairly quickly on the close. Notes of black currant leaf and fruit skin ride out the close. Enjoy now and through 2020.

Underripe strawberry and watermelon tones carry the nose and palate, with Mediterranean shrubs in the background. Medium in weight, with a nice balance of acidity, cranberry-skin tannins offer support from start to finish.
Jammy red fruit aromas mix with floral and sweet spice undertones on the nose. Medium in weight, with gentle acidity, the palate bursts with red berry flavors and notes of anise and mint.

A touch shy upon first sniff, this wine opens up more with time to reveal bright aromas of brambly berry, raspberry and cherry, all hit by a decent dusting of cinnamon. The medium-weight palate is straightforward and approachable, with moderate tannins and a mouthwatering finish that leaves the palate refreshed. Drink now.

Mango, cantaloupe and lychee shine on the nose, with subtler hints of grass and peach blossom. This wine is simple and pleasant in its flavors of melon, orange zest and fresh cut grass, ending on a juicy orange note.
Cantaloupe and stone-fruit aromas of this Trepat-based Cava are clean but basic. That also describes the palate, which is good but a bit soft and low on acidity, with some dry orange flavors.

A very reductive take on the grape, this bottling shows lawn cuttings, guava skin, tangy green orange pith on the nose, but also hints of an oily underlying structure. Those aromas come together on the palate, with dried grass and citrus skins proving rather pungent.

Pear and melon aromas are good but basic. Citric acidity is grabbing, while citrus and peach flavors show a hint of green pepper on the backside. On the finish, the fruit character doesn't last long. Drink immediately.

Aromas of charred wood and black pepper meet concentrated flavors of black cherry and blackberry in this full-bodied wine. A hint of sweetness rounds its edges on the palate and gives a jammy note to the finish.

Barrel fermented in 20% new French oak, using indigenous yeasts, this is soft and supple, with a sense of impending oxidation. Bruised apples and pears constitute the fruit, and it should be consumed over the next year or two.

Medicinal, rubbery aromas suggest earthy berry, compost and latex. This Grenache-Carignan-Syrah blend feels baked and chunky but not fully defined. Roasted dark-berry flavors finish heavy and without finesse.

Bright aromas of strawberry, lavender, violets and rooibos are met with cedar and ginger. These carry through to the palate where an element of charred wood is introduced. Ample acidity and a mid-weight body offer a nice mouthfeel and a long, woody finish.

A wealth of oak toneswood, vanilla and cocoaride over a core of cherry jam. The full-bodied palate follows suit, with pillowy tannins and mild acidity giving just enough support. The oak sticks out a bit, but beneath that layer is a rich fruity core.

Solid plum and berry aromas lead to a fruity palate that's bouncy but not deep or layered. Candied berry flavors are satisfactory, but kind of basic. A flush finish closes out this varietal Monastrell.

Made with 60% Sangiovese and 40% Alicante, this opens with aromas of leather, baking spice and a hint of violet. The easygoing palate suggests red cherry, raspberry jam and star anise alongside smooth tannins.

Pleasing aromas of spiced bramble, anise and dark flowers give a good start to this wine. Medium in weight, with a mix of ripe and tart berries, this wine is well-balanced and well-structured but simplistic in its profile.

Attractive in underripe peach and spry lemon aromas, the medium-bodied palate shows juicy melon and stone fruit flavors balanced by lemon-lime acidity. This is a crisp, refreshing Chardonnay, perfect for simple enjoyment.
This wine is straightforward and rich in ripe tropical fruit aromas and flavors. Well-balanced acidity helps maintain freshness on the medium-bodied palate, leading to a crisp, clean finish.
This has subdued aroma suggesting forest floor, leather and a whiff of menthol. The light-bodied palate offers tart sour cherry, cranberry and a note of dark culinary spice alongside racy acidity.

Woody berry aromas are hot but also creamy and show vanilla notes. A bold, grabby palate delivers oaky flavors of prune, spice and chocolate. Some heat and aggressiveness must be dealt with on a firm finish.
This opens with aromas of toasted oak, ripe apricot and butterscotch while the textured palate offers cedar, vanilla and lemon drop. It closes on a note of bitter almond.

Whiff of wild berry, moist earth and chopped herb aromas merge with a blue flower note. Suggestions of the nose carry over to the light-bodied delicate palate along with a hint of ground pepper. Bright acidity and dusty, not very persistent tannins provide gauzy support. Drink soon.

Intriguing notes of curing spice, game, green pepper, coriander and cedar grace the black-fruit core of this Cab. The tannins are soft and approachable, while seductive notes of campfire and charred fruit skin unfold on the finish. Drink now.

This is fresh, fruity and off dry, with a buttery smooth mouthfeel. There are mixed tree fruits and just enough acidity to offset the sweetness adequately. It's a perfect springtime sipping wine, low in alcohol, ripe with fruit flavor, and should be consumed over the next year or two.

Fresh lemon juice freshens the richer aromas of butter cookie and caramelized sugar. The creamy mouthfeel gives way to bright, juicy pineapple, lemon curd and vanilla flavors, finishing crisp and fruity.

Grown in the comparatively cool conditions of the plateau of Alij, this wine has a crisp, poised character. Its citrus fruits and touch of minerality give freshness and a good texture. Drink this bright wine now.

Black fruit, dark lilacs and wet earth show on the nose of this blend of 54% Cabernet Sauvignon, 22% Merlot and 24% Petit Verdot. Elderflower and elderberry flavors show on the sip, which is tight and sticky in texture and could use a little more mellowing.

Restrained and earthy, this Sauvignon displays citrus peel and crushed stone aromas. The palate offers a bit more intensity and complexity, with grapefruit zest creating a focused line of acidity from start to finish.

There's a density to the nose and palate that can't be ignored, which translates to a syrupy aroma and thick palate. There are some uplifting tones of herbs and savory cherry that offer levity, with brisk acidity and bolstering tannins giving support.

Pure varietal and estate grown, this opens with concentrated, sweet berry preserves of strawberry and raspberry jam. It stiffens up in the middle as it moves into rather astringent, lightly earthy tannins.

Despite the high alcohol, this is relatively restrained, with flavors mixing rosewater and raspberries. It's a simple, lightly fruity wine, with stiff tannins that introduce suggestions of black tea and a whiff of tobacco.

This ripe wine, with its rich tannins and smooth texture, is delicious. Balanced and soft, it's a ripe blend of Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Jaen. With blackberry and black-currant flavors, it is fruity. It has no wood aging, although there's some final spice from the fruit. Drink now.

This young wine is quite tight and tannic, with hard fruit flavors of red currant. Stemmy scents and flavors are out in full force, and this might well want another year or two in bottle before it's all pulled together. There's a finishing lick of ultra dark chocolate threaded through those chewy tannins.

This is a straightforward yet not overly expressive Shiraz, with subtle notes of currant and plum skin on the nose and mouth. The structure is easy and approachable, with soft tannins and fruit-skin flavors that lend subtle grip through the licorice-laced finish. Drink now.

The oak is far out front, with aromas of vanilla, shaved coconut, toast and freshly chopped wood, making it hard to get at the notes of dark fruit and herb. The flavors show fruit mixed with a heavy barrel influence, with the latter winning out on the finish.

This affordable blend combines Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Syrah and Zinfandel. Elusive and thick in concentrated black fruit and leather, it offers massive, assertive tannins and a lasting imprint of dried herb.

This is a straight-ahead, electric red, slightly off-dry ros, made from Pinot Noir grapes. Red fruits with a spicy kick have plenty of fruit sweetness, though not necessarily residual sugar. Given that it's a 2015, it should be consumed as soon as possible.
The nose wants to give almost nothing away. The palate, however, presents subtle green pear and yellow plum on a very slender, dry body.

This rare native grape creates a wine that is enjoyable in primary fruit expression. Floral and spicy, with a wealth of red cherry and black berry flavors, this is light bodied but crisp, clean and perfect with a slight chill.

Ripe red fruits dominate this soft wine. The fruitiness of Trincadeira is boosted by the firmer character of Alicante Bouschet and Touriga Nacional, yielding a rich wine that is smooth and juicy, with spice and dark-coffee flavors. Drink now.
This medium-bodied, dry and spicy-tasting wine has a relatively light color, aromas like cedar and cinnamon and lean cherry flavors. A definite touch of tannin adds grip to the mouthfeel.

This wine is mostly Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah. Aromas of blueberry pie and huckleberry pop, showing grace notes of barrel spice and herb. The flavors are lighter in style, losing concentration in the middle and seeming watery, and never come back together.

In terms of sheer hedonism, this is a successful wine, full of oaky aromas of vanilla cake, caramel and plum pudding, loaded with crme brle and ripe fruit flavors. But the oak winds up feeling single-noted by the finish, and the grape seems lost in the seasonings.
Berry and spice aromas that suggest clove open this medium-bodied Garnacha. Spiced berry flavors hint at cinnamon, while chocolate notes are welcome on a plump finish.

Sauvignon Gris may be only 10% of the blend but it gives a delicious perfumed character to this wine. Grapefruit and apricot flavors combine with the mineral texture to give a rich while still taut wine. Drink from late 2018.

This small 12-acre property has a high proportion of Merlot in its blends. Still packed with high-toast wood flavors, this wine has a future, with plenty of ripe red-berry fruits and a generous texture. Wait for the wood to dissipate and for the fruit to come forward.

This wine is rich with sweetness although it shows only a light botrytis character. It has a touch of spice from the wood aging as well as honey and lemon to balance the sweetness and acidity. Even though young, it is ready to drink.

Aromas of juicy black plums and raspberries meld with vanilla and sage on the nose. Loaded with flavors of vanilla and baked plums, the palate is plush in feel, with hints of raspberry, white pepper and oregano. Mellow acidity fades into the medium-length finish, showing soft notes of blackberry speckled with pepper.
Bright, pleasant aromas of yellow apple, pear and papaya lead to a palate chock full of tropical-fruit flavors. It finishes a little tangy.

Elton is a new label under the Willamette Valley Vineyards umbrella, though the vineyard has been a favored designate for the past decade. This latest release falls a little short. The barrel flavors of buttered nuts have a slightly oily mouthfeel, and the apple and orange fruit is only moderately ripened. It seems to promise more than it delivers, given the packaging and price.

Fruity aromas of wild red berry and a whiff of moist soil lift out of the glass. On the restrained light-bodied palate, bright acidity and dusty, not very persistent tannins give sheer support to red cherry and a hint of white pepper. Drink soon.
Underbrush, violet, aromatic herb and wild berry aromas appear at the forefront. The light-bodied palate is less expressive, showing dried blackberry and clove alongside dusty tannins.
Exotically floral, this wine is extreme in spicy acidity and robust earthiness, a mix of rose petal, citrus and black tea that struggles somewhat to find balance and fruit.
A nose of honeydew melon and vanilla bean set the stage for flavors of apple, nectarine and hazelnut. This wine is full on the palate, with closing notes of citrus fruit and a hint of toasted nuts.

This blend of Riesling, Vidal Blanc and Seyval Blanc has soft aromas of elderflower, lemon, wet stone and dried apple. Zippy acidity tingles on the palate and lends itself to a long finish full of minerality.

This wine is made from three barrels were chosen for their particular aroma and flavor characteristics. It carries aggressive, spicy cranberry flavors and searing acidity that cuts the palate short. Drink now.

Exuberantly fruity and forward, this light-footed kabinett offers loads of sweet, juicy tangerine, grapefruit and berry flavors. It's not a complex wine but approachable and easy drinking, with a clean mineral finish.

This playful, easy-drinking blend of 46% Shiraz, 31% Cinsault, 20% Mourvdre and 3% Grenache is ripe and fruit-forward, offering oodles of black plum, cherry and currant tones that are hit by accents of blackcurrant leaf and bramble. The juicy palate boasts soft tannins and bright acidity, resulting in a clean, mouthwatering finish. Drink now2019.

From a chateau owned by the Bouey Bordeaux negociant family, this wine is ripe, rich and soft. Its tannic structure gives just-enough support to the attractive red-currant and berry fruits. Drink this forward, fruity wine from 2020.

Aromas of mint, woodspice, raspberry and coffee are followed by ripe red-currant flavors. Soft, lightly grainy tannins provide support. It has good things going on and is varietally correct but seems a bit woody.

Dry and astringent, this is remarkably similar to a hard cider. Half was fermented in stainless steel, half in concrete, and it is the concrete that comes out in the aromatics, much more than fruit. For food pairing, look to the sorts of things that would accompany a good cider.
From Dijon clones, this shows dried cranberries and a touch of leather. The finish seems a bit attenuated also. Two bottles were tasted; the second a little less leathery, but with comparable fruit.

The least expensive of the winery's Pinots, this has a light and fruity style that makes it instantly approachable. Simple red-berry flavors, crisp acids and a little crunch to the tannins give it some extra depth.
An earthy overtone sits on the nose. The palate has a similarly earthy ring but adds gentle pear and lemon notes to a very light, dry body.

Light rose buds, dried potpourri and tart cranberry aromas show on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate is a touch thin but with decent grip, and delivers easily likable flavors of cranberry and cinnamon.

This wine is very fruity in flavor and almost sleek in texture, but still has the varietal's typical firm tannins and hints of black pepper in the generous black-cherry flavors. It's medium bodied, not too heavy or too astringent, so it will be more versatile than many.

Aromas of toasted nut, bread crust and a whiff of grilled rosemary lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the palate along with yellow apple skin and a hint of coffee while brisk acidity gives it a rather lean finish.
Earthy forest and mushroom belie a hearty, dense and velvety expression of rich dark cherry and huckleberry in this full-bodied powerful wine.

Aromas of orange peel, melon and vanilla come together fairly well. This feels plump but solid, with modest acidity. Melony flavors turn yeasty on a lightly oxidized finish that lacks length and kick. Drink now.

Despite the extra years in bottle, this wine has not really come together. Somewhat awkward and astringent, it pushes stiff berry fruits against drying tannins. Sometimes blending is a better approach than focusing too specifically on a single block and clone.
This entry-level, simple yet well-made wine offers straightforward cranberry and cherry fruit. It's fresh and bright, with juicy youthful appeal. Drink now while it's at its freshest.

Made from the regional grape of unknown origins, Minutolo, this wine is not bashful with its heady floral and fruity nature. Ripe tropical fruit, grapefruit and white flower tones carry the nose and palate. This is medium in weight with a delightfully astringent texture that helps maintain balance.
A touch of cream joins the pear note on the nose. The palate, however, has a main theme of fresh lemon on a slender, dry body. Drink soon.

The ocean is never far away in all wines from the Lisboa region. The crispness and the bright red fruits of this open wine testify to that fact. This is a light wine, full of fruit, delicious now and ready to drink.
A tightly wound framework of bittersweet tannin and oak dominate in this mountainous red, which exhibits pencil shavings, cedar and sage around ripe full-bodied black cherry and plum.
Aromas of ripe pear, yellow peach and medicinal herb follow over to the vibrant palate along with yellow apple and tangerine zest. Bright acidity gives it a crisp clean finish.
Pleasing aromas of almond butter, lemon zest and kiwi lead to papaya, pineapple and other tropical-fruit flavors. It delivers immediate appeal.
Lightly toasted apple, melon and guava form the core of this ripe and fruit-forward wine. It's light in body and style, with clean yet delicate acidity and a brisk close. Drink now.

Citrus blossom, white stone fruit and medicinal herb aromas mingle with a whiff of bread crust. The invigorating palate shows Golden Delicious apple and nectarine rind balanced by lively acidity and racy bubbles. It closes on a walnut note.
Lightly floral, this delicate but quite drinkable wine shows flavors of peavine, lime and pineapple. The fruit is just ripe enough, balanced and clean, with refreshing acidity.

Superripe Merlot, 60% in this blend, gives this wine power and density, with full-bodied black fruit and firm tannins. Wood aging, partially in new wood, has brought in spice as well as a dry core that indicates the potential of this wine as it matures. Drink from 2023.
This soft, juicy wine has ripe black-currant fruits and some smoky tannins. It is warm, generous and likely to mature quickly. Drink from 2020.

Fresh red- and black-berry aromas are underscored by tilled earth on the nose. The palate is similar in character, boasting a ripe and juicy feel, with medium weight, light tannins and soft acidity. Drink now.

Murky, gamy aromas indicate that 2014's wet, humid conditions affected this wine. In the mouth, this is heavy and tough, with grating tannins. Black-fruit flavors combined with lemony oak are chunky, massive and acidic on the finish. This wine is good but has balance issues.

Fresh apple, orange and green melon are at the fore of this straightforward yet refreshing and tasty wine. It is light in weight and concentration, offering fruity flavors of apple and pear that finish bright and clean. Drink now.
Mirabelle plum and very ripe pear create a fruity expression on the nose. That same fruit is abundant on the palate. This is a fruity wine with a medium-dry finish.
Subtle notes of yellow plum have an edge of freshness on the nose. The plum notes also pervade on the juicy, fruit-driven palate. This is light easy, dry and refreshing.
Aromas of yellow peach, citrus and a whiff of almond carry over to the medium-bodied palate. Fresh acidity gives it a bright finish.

Aromas of pear and lemon rise from the rather neutral nose. The palate comes in with far more fruit in notes of ripe apple and pear, with freshness and a creamy aspect. This is a fruity, easy, dry wine. Drink soon.
Subdued notes of ripe, yellow pear play on the nose and palate. Freshness balances this beautifully, giving it a dry, crisp finish. Drink soon.

Just a hint of cherry appears on the shy nose. On the fresh, light and translucent palate the fruit tone is pure but tart. This is fresh, honest and still has the slightest tannic grip. A very balanced, fresh-faced wine. Drink soon.
The nose offers a touch of ripe pear. The palate shows less fruit and majors on a neutral but clean and balanced, dry body. This is simple but refreshing. Drink soon.
Sweet herb, lime twist and peach aromas are followed by sleek, narrow citrus and stone-fruit flavors that drink off dry.
Offering classic, varietal fruit flavors of apple and pear, this pleasant wine is lightly spiced and buoyed with supporting acids. It was finished in 5% new French oak.
This seems to be quickly drying out, with fruit-leather flavors more than fresh berries and cherries. There's ample acidity and stiff tannins. Best to consume this as soon as possible.

Restrained aromas of crushed mineral, apple and lemon turn ripe and sunny on the palate. Delicately sweet, it's an approachable, briskly balanced wine that finishes on a vibrant tangerine note. Drink now through 2019.
This is stylish and youthfully fresh and tasty. Fermented in cement and aged for 10 months in neutral oak, it's got ripe spicy berry and plum flavors, just a touch high toned. Drink now through 2019.
Produced by the winemaking team of Chteau Giscours in Margaux, this crisply herbal wine has great citrus and ripe yellow fruits and a rich, creamy texture. It is ready to drink.

All the winery's wines are 100% varietal, and this is a solid effort with substantial flavors of mulberry and blackberry fruit. There's a streak of cola and lightly earthy tannins. Flavors are broad and accessible, and the wine finishes with a streak of vanilla.
This is a rich red-fruit-dominated wine. Berries and acidity combine with light tannins to give a wine that bursts from the glass. Enjoy this attractively fruity wine soon.

From the new venture from major producer Sogrape, this wine is soft and juicy, with attractive red fruits. Its acidity and gentle tannins are balanced with the refreshing fruitiness. The wine is ready to drink.

Aromas of pollen, wildflower honey and peach are enticing on the nose. This off-dry wine is ripe yet balanced, with flavors of orange, peach and juicy mango. The ripe melon finish is charming and clean.

There's an intriguing levity to the nose of this this wine in its pressed violet, mint and wild strawberry aromas. Medium in weight, with solid tannic grip, the palate offers more of the same, yet ends on a chalky, mineral finish.

Rock manager turned winemaker Sheri Hood honors some old-school rockers (the band MC5) with this affordable Pinot. Boysenberry and plum fruits come along with stiff earthy tannins. For the modest price it has plenty of flavor and some muscle as well.

Barrel aromas are at the fore, with notes of vanilla, dill, toast and baking spice, along with a light meaty note. The flavors show a luscious, velvety feel, with the oak influence running quite high.

This variety is unheard of in the appellation. Quite pale in color with an orange tinge, the aromas bring notes of macerated cranberry and cherry, along with a vanilla note that gives the impression of confection. The palate brings lighter-styled fruit flavors, with the oak taking over on the back half. The tannins are quite light for the variety. It's intriguing but doesn't seem varietal.

Oaky vanilla and sweet spice overpower apricot and lemon aromas on the nose. A rich vanilla tone leads flavors of mango, apricot, and mandarin on the palate. The mouthfeel is soft, with balancing acidity and a clean vanilla and apricot finish.

An austere wine, this does not shy away from flavors of stem, beet root and rhubarb. The fruit touches on strawberry, but does not display the ripe flavors you might anticipate from the listed alcohol. It's high acid, herbal and earthy.
Fresh and leesy, this all-stainless wine has cucumber, apple and green-melon flavors, done in a light tart refreshing style. Drink up.

Another barrel selection, this seems quite thin in comparison with the rest of the winery's 2013s. It's tart and acidic, without the supporting detail and overall elegance of the rest. There are simple fruit flavors of citrus and sour berries.
This is a nice, juicy wine that has interesting fruit and earth aromas, good ripe berry flavors and an easy-going texture. It feels medium bodied and tastes not too strong and not too weak.

This full-bodied wine is loaded with aromas of pear nectar and grilled baguette, and very ripe fruit flavors. It has a warmly oaky personality, showing vanilla and coconut in addition to generous pear notes.

Interesting bay leaf and clove aromas are followed by focused and bright black-cherry flavors and a vivid texture shaped by firm acidity and moderate tannins. It has a lean and lively feel and no oakiness.
Aromas of dark fruit, smoked meat and herb lead to plentiful plum flavors that miss a bit in the middle. It comes up short on the finish but otherwise provides appeal.

This opens with aromas of red berry, underbrush, mint and leather. The palate is more straightforward, offering blackberry, powdered sage and hints of baking spice set against bright acidity and dusty, not very persistent tannins.

Effusive aromas of strawberry and raspberry lead to rich, equally fruity flavors and a velvety texture that balances some tannin with a touch of ripeness. It's a full-bodied, mouth-coating and smooth blend.
Dusty aromas suggest apple. A full, round palate is soda-like and not precise, while this tastes of lightly spiced apple with a dusting of powdered sugar. A short, mellow finish is nondescript.
