The 67% of Cabernet Sauvignon in this wine gives it both richness and a firm structure. It is a solid wine, still showing its oak aging but with juicy fruit and acidity. It will develop as it softens, so drink from 2022.

Medium straw in color, this wine features aromas of apple and honeysuckle. It is tart at first sip, with flavors of lemon-lime and Gala apple that are slowly overtaken by strong notes of eucalyptus. Fruit flavors return on the finish, offering a closing note of pear.
This wine is tannic and dusty, a big, dense expression of a formidable grape that leers into smoky, dark and brooding territory. Blackberry and cherry drip from an herbal backdrop of intensity.

A number of wineries draw upon grapes from this excellent site. Here, the flavors are of cranberries and raspberries, and remain tart and rather acidic. The tannins are stiff and leave a slightly bitter aftertaste.

Solid, at first seeming to be a bit on the chunky side, this thins out in the mouth, offering tart berry fruit. Along with that come some stemmy components and tannins that are just hitting not-quite-ripe flavors. It's a sound, but not distinguished, estate selection.
Unusual aromas of watermelon Jolly Rancher, lime zest and white flower are followed by light flower and peach flavors that finish tart. It doesn't all come together.

Red berry, toast and underbrush aromas mingle with a whiff of eucalyptus. The tightly wound, austere palate offers sour cherry, espresso and a hint of star anise set against grainy tannins that leave an astringent finish. Drink after 2021.

This blend of 90% Negroamaro and 10% Malvasia Nera is bright in red currant and red cherry aromas, with dustings of saw dust and anise. Medium in weight and displaying lively acidity, the palate is racy and streamlined in crisp red-fruit flavors under a layer of vanilla.
Apple peel, grapefruit and riper tropical fruit notions meld with a floral background in this light-bodied, crisp wine. The concentration is light, yet what's there is quite enjoyable.
Delicate hints of yellow cherry and apple sweeten this uncomplicated but fresh wine. Off dry in style, it's pleasantly sweet and tart on a zesty lemonade finish. Drink now.
Ripe red fruits combine into a pleasant, though generic style. There's a touch of earth underlying the tannins, and a high-toned edge to the aromatics.

From the more experimental side of the Craft Wine Company, this ros blends St. Laurent, Zweigelt, Blaufrnkisch and Grner Veltliner. The result is a pretty but somewhat dilute ros, with thinnish raspberry fruit, rosewater and a touch of neutral wood. It's fully mature and should be consumed in the near term.

Crisp raspberry and red cherry flavors are invigorating and fresh on the palate of this easy-drinking, juicy Pinot Noir. It's delicate in concentration and light in body but balanced by soft but pleasantly bitter tannins. A hint of vanilla lingers on the finish. Drink now through 2020.

This blend of Syrah, Touriga Nacional and Petit Verdot is smooth, ripe and full of black-cherry and plum fruits. With its acidity, crisp texture and soft tannins, it will be ready to drink from mid-2018.

This is a good but basic ros Cava. Aromas of mild citrus fruits and vanilla lead to a good but basic palate with just enough energy and acidity. Cantaloupe and citrus-peel flavors are steady on the finish.

Except for a hint of lime, this basic brut Cava smells neutral. A simple palate is citrusy and in solid shape. Generic white-fruit flavors come with mild green notes of celery and scallion. It's lively but lacks flavor on the finish.
This wine is fresh and forward, with simple but appealing flavors of raspberry and cherry candies. The flavors don't go any further than that, but for a fruity quaffable wine, it's quite well done.

This has a funky nose of truffle, game, scorched soil and just a whiff of barnyard. The fleshy palate has a rustic allure, showing baked plum, blackberry extract, vanilla and the same truffle and gamy notes of the nose. Grainy dusty tannins provide the soft framework.

Aromas of ripe red berries and violets are fresh and light on the nose. A juicy, medium-bodied palate of blackberry and racy cranberry flavors shows good concentration, with floral accents that dot the finish.

This ripe wine is full of black fruit as well as a serious tannin structure. Rich, concentrated, juicy with berry flavors and with layers of acidity, it strikes a balance between firm tannins and black fruit.
This is a velvety thick and oaky red, aged some time in bottle. Somewhat herbal in clove, cedar and graphite notes, its texture is defined more by leather.

This Bordeaux-style blend is comprised of mainly Cabernet Franc and rounded out with Merlot and Petit Verdot. This wine offers black currant, black plum and pepper, with additions of toasty clove, nutmeg and charred wood. Barnyard and fig bring depth of character to the mix. The acidity is bright and the tannins are present but soft. The finish is long and full of oak spice.

Sourced from both Volcano Ridge and The Pines vineyards, this is a smooth, supple wine, 100% varietal, with a mix of plum and blueberry fruit. Somewhat high toned and bright, it is ready to drink over the next couple of years.

There's a warm, ripe character to this wine, which boasts generous waves of macerated berries and cherries throughout. Accents of licorice, star anise and curing spice lend interest to the round, creamy palate. It's an easy, fruity pour that's best enjoyed now.

There's the slightest pink tint to the color of this bottling, which shows baked apple and poached pear aromas on the ripe but pleasant nose. The palate is also quite ripe, showing more cooked pome fruit and squeezed lime, with a decent texture.

This bottling is very mellow and shy on many fronts, though it emerges from its shell with patience. Light aromas of red fruit and dark spice lead into a palate with a full mouthfeel, carrying flavors of raspberry, rose petal, loam and eventually sharp baking spice.
This is a nice, juicy wine that has interesting fruit and earth aromas, good ripe berry flavors and an easy-going texture. It feels medium bodied and tastes not too strong and not too weak.

This full-bodied wine is loaded with aromas of pear nectar and grilled baguette, and very ripe fruit flavors. It has a warmly oaky personality, showing vanilla and coconut in addition to generous pear notes.

Interesting bay leaf and clove aromas are followed by focused and bright black-cherry flavors and a vivid texture shaped by firm acidity and moderate tannins. It has a lean and lively feel and no oakiness.
Aromas of dark fruit, smoked meat and herb lead to plentiful plum flavors that miss a bit in the middle. It comes up short on the finish but otherwise provides appeal.

This opens with aromas of red berry, underbrush, mint and leather. The palate is more straightforward, offering blackberry, powdered sage and hints of baking spice set against bright acidity and dusty, not very persistent tannins.

Effusive aromas of strawberry and raspberry lead to rich, equally fruity flavors and a velvety texture that balances some tannin with a touch of ripeness. It's a full-bodied, mouth-coating and smooth blend.
Dusty aromas suggest apple. A full, round palate is soda-like and not precise, while this tastes of lightly spiced apple with a dusting of powdered sugar. A short, mellow finish is nondescript.

The 67% of Cabernet Sauvignon in this wine gives it both richness and a firm structure. It is a solid wine, still showing its oak aging but with juicy fruit and acidity. It will develop as it softens, so drink from 2022.
Fruit-forward aromas of black currant and plum lead to plump, easy-drinking fruit flavors. It's straightforward, though it seems to lack concentration, especially in the middle.

Baked licorice leads the nose on this blend of 74% Merlot and 26% Cabernet Franc, along with thyme and stewed elderberries. The mouthfeel is lighter bodied, carrying flavors of exotic marjoram and red currant.

The nose is closed and does not want to give too much away. The palate, however, has lovely lemon and fresh pear fruit on a rather light, dry body. This is fresh, easy and fairly neutral, but clean and fresh. Drink soon.
Fruit-forward aromas of black currant and plum lead to plump, easy-drinking fruit flavors. It's straightforward, though it seems to lack concentration, especially in the middle.
A neutral nose offers a quiet, lemony streak. The palate is equally neutral, almost dilute, but fresh and clean. Some apple and pear notes appear on the refreshing finish. Drink soon.

A blend of 60% Primitivo and 40% Negroamaro, this shows a mix of spiced blackberry and cranberry aromas under a sheen of toasted oak. The medium-bodied palate is well structured with juicy acidity and medium-grained tannins, and is rounded out by soft, ripe berry flavors.

This blend of Primitivo and Negroamaro is linear in its expression of ripe cherry, baking spice and graphite. The medium-bodied palate starts juicy up front, but dries out as it reaches the tense, plum-skin finish.

Forward vivid scents of cranberry and raspberry introduce similar fresh fruit flavors, backed by slightly harsh notes of skin and stem. It's a sturdy serviceable effort, which finishes with a hint of chicken broth.
This wine's aromas include notes of yellow apple, melon and lees. The palate brings a rounded feel, showing little apparent new-oak influence. It's a straightforward, varietally correct wine.

Aged in wood for 12 months, this blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon is already balanced and stylish. Its wood aging has added spice without masking any of the black-currant fruit. Drink this wine from 2019

Produced in the heart of the Entre-deux-Mers region, this wine is rich, young and fruity. And that's the way it should be, because this is not a wine for aging but for enjoying with its black fruits and ripe texture. Drink from mid-2018.

Named after the stagecoach that used to stop here on its way up the Mdoc, this wine is light, with soft blackberry fruits and acidity. An easy wine that's likely to mature quickly, it should be ready from 2019.

A mix of black and red cherries carry the nose, with tobacco leaf and herbal spice tones in a more moderate concentration. There's levity to the mouthfeel from the crisp acidity and light, sandy tannins, yet the palate offers a good deal of racy fruit flavors that end clean and refreshing.

A blend of Merlot, Sangiovese, Cabernet Franc and Syrah, this has a shy nose that eventually reveals aromas of baking spice and black-skinned fruit. The straightforward palate offers sweet vanilla and cherry jam alongside round tannins.

Ripe and fruity notes of yellow Mirabelle plums make for an appetizing nose. The palate has a similarly rich impression but lacks a little direction and focus. There is plenty of fruit and lemon brightness. Drink soon.

Here is a light, tart, all-stainless style of wine, with interesting phenolic flavors of pear skin and green apples. Juicy acids bring a citrus component into it as well. It's lively and fresh: a good all-purpose crisp white wine.

High-toned cherry aromas meld with saw dust, anise and game on the nose of this pure expression of Nero di Troia. Light- to medium-bodied in style, flavors of savory bramble berries offer plenty of zip to the palate, with soft tannins giving just enough support. An herb-dusted cherry note marks the finish.
With aromas of white peach and honeysuckle, this wine has flavors of ripe peach, marzipan and orange blossom. It is sweet but not cloying, with a burst of refreshing brightness on the finish.

This wine is rich, with superripe tannins and a barnyard character. It has structure but it mainly focuses on fruit and acidity. Made by the team at Cos d'Estournel, the wine has a rich structure and will be ready to drink soon, from 2019.
This wine offers a bouquet of grapefruit and lime zest followed by flavors of chirimoya and guava. Grapefruit flavors return to the palate just in time for a zippy finish.
This estate features biodynamically grown fruit and artisanal winemaking practices. This wine is tart and focused in snappy lemon, orange and pineapple flavors.
This wine has a nice oomph of blackberry flavor and full enough body to carry it well. It feels rich and velvety on the palate and a generous layer of fine tannins doesn't get heavy.

Lemon balm, herbs and citrus blossom aromas show a nice, clean intensity on the nose. Bright on the palate, with a bit of weight and roundness, citrus pith and fleshy yellow apple flavors meld with more balmy, herbal notes.

Mild white-fruit aromas suggest peach juice. This Godello is both plump and citrusy in feel. Generic citrus flavors are closest to orange. This is a touch bitter and slightly oxidized on the finish, so drink now.
Lemon and hay aromas carry delicate pollen and floral tones on the nose. Medium in weight and acidity, the palate is yellow-fruit driven, with a grapefruit zest vein of acidity.

This is a big bold wine that lays on the oak flavor without restraint. A strong aroma of cedar and baking spices is followed by very concentrated dark-fruit flavors and spicy charred oak flavors. It is quite tannic and almost thick in texture, giving plenty of grip on the palate.

Compared to the 2015 vintage which retained its liveliness, this new vintage seems woody and oxidized. It's a natural wine, and those can sometimes thrill tasters willing to stretch out a bit. Here, it's soft and slightly flat, with flavors of mashed fruits. Drink up.

Light floral and peach aromas lead to a lively palate full of fresh fruit, lychees, and honey while a subtle fizz helps balance out considerable sweetness. It's a charming, light wine that's easy to swallow.

Very much the local white grape, Arinto benefits from the relatively cool climate of the region to give a delicious, crisp wine. It is aromatic, full of citrus flavors with a zesty, mineral edge. Drink this wine now.
There's plenty to enjoy about this lighter-than-average Primitivo. It's ripe and spicy, with a strong showing of bramble berries and anise. A soft, pliable feel make it immediately appealing.

While closed on the nose, the palate of this easy-drinking Riesling is plump in tones of juicy yellow peach and citrus. It's a lively, mouthwatering sip offering just a touch of bitter herb on the finish. Drink now through 2019.

Vineyards close to Portugal's highest mountain range give this wine a crisp, cool character. A blend of Touriga Nacional and Alfrocheiro, it is fruity with red currants and plenty of acidity. The wine is ready to drink.

Smoky, earthy aromas are cloaked by red- and black-fruit intensity on the nose. The palate brings ripe berry flavors boosted by leather, cedar and allspice, while the tannins are grippy and spicy but cut through by a vein of acidity. Tangy currant and allspice tones carry through the finish.

Aromas of orange-blossom honey, peach and lemon zest waft from the glass. The palate shows clementine, ripe white peach and lemon juice, with a crushed rock minerality. The sweetness is balanced by a bright backbone of acidity leading to a clean lemony finish.

The elegant Minho stone manor house is the heart of this fine vineyard. The wine, still with a light prickle on the tongue, is a classic from the Vinho Verde region, crisp, incisive and packed with fruit. Drink this tangy wine now.

Ripe tangerines are accented by notes of caramel, crushed earth and fennel in this earthy, slightly savory kabinett. Bristling lemon acidity and honey tones brighten the midpalate, leading a finish edged by spice and a hint of tannins.
This wine offers aromas and flavors of baked red currant, red plum, eucalyptus, black pepper and rare meat. Its zippy acidity is a great match for the full body and depth of flavors.

This winemaker's selection is from a warm ripe vintage, yet it remains rather light. The fruit touches on pomegranate and raspberry, and a whiff of ground coffee suggests some time in a percentage of new or once-used oak. It's light on the palate and stiffly herbal through the finish.

The winery makes a number of block and clone cuves, along with regular and reserve Pinots. It would perhaps differentiate them as well as showcase them more distinctively to focus on blending fewer, more complete wines. This reserve has the same high acid, herbal, earth and stem character as the regular bottling.
Just a touch of fresh apple appears on the almost mute nose. The palate follows with easy, clean apple and ripe pear notes on a slender, light body. The finish is dry and refreshing. Drink soon.

This very sweet, 210g/l dessert wine was produced cryogenically. It's peachy and syrupy, with candied apricots and a touch of maple syrup. There's just enough acidity to cut some of the treacle, but the sweetness has a sugary granularity rather than a smooth, integrated mix of flavors.

Baked licorice leads the nose on this blend of 74% Merlot and 26% Cabernet Franc, along with thyme and stewed elderberries. The mouthfeel is lighter bodied, carrying flavors of exotic marjoram and red currant.

The nose is closed and does not want to give too much away. The palate, however, has lovely lemon and fresh pear fruit on a rather light, dry body. This is fresh, easy and fairly neutral, but clean and fresh. Drink soon.
Nothing but the slightest hint of lemon appears on the closed nose. The palate is clean and fresh, just hinting at green pear. Drink soon.

You'll find aromas of toast, nut and a whiff of adhesive bandage on this. The aromas carry over the rather lean, somewhat muddled palate along with dried cherry, a hint of lead pencil, powdered sage and a confectionary note alongside steely bubbles.
Toasted nut, medicinal herb and bread crust aromas follow through to the lean palate along with yellow-apple skin, sage and bitter almond. Fresh acidity and a vigorous perlage provide the backdrop.
Raisin and prune aromas announce a chunky palate that's solid but not agile or elegant. Flavors of prune and cassis come with a sense of grape skins. It finishes well.
Aromas of red currant are bright and fresh, with little apparent new-oak influence. Raspberry and currant flavors bring more of the same. It's a straightforward, easy drinker.

This is a good, solidly built table wine with a robust texture and bold fruit and dark-spice flavors. It barrels straight ahead in style and will easily wash down some Korean barbecue or steak fajitas.
Lettuce and white-fruit aromas lead to a plump palate with modest acidity. Yeasty melon and powdery apple flavors dry out on the finish, leaving a note of tropical papaya.
Slightly stalky aromas are not the cleanest. In the mouth, this has lime-like acidity and yeasty white-fruit flavors that include mild green notes. A chalky finish closes out this basic Cava.
Hints of fresh, green pear and a touch of lemon appear on the nose. The palate offers more of the same on a dry, light body which lacks a little focus. Drink soon.

Rich, probably too rich, this is a smooth, concentrated wine. Its tannins are already embedded in the cushion of superripe fruit offering flavors of black plums and dark chocolate. The wine will age quickly; drink from 2019.

Subdued notes of lemon and herb on the nose extend to the palate of this off-dry, slightly earthen Riesling. Pressed apple and pear flavors are moderately concentrated but pleasantly clingy on the finish. Drink now.

Ripe, sweet yellow peach and tangerine flavors are shaded by darker tones of smoke and sea water in this slightly rustic, savory kabinett. It's well balanced by acidity and the finish is refreshing and crisp.
This wine is ripe, soft, rich and smooth. Its tannins are totally integrated into the generous damson fruit. Lightly textured and with balanced acidity, the wine is ready to drink.
Underbrush, dried herb and toasted aromas lift out of the glass while the no-frills palate evokes wild cherry, ground clove and a hint of coffee bean. Fleeting tannins give loose support. Drink soon.
Fleshy and simple, this is packed with flavors of strawberries. It's fresh and forward, with a ripe core of fruit. Don't look for complexity here, just enjoy it for its lush strawberry goodness.

Intriguing aromas of dark pomegranate, white pepper, crushed gravel and herb meet with a touch of tar on the nose of this appellation blend. The mouthfeel is heavy and the density impresses, but the flavors of rich cranberry and tart orange rind are a bit muddled and sour.

Aromas of toasted walnut, yellow stone fruit and candied citrus zest follow through to the vigorous palate along with bitter yellow-apple skin and a hint of medicinal herb. Steely bubbles provide a rather aggressive perlage.
A hint of smoked nuts lends a savory tone to flavors of pressed apple and pear. While delicate in concentration, it's dry and approachable, with refreshing lemon-lime acidity. Drink now.

Slighty muted tones of strawberry and red apple are glazed with caramel in this slightly off-dry blanc de noir, a Pinot Noir vinfied like a white wine. Light bodied and soft in acidity, it's an easy, approachable wine to drink now.
A ripe, rich, perfumed nose of butter, citrus, melon and yeast lead into a palate that feels a little disjointed, with a creamy, weighty texture yet biting acidity and very little fruit.

Made with 70% Sangiovese and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, this has subdued aromas of red plum and baking spice. The aromas carry over to the simple palate together with a hint of vanilla. Round tannins lend easy support.

This wine, with its earthy aroma and light oak aging, is made for early drinking. Its red fruits and acidity are generous, rounded with the warmth of the Alentejo in its texture. The wine can be drunk now.

Thick, oaky and exceptionally high in alcohol, there's no subtlety to this wine. The full-bodied fruit flavors bring apple, melon and papaya into play, but it would be difficult to match this to food.

This Chardonnay is reminiscent of a fruit salad, with lush aromas and flavors of lemon, banana, pineapple, honeydew and peach yogurt. Mild acidity keeps everything in check and leads to a short finish.

Spicy aromas of licorice and cedar mingle with vanilla and cassis on the nose. The tannins are somewhat gritty on the palate, with spicy black pepper, cedar and pomegranate flavors. The acidity helps pull this wine together but tannic, oaky flavors overpower with only a suggestion of black fruit on the lingering finish.

Not quite as concentrated as the previous vintage, the fruit flavors of melon and pear are correctly varietal, yet somewhat dilute. The wine was fermented entirely in tank, and there is just a hint of metal flavoring the finish.
Subdued aromas of nut, dried apricot and overripe nectarine zest all follow over to the straightforward palate along with a hint of yellow apple. A light touch of almond marks the close.

This opens with muddled aromas suggesting minestrone soup, prune, celery and coffee that carry over to the full-bodied palate along with mature black cherry, baking spice and crushed black olive. Loose-knit, close-grained tannins try to hold it all together.

While oak dominant on the nose in aromas of roasted berries, the palate reveals a bit more complexity and balance. Medium-bodied and silken in feel, this shows ripe berry flavors, lifted by shades of violets and crushed granite. There's a slight dip in concentration on the midpalate yet overall this is enjoyable for its soft, approachable feel.
Lush and rich aromas of candied red cherries and vanilla dust show on the nose of this bottling. Rosewater and fruit punch flavors arise on the sip, riding into a vanilla dust finish.
Light aromas of melon, pear and herb lead to similarly faint fruit flavors. It's cleanly made but everything seems very dialed back.

Furry plum and berry aromas are good but fragmented. Racy acidity creates tension and some rawness on the palate, while this wine tastes of tart black plum and black currant. Latent acidity on the finish results in strained freshness.

There's a very strong scent of licorice on the nose of this blend of 54% Syrah and 46% Merlot, along with dark-red fruit and myrrh. Eucalyptus oil flavors arise on the palate, giving intrigue to the black cherry, peppercorn and roasted meat touches.
The nose is extremely shy but the tangy straightforward palate shows white cherry, Gala apple and a hint of almond. It's linear and crisp, with bright acidity a vivacious perlage.
A ripe, fruity blend of local Do grapes, this unoaked wine bursts with blackberry flavors. Acidity and tannins back up the juicy fruitiness of the wine. Drink now.
Full bodied and voluptuous, this fleshy red blend offers soft, easy black cherry and berry flavors powdered with cinnamon and cocoa. Soft, yielding tannins amplify its plush, easy style. Drink now.
Floral and honey-like aromas lead to very sweet flavors of apricot and peach in this medium-bodied wine. A good choice for friends that only drink sweet, or with your dessert.

This wine is 50% Cabernet Sauvignon along with 25% Cabernet Franc and 25% Malbec. Slightly elevated volatiles are followed by aromas of cherry, cinnamon, green herb, licorice and baking spice. Flavors are light and elegant in style.

Dusty aromas of white fruits are equaled by barrel-based vanilla scents. A round, easy palate gives off a powdery sense, while this barrel-fermented Viura-Tempranillo blend tastes yeasty and of green banana. Latent acidity on the finish creates mild sourness.
Aromas of watermelon Jolly Rancher, peach and flower are followed by broad honeysuckle and stone-fruit flavors. It doesn't all come together.
This is a serviceable red, built to be enjoyed now, approachable in its mix of doughy leather, black cherry and structured tannin.
Strawberry jam and green herb aromas are joined by a delicate floral flavor on the medium-bodied palate. Bright acidity and grainy tannins lead to a crisp, dry finish.
Ripe pear notes signal a fresh, fruity wine. The palate is slightly dilute but offers crisp lemon to brighten a fairly neutral but dry palate. Drink soon.
Underbrush, toast and scorched earth aromas follow over to the rather lean palate along with dried cherry, a hint of prune and clove. Dusty fleeting tannins give it an abrupt finish.
Red berry jam aromas meld with fresh raspberry and baking spice on the nose. The palate is light in feel, with ripe juicy berry flavors struck against a dry, chalky finish.

Dusty mineral and saline notes lend savoriness to muted red apple and raspberry in this dry blanc de noirs, a Pinot Noir vinified like a white wine. The palate is broad and soft in acidity, finishing brisk but clean. Drink now.

A dark and rusty color combined with leafy red-fruit aromas gets this Trepat Cava going. A pulling palate borders on astringent, while leafy, slightly bitter citrus flavors are rustic and match the nose.
Spiced red-berry aromas meet shades of herbs and sarsaparilla on the nose. Sandy tannins and bright acidity provide the backbone for a medium-bodied palate of tart red fruit and savory herbs.

Raspberry and currant aromas ride over subtle tones of cedar, licorice and vanilla bean. This is a big wine, with intense oak flavors of vanilla, allspice and cedar that overpower the cranberry and raspberry fruit flavors. Plentiful grippy tannins are balanced by a backbone of acidity. The spicy tannic finish dissipates to a softer cedar note.

Produced from organically grown grapes and bottled without sulfur, this wine is young, crisp and full of black fruits. Its tannins and juicy acidity suggest the wine needs to age and fill out. Wait and drink from 2020.
This bright wine offers black-currant flavors and firm tannins. It is more fruit than structure, giving a generous wine that will age quickly. Drink from 2020.

This wine treads a fine line between serious wood aging and ripe fruit. At this young stage, both characteristics are in play, giving a wine that is both full of black fruits and toasty, dry flavors. Give it time and drink from 2023.

The nose carries aromas of ruby grapefruit alongside honeydew melon. Bright lemon-lime acidity enlivens flavors of key lime and gooseberry on the grassy palate. Hints of bitter lime creep on the finish.
Aromas of clementine and juniper berry set the scene for flavors of apricot, white peach, and almond. Offering nice mouthfeel, this wine has a touch of almond blossom on the short finish.
Aromas of honeysuckle and a whiff of tropical fruit lift from the glass while the soft round palate offers yellow peach and a confectionary note. It's simple but well made.

The grape is rare in Oregon, and most commonly found in Central Europe, where it produces a spicy tannic somewhat rustic red. Here, it's rather thin, in both color and flavor, with dilute strawberry fruit. It's texturally most interesting, and that holds your attention through an otherwise ordinary finish.

First produced in 1850, this is widely seen as the original branded red wine in Portugal. The Castelo fruit, then and now, comes from the Setbal Peninsula. It gives a crisp, juicy and light wine with soft tannins. There is some spice, although the main thrust of this wine is delicious red fruit. Drink now.
Aromas of clover and yeasty vanilla lack concentration. This feels a bit oily, while nonspecific citrus flavors finish with a note of grape skins and brine. It's acidic and medium to light in body.

Earthy, soupy berry aromas are touched up by forced oak. This wine is tannic, screechy and acidic on the palate, with a swath of creamy oak. Herbal, saucy plum and berry flavors finish raw, pulling and tannic, with an excess of oak flavor.
Jammy red-fruit aromas linger under a blanket of oak-driven coffee in this wine. The palate mirrors the aromas, yet the creeping acidity and medium-grained tannins offer a nice counterbalance.

This seems somewhat disjointed and angular, with tart, almost sour berry and cherry fruit. There are acetic scents and chewy tannins. Though labeled reserve, it's a wine that fails to deliver the more subtle pleasures of the grape. Perhaps this would best be served along with a hearty stew.

A mix of five different Pinot relatives (not clones), this seems a bit overworked. It's flat in the mouth, and the mix of grapes, some white, some red, simply blends into a rather generic tasting white wine. If it resembles anything, it's a Pinot Noir Blanc, and it's already drying out, so drink up.

A particularly good value, this appealing and inexpensive wine adds light and tasty oak and spice accents to a good base of plummy flavors. It feels light and fresh on the palate and has enough concentration for a bit of a lingering finish.
Delicate hints of candied red apple and honeydew extend from nose to palate in this easy-going white blend. Off dry and soft in acidity, it's an approachable everyday sip. Drink now.
The Arinto in this attractive wine gives it a floral character. Bright acidity and citrus fruits add a crisp lift and go with the hint of oak aging. This refreshing wine can be drunk now.
This is hugely tannic, nearly impenetrable wine, hard to break through, a mix of pencil lead, tobacco leaf and dried herb that presents as bittersweet and a touch green.
Dried black cherries, baked earth, rust and a hint of feral aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers an interesting line of tart red fruit along with dried thyme and a meaty touch.

Snappy aromas of tangerine lead to a chunky palate with thickness as well as cutting acidity. This tastes of dried melon and bitterness, while on the finish it's chunky, with distant flavors of green melon.
The nose on this 85% Vermentino and 15% Viognier blend reveals delicate aromas of candied citrus and almond. The palate is straightforward, offering white peach and bitter almond notes.
Raisiny aromas indicate that this Syrah is a bit overripe and lazy. Its big, bulky palate is weighty but unfocused, with a jammy berry flavor profile backed by a plump finish.

A blend in equal parts of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, cedar and cooking spice. The lively palate offers cherry jam, tangerine and mocha alongside supple tannins.
This wine has a persistent bitter note that's part earthy, part savory and a touch extreme. Rhubarb, rose, black tea and cardamom all figure in, but don't get along all together well.

Brandied cherry juice and crushed herbs have a slightly saucy feel in this Rosato from the thin-skinned Bombino Nero. There's nice weight to the palate, which boasts flavors of strawberry jam and additional herbs, alongside soft acidity in the background.

Though considerably higher in finished alcohol than the previous vintage, this still carries an impression of underripe fruit. It's tart, thin and tannic, lightly cloaked in baking spices from barrel aging.

This wine comes off as a bit green out of the gate, with aromas of mortared fresh herb along with blueberry, woodspice and vanilla. Flavors are soft and light, concentrated in the middle but missing at the edges. The tannins bring a lightly gritty feel.

A mild nose offers bready aromas. The plump, foamy palate delivers short, briny flavors of generic citrus fruits in front of a clean finish with no complexity. Enjoy this in casual situations, or blended with fruit juice.

Lightly earthy, this offers pleasant berry fruit, though it comes across as more generic than specific to the variety. There's a light touch of toast also, perhaps from the barrel aging. Drink up over the next couple of years.
Dull aromatics open the way to thick dense red fruit, oak and a thickness of tannin in this estate-driven red which drinks heavy on the palate. Cedar and pencil shavings accent it well.

Heady aromas of canned peach, kumquat and pollen convey the awaiting playful sweetness. The confected palate shows flavors of ripe yellow peach, candied mandarin and quince. This wine is plush with just enough acidity to keep it from becoming cloying, while flavors of Satsuma and honeydew melon carry through the medium-short finish.

Used leather, underbrush scorched earth and toasted aromas slowly appear on this evolved wine. The mature palate shows prune and the heat of evident alcohol. It's seen better days for sure. Drink sooner rather than later before it dries out completely.

Made with 90% Sangiovese and 10% Merlot, this has aromas suggesting moist forest floor, truffle, cassis and a whiff of graphite. The palate is on the lean side, offering suggestions of blackberry, orange rind, game and star anise alongside dusty, rather fleeting tannins and firm acidity.
This opens with delicate aromas of black plum and baking spice. The simple palate delivers vanilla, prune and star anise alongside round tannins.

Medicinal berry and plum aromas result in a latex scent. High acidity creates pinching and narrowness on a palate with plum and berry flavors that are more racy and red than dark and ripe. Edgy tannins resurface on a raw finish.

This ultraripe blend of 85% Negroamaro and 15% Malvasia Nera is jammy in black- and red-fruit aromas, with sweet baking spice aromas peppered throughout. The palate feels thick, with black fruit tones under a sheen of cocoa dust and licorice. A bit of acidity helps clean things up come the finish.

Rich and fruity, this bargain buy shows strawberry and blackberry jam aromas and flavors, speckled with green herb and floral tones. There's some breadth to the palate from the ripe fruit, yet enough tannic grip and acidity to maintain balance.

Primarily Cabernet Franc, this blend has pleasing aromas of cranberry, plum, lavender, mint and licorice. There is also a charred oak note that carries through onto the palate and overpowers the other flavors. Zippy acidity adds a welcome freshness that cuts though some of the rough tannins. The finish is long and woody.
Aromas suggesting underbrush and smoke carry over to the simple palate along with raw cranberry and a hint of clove. It's light bodied, with racy acidity and a lean finish.

Aromas of stewed prune and toasted notes lead the nose on this brawny red. Searing alcohol dominates the palate and throws it off balance while blackberry extract, licorice and toasted oak notes linger in the background. Grainy tannins give it an astringent finish.

Snappy aromas of tangerine lead to a chunky palate with thickness as well as cutting acidity. This tastes of dried melon and bitterness, while on the finish it's chunky, with distant flavors of green melon.
Prune and cassis aromas are timid and earthy. This crianza from a cool, rainy year feels choppy, but has substance. Spicy, peppery red-fruit flavors are dry and finish with acidic freshness.

Sarsaparilla, cherry and blackberry show medium intensity on the nose. Light in feel, with juicy dark fruit flavors shot through with pomegranate acidity, the palate is supported by medium-grained tannins. A light cherry cola flavor rounds out the finish.
Soft aromas of lemon oil, dried hay and crushed stone carry the nose. The palate shows a bit more ripeness in yellow apple and grapefruit flavors, with a mild vein of acidity offering some balance.
Yeasty pear and melon aromas are basic. That could be said for the palate, which is soda-like. Mild citrus and apple flavors dry out on a finish with grassy notes.

With more Cabernet Sauvignon than Merlot, this wine has delicious black-currant flavors as well as a dry edge to the tannins from 12 months in wood. It leaves a bright, fruity aftertaste. Drink from 2021.
This wine is ripe, bright with black-currant fruit and crisp acidity. It is simple, easy and fruity. Oak aging gives a smooth character to the soft, warm wine that is ready to drink.

Bruised apple peel and very ripe, yellow pear signal ripeness and abundant fruit. While the palate is light it is similarly generous with fruit, helped along by a touch of residual sweetness. This is fruity and friendly, with an off-dry finish. Drink soon.
Candied flavors like caramel and butterscotch make this full-bodied wine seem sweet, while a lush, soft texture coats the palate.

While quiet on the nose, hints of fresh apple and blossoms are a pleasant introduction to this brisk, uncomplicated white blend. Off dry and light in body, it's an easy quaffing wine, with a fresh grapefruit finish.

Jammy red berry aromas and flavors mix with grilled herbs and are grounded by a sanguine vein. Medium in weight and structure, the acidity starts off soft but builds on the midpalate, offering a bit a levity on the finish.
Earthy berry aromas are a bit stalky and flat. This crianza is firm and choppy, but also stewed on the palate. Spicy plum and olive flavors are ordinary if not a touch underripe.

Oily aromas of orange peel are lively but imprecise. This Verdejo ranks as fruity but simple, with plumpness and citric acidity. Briny citrus flavors give off a sense of grape skins that extend onto the finish.
Reduction clings to the nose but the body is fresh and clean. This is dry and lacks a little fruit and direction but has freshness to redeem itself. The finish is dry and clean. Drink soon.
Light aromas of white flower, lemon curd and spice are followed by sleek, light fruit flavors. It's a straightforward, varietally correct wine.

Pungent pineapple aromas, along with a hint of kerosene, indicate that this will not be your standard style of Oregon Pinot Gris. The intense herbaceous character dominates, suggesting some of the stylistic terminology that might accompany a particularly biting Sauvignon Blanc. Some 10% was fermented in concrete egg.

An entry-level effort, this has thinly-ripened berry flavors, stiff tannins and acids like a squeeze of fresh lemon juice. But it is the aggressive earthy and herbal components that dominate and continue to resonate through the finish.

Powdery nectarine and orange-rind aromas comprise the nose on this tangy ros Cava with a soda-like mouthfeel. Slightly tart apricot and orange flavors show latent bitterness prior to a yeasty-tasting finish that's not that long.

A hearty 12% Cabernet Sauvignon is added to this wine, which is aged in 100% French oak. Reduced, with sizable oak influence, it shows dried herb components wrapped in bittersweet black pepper and leather.

Almost tawny in color, this wine offers aromas of red and black plum, dried fig and prune, with secondary notes of cedar and balsamic. These aromas translate onto the palate where the tannins are abundant, yet silky, and the acidity isn't shy.
This lightly perfumed wine is also crisp and fruity. Good acidity, citrus fruit and a zesty texture give freshness and a bright character. The wine is ready to drink.
Melon and kiwi aromas are a touch green. This wine feels tangy but also plump, while lemon-lime flavors give way to skins-driven bitterness. A bland finish with residual tang is direct in feel.

Smoky roast beef aromas mingle with peppercorns and black cherries on the foxy nose. The palate shows ripe cherry and cranberry, alongside cedar, pepper and sweet baking spices. The tannins provide an appealing grip, with balanced acidity and good structure. The finish kicks off on peppery spice then softens into raspberries.
This Viognier is bursting with passion fruit, honeydew, peach and elderflower aromas that carry right through to the palate. The mouthfeel is a little flimsy but there are great flavors here.

This is part of the winery's Winemaker Series, a limited production wine that was barrel-aged for 17 months in two-thirds new French oak. It remains stiff and quite astringent, with vanilla being the principal flavor. In fact, there is so much vanilla that it more or less covers most of the fruit.

Fruit for this wine comes from Block 66 of Double Canyon Vineyard in the Horse Heaven Hills. The aromas aren't entirely harmonious, with notes of dark, slightly overripe-seeming fruit along with black pepper and licorice, showing some volatility. The black-raspberry flavors are light and compact. It doesn't come together.
Despite the excellent vintage this is just barely ripe, with green notes among generic red fruits. Tannins are stiff, and a hint of butter runs through the finish. Nothing really jells.

This blend of 79% Shiraz and 21% Mourvdre is dense and concentrated, with deep notes of all-fruit preserves, raspberry sauce and licorice. The palate offers more decadence in waves of fudgy brownie and candied cherry, while the thick and chewy tannins lend some serious grip and a firm texture. Drink now.

Mild fruit aromas are crowded by peanut and burnt-wood notes. This Viura-led blend is full and round on the palate, with forceful flavors of nutty stone fruits, sea brine and wood resin. A lean, acidic palate is better in feel than weak flavors.

This wine is straightforward in its ripe melon and citrus aromas, which carry to the lightly concentrated palate. There's something enjoyable about its simple, fruit-driven nature that makes it an easy wine to sip on.

Aromas reminiscent of a struck match and a whiff of medicinal herb lead the nose. The palate is on the lean side, offering yellow-apple skin, lemon zest and a taste of bitter walnut alongside continuous lively bubbles.

This wine comes from a small 12-acre vineyard. Black-currant fruits and firm tannins keep the wine structured while maintaining a crisp character. The wine is simple, fruity and will be ready to drink from 2020.

Predominately Uva di Troia, with additions of Aglianico and Montepulciano, this blend shows aromas of peanut skins over crushed bramble berries and violets. The palate is light in feel, tart berries are zesty and bolstered by drying, grippy tannins. Racy acidity cuts this short but makes it a food-friendly wine.

A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Malbec and Petit Verdot, this has aromas that bring notes of black licorice and cherry, along with light oxidative notes. It's a shame, as good things are happening on the palate.

Slightly reductive aromas of wet clay and sour olive meet with dark cranberry fruit and camphor on the nose of this bottling. The palate is tart with raspberry and orange rind and gains complexity from the forest moss and wet wood flavors.

While the nose is earthen and mineral, the palate of this light-bodied blend of Silvaner and Riesling offers pleasant lemon and green melon refreshment. It's a juicy, uncomplicated sip, with subtle sweetness and a brisk finish. Drink now.
A good blast of black cherry and cedar in the aroma is followed by rich, grapey flavors on a moderately firm texture. It is softened by a hint of sweetness on the finish.

Red- and black-plum aromas dominate the nose, with layers of coffee, kirsch and geranium in the background. A coffee tone starts off on the palate, moving to cranberry, grape and plum flavors. Zippy acidity matches the full body to create a nice balance.

It's not apparent what's going on with this wine, which tastes disjointed and aggressively stemmy. Its fruit is thin and generic, plain red berries, with a whiff of compost. But the impact of stems (whole clusters?) is what dominates. Two bottles tasted with equal results.
Aromas are light and dominated by barrel notes, including vanilla and coconut. The black-fruit flavors are sweet and rich, showing quite a bit of warmth. It doesn't all add up.
Despite the excellent vintage this is just barely ripe, with green notes among generic red fruits. Tannins are stiff, and a hint of butter runs through the finish. Nothing really jells.

This blend of 79% Shiraz and 21% Mourvdre is dense and concentrated, with deep notes of all-fruit preserves, raspberry sauce and licorice. The palate offers more decadence in waves of fudgy brownie and candied cherry, while the thick and chewy tannins lend some serious grip and a firm texture. Drink now.

Mild fruit aromas are crowded by peanut and burnt-wood notes. This Viura-led blend is full and round on the palate, with forceful flavors of nutty stone fruits, sea brine and wood resin. A lean, acidic palate is better in feel than weak flavors.

At just 10% alcohol and 22 g/l residual sugar, you might expect a fruity wine with a fair amount of sweetness, which indeed is what you get. Simple fruit flavors of apple and melon come with a slightly granular sugary finish.

Lemon peel aromas take on a slightly savory cheese-rind like tone on the nose. The palate offers richness from oak, displaying toasted nut flavors over lemon and apple. The oak seems a bit disjointed, throwing the fruit tones off balance.

Saucy plum and cherry syrup aromas turn brighter and cleaner on the medium-bodied palate. A bit of sweet spice kicks in on the midpalate, but ultimately this is primary, soft in feel and straightforward.

Canned peas taking center stage over grapefruit and white flowers in an interesting mix of aromas. There's decent weight to the palate, with bright acidity to boot, yet the flavors are subdued and focus on the citrus and herbal elements.
This wine shows mealy apple, margarine and nut aromas on the nose. The flavors are similar yet the mouthfeel is easy-going and pleasing.
Sweet-tart red cherry and berry flavors are plump and juicy in this fresh, easy drinking Dornfelder. It's not a complicated wine but balanced in sweetness and acidity. Drink now.

This Merlot shows aromas and flavors of bright cherry, red plum and baking spices. The fruit comes off as tart on the palate but the oak spices are appealing. Not much tannic expression but a nice acidic lift keeps the finish going strong.

Wild-berry aromas are muted and a shade green on the nose. Cassis, wild raspberry and tart cranberry flavors are at odds with cedar, cinnamon and oak influences. Lacking focus, crushed velvet tannins attempt to pull everything together, riding into a tangy finish.

Violet, blueberry and cedar aromas ride over a rubbery tone. Mild acidity struggles to keep jammy pomegranate and cranberry flavors in check, while structured tannins and white-pepper flavors tingle on the tongue.

Subdued aromas of underbrush, moist soil, chopped herb and a whiff of red berry appear in the glass. The simple light-bodied palate shows suggestions of sour cherry and white pepper alongside loose fleeting tannins. Drink now.
This opens with earthy aromas of black-skinned fruit, tilled soil and a hint of crushed black olive. The aromas carry over to the extremely simple palate alongside round tannins.

Viognier above 16% alcohol is really pushing the boundaries of ripeness, and it results in a rather flat-tasting wine with one-dimensional fruit flavors and nothing else. Peaches and melon, with a hint of citrus rind come through, but how do you match this to food?

Made in Montana with grapes from Yakima Valley, this wine shows aromas of tangerine, white peach and honeysuckle. The palate is juicy in ripe lime, fresh apricot and blossom tones, with enough acidity for balance. The finish is brief and peachy.
Spiced fruit cake aromas dominate the nose and carry to the medium-bodied, approachable palate. This is simple and straightforward with everything in balanceperfect for everyday enjoyment.

An atypical variety for such a southern region, this Pinot Grigio shows some semblance to its brethren in the north, with apple, citrus and blossom tones, yet its missing all of the vibrancy and verve from a lack of acidity. Nevertheless, it's a perfectly clean and simple drink.

A dark color and damp aromas of raisin lack freshness. Overall, this wine is stewed and oaky, with a heavy palate that's showing salty oak-driven berry and prune flavors. It's missing in balance and finishes with persistent saltiness.

Reticent on the nose in aromas of struck flint, citrus and pollen, these notes carry to a astringent palate of apple and citrus. Medium in weight, there's just enough mouthwatering acidity to maintain freshness.
Aromas of soda water, peach and melon lead to broad, dry, slightly viscous fruit flavors. It's an unusual interpretation of this variety.

Rubbery dark-fruit aromas come with cheesy oak scents. This basic Toro has a sticky, saucy mouthfeel bolstered by tartaric acidity. Short, oaky berry flavors are chocolaty, while the finish offers mostly residual oak notes.
Medium cherry in color, this wine offers aromas of blackberry, cassis and smoked meat. Flavors of black cherry, flint and game never quite coalesce, dropping off into a soft sage-tinged finish.

This wine offers candied citrus aromas and flavors, with a chalky fruitiness reminiscent of crushed vitamins on the palate. It has mild acidity but is a little flimsy in feel. The finish is long and sour.
This opens with earthy aromas of black-skinned fruit, tilled soil and a hint of crushed black olive. The aromas carry over to the extremely simple palate alongside round tannins.

Viognier above 16% alcohol is really pushing the boundaries of ripeness, and it results in a rather flat-tasting wine with one-dimensional fruit flavors and nothing else. Peaches and melon, with a hint of citrus rind come through, but how do you match this to food?

Made in Montana with grapes from Yakima Valley, this wine shows aromas of tangerine, white peach and honeysuckle. The palate is juicy in ripe lime, fresh apricot and blossom tones, with enough acidity for balance. The finish is brief and peachy.
Barrel fermented for 10 months, this wine, now three years past its vintage, remains awkward and oaky. Flavors of wood and butter dominate, with light generic fruit well in the background.

Ultraripe cherry and blackberry aromas are covered in a sheen of dark chocolate on the nose of this Negroamaro, Primitivo and Malvasia Nero blend. The medium-bodied palate turns more jammy in baked strawberry and cherry flavors, with grainy tannins and just enough acidity for balance.

A largely neutral nose hints at papaya and melon. This Viura is lean in feel, with lemony acidity. Generic nectarine and melon flavors flatten out on a finish that's showing early-onset oxidation. Drink right away for best results.
Baked berry and sweet spice aromas dominate the nose, while toasted oak tones arise on the palate. Medium in weight and light in concentration, crisp acidity keeps this refreshing, but short.

A dark purple color and aromas of blackberry, creamy oak and pencil lead to a raw, pulling palate that's thick but also high in tartaric acidity. Grainy oak and mocha flavors make a louder statement than does the fruit.
Toasty and woody, this wine is currently dominated by the wood aging, leaving little space for the juicy red fruits in the background. It will soften and should be less aggressive from 2019.

Stalky aromas of earthy plum and burnt leaves are not fully ripe. A choppy, gritty palate holds saucy flavors of salted plum, tomato and herbs. A short finish with herbal notes is appropriate. The blend holds Garnacha, Carignan and Syrah.

Scents of wet hay and overripe raisined fruit don't mislead: those are also the flavors. Some tarragon and citrus is in view, but overall it's disjointed and seems already well on the way to being over the hill.

Mild aromas of green apple and lemon have a grassy undercurrent, yet the palate is surprisingly lush in flavors of canned peach and mandarin. The finish is rubbery, with notes of lime pith and orange-blossom honey.

Aromas of ripe black-skinned fruit, violet and a whiff of wet leather lead the nose. The palate starts off with fleshy black cherry and a hint of clove then but quickly falls apart thanks to loose, fleeting tannins.

Made entirely with organically farmed Sangiovese, this has delicate aromas suggesting wild berry and blue flower. The fresh, simple palate offers hints of Marasca cherry and raspberry alongside bright acidity.
Pale lemon and thyme aromas precede a very buttery flavor in this split-personality wine. It is medium bodied, crisp at first sip but turns butterscotchy on the palate.

Flowery, yeasty aromas are also soapy and buttery, which makes sense given that this is overly mature and was brought up in oak barrels. Moderate acidity means balance is fleeting, and the wine tastes of stale stone fruits and yeast.
Despite the landmark vintage, this wine seems thin, under-ripe, and rife with green stem and herb flavors. The tannins are substantial, hard and bitter, effectively blocking out the finish.
The Noir is an equal blend of co-fermented Gamay Noir, Pinot Noir and Trousseau Noir. An interesting experiment, but it emerges with a bitterness around barely ripe flavors of rhubarb and pink berry.

Raw, herbal, oaky aromas include notes of Navajo sage stick and oak-driven clove. This wine is 85% Monastrell with Syrah, and it feels grabby, tannic and oaky. Creamy oak flavors are soupy, while this wine is plump, chewy and tastes of forced oak on the finish.

This wine is half Syrah with the rest equal parts Pinot Noir and Tempranillo. Aromas are locked up on first pour, only revealing high-toned notes of barrel spice. Over time, notes of candied raspberry, black licorice and dried cherry start to emerge. The palate brings plump red- and black-fruit flavors. Cranberry notes linger on the finish.
This wine, with its light structure and ripe red-berry flavors, is all fruit. It has stalky tannins and plenty of acidity and crispness. It's light, fruity and ready to drink.

Cidery apple aromas are yeasty and powdery. This is regular in feel, without much body or depth. Basic flavors of lemon-lime and apple juice are sugary, while this showslightly oxidized flavors on the finish.

A fruity blend of Cerceal, Bical and Encruzado, this easy, fruity wine is tangy, full of citrus and orange zest and refreshing. Acidity and crisp flavors are balanced by ripe yellow fruits and an attractive perfumed edge. Drink now.

Funky aromas of moist underbrush, tilled soil, new leather and game carry over to the rather muddled palate along with black cherry extract, a green note of powdered sage and a hint of clove. Dusty fleeting tannins leave a drying grainy finish.
This soft, semisweet Dornfelder is a candied swirl of cherry-cola, vanilla and chocolate flavors. It's a plush, easy wine for early consumption.

Toast, cured meat and roasted herb aromas come to the forefront. On the vivacious palate, dried sage and toasted walnut underscore yellow apple while lively acidity and vigorous bubbles provide the aggressive setting.
This dessert-style wine is quite flavorful and sweet, from the aroma of apple cider and toasted nuts to flavors of golden raisins and honey. It has an almost thick texture and syrupy finish.

This wine is a blend of Sauvignon Blanc (61%), Smillon (23%), Riesling (12%) and Albario. The aromas are a bit faint, with notes of herb, fig, pear and soda water that don't seem entirely in sync. The palate brings broad, dry flavors that come up short.
This wine has soft tannins and juicy red fruits. It is ripe, with a gentle texture, bright fruitiness and enough tannins to give the fruit their support. Drink this attractive wine now.

The aromas are oak dominated, with notes of vanilla extract, coconut, dill, spearmint and freshly hewn wood, with the fruit struggling to get to the surface. There's a soft, pleasing feel to the palate but the wood again gets in the way. The fruit is hard to find.
Viognier can turn sharp and bitter, as it hints at here. The flavors emphasize green botanicals, lime skin and pith. It's definitely on the less-than-optimal side of ripe for this difficult grape.
An outlier grape for southern Italy, this Pinot Nero is primary in its ripe cherry and raspberry flavors. It's light, bright and juicy nature make it an easy-drinking selection.

Aromas of cranberry, cherry pie and baking spice are inviting on the nose. The palate brings more cranberry and cherry, joined by ripe, juicy pomegranate. Gentle tannins slowly emerge while the tart acidity lightens the baked quality of the fruit flavors. Tart fruit tones linger on the finish, with clove and a final grip of tannin.
This wine seems awkwardthere is no other way to put it. Unintegrated, lumbery oak flavors jut out in front of brambly berry fruit. Nothing hangs together and the oak treatment is rough and outsized.

Soupy raisin and prune aromas are earthy and sleepy. This feels a lot like prune juice, but with tannins. Prune is also the sole flavor on this overripe but still decent gran reserva from a hot vintage.
A good amount of fruit concentration gives this medium-bodied wine likeable aromas and flavors, while a soft smooth texture and a dab of sweetness make it easy on the palate.

At this stage, the wood-aging component of this wine dominates the gentle black fruits. An element of high toast and black-chocolate extraction flavors give bitterness. It seems this wine will always have a hard edge.

Dark, jammy fruit aromas are at the core of this otherwise oak-driven wine. Baking spice flavors of vanilla and cocoa powder are prominent and not entirely integrated with the baked fruit character. Medium weight and soft acidity make this an easy-drinking sipper.
There's a great deal of oak covering the red berry aromas on the nose. The medium-bodied palate shows a bit more integration, melding dark cherry and blackberry flavors with baking spice.
Ripe red berry and plum aromas are covered in a sheen of vanilla and cocoa in this Negroamaro-dominant wine. Medium in weight, with a soft feel, enjoy this with hard cheeses.
Plenty of grapey, jammy aromas and flavors fill this medium-bodied wine to the rim. It is lightly sweet, very fruity, and smooth and soft in texture.
Delicate apple, pear and mineral flavors give a fruity but lean personality to this light-bodied wine. It makes good, basic refreshment.
Intensely savory notes of crushed earth and pollen juxtapose prettier red apple and tangerine. While rustic in style, its light body and subtle tangerine sweetness offers approachable refreshment.

This 50-50 blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Malvasia is a bit closed on the nose. The palate offers more in its juicy melon and apple flavors, with a hint of florals in the background. This is light in weight and intensity, yet perfect for the price.

The winery's white wines are extraordinarily high in alcohol, which inevitably blows out any subtleties and varietal character. This is thick, fruity, almost syrupy, with principal flavors of canned peaches.

The label suggests that this is done in a sweeter style, though it's principally the superripe fruit that you taste. Round and simple, with flavors of peaches, it doesn't deliver the aromatics or the flavor complexity of most Oregon Rieslings.

Volatile aromas get things off to a difficult start, with a burning sensation and a touch of vinegar. Thin berry fruit and a hint of vanilla wafer come across in the mouth. Two bottles tasted. Drink up.

Soft scents of white flowers, pear and peach subtly make themselves known on the nose of this direct wine. It's lightweight and approachable, with ripe-fruit and sweet-orange flavors that flesh out the palate. Drink now.
Pleasant white-fruit aromas are simple. This has a fresh but highly basic mouthfeel. Melony flavors come with green pyrazine notes, while this is dilute on the finish.

This golden oak-aged Airn smells almost entirely of wood grain and vanilla. On the palate, it's resiny to an extreme. Flavors of raw wood and coconut are devoid of fruit, while this tastes like liquid oak on the finish.

Tropical fruit and sucking-candy aromas are inoffensive and lively. This varietal Merseguera is texturally pulpy but also zippy due to high acidity and only 12% abv. Lime and lychee flavors finish quickly.

Heavily charred aromas suggest a steak or hamburger left on the grill for too long. In the mouth, this is compact and boxed in by rock-hard tannins. Like the nose, this young Toro tastes burnt and grilled. Flavors of black coffee and clove dominate an oak-driven finish.

A light straw color, with a hint of tawny skin, this is a blocky, simple and fruity style, high in alcohol with flavors of peaches. There isn't much to it beyond that one-dimensional fruit, and it finishes short and quick.
Raisiny, saucy aromas are slightly volatile. A wide, saturated palate comes up short on focus and acidity, while a mix of raisin and green-herb flavors lands on a heavy finish.

A strong, smoky aroma and equally obvious oak flavors dominate this very full-bodied and fairly smooth-textured wine that was aged in whiskey barrels. It's a one-note song, recommended for people who really like that note.
Stalky cherry and berry aromas announce a lean, tart palate with a texture influenced by grape skins. Plum and currant flavors are thin, and this is earthy, tangy and low on ripeness on the finish.

A nose with mild citrus and banana aromas is indicative of the fleshy but basic wine that follows. Dry flavors of peach pit are slightly bitter, and it's dull on the finish. This wine marks Cuatro Rayas's 40th year.
Nectarine and orange aromas are basic and yeasty. A peachy, pulpy palate with flavors of orange and bitter grape skins loses fruit rapidly on the finish.
This wine is somewhat dull in texture and elusive in fruit, offering a strong sense of oak and sulfur.

The nose of this wine is melony and chunky, with a touch of oak. The palate feels solid enough but still a bit mushy, while dry, creamy flavors of tropical fruits are diffuse in front of a finish that's low in verve.
This wine is already past its prime. The blend of Mller-Thurgau, Viognier and Moscato is interesting, but the fruit is fading into a simple, lightly peachy syrup, with a hint of plastic. Drink now.
Briny, wayward aromas of grape skins and yeast are funky and unfocused. This Verdejo has a pulpy, soft mouthfeel and flat white-fruit flavors that turn bitter on the finish.
This dense and rich wine is dominated by dark-chocolate flavors of excessive extraction and bitterness. The fruit is hard to find in this wine that will probably remain tough.

With aromas of petrol and spearmint, this wine has flavors of lemon-lime and eucalyptus that do not feel completely integrated. Citrus and minty flavors fight for dominance on the palate, with cooling herb flavors overpowering the finish.
A dull gold tint and steamrolling barrel aromas announce an oak-heavy wine that's tight, resiny and high in acid. Woody flavors of salted apricot echo on the finish.

This medium-bodied straightforward wine has good fruit flavors and a few hints of black pepper and tobacco to keep it interesting. The texture is smooth and only a light touch of tannin shows through.

As most Methven Pinots are estate grown, it's not entirely clear what distinguishes this from the others. What it does show, rather agressively, are aromas of leather. Those same flavors render the wine thin, astringent and bitter, amplifying the drying tannins.
Rough, rubbery aromas suggest road tar. This Monastrell feels clumsy and hollow. Raw, slightly weedy berry flavors are green and minty on a chewy finish.
A serious commitment to wood aging has given this wine a dark-chocolate and extracted set of flavors. This masks the wine, which seems almost austere. It will likely remain tough.

This Sauvignon Blanc has little to no varietal character. The nose is quiet, with just a hint of peach. A round palate shows almost no acidity, while this tastes peachy and yeasty prior to a pulpy finish.
This wine has respectable but generic fruit flavors, a soft texture and a touch of sugar to round off its edges. It is light to medium bodied and tastes low in acidity.
This wine is severe in acidity, with a somewhat jarring lack of fruit. Butterscotch and melted butter develop in the glass for a lingering richness.

Pushy oak and heavy clove aromas seem excessive for this level of Garnacha. A rough, grating palate leads to oak-heavy flavors of clove and blackberry, while a persistent flavor of oak-driven clove controls the finish.
Prickly citrus aromas include notes of white flowers. Yeasty grapefruit and lime flavors are bland and short, while this ends flat, yeasty and lightly oxidized.
This Tinta de Toro smells like a cherry Lifesaver. In the mouth, there's not much body or substance. Candied blackberry and cassis flavors are medicinal and jammy on the finish.
Jammy, baked aromas are raisiny and slightly volatile. This blend of 85% Monastrell and Syrah is heavy and soupy, with dull edges. Herbal prune and raisin flavors are raw and green on the finish.

This pale-colored wine, a blend of Tinta Francisca and Tinta Roriz, was aged in wood for eight months. That was probably too long, for the fruit has been sucked into the wood, leaving a trail of acidity behind.
Made entirely from Merlot, this sweet pink wine might pass for a simple white Zinfandel. The sugary sweetness comes with light flavors of cherry Kool-Aid.

Stalky aromas of citrus peel are stale and mostly fruitless. A full, flat palate indicates a wine that has lost its youthful freshness, offering bitter apricot flavors and a finish that's low on acidity.

The nose of this Marquette is all spice and jammy dark berries, with whiffs of Luxardo cherries. The rounded palate shows warm, baked cranberry, blackberry, blueberry sauce and cedar. Soft tannins lend structure and quiet acidity teeters on the edge of flabby, finishing on cassis and a woody tang.
Rubbery, medicinal berry aromas smell like Pepto-Bismol. A chunky palate is big and blocky, with no elegance or charm. Candied, grapy flavors finish hard and scratchy.
A light color and yeasty aromas of sourdough and dusty white fruits are the greeting on this modest white made from Chardonnay, Viura and Moscatel. Flavors of lime are yeasty and finish bitter.

Stalky aromas are more rough and fruitless than smooth and clean. This brut reserva foams up on the palate and feels clumsy. Briny flavors suggest white pepper but not much fruit, and it's grassy-tasting on the finish.
Tropical fruit aromas are soft and syrupy. This is chunky and low in acidity, with oily stone-fruit flavors. The finish feels a bit warm and cloying.
Strange, yeasty aromas suggest boiled ham and buttercup. This feels full and fleshy, with low acidity. It tastes like it smells: yeasty and much like ham, with little fruit.
Chunky oak rests heavily atop aromas of stale white fruits and nuts. This is obtuse in feel, with stalky, oaky flavors that are largely devoid of fresh fruit.

This Demeter certified blend of Uva di Troia and Montepulciano carries odd aromas of peanut skins, asparagus and saucy, sour red fruit. The palate offers a bit more enjoyment with its more fruit-forward nature, bracing acidity and abrasive tannins carrying to the finish.
This blend of Tempranillo, Petite Sirah, Mourvdre and Syrah is thin and leathery. It's already dried out and not heading in a better direction. Two bottles sampled with the same results. Drink up.
This wine is slightly bittersweet and off-putting, with a dullness to the texture.
Melony aromas are neutral at best. A pulpy, citric palate holds briny orange flavors that don't show a lot of depth or quality. It falls apart on the finish.

Blatant aromas of milk chocolate and candied-berry fruits amount to a soupy, heavy, jammy nose. This Monastrell feels choppy and broken. Saucy berry flavors are loaded with oak and clove notes, while this wine tastes like chocolate and feels hot on the finish.
This offers light aromas of yeasty white flowers and lemon-lime. The palate is weak, while generic white-fruit flavors fall off quickly and taste oxidized on a bready finish.
Not even close to ripe, with not varietal character, this tart, herbal and stemmy wine just doesn't click.
Scents of pumpkin, pyrazines and general murkiness lead to a dilute palate. Fruitless flavors of onion and lime finish bitter and with notes of green peppercorn.
Weathered wood and sawdust aromas are drab. That palate is rounded by flavors of vanilla, oak planks and cherry. Lacking acidity, this finishes flat and oaky.

Many years in bottle haven't done much for this briary wine with weedy aromas of field greens and spice. A choppy palate with uncontrolled acidity is less than comfortable, while the finish offers nothing but rawness and tannins.
Aromas of confected orange and molasses are joined by a rubbery note. The palate is sugary, with flavors of candied orange, lychee and dried pineapple, finishing with peach syrup and latex.
This wine is extreme in bay leaf and green, herbal flavors, with a touch of oxidation.
This funky, skunky Cava smells stale and slightly rotten. A weedy flavor profile offers no help, while this tastes pickled on the finish.
Aromas suggest pine oil, pineapple and mango syrup. This wine is shapeless, tasting oddly of rose water and flavored tea. The finish is deficient.

Intense aromas of potpourri mask cedar and red currant on the nose. Tart cranberry and cedar create a sour palate, while gritty tannins feel disjointed. The finish brings underripe flavors of raspberry and cedar.

Funky grapefruit and passion fruit aromas are uncommon and not appealing. This white Grenache is wide but spread thin, with no focal point to the palate. Bitter, weedy citrus flavors don't improve on a finish with a dominant green character.

This isn't just a great wine for what was a notoriously cool, wet vintage, it's quite simply a magnificent wine. Perfumed and loaded with finesse, it opens with scents of woodland berry, iris and baking spice while the vibrant, balanced palate doles out Marasca cherry, dark culinary spice, crushed herb and menthol. Refined tannins and fresh acidity provide the taut framework while a licorice note wraps around the finish. Gorgeous. Drink 20222034.

A hallmark expression of Nebbiolo, Produttori del Barbaresco's 2013 Rabaj Riserva offers aromas of wild red berry, menthol, Alpine herb, saddle leather and dark culinary spice. The concentrated palate boasts enviable finesse and is practically weightless in the mouth, showing crushed black cherry, juicy raspberry, orange zest, clove and licorice alongside firm, velvety tannins. Bright acidity provides impeccable balance. Drink 20212033.

Enticing scents of wild berry, rose, baking spice and balsamic aromas come together in the glass. Juicy and full-bodied, the flavorsome palate shows succulent Morello cherry, cranberry, licorice and ground white pepper alongside a backbone of vibrant acidity and firm, polished tannins. It's already exceptional but will benefit with more aging. Drink 20202038.

Intense scents of cherry, star anise and iris float out of the glass. It's firmly structured and loaded with finesse, offering crushed raspberry, Marasca cherry, cinnamon and star anise framed fine-grained tannins. Bright acidity lends balance and energy.

Forest berry, chopped mint, clove and new leather aromas take center stage on this elegant, full-bodied red. The savory, smooth palate doles out succulent red cherry, raspberry compote and licorice while vibrant acidity and tightly knit, refined tannins provide balance and support. It has great energy and is loaded with flavor but will be even better with a few more years aging. Drink 20202038.

Vintner Austin Hope, whose family is intertwined in the rise of Paso Robles, spent years working to release a wine of this caliber. Dark and thick in the glass, aromas of black currant and blueberry meet with roasted coffee, chocolate syrup and baked plum on the wondrous nose. The palate is soft and extremely expressive, with blueberry, black pepper, firm midpalate tannins and a finish that's redolent of cappuccino candies.

Red berry, blue flower, crushed herb and exotic spice aromas unfold in the glass. Elegant, structured and delicious, the full-bodied palate delivers red cherry and licorice, chopped mint alongside bright acidity and firm, refined tannins. It's impeccably balanced and will age gloriously. Drink 2021 -2043.

Still young but already boasting extraordinary pedigree, this fantastic wine opens with hallmark scents of wild berry, new leather, chopped herb, tilled soil and a whiff of violet. The polished, full-bodied palate delivers juicy wild cherry, crushed raspberry, white pepper and licorice while youthfully assertive, noble tannins and bright acidity provide age-worthy structure. A pipe tobacco note lingers on the finish. Drink 20232038.

A deep, velvety purple color in the glass, this bottling by proprietor Roger Bower and winemaker Adam Henkel shows dark-chocolate-covered black cherries, fresh blackberry, white pepper, violet oil, port reduction sauce and spice sake on the lavish nose. Firm tannins frame the palate, which carries black currant and roasted lean beef flavors through soy and pepper sauce into a finish of caramel and espresso grinds.

A sultry shade of dark purple, this luxury bottling by the Daou brothers shows freshly smashed black currant, gravelly minerality, black pepper, espresso and shaved chocolate on the nose. The palate is black to the core, from blueberry to dark chocolate to lava rocks, with strong yet polished tannins and wel-balanced acidity. Decant now or drink 20202035.

Wonderfully aromatic notions of blood orange zest and ripe Meyer lemon swirl on nose and palate of this wine. Its slender yet concentrated body imbues that citrus tautness with hints of richer fruitthink juicy Mirabelle plum and ripe orange. A lemon note keeps the balance firmly in the tart camp, making for a zesty, intense and clean midpalate and finish. That blood orange aroma lingers magically. Drink 20202035.

A faint, flinty touch of reduction still informs this wine's lifted citrus scents. On the palate, a taut, textured structure sends zesty lemon flavors darting across the tongue. This still needs to open up, but all the ingredients for an explosive citrus party are here. It has concentration, freshness, fruit and potential. This may become smoother but will remain beautifully slender. Drink 20202035.

Fragrant and elegant, this opens with a textbook Nebbiolo bouquet showing scents of tilled soil, rose, wild red berry, Alpine herb and a whiff of new leather. The taut, vibrant palate evokes sour cherry, juicy strawberry, licorice and clove framed in refined tannins and bright acidity. It's balanced and gorgeous but still young, so give it several more years to evolve into the beauty it's destined to become. Drink 20202033.

This wine takes a light-handed approach, allowing its soul to speak quietly in a blur of perfumed rose petal, lavender and wildflower. The expansive, velvety palate offers highlights of pomegranate, strawberry and freshly squeezed citrus, with pronounced earthy sensations of crushed rock, salt and turned earth.

This wine offers incredibly inviting aromas and a fresh, vibrant fruit-driven framework which suggests long-term potential. Youthfully gritty tannins hide beneath a forceful foundation of black raspberry, rose petal and warm baking spice, with a hint of dried herb creeping in. Enjoy 20202025.

Extremely dense in the glass, this epic bottling offers lavish and penetrating aromas of black currant and elderberry jam on the nose alongside seared beef, chocolate cake and a pinch of violet. Expertly balanced, polished tannins make for a soft mouthfeel yet firm structure, carrying flavors of black fruit, chocolate and grilled figs that lead to an espresso note on the finish.

New leather, camphor, forest berry, dried rose and culinary spice are some of the aromas you'll find on this exceptional red. The firmly structured, poised palate doles out juicy cranberry, crushed raspberry, white pepper and star anise framed in tightly-knit, refined tannins while bright acidity provides energy and balance. Drink 20202033.

This wine's shy, elusive nose promises hints of ripe citrus and herbal savor. The palate obliges with streamlined, zesty citrus notes and the salty tang of thyme and sage, surrounded by bright lemon freshness. A compact, incisive package of refreshing delight, it dances on tiptoe but knows its every step.

Deliciously crafted and full-bodied ripe, this shows dense layers of blackberry and blueberry crumble succulence and richness, well-etched flavors that are wrapped in soft integrated oak. Juicy and earthy, it offers length and breadth, the tannins roundly structured. Memorable seasonings include chocolate and clove. Enjoy best 20242034.

Four years after bottling, this vibrant, peppery red is still taut, begging for time to allow its fruit and earthen complexities to meld. Pristine black-cherry and plum flavors penetrate deeply on the palate, shaded by whispers of smoke, violet, tar and leather. It's powerful, complex wine that's yet to see its peak. Hold till 2020 at least, but it's likely to improve for another decade still.

Perfumed and meaty, this coastal wine offers strong elements of cured bacon and intense hints of smoke. The nose is additionally gorgeous in rose and dried herbes de Provence. Crisp, savory fruit gives it freshness and complexity, a succulent tartness that lingers a long time on the palate.

One of the better Chardonnays tasted in recent years from the Central Coast, this bottling by proprietor Blair Pence is both brisk and warm on the nose, with lemon balm, crushed limestone and yuzu cutting through white peach and butter. The tactile chalkiness on the sip is remarkable, carrying flavors of lime pith, Asian pear, sea salt, shaved lemongrass and lime leaf.

Dark-skinned berry, menthol, new leather, blue flower and baking spice aromas take center stage. On the radiant, full-bodied palate, vibrant acidity lifts red cherry, raspberry compote, star anise, clove and tobacco while youthfully taut, fine-grained tannins provide firm support. Hold on to this for even more complexity once it unwinds and develops. Drink 20232038.

Combining hyper-concentrated fruit flavors with enticing, sophisticated oak nuances, this wine is a gentle giant.
