On the palate the fruit is fresh and crisp, ripe but still wonderfully crunchy, just like a fine web of tannins that crunch like starched tulle. There is ample freshness, good concentration and a finely struck balance. Highly appetizing, neither light nor heavy, just right.

Cranberry, hibiscus and rosewater converge on the soft, plush nose of this bottling, which also shows hints of star anise and baked goods. It's a light and playful wine on the sip, where juicy raspberries meet with gravelly minerality. This is light, fresh and full of long, simmering acidity.

Underbrush, truffle, iris, baking spice and aromatic herb aromas all come seamlessly together on this alluring wine. The tense, savory palate delivers ripe black cherry, red berry, star anise and ground clove. Tightly knit, fine-grained tannins and bright acidity offer balance and support. Drink 20202029.

This is brooding on the nose with the allure of an elderberry aroma. The same note dominates the palate which has a smooth, sensuous body, still held tight by brisk, fine tannin and lively acidity. There is almost stealthy, surprising grip. With its ample fruit this is already enticing, but structure and freshness promise more pleasure to come. Drink 20182028.

A two-acre parcel of 84-year-old vines forms a great starting point for this intense wine. With considerable acidity as well as dark tannins, the black-currant fruit is still firmly embedded in the wine's dark core. So wait, and drink it from 2019.

A blend of 43% Grenache, 24% Mourvdre, 20% Syrah, and 13% Roussanne, the aromas show a lot of subtlety, with notes of raspberry, garrigue, stem, pepper and moist earth. The palate brings a compelling sense of texture that is absolutely swoon-worthy, running just a touch warm.

On first pour, this wine is not ready to reveal its charms, with locked-up notes of plum, herb, coffee, licorice, smoke, flower and spice. The fruit flavors are rich yet sophisticated, gliding across the palate to a lingering finish.

Baked red currants and cherries are lifted by vanilla, dewy sagebrush and hint of peppercorns on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is bright and energized with tart red fruits, but it's approachably rich and spiced with jasmine and Earl Grey tea flavors.

Berry, plum, cola and mineral aromas amount to an inviting whole. A solid yet racy palate delivers punches and jabs of herbal blackberry, plum and spice flavors. On the finish, this blend of Syrah, Carmenre, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon is generous with oak, coffee and herbal fruit flavors. Drink through 2022.

Mourvdre and Syrah each make up 40% of this blend, with the balance Grenache. The aromas draw you into the glass, with notes of garrigue, black pepper and blackberry. The palate is dense and ripe, pulling no punches but delivering a whole lot of hedonistic appeal. The value can't be beat.

A fresh, tropical whiff of passion fruit clings to the pear notes on the nose of this wine. The palate, on the other hand, is far more savory, with its textured, yeasty mouthfeel and sage and celery salt fragrance. It's soft but full-flavored.

Gritty in oak, this coastal appellation wine is bright and herbal, offering crisp, vibrant overtones of cranberry, pomegranate, strawberry and rose. A streak of fresh mint and lavender adds floral elements that contribute to its lovely profile of delicate elegance, supported by mellowed oak.

Blended with 14% Cabernet Sauvignon, then aged 18 months in 64% new French oak, this is a lovely example of the variety: velvety, with smoky undertones of oak. Milk chocolate, raspberry and wild truffle combine well on the medium-bodied palate, the finish bright and focused in acidity.

This wine's wonderfully pithy, pear-fruited nose hints at once at freshness and depth. The palate honors this with pristine, ripe pear notes and lovely, fragrant lemony depth. Everthing about this brims with pear and Mandarin fruit, concluding in a refreshing citrusy finish.

Jammy blackberry, prune, tobacco and oak-grain aromas lead to a flush, chewy and balanced palate, with just enough natural acidity to make things nice. Blackberry and toasty oak flavors include notes of mocha and exotic spices, while this is rich, dense and balanced across a full-bodied finish. Drink through 2021.

Subtle, nuanced aromas of freshly dried grass, yellow flower and beeswax mingle with notes of honeydew rind, apple skin and Asian pear on the nose of this delicate and superbly balanced wine. The palate boasts a bit more forward-fruit and concentration, with loads of baked apple, honeycomb and toasted nut flavors. A salted butter character and a hint of savory umami unfold on the enduring finish, lending lift and intrigue. Drink now2023.

Rich in green apple and fig, this wine offers medium-bodied weight and breadth and grainy acidity. From the famous site planted to densely concentrated berries, it's fleshy and textured, with plenty of complexity from spice and oak.

A big wine that's unabashedly oaky, this one sports a delicious, spicy, toasty, and lightly smoky character from the first whiff through the densely packed flavors and then continues to linger on the finish. The texture is dense, soothingly tannic, and coats the tongue and sides of the mouth with spiciness as well as ripe berry and new leather accents.

Pence is one of the few producers growing and making Gamay in California, and they're setting quite a standard. Aromas of red cherry, cola, hibiscus, pomegranate, fennel and cracked pepper lead into a lightly bodied palate full of airy berry fruit, juniper and licorice spice. Quite refreshing and just complex enough.

Whiffs of violet and red raspberry perfume this charming, vibrantly fruity wine. While lavish and full bodied, it's balanced neatly with tart blackberry acidity and finely textured tannins. It's lovely already but likely to maintain well through 2025.

There's a surprising amount of depth and complexity to this wine, given it's price tag. Initial minty, earthy aromas give way to a core of crme de cassis, blackberry and black plum fruit. The medium-weight palate is plush and creamy, with concentrated black-fruit flavors that are framed by a solid tannic structure. Hints of char, tobacco and cigar-box spice unfold on the finish. It should hold well through 2022, but it's an absolute pleasure to drink now.

Vanilla, honeysuckle and grapefruit are shaded in savory shades of earth, pollen and nuts in this creamy, full-bodied Viognier. It's a hefty, concentrated wine with soft acidity but hints of lemon and orange peel brighten a lingering finish.

In 1966 when this wine was first made, the best of the large barrels was No 5, and the name has stuck. It is a rich wine, full of firm tannins with the potential of fine fruit to follow. With its dark structure and acidity it needs to age a few months more. Drink this rich wine from late 2018.

The nose gives very little away. While the palate also still needs to unfold and blossom, it shows all of the elements needed for successful development. Ample freshness and a fine tannic grip showcase the beautifully pure red berry fruit. A beautifully understated and elegant wine, drink 20192028.

This wine's combination of ivy leaf and golden pear scents makes for a highly seductive nose. On the palate, bright, ripe lemon takes center stage. It lends an appetizing accent of freshness that complements the yeasty texture of the concentrated midpalate.

Very elegant aromas of black plum, black cherry and black currant meet with bay leaf and mint on the deep nose of this blend of 61% Syrah and 39% Grenache. It's soft on the palate, with a cohesive flavor profile that pairs deep berry flavors with pepper and dried herbs. The Syrah is well tamed, proving mellow and soft overall.

Pale pink in color, this is a pitch-perfect ros, with aromas of watermelon, pink grapefruit, rose petal and lemon rind. There is great zip to the palate and a chalky texture, carrying fresh but tight red-fruit flavors. It will please New World and Old World fans alike.

One sniff gives this away as real-deal Carmenre, meaning it's spicy, foxy and fruity, but also herbal and piquant. A deep, firm palate is well cushioned and in balance. This pours on dark flavors of peppery blackberry prior to a toasty finish. If any wine captures the essence of Peumo Carmenre, this is it. Drink through 2022.

Jumpy berry aromas include notes of juniper and oaky maple. Once this settles, what you have is a fully extracted Syrah with a rich but balanced palate. Spiced plum and wild berry flavors are powerful but show restraint, while this shows savory flavors of dark fruits, olive and spice on the finish.

From a historic vineyard, this Chardonnay is quite Burgundian in style, showing much potential for this grape in Paso Robles. Reserved aromas of lemon rind, vanilla shavings and cashew are quite fresh, while the palate drives the middle road, with tight grapefruit rind and mandarin pith flavors on one side and plumeria and guava on the other. Chalky texture throughout.

Floral aromas of violet petal blend with berry and cassis notes to form a fruity pleasant nose. This blend of 60% Carmenre and 40% Malbec features tight tannins that create a downward pull on the palate. Baked plum and spice flavors are fairly straightforward on a lasting finish. Drink through 2023.

Coming from a vineyard that is increasingly establishing its prominence, fruit-forward aromas of plum, boysenberry, dried herb, spice and moist earth are followed by saturated sumptuous blue and red-fruit flavors. It's undeniable in its appeal at a price that can't be beat.

Subtle aromas of exotic spice, crushed herb and wild berry slowly unfold in the glass. The austere, medium-bodied palate offers sour cherry, pomegranate and star anise set against bright acidity and tightly knit, close-grained tannins. It needs time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 20202033.

Planted on the granite soil typical of the region, the vines behind this wine give a textured, mineral character to the black fruits. That makes this a rich wine, although one that needs to be aged. Drink this concentrated wine from late 2018.

Deep tannins mark out this structured wine. A dense texture dominates the young black fruit. This will change, because the fruit is as powerful as the tannins. The wine will age well; drink from 2019.

Fresh lemon, grapefruit and apple flavors are embellished with decadent swirls of vanilla, spice and cream in this lavish white blend. It's silky smooth, almost creamy, in texture, but balanced neatly by sunny tangerine acidity and hints of dusty minerals.

Harvested at night to keep freshness, this wine comes from 35-year-old vines. It has a fruity character, bright with red-cherry acidity and a rounded, smooth texture. The edge of tannins and intense acidity make it a food wine. Drink from mid-2018.

Schist rocks in the Les Charmes vineyard give this wine its rich mineral character. Along with that are tannins both from the fruit and the wood aging, making this a rich wine that needs to age. Drink from 2019.

Owner Jacky Gauthier has produced a rich wine from low-yielding vines. The tannins and dark, firm texture are both rich and well placed to support the black-plum and berry fruits. This ripe wine will be ready to drink from late 2018.

Old vines and 10 months in wood have given this wine both concentration and great elegance. Ripe berry fruits have been smoothed by hints of toast, balanced acidity and ripe tannins. Drink this wine from mid-2018.

Earthy, gamy notes accentuate muted tones of strawberry leather and dried plum in this rustic but elegant wine. Ripe and rich on the palate, it extends long through a delicately tannic, cocoa-dusted finish.

Ripe black fruits and generous tannins give this wine richness and dense texture. It is aged for seven months in wood, adding a caramel and toast character to the generous fruit. The wine is packed with fruit and ready to drink.

Aged in large wooden barrels, this wine is dense, with a firm texture and juicy, crisp black-currant fruit. Bright acidity gives a lively aftertaste, although the structure remains firm and the wine needs to age. Drink from 2019.

The Tte family is well known in Beaujolais. Here they have produced a richly textured wine with just the right amount of tannin and acidity to highlight the generous red fruits. Drink this wine from late 2018.

This wine is on the edge, complex in white pepper and cool-climate characteristics of dried herb and leather. Brawny and full-bodied, it's also bright in underlying acidity, with plenty of elusive power.

Ngociant Florent Descombe has produced a range of cru Beaujolais, including this one. Sourced from vines on the slope of Moulin--Vent, it is firm and packed with tannins. There is no compromise in the rich structure that permeates the ripe black fruit. Drink from 2019.

Heady scents of pressed violet, tilled soil, perfumed berry, new leather and a balsamic note of camphor flow out of the glass. Vibrant and linear, the medium-bodied palate evokes juicy Marasca cherry, ripe raspberry, licorice and crushed mint framed in taut, refined tannins. Bright acidity lends balance. Drink through 2026.

Cool black-fruit aromas are solid, a bit oaky and show nothing that's unnecessary. A fully extracted palate with moderately hard tannins is where you'll find herbal black-fruit flavors along with tobacco and spice notes. A dry finish is firm and peppery. Drink through 2023.

Among the winery's larger offerings, this wine doesn't hold back on quality, offering tight-grained tannin expression around rounded flavors of plum compote, blackberry bramble, cedar and clove. Bright, focused acidity tempers the ripeness and underlying richness, making for a welcome drinking experience.

This blends 65% Cabernet Sauvignon with 35% Merlot, the two playing well against each other to provide a broad soft expanse of decadent flavor. Cherry, plum, vanilla and well-integrated oak make it round and opulent, with a fleshiness that persists through a lengthy finish.
Chocolate mocha caramel flavors contribute a deep sense of richness in they approachable, well-rounded wine, a testament to the appellation's dusty nature and embrace of black cherry.

Friendly ripe yellow pear notes perfume the nose of this wine. That generous fruitiness continues on the rounded, pear-driven and juicy palate. The body is cushioned with all of this fruit but remains streamlined and bright thanks to vivid lemon notes.

This wine is pretty in honeysuckle and honeycomb aromas, featuring beautifully resolved acidity in a dry, welcoming context. Spicy lemon is bracing before it mellows, allowing room for green apple and pear.

This dramatic and inky-colored wine has tight aromas of pencil lead, blackberry and mint followed by extremely concentrated flavors like berries, black cherries and black pepper, but with lighter floral accents, too. The structure is huge due to very firm tannins and robust alcohol, so the wine needs time to mellow. Best after 2022.

The nose of this wine just hints at lemon, but the palate is brimming with fruit. Its lemon sherbet and yellow plum notes are boosted by a dollop of residual sweetness and countered by a zesty freshness that helps it finish dry. A lovely, fruity and very refreshing wine.

Very fresh and crisp on the sip, this bottling shows lively lime flavors, steely minerality, citrus blossoms and pomelo pith, and is reminiscent of a crisp summer morning. It's tightly wound on the palate, where vibrant lime and orange-peel flavors hang from a chalky texture, with Asian pear, Meyer lemon, tangerine and petrol toward the finish.

Firm tannins mark this wine out for a good future. Its structure and generous fruits are slowly developing, promising richness as it matures. A dense wine packed with both fruit and tannins, it will be ready from 2019.

Candied orange peel and dried apricot are accented by heady notes of vanilla, cream and spice in this opulent wine. Three years after bottling, it reveals spicy potpourri notes of maturation, but plenty of fresh tangerine and peach remain. Rich and rounded, it's a lavish wine with a long, slightly warming finish.

A tropical suggestion of passion fruit plays with the pear notes on the nose of this zesty Viennese field blend. Freshness and texture are key, imbuing the slender body with zesty, aromatic tangerine-laden depth This is enlivening, aromatic and bold, with a refreshing dry finish.

Sourced primarily from Stagecoach Vineyard on Atlas Peak and blended with a small amount of Oakville Vineyard grapes, this is a blend of 57% Cabernet Sauvignon and 22% Cabernet Franc, with small percentages of Merlot, Petit Verdot and Malbec. Big, tannic and overpowering in its youth, it reveals hints of cedar, pencil shavings and sage, with a rich black-cherry core. Enjoy 20232033.

This wine comes from the grand estate of Pierreux with its handsome chteau. Rich and fruity, it has a spicy, vanilla character from aging in wooden vats. With its ripe black-plum and damson flavors, the wine is smooth and generous, ready to drink now.

This medium-bodied wine has an appetizing lip-smacking texture and a rather taut balance that could take on a wide variety of food pairings. It's all fresh berry and cherry flavors, snappy acidity and firm tannins.

A blend of 95% Sangiovese and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon, this opens with aromas of iris, red plum and baking spice. The juicy, fragrant palate doles out ripe black cherry, white pepper, star anise and tobacco while fine-grained, polished tannins provide support. Enjoy through 2028.

If you want to try noninterventional wine from Itata, Rogue Vine is a good place to start. This blend of Malbec, Carignan and Syrah opens with leathery blueberry aromas graced by mocha. A smacking palate is tannic and firm but not mean. Intense cassis, tobacco and spice flavors finish flush and saturated.

The scent of freshly cut Conference pear peels combines with crisp, green apple notes in this wine. The palate shows the characteristic, yeastiness that shimmers with saltiness, but juicy pear fruit plays the starring role. The finish is totally moreish.

Coming from one of the state's top vineyards, this wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (78%), Cabernet Franc (10%), 7% Petit Verdot and Merlot. The aromas are tightly wound on first pour, with pleasing notes of red and black fruit, along with plum, mocha, herb, flower and spice. The flavors are pitch black, soft and silky in feel with highly structured, ever so slightly dry tannins that smooth out with some time open. This one needs additional time. Best after 2021.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, new leather and eucalyptus. The concentrated palate offers ripe black cherry, blackberry jam, tobacco and licorice alongside brooding tannins. Drink 20182027.

This is big yet approachable wine with many years ahead of it. There's mocha, black cherry, soy sauce and violet tones wrapped in structured, mouth-filling tannins, plenty of acidity and an umami finish. Drink now2032.

A dark color and leathery, spicy, musky aromas lead to a medium to full palate with boldness and balance. Spiced cherry and black-plum flavors are lasting on a finish in which moderately complex fruit and spice flavors fade away with grace.

Very good concentration and a sleek texture make this medium to full-bodied wine from the Sierra Foothills easy to appreciate. It has layers of ripe black fruits, nuances of toasted oak and cedar, and fine-grained tannins that provide good backbone.

Rawness and aromas of tree bark, tomato and spice form the greeting on this Limar Syrah that spanks the palate with scratchy gravelly tannins and acidity. Flavors of red plum and currant are earthy, while some oak character is found on a rugged finish. Drink through 2024.

Beaujolais holds many old vineyards, but this one sets a record at 114 years. This wine is firm and concentrated, with wood aging giving a minty character as well as a dry core, . Low-yielding vines bring richness and a solid texture that will repay another few months aging. Drink from mid-2018.

All coming from Hedges Estate Vineyard and aged in 100% new French oak, this wine has had a full five years to develop and it's made the best of it. Aromas of spice box, dark fruit, vanilla and high-toned herb are followed by luscious black-fruit flavors that stretch out on the finish. It's unabashed in its appeal with a lot of life in front of it.

The fruit for this wine all comes from Hedges Estate Vineyard. Brooding aromas of soil, dark fruit, cigar, herb and spice box lead to palate-coating dark-fruit flavorswell balanced fruit flavors. Firm, lightly chalky tannins provide support. Give it some time in the cellar to develop. Best after 2020.

The aromas bring notes of cigar box, mortared herbs and cherry. The palate is tart, fresh and acid driven, with well-balanced fruit flavors that stretch out on the finish. It should still have a good life in front of it.

An aroma like white pepper and damp earth leads to brawny fruit flavors in this full-bodied, concentrated and complex wine made from a grape variety genetically identical to Zinfandel, but often with slightly different flavors. It has a good firm texture, attractive balance for a wine of its size, and a lingering finish.

A blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Merlot, Malvasia Nera and Colorino, this opens with aromas of toast, oak, underbrush and espresso. The concentrated, medium-bodied is dense yet linear, delivering ripe black cherry, crushed blackberry, licorice and coffee bean. Assertive, close-grained tannins grip the finish.

An uncommon find in the appellation, this red is blended with 6% Cabernet Sauvignon and given nearly two years in 60% new French oak. Dusty, it's bold and rustic, with shocks of currant, blackberry and broadly distributed oak, the lasting note a mix of clove and black pepper.

With 8% Petite Sirah, this is a velvety herbaceous wine with earthy undertones that presents as both rustic and refined. Leathery black pepper meets mushroom and cedar as the medium-ripe flavors lead to a juicy finish.

There's a strong hazelnut character on this bottling from an iconic vineyard, with touches of lemon-laced crme brle and pink grapefruit zest. The nutty quality translates to pecans on the sip, with orange marmalade, toasted croissant and a slight bit of marshmallow toward the finish.

From the northernmost Beaujolais cru, this wine is bold, ripe and fruity. Its tannins and acidity promise good aging and the chance to enhance the fragrant red-cherry fruitiness. This wine will be ready from late 2018.

The 55-year-old vines behind this wine have produced a rich wine. Still-dense tannins mark it out as youthful and needing to age further. It will do this well, broadening out the red-berry fruits and increasing the density of the wine. Drink from late 2018.

Richly fruity, this wine is dense, structured and impressive. Ripe black fruits and strong tannins will allow it to age. The property was purchased by Dominique Piron from leading restaurateurs, the Lameloise family. Drink from 2019.

This wine's grassy notes of fresh, green foliage grow richer with air, but thast green, vivid freshness remains on the palate. Lime and lemon freshness pervades the slender palate, giving it verve. The finish is dry and has more grassy intensity.

Compact plum and currant aromas are floral at first then more spicy and foxy as this blend led by Syrah and Carmenre airs out. A tough palate flush with tannins deals spicy, herbal plum flavors with ample chocolate and spice from oak. On the finish, this dries out and tastes peppery. Drink through 2022.

Intense aromas of ripe peach, tangerine, ginger and white blossoms meld with underscores of slate and smoke in this project from Thomas Pastuszak, wine director at The NoMad. This powerful wine displays rich fruit, floral and spice notes on the palate, with enough acidity to maintain balance. The finish carries on and on in apricot and orchard blossom tones. A perfect match for pork or fowl.

Toasty oak and savory cherry and plum aromas are meaty and calm. On the palate, this is linear and compact, with a beam of acidity that keeps things healthy and plodding ahead. Spicy oak flavors blend nicely with tomato, herbal plum and red currant notes. Drink now through 2024.

Dry earthy aromas of black fruits are subtle and calm, not loud, oaky or overtly herbal or spicy. A bit of clamp is found on a firm palate, while this Bordeaux blend tastes of spicy, lightly herbal plum and berry fruits. A steady thorough finish feels right. Drink through 2022.

While this is currently slightly tight and closed, it shows the structure and elements to present a complete and well-balanced wine with a little time. Scents of charred plum skin, dark chocolate, cigar box and roast beef dance in the bouquet, while the bold, firm palate offers flavors of black fruit skin, cassis and char. Drink 20192022.

The merest hint of passion fruit gives this wine's nose a tropical twist. The palate still has some sprightly fizz, combining earthy, soy-like savory texture with pithy citrus notes. It's slender in body and finishes on a dry, refreshing note.

This estate is named for the Romans who originally planted vines here. With touches of wood aging giving spice and toast along with rich, juicy black-plum fruits, this is a wine to age. It will be best from 2019.

This wine has a smoky character that lies over the juicy fruit, adding extra interest and texture to this already structured wine. With solid tannins and rich red-plum and cherry fruit, this wine is still developing. Drink from late 2018.

More subtle in style compared to Giesen's other single-vineyard offering, Matthews Lane, this wine offers stone fruit, lemon tea, snow pea and wild mint aromas. The opulent palate boasts tongue-tingling acidity and a citrus zing amidst a round texture.

This rich, structured wine is full of both ripe tannins and generous fruit. It is dense, as befits a Morgon, while also having a layer of juicy red-berry fruits. The structure and acidity promise aging. Drink from 2019.

Fragrant plum and red cherry notes have an alluring hint of cinnamon. The palate retains these rich, aromatic flavors but presents them on a fresh, slender canvas that shows both fruit and spice. Lovely and highly appetizing.

Earthy mint and blackcurrant leaf aromas sit atop the rich, concentrated black-fruit core of this wine. The medium-weight palate offers bold blackberry, cassis and boysenberry flavors, framed by firm yet well-integrated tannins that provide a crushed-velvet texture. Notes of berry compote, dried fynbos, green peppercorn and roast beef all unfold on the lingering, layered finish. Drink now2021.

Aromas of roasted red cherry, sharp black raspberry and herb-tinged smoked pork in mulberry sauce make for a mouthwatering entry to this bottling. The oak is strong on the palate, giving a vanilla overlay to the cranberry and rose petal flavors. A hint of juniper shows on the finish.

This Syrah-Mourvdre-Cabernet Sauvignon from the Apalta subzone of the Colchagua Valley deals spicy aromas of road tar and black plum. A tight integrated palate is firm more than luxe, while nicely merged cassis, plum and oak flavors add up to quality. Rich flavors of tobacco and chocolaty oak bolster a long finish. Drink through 2022.

This rich wine is full bodied, structured and, for a bottling from this appellation, packed with tannins. At the same time, the fruit shines through the wine's dry core, giving black plum and cherry flavors as well as acidity. The wine will develop further, so drink from late 2018.

Bright, focused acidity flirts with the medium-bodied palate that boasts flavors of lemon and grapefruit. A background of supportive oak never gets in the way, offering complementing tones of nutmeg and vanilla.

This is a soft oaky wine that builds power and concentration as it opens and expands on the palate, showing brawn and plenty of body. Juicy blackberry is lifted by integrated acidity and welcome jolts of black pepper.

Vibrant on the nose in vivid notes of red apple, peach blossom and slate, the palate carries similar tones along a lime-zest river of acidity. There's nice weight and feel to this wine, with a good concentration of flavors and a delicate astringency to the citrus blossom finish.

Named after the cherry trees (cerisiers) that surround the vineyard, this wine is richly flavored, yes, with cherries as well as crisper red currants. It is spicy, with a touch of pepper as well as some firm tannins. Drink this fruity, young wine from late 2018.

Grown on volcanic soil on the slopes of Mont Brouilly, this wine has a strong mineral character as well as rich black fruits. It is a concentrated wine with a dry core and balanced acidity. Drink from mid-2018.

From a selection of the estate's best fruit, this wine is richly structured, firmly textured and likely to age well in the medium term. The black fruits are still young, giving a brightness to the wine that perhaps should be allowed to calm down. Drink this ripe wine from late 2018.

New leather, tobacco and underbrush aromas emerge along with a balsamic whiff of camphor. Firmly structured, the youthfully austere palate evokes tart cherry, red raspberry, star anise and chopped herb framed in taut, fine-grained tannins. It's balanced, with bright acidity. Give it time to fully develop. Drink 20232033.

A full-fruit nose with grapy aromas of boysenberry and not much oak character gets this low-alcohol (12.5%) Cabernet off to an unconventional start. Jamminess is maintained on the palate, which feels plump but shy on tannic structure. Easygoing berry-compote flavors settle on blueberry on a soft finish. Only 450 cases were made. Drink through 2020.

A dense nose with prune, mint and green-herb aromas is soft, round and loses spunk as it breathes. A wide chunky palate is full but inexact, while this tastes oaky and savory, with spice, berry and tobacco flavors. Heat and chewy tannins propel the finish on this Apalta Carmenre. Drink through 2020.

There's currently an upfront oaky presence to this wine, with bold notes of toasted vanilla, char and sweet spice that sit atop a brambly, ripe dark-fruit core. Flavors of cherry pie, baked plum and boysenberry abound on the medium-weight palate, framed by structured tannins that result in a texture like crushed velvet. Notes of pepper, game and leather unfold on the evolving finish. Drink now2022.

The nose brims with fruit. Fleshy, almost overripe red cherry sets the tone on the nose that carries through to the palate. The body is juicy but has some grip while the cherry fruit attains crunch, a touch of white pepper spice and more freshness than the nose would suggest. The finish is vivid and moreish.

Sophisticated and full bodied, this generous style of wine wraps complex and subtle oak spices around a warm, generous core of ripe pear and apple notes. Wonderful vanilla bean and nutmeg nuances linger in the creamy texture and echo on the finish.

Very chalky aromas of lime skins, lemon rinds and a touch of Gala apple flesh makes for an inviting nose to this estate bottling. The palate picks up the region's telltale sea salt flavors, which give savory depth to the seared lemon rind flavors. The acidity and texture are both firm.

Burly red fruit meets charred oak and a soft supple texture in this medium-bodied wine that's made entirely from estate-grown grapes. A pretty undertone of violet provides floral flourish as white pepper teases on the lengthy, earthy finish.

Substantial fruit flavors and good structure highlight this medium- to full-bodied, concentrated wine. It has a straightforward, no-nonsense approach and offers great value. Enticing black cherry and raspberry flavors are supported by fine-grained tannins and crisp acidity. The fruit notes are pure, clean and linger nicely on the finish.

Hailing from one of the coolest vintages the state has ever seen, the aromas bring brooding notes of cherry cola, raspberry, dried leaf, wood and cigar box. The flavors are light, tart and focused, maintaining a sense of freshness. It's a lovely offering from this challenging year.

This is a traditional dry, full-bodied and well-balanced Zin that's made to go with a hearty meal. Ripe but not sweet boysenberry flavors are shaded with mineral, wood smoke and light baking spice accents, while firm tannins lend grip to the mouthfeel.

Truffle, tilled earth, exotic spice and woodland berry aromas emerge in the glass along with a toasted note. It's racy and firmly structured, offering tart red cherry, cranberry, coffee bean and clove set against tightly drawn, close-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Drink 20202028.

The aromas are subdued for the variety but intriguing, with notes of pear, ginger, wet rock and peach, along with cinnamon and light barrel spices. The palate is considerably more forward, with abundant stone-fruit flavors that show concentration and richness along with a sense of restraint.

This estate is the most famous and influential in Cte de Brouilly. This wine, from 50-year-old vines, is rich and structured while also having delicious ripe berry and black-cherry fruits. It is likely to age well over the next few months, being ready to drink from mid-2018.

Quite dark in the glass, this bottling shows deep blackberry and black currant aromas alongside baked goods and a touch of violets. There is impressive density to the palate, where black plum flavors blend with lavender and baking spice on the finish. The tannins are still quite firm.

This wine displays the typical mineral texture associated with this vineyard of granite and schist soils. The texture is given further strength by tannins that suggest the wine needs to age. There is plenty of black fruit as well, so this wine will be best from 2019.

This Pinotage-based blend, with 15% Shiraz and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon, is dark and brooding in the glass. Initial aromas of rich, ripe black berries and cherry sets the stage for the bold, concentrated palate, with notes of char, espresso, licorice root and earthy spice throughout. Medium-plus in weight, with robust and gripping tannins, this firmly structured pour shows great power and length. Drink 20202025.

This is the fourth harvest from owners Virginie and Grgory Barbet and they've made a fine job of it. The wine, with its rich black fruits and concentrated tannins has the structure typical of this appellation. The juicy fruits go along with tannins to give a wine that should age. Drink from late 2018.

This wine from a 2.4-acre vineyard is firm and structured as befits a bottling from this appellation. Rich smoky tannins and fruitiness are balanced and lifted by the juicy red-fruit acidity. Drink from late 2018.

This dense, well-structured wine has bold tannins as well as rich cherry and blackberry fruits. The structure and the fruit are still young and up front, needing to calm down before the wine will be ready to drink. Wait until late 2018.
This is a ripe and juicy wine. Tannins support the generous layers of red-berry and cherry fruits and acidity. The wine has a succulent quality, spicy and fruity at the end. Drink from mid-2018.
A blend from several small parcels, this wine has richness and structure. It is dense, packed with firm tannins as well as juicy black-cherry flavors. This firm wine will age. Drink from 2019.

Lovely scents of forest berry, new leather, Mediterranean herb and a whiff of pipe tobacco take shape in the glass. It's racy and elegant, offering crushed strawberry, red cherry and star anise set against a backbone of firm acidity and taut, refined tannins. Drink 20202029.

Low yields from a cool vintage make for a delicate nuanced experience in the glass in this perfumed velvety wine. Plum and cherry flavors are crisp and tart, with the acidity persistent. White pepper and ocean spray contribute context and complexity.

Over one million cuttings from the Matthews Lane Vineyard have been supplied to nurseriesand therefore wineriesaround Marlborough, so in theory, there's a small piece of it in many of the wines from the region. It's special, then, to taste Giesen's single-vineyard version, aged in 1000 liter German fuders. Trademark regional characters of jalepeo, green beans and grass marry with lemon balm, pressed yellow flowers and butter, all ensconced in an oily texture, slippery acidity and a grassy finish.

This wine has a puckering sensibility of tannin on entry but settles in the glass to show a fresh core of strawberry, black cherry, cedar and soy. The oak is buttery and spicy, good at playing a supporting role to the density of mountain-grown high-toned fruit.

This is a ripe and smooth wine. With firm tannins cushioned by rich black fruits, it is spicy, smoky and will age. The wine, from the personal property of the Barbet family that also runs ngociant Jean Loron, will be ready to drink from mid-2018.

Black cherry and elderberry create a brooding impression of fruit. The palate adds freshness and spicy charm. There is a lovely contrast between plump juiciness and vivid tartness that adds a little drama to the palate. The tannins give way to a fine crunch on this medium, fruit-driven body. The finish is dry and moreish.

Floral aromatics are the star of the show in this full-bodied, densely packed wine, blended with 2% each of Grenache, Petite Sirah, Malbec, Zinfandel and Carignane. Tart in acidity, it's juicy and bright, with a persistence of black raspberry.

This wine, from a vineyard first planted in the 1860s, has good balance an a distinctive flavor profile, as meaty earthy nuances vie for attention with delicious plummy flavors and a broad, rather soft texture. Full body gives the wine a little grip on the palate in lieu of heavy tannins.

Waxy blossoms, lemon peels and gooseberries perfume this zesty, dry white. Fresh grapefruit and lemon flavors are cutting and pristine, lingering on a revitalizing mineral tone. Drink now through 2020.

Earthy aromas of sunbaked soil, new leather, overripe plum and a whiff of game come together on this. The chewy, savory palate doles out fleshy black cherry, crushed raspberry, cinnamon and star anise framed in lithe tannins. It's already hit its ideal drinking window so enjoy soon.

Rachel Silkowski works for winemaker Brian Loring, and his ripe and rich style is certainly apparent in this bottling with an incredibly long name. Dried alpine strawberry meets with mace and allspice on the nose, while the palate packs tarragon-laced boysenberry flavors alongside shaved licorice and allspice.

Truffle, moist soil, ground clove leather and balsamic aromas emerge on this along with an earthy whiff of game. The smooth, ripe palate doles out fleshy black cherry, prune, licorice and cured meat alongside polished, velvety tannins. It's already hitting its ideal drinking window so drink sooner rather than later.

Whiffs of leather and barnyard lend earthen complexities to bright blackberry and cherry on this elegant wine. Medium bodied and taut, it finishes long, with a bite of bitter nut skin and bold yet integrated tannins.

Full bodied and full flavored, this complex wine smells like black olive, wood smoke and tobacco, tastes like blackberry and dried herbs and feels broad and firmly tannic on the palate. It's built to age well, and should show even more nuances after 2020.

Smoky mocha hints precede notes of aromatic black cherry. The smooth and lush ripeness of the fruit only becomes apparent on the rich, almost luscious palate. The body is smooth and rounded, pliable and plush. The tannins are present but soft, it is ripe black cherry fruit that reigns supreme. Lovely freshness on the finish makes for a bright, long aftertaste.

Made with 70% Cabernet Sauvignon and 30% Sangiovese, this boasts inviting aromas of blue flower, cedar and red-skinned berry. The bright palate doles out juicy Marasca cherry, red raspberry, a hint of mocha and star anise alongside silky, polished tannins.

Dense vanilla and baking spice aromas decorate the dried plum and purple-flower aromas on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from the eastern mountains above the Salinas Valley. Black plum sauce, peppercorns and dark chocolate flavors show on the sip, which is quite heavy and dense but expertly structured to stand the test of time.

This blend of grapes from Rita's Crown and Radian vineyards delivers a unique nose of wet wood, lemon verbena, macadamia nut and nectarine cream. The mouthfeel is zippy and the backbone is quite chalky, carrying flavors of poached Asian pear, sea salt and lemon zest, with touches of pecan and browned butter.

This Maipo Cabernet is spicy and dry on the nose as opposed to bursting with ripeness. A dry tightly wound palate defines the word firm, while slightly rustic Old World flavors of mixed spices, dried red fruits and oak finish with structure. This is the type of Cab that will benefit from further aging. Drink through 2026.

Earthy black-fruit aromas open wild and give this blend of Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Syrah some teeth. A fleshy fully stacked palate shows structure and tight tannins. Spicy blackberry flavors benefit from integrated oak, while chocolate and residual spice flavors make for a dark finish. Drink through 2022.

Highly appetizing notes of Mirabelle and fresh green pear dominate the nose of this wine. The palate is lithe and slender, with a citrus focus, a yeasty, savory midpalate texture and a moreish, salty finish.

Strong spice aromas and ripe, bold fruit flavors make this a powerful, extroverted wine with a lot of flavor impact. It seems to represent a style shift at Williams Selyem. Nutmeg, ginger and clove leap from the glass and laser-focused black-cherry flavors fill the palate, supported by firm tannins and acidity. Best after 2021.

Black currant, elderberry, charred beef, dried violets and cedar show on the nose of this dark, complex bottling. The energized sip delivers tart black plum before offering more elegant and woody flavors of sandalwood and myrrh, with leathery tannins and savory meat flavors throughout.

Earthy notes of mushroom, white pepper, dried leaves and buttered cannellini beans lead over aromas of lemon and stone fruit. The palate boasts mouth-watering acidity yet not without weight and texture, thanks to time maturing on lees.

Paso Robles isn't known for Pinot Noir, although this historic vineyard has been growing it successfully, and with plenty of aging ability, since 1964. Aromas of light berries, tarragon and sandalwood lead into a palate full of mint, fennel pollen, mulberry and dried plum, altogether exhibiting a li hing mui sort of character.

Aromas of iris, tilled soil, new leather, chopped mint and ground clove take shape in the glass. The vibrant, austere palate delivers Marasca cherry, cranberry, espresso and a toasted note while a hint of tobacco marks the close. Close-grained tannins provide assertive support. Give this time to fully develop. Drink 20212031.

This wine hails from two top vineyards. A full eight-years-old and coming from a cool vintage, the aromas are light, with notes of cedar, cherry and herb, dotted with wood spice. The palate brings quite tart fruit flavors, accented by racy acidity and supported by firm, tightly wound tannins. With acid like this, it absolutely requires some food alongside it to be properly enjoyed. Steak should do.

Soft red rose petals, cranberry, wet slate and dust show on the nose of this bottling, one of the first new-block designates released by this producer. The palate's plush texture carries strong soil flavors of crushed gravel and turned earth, which give depth to the background of ripe raspberry and pomegranate fruit.

The aromas leap up out of the glass, with exquisite notes of plum, spice and cherry cream. On the palate, it's rich with soft fruit flavors, showing ripeness but still maintaining its balance, with the neutral oak aging bringing an aching sense of purity. Candied-cherry notes linger on the finish. It's a whole lot of wine for the money, with a big yum factor.

Herbal notes of menthol, garrigue and blackcurrant leaf are upfront on the bouquet of this wine, supported by red forest-berry fruits. Medium in weight and body, it offers fine yet present tannins that frame the red currant, strawberry and rhubarb fruit. Hints of sous bois and spicy oak dance on the earthy finish. Drink now2023.

The aromas erupt from the glass, with notes of potpourri, orange peel, moist earth, stem and garden herb. The palate shows a pleasing mix of earth and savory flavors that deliver a lot of elegance and intertwine effortlessly through the finish. The variety seems a bit hard to find but the expression is quite intriguing.
Firm and with great poise, this ripe wine has benefitted from the ripe vintage. It is succulent, balanced between poised tannins and the black-cherry fruits. This rich wine is ready to drink.

This estate has been vastly improved since it was bought by the Richard family whose coffees are familiar in many French cafs. Richly aromatic and juicy, this wine is full, packed with fruit and acidity, and already delicious to drink.

Plumes of honeysuckle, citrus peel and spice perfume this vibrant varietal Marsanne. It's medium to full in body but feels spry and fresh, boasting crisp pink grapefruit and guava flavors. Drink now through 2020 to enjoy its youthful appeal.

Truffle, new leather, pressed blue flower, menthol and a whiff of game lead the way. The aromas carry over to the ripe, full-bodied palate along with fleshy black cherry, steeped prune, cinnamon and star anise. Buffed tannins provide the framework. It's already accessible but will maintain well for the next several years. Drink through 2023.

This lovely wine has a baked aspect to the fruit that makes it warm and welcoming. It's otherwise edgy in high-toned characteristics of rhubarb, cranberry, orange and forest floor, with bolts of cardamom throughout. Complex, the oak is prominent yet integrated.

Elliott Dolin's wines continue to make the strongest case for the potential of Malibu viticulture. This bottling shows rounded aromas of lemon rind, white peach, tangerine and a touch of butter. There is great energy and grip on the sip, where nectarine flavors meet with sea salt and sandalwood.

Aged for a short period in large wooden barrels, this wine comes from organically grown grapes and has a smooth texture. It emphasizes the pure, clean fruit and brings out the tannins for aging potential. Drink from 2019.

This is a ripe, densely structured wine with the typical perfumed character of the appellation. Ripe berry fruits and layers of acidity lift the wine and give it a crisp texture. Produced from 75-year-old vines, it will be ready to drink from late 2018.

Rich in fruit and oak flavors, this medium to full-bodied wine has cinnamon and cedar aromas, ripe black cherry and red-cherry flavors, a firm and rather tannic texture and an oaky spicy finish. A sense of warmth and sweetness makes it hard to resist.

A creamy note of yellow apple fruit constitutes this wine's nose. The palate follows through with creamy, rounded but still precise freshness. This is a slender, textured Chardonnay with bright, lemon-like acidity and a leesy texture.

One of a range of wines produced by ngociant Florent Descombe, this properly structured wine is rich in black fruits as well as tannins. Coming from the impressive Cte du Py slope, it has power and concentration as well as layers of fruit. Age this wine longer and drink from late 2018.

The inviting nose on this bottling combines rich black cherry, zesty raspberry, allspice and dried ginger aromas. The palate delivers big fruit flavors of baked boysenberries and ripe cranberries, which are balanced by a bit of tartness.

This wine is more full bodied and rich than first glance would suggest. It has a rather light red mahogany color. Generous strawberry and red-cherry flavors on a mouth-filling texture show light tannins and relatively soft acidity but plenty of viscosity. It was made from 100% Pommard clone vines and aged in 60% new French oak.

Smooth on entry, with a gravelly texture that develops in the glass, this wine welcomes with a strong perfume of rose petal and strawberry. High-toned, it integrates healthy portions of oak into the savory fruit, with a persistence of acidity on the finish.

Blended with 14% Merlot, aromas of char, smoke, ground green herb, spice box, graphite and dark cherry lead to plentiful, saturated dark fruit and barrel flavors with a pleasing mouthfeel. It hits a lot of high notes.

Named after the grower who owned the estate for many years (his daughter now runs it), this wine is dense, structured and complex. It has a strong mineral element as well as generous tannins and ripe berry fruits. This complex wine will age well. Drink from 2019.

This wine's wonderfully heady citrus pith and pear notes hit the nose. The palate joins with a rounded mouthfeel and more savory flavors; this is all about textured miso and salty sage. A spike of lemon brightness leads to a clean finish.

This blends in 13% Petit Verdot and 6% Syrah, strong, powerful varieties that contribute power and dark color. Blackberry, chocolate and coconut ride a rich wavelength of soft mellowed tannin and fig flavor, finishing in a bite of graham cracker.

This wine, with its floral aroma, is rounded, potentially rich and has layers of firm tannins. It comes from a blend of two of the sectors of Julinas, a combination that brings out great fruit and a fine, dusty structure. Drink this wine with its good potential from late 2018.

From a great site, this tiny production wine is dark gold in color and oaky on the nose. Baked caramel apple, lemon chiffon and nutmeg all play a rolebold flavors that highlight this well-made effort that offers a throughput of bright acidity.

Fresh lime-spritzer aromas meet with whiffs of smoke and wood ash on the nose of this bottling. The palate is extremely zippy, with sea salt and lemon-zest flavors on the forefront and more complex Brie rind, cashew cream and dried apple toward the finish.

Aromatic and attractive, this wine spends a little time on its skins, causing it to burst with aromas of flowers, peaches, lime leaf and a bit of honey. The skins also contribute to the satiny texture, balanced by crisp acidity and finishing with a limey, saline tang.

Aromas of tilled soil, plum cake, exotic spice and a whiff of toasted oak come to the forefront of the nose. Elegantly structured, the taut, linear palate doles out wild cherry, cranberry, licorice, crushed herb and clove set against vibrant acidity and fine-grained tannins. Drink from 20192024.

This lush, plush and almost syrupy wine has oodles of blackberry and chocolate aromas, a full body and ripe fruit flavors. A subtle layer of oak spice intermingles with all that fruit while soft tannins make it feel broad but not astringent on the palate.

This is an extremely smooth, mellow, complex and interesting wine. From the first whiff of cedar and cinnamon in the aroma, to intricate flavors of raspberry, black tea and clove, it brings a lot of nuances to the palate and wraps them in a soft blanket of mild acidity and light tannins.

This is a full-bodied, well-balanced and mouth-filling wine that offers ripe berry and cherry flavors enhanced by subtle baking spices. It has a good framework of fine-grained tannins and supportive acidity to keep it lively on the palate.

Parducci has been making great-value Petite Sirah for decades and here's another super example. This is an unusually complex wine for the varietal, offering hints of violet, anise and black pepper, along with rich blackberry aromas and flavors. The mouthfeel is big and tannic, but not overly so, and the rich flavors melt over the palate and linger a long time on the finish.

Cofermented with just under 5% Viognier, this varietal wine was aged in neutral French oak, the better to let its earthy core speak loudest. Mushroom, pine forest and black pepper highlight a broad brawny plate that's densely packed and moderately structured.

Sourced from a particularly well-drained block in the Lahoma Vineyardslocated on the western shore of Seneca Lakethis is an incredibly pristine dry Riesling, with aromas of racy lime, ripe green pear and crushed stone. The palate offers an intriguing balance between weight and tension, showing ripe tree fruit braced by a vein of lime zest and powdered minerals, ending on an ultraclean, quinine finish.

Ripe boysenberry, blackberry and cherry tones are accented by hints of game, licorice root and lemon oil in this well-balanced and accessible Pinotage. The palate is smooth and plush, with well-integrated tannins and enough acidity to balance the opulent fruit flavors.

A rich overlay of cocoa and roasted coffee bean sit atop ripe, brambly notes of blackberry, boysenberry and black cherry on the nose and mouth of this decadent, immediately likeable bottling. The plush mouthfeel offers silky tannins, with ample acidity and hits of toasted oak and fresh mint leaves that add depth and lift through the close.

This is a proprietary estate-grown blend of Syrah, Grenache, Mourvdre and Zinfandel, aged in French oak (45% new). Savory flavors of earth, black licorice, tobacco, meat and leather are lifted on the palate by fresh blueberry and blackberry tones, dusted in chocolate shavings.

The smell of freshly peeled ripe golden pears shimmers on the nose of this wine, alongside yeasty richness. The palate puts more stress on the rich, textured seam of yeast, which has a satisfying, sonorous miso note.

Tangy plum skins and mulberry sauce meet with salt and pepper and roasted duck aromas on the nose of this blend of 50% Grenache, 35% Syrah and 15% Mourvdre. The palate is full of brambly fruit, lifted by smoke and sagebrush.

Lovely aromas of exotic red cherries, sultry mace, spicy cinnamon and white sage show on the nose of this fresh and crisp bottling. There is ample peppery spice to the palate and a strong tannic tension, with flavors of Earl Grey tea, cranberry and pomegranate. Cherry compote shows on the finish.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of ripe black-skinned berry, underbrush and leather. The juicy palate doles out ripe black cherry, clove, licorice and white pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. Enjoy through 2025.

This is a great taste of the freshness of Sonoma without the sticker shock, showing freshly pressed red berries, vanilla and wet slate on the nose. It's light in density on the sip, so the flavors of cranberry, carnation, wet earth and brown spice sail effortlessly across the palate.

Dense dark aromas of road tar, eucalyptus, blackberry, tea and barrel spice are Chilean through and through. Aresti's 65th anniversary blend is dry, oaky and intense on the palate. Woody creamy berry flavors are robust as this finishes oaky, spicy and fleshy.

This wine is brooding in aromas of dark fruit, earth, cola, chocolate, dried herbs and a whiff of smoke that carry to a toasty, medium-bodied palate, leading to a medicinal, herbal and oaky finish. The structure and fine tannins of this wine suggest it will age into something quite lovely. Drink 20182025.

Attractive and focused raspberry and black-cherry flavors fill out this medium-bodied wine. The aromas are fruity, with touches of clove and cinnamon, while the flavors are clean, pure and delicious. The wine has just enough tannin to firm up the texture, along with good acidity for balance. Drink now or hold through 2022.

Thick and hearty aromas of elderberry and blueberry jam meet with lilacs and black pepper on the rich and spicy nose of this blend of 50% Syrah and 50% Teroldego. The sip is dense and attention-grabbing, with strong blackberry and boysenberry flavors alongside loamy soil and chalky tannins.

This full-bodied wine has a big structure, strong oak, spice and red fruit flavors all wrapped in fine-grained tannins. The color is relatively light, but the aromas are full of toasted oak and nutmeg while the flavors have vivid cranberry and cherry. The wine should mellow with age, and will be best after 2020.

This is extremely racy wine that starts with clean chalky aromas of apple skins and Meyer lemon pith will pair excellently with fresh raw shellfish. The tightly wound palate clings to the tongue with a limestone-like grip, delivering flavors of Asian pear flesh, yuzu zest, oyster shell and tons of wet gravel.

Healthy doses of black pepper and smoked meat in both the aromas and the flavors give this wine a pretty forceful personality, and it has good fruit to back them up. It smells like cracked pepper and cedar, tastes spicy, meaty, quite firm in texture and brings out raspberry and red cherry on the finish.

Named after the rocky soil of the vineyard, this wine is suitably firm and structured. A mineral texture gives an edgy character and enhances the firm tannins. The wine, rich in fruit potential, will age well. Drink from 2019.

This bold, ripe wine is packed with rich fruit and tannins. It is produced by direct descendants of the Loron family of ngociants who still run the estate. With its dense texture and rich concentration, it will be ready to drink from late 2018.

This brother-and-sister team have produced a structured wine as part of their ngociant business (they also have a family domaine). Packed with red-cherry fruits and acidity, this wine is young but promises a good future. The crisp texture and the tannins will keep the wine developing until 2019.

Peppery, this old-vine wine is well integrated and thickly restrained, with a lip-smacking taste of blackberry cobbler and dark chocolate. Gritty tannins give it texture and ample weight, while a freshness of acidity persists.
Fresh lemon acidity invigorates this glossy, unctuous white wine. Full bodied and fleshy on the palate, it offers soft red apple, grapefruit and hazelnut flavors accented by a hint of dried herb.

A kiss of honey extends from nose to finish, accenting fresh apple and grapefruit flavors in this plush, full-bodied white. It's brawny and expansive on the palate, but sunny lemon acidity cuts through the fat, adding freshness to a lingering finish.

This wine is big, rich and bold. Its black fruits and tight acidity indicate the aging potential of this wine. Add in the firm tannins and mineral texture, and it will take time to mature. Drink this dense wine from 2019

Producer Marc Delienne, fresh from Paris, has made an impression with his three cuves of Fleurie. Aged in wood, this rich, concentrated wine has density and great power. Tannins and dark fruits promise aging potential. Drink this wine from late 2018.

Dusty plum, tobacco and dark chocolate play against a soft texture in this varietal wine with a Merlot-like sensibility. Black and red currant and cherry mix well on the fruity palate, seasoned in appropriate measures of cedar, black pepper and clove.

Ripe, juicy cassis and blackberry notes seduce from nose to finish here. It's a brawny, rather lavish wine, both in body and fruit, but nuanced too, accentuated by hints of garrigue, leather and earth. Richly concentrated and long on the finish, it's framed neatly by fine, persistent tannins.

Sanguine and smoky, this wine has a welcome herbal component that keeps it fresh and complex in the glass. Thick and densely concentrated in blackberry and plum, it persists in an underlying vibrancy that helps balance and complement its more luxurious tease of dark chocolate.

This classically styled Cabernet Sauvignon-driven blend shows power and structure in equal measure, with a backbone of integrated oak. Raspberry, black cherry and cassis flavors are succulently displayed along a carpet of thick concentrated richness.
The aromas show nuance, with notes of toast, assorted dried herb, cherry and plum. The fruit flavors are seamless in feel, showing concentration and depth. It's thoroughly enchanting.

With its Burgundy-colored tile roof and porticoed facade, this is a showpiece estate in Julinas. The wine it produces is dense, with solid, complex tannins. Ripe red fruits plus acidity and a core of dryness will allow it to age. Drink from late 2018.

Fully concentrated in dusty black fruit and tobacco, this blends 79% Cabernet Sauvignon, 15% Petit Verdot, 3% Merlot, 2% Malbec and 1% Cabernet Franc. Mellowed in terms of ripeness and body weight, it offers sizable tannins that provide structure along the midpalate.

The aromas explode with notes of honeysuckle, ripe peach, apricot and creamsicle. The flavors are supremely rich but also show a beautiful sense of delicacy along with a pronounced finish. It's full bore but delicious.

Ripe black-fruit aromas are nicely toasted and subtle. On the palate, this is chewy and concentrated but not too heavy. Darkchocolaty oaky blackberry flavors are just spicy and feral enough to let you know this is Syrah. As a whole, this is smooth and ready to drink.

There's a potent smoky character on the nose of this bottling, with hickory and oak aromas wrapped around the strawberry and plum flavors. The palate is fresher in a note of red plum, yet smoke, salt, peppercorn and oregano tones pervade. It's savory without being rich, showing a strong backbone of acidity.

Appetizing notes of green and yellow pear and even a touch of yellow plum play on the nose of this wine. The palate has that varietal, textured backdrop, but pear, plum and fresh, ripe lemon notes take center stage. It's concentrated and fruity, with a citrusy finish.

Light in the glass, this bottling by Winemaker Lane Tanner offers plum, red cherry, baked earth, shredded slate and a hint of vanilla-laced croissant on the nose. The palate shows energetic acidity and a grippy texture, with underripe strawberry, plum skin and green-peppercorn tones.

Cherry syrup and a roasted meat element are revealed the nose of this bottling from a winery with a popular tasting room in downtown Paso Robles. Vanilla and baked good flavors show right away on the palate, where chalky tannins and rich cherry fruits arise mid-sip to ride a bountiful acidity and touch of pepper spice into the finish.

Zesty freshness and lemon brightness characterize the nose and palate of this slender, sinuous wine. Herbal savor tinges the edges while ripe pear fruit comes to the fore. Lovely, lively and wonderfully taut.

Aromas of French oak, vanilla, exotic spice and espresso follow over to the medium-bodied, linear palate along with cranberry, licorice, chopped mint and coconut. Racy acidity and austere, fine-grained tannins provide balance and support. Drink 20192028.

Aromas of pressed blue flower, perfumed berry, dried herb and exotic spice are in the forefront. The vibrant, linear palate delivers dried black cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice and a hint of coffee set against taut, fine-grained tannins that leave a firm finish. It's balanced, with fresh acidity. Drink 20212033.

There are loads of sagebrush, thyme, peppercorn and dried oregano aromas on this blend of 50% Grenache, 35% Syrah and 15% Mourvdre, all set against a baked boysenberry frame. The mouthfeel is easygoing and airy, with flavors of tart berry, plum skins and more garden herbs. A peppery spice extends through the finish.

A tiny production wine from a backbone site, used in many of the producer's other wines, this is brash in coconut and black currant, the tannins grainy and firm, given additional heft by the ripeness and generous use of oak. Velvety smooth, it's densely packed in black pepper and clove.
Mint and violet notes accent a dense black-cherry core in this full-bodied, juicy wine. Light touches of baking spices and dried herbs add complexity and play into a layering effect on the palate.
While this wine is tough and closed up at this stage, it has good potential. The weight shows it has plenty of ripe fruit while wood aging has added spice. The wine needs time, so drink from 2019.

Aromas of wild berry, tilled soil, new leather, camphor and a whiff of violet take center stage on the nose. Bright and succulent, the vibrant, graceful palate doles out juicy red cherry, crushed raspberry and baking spice. Taut, refined tannins and racy acidity lend balance and tension. Fans of elegance will love its ethereal finesse. Drink 20192026.

With a waxy nose of peach and apricotboth dried and freshthis is a dry, light-bodied wine that dances on the palate in moderately high acidity. Fermented entirely in stainless steel, it remains softly textured and vibrant from start to finish.

This is a beautifully balanced wine with medium body and nicely firm tannins supporting fairly rich black fruits and herbal accents. It is sleek and agile rather than big and rich, and its appetizing texture should make it really versatile at lunch or dinner.

Earthy aromas of pepper spice, roasted meat crust and red cherry sauce show on the nose of this bottling from a new property in Ojai. The flavors are clean yet pleasantly rustic, full of cooked herbs, dust and rounded cranberry. It's light in body, soft in texture and easy to drink.

While this displays dark aromas of burnt oak, road tar and blackberry, the palate is not heavy or overly hard driving. Plum and berry flavors are loaded with wood spice and nutmeg accents, while this tastes chocolaty on a bold finish. Drink this exemplary Carignan through 2025.

Menthol, mature black-skinned fruit, clove, pressed violet and balsamic aromas take shape in the glass. The linear, elegantly structured palate is youthfully austere, offering tart red cherry, cranberry and licorice alongside assertive, fine-grained tannins and firm acidity. Give this time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 20202033.

This blend of 55% Grenache Blanc and 45% Viognier is one of the zippiest white wines you can find. It's restrained on the nose with honeydew, yellow grapefruit peel and wet slate aromas, and then the wound-up acidic power explodes on the sip, where tart apple and pear flavors linger behind the sizzle.
This wine is thick and sinewy, ripe and soft in texture. Spicy clove, pepper and cinnamon highlight a richness of strawberry puree and mocha chocolate flavor, the oak subdued in the background.

This is a very young but already fully enjoyable twist-top bottling from a unique site in the rugged mountains north of the Santa Maria Valley. Fresh aromas of blackberry and black currant meet with rosemary and tarragon on the nose while the easy-to-quaff palate shows flavors of freshly plucked boysenberries, oregano and marjoram. The high alcohol is completely hidden.

Aromas of French oak, exotic spice and black-skinned berry take center stage. Fresh and linear, the palate offers cassis, cranberry and crushed raspberry framed in fine-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Drink through 2023.

Swirls of orange blossom and vanilla introduce this richly textured Roussanne. Soft, honeyed flavors of tangerine and pear are broad and expansive on the palate, accented by hints of earth and sunny lemon acidity. Drink now through 2021.

Leathery berry aromas are dense and earthy, while not showing any of the green character that sometimes plagues Carmenre. A flush mouthfeel is solid and fruity, with berry and plum flavors that are roasted and meaty. Savory notes on the finish suggest a pairing with barbecue.

A bright bouquet of red currants, strawberries, back pepper, olives and medicinal bitters show this Pinot to be approachable when young, particularly by Martinborough standards. The palate is silky, savory, earthy and red-fruited, finishing salty yet refreshing.

This ripe, soft wine is rich with red-cherry fruit and a generous texture from old vines. Spice, fruitiness and a hint of tannins contribute to a wine that is delicious and rounded, ready to drink now.

A perfumed wine, this is rich in tannins and generous, ripe black fruits. Aged nine months in wood, it has a hint of caramel as well as spice that adds extra dimension. It is juicy, ripe and needs to age further. Drink from late 2018.
Densely tannic, this rich wine is dark and structured. The black fruits have great weight and a generous nature. The acidity, typical of the vintage, indicates the wine needs to age. Drink from 2019.

The granite soil of Morgon is very much in evidence in this firm, mineral-textured wine. With dark tannins and the potential of rich fruit, the wine is structured and needs time to mature further. Drink from 2019.

This ripe, succulent wine, from the producer's home vineyard, is softly textured and richly fruity. Dense texture gives it a full-bodied feel as well a dry edge. This wine needs to age further. Drink from mid-2018.

The richness of Grenache is offset elegantly with Syrah's edgy, peppery finesse in this elegant blend. Black cherry and strawberry preserves are plump and ripe but balanced neatly with zesty acidity and bristling undertones of savory herb and chalky tannins.

Lanci is one of the villages of Beaujolais-Villages, next door to Morgon and sometimes seeing itself as a Beaujolais cru in waiting. This wine certainly has structure and aging potential along with plenty of red fruits and acidity. These elements suggest that the wine will be ready to drink from late 2018.

Aged in large wooden 158- and 800-gallon barrels, this wine is rich with spice and toast flavors over the soft tannins. It has great black-fruit flavors, acidity to balance and a ripe aftertaste. The wine is smooth and can be enjoyed now but will be better from mid-2018.

Underbrush, new leather, game, pipe tobacco and menthol aromas lift out of the glass. The full-bodied palate offers dried black cherry, licorice, a hint of mint and the same gamy note as the nose alongside assertive, close-grained tannins. Drink through 2022.

Aromas of dark culinary spice, mature berry and a whiff of new leather emerge in the glass. The tightly wound, tense palate offers wild cherry, licorice and clove framed in taut, fine-grained tannins. Give this another year or two at least to fully develop. Drink 20192025.

This is a surprisingly bright and herbal Pinotage, with an intense fynbos streak to the bouquet and a distinct, almost mentholated character that lifts the ripe plum, cherry and berry fruit. Framing tannins lend structure to the medium-weight palate, while notes of lightly charred black fruit and espresso unfold on the spicy close.
A shy nose belies a simplicity of green apple and fennel in this full-bodied fleshy wine that satisfies in freshness and complexity. Toasted oak marks the lengthy finish.
Violets and raspberries perfume this soft, pretty wine full of sun-kissed berry and cherry flavors. It's not complex, but irresistibly plush and fruity. Drink now through 2021.

Lavishly ripe blueberry and blackberry flavors penetrate through this robust yet freshly balanced red. It's a juicy, easy-drinking wine but pristine in fruit with hints of nuts and spice. The finish is softly tannic, almost powdery.

Graham cracker and vanilla wafer aromas entice on the nose. This is a ripe, dense wine which boasts a sinewy backdrop of leather among a broad expanse of rich fruit flavors. A cinnamon note lingers on the finish.

Named after the general who was so involved in American independence, this ripe and generous wine is warm with red-berry fruits and attractive acidity. It is smooth, with hints of vanilla and tangy black fruits at the end. Drink now.

This is a firm, structured wine produced at one of the many estates of Duboeuf. Rich black-cherry fruit contrasts with the dry core of the wine. Ripe and juicy, it will be ready to drink from mid-2018.

Black cherry, smoke and a lick of mocha signal richness right away. The palate continues in the same vein, imbuing dark, ripe fruit with the richness of chocolate and mocha. Inherent freshness keeps this balanced. A modern, international style with an Austrian accent.

Inviting, dense aromas of dark cherry and cranberry meet soft, sweet spice accents on the nose of this single-vineyard wine. Medium in weight, with ample roundness and structure, crunchy red-fruit flavors are bolstered by a peppered mesquite tone.

Crisp and dry, this light-bodied wine has vivid acidity and fresh Bosc pear and white peach flavors along with a lightly astringent texture that's very appetizing. It will be just the thing as an apritif with toasted almonds and olives. Blended from Grenache Blanc, Roussanne, Picpoul and Viognier.

Violet, black-skinned berry and vanilla scents are front and center while the concentrated, polished palate doles out juicy red cherry, cinnamon, mocha and a drop of vanilla. Fine-grained tannins provide the lithe framework. Enjoy through 2025.

This soft-textured, mouth-filling wine has woodsy, fallen leaf aromas, gentle flavors that combine savory and fruity accents and mild acidity and tannins. It's medium to full-bodied and soothing to sip.

An 18th-century family-owned property is the source of this crisp, textured, ripe wine. With plenty of tannins to give it structure and perfumed black fruits to convey the juicy character, it is in good shape to age a little longer. Drink from mid-2018.

This blend of Carmenre, Syrah, Cab Sauvignon and Petit Verdot smells of forced oak and mint on top of standard berry scents. The palate is full and oaky but not heavy. Ripe yet racy flavors of jammy berry fruits are woody on a finish that's tannic and rubbing.

This wine boasts a fruity nose of tropical and citrus notes along with white flowers and ginger spice. The acid is balanced by some fruit weight and a chalky texture, while a copper penny tang keeps things interesting.

Plum and raspberry aromas are on the spot and inviting, with a touch of smoky darkness. A firm, slightly clamping palate is lively and extended, while this tastes of savory, saucy plum and berry fruits. A note of ocean salt pokes through on a solid finish.
Very fresh, primary notes of green pear and apple swirl on the nose of this wine. The palate adds a savory element of chervil, celery salt and yeast to this refreshing, moreish package.

Full of yummy, ripe plum, boysenberry and black-pepper flavors, this full-bodied and smooth-textured wine is a great value. It's very mouth filling, soothing and delicious and has a deep color, lush and fruity aromas and soft tannins on the palate.

Crisp blackberry and cherry flavors are bright, but this complex wine is more about their interplay with earthier tones of smoke, game and mushroom. Rich and full on the palate yet balanced firmly with tannins and acidity, it's a stately wine with a lingering, slightly astringent chestnut finish.

From a vineyard recently replanted and coming into its own, this offers dusty weavings of tobacco, clove, tar and leather, as burly and brawny as a humidor. Big-boned and ripe, the tannins are seamless on the palate and soft on the finish.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of underbrush, cedar and black-skinned berry. The chewy palate delivers blackberry jam, licorice, black pepper and coffee alongside fine-grained tannins. Enjoy now through 2024.

Bolstered by a splash of co-fermented Syrah, this wine's soft and inviting nose shows black cherries, smoke, bay leaf and crushed rose petals. This bottling contains more hickory smoke seasoning than past vintages, which surrounded the red cherry and purple flower flavors. It's a great pairing for a barbecue.
This is a ripe and juicy young wine. With soft tannins and bright red fruits, it is crisp while also structured. It will age further to give a generous, full-throated wine. Drink from late 2018.

A slight hint of ripe, red cherry appears on the nose. The palate has a gentle, red-fruited freshness and a juicy generosity. A slight frame of tannins provides a gentle structure in this honest, fresh-faced and highly appetizing Pinot Noir.

Sublime in texture, all smooth and velvety contours, this fruit-forward wine has a medium-bodied frame rich and ripe in white peach and vanilla. The peach turns to guava and mango as it develops additional fleshy creaminess in the glass.

Immediately appealing on the nose, this reserve offers a wealth of aromas in brandied cherry, anise, clove and savory dried meat tones. The palate works to further integrate these notes into flavors of juicy cherry, rich plum and shots of cranberry. Sultry in feel, with integrated, bolstering tannins, drink this wine through 2020 to enjoy its luscious primary flavors and developing sanguine tones.

Smoked meat, dried mint and roasted black plums combine for a complex sense of elegance on the nose of this bottling. The flavors are cohesive yet varied, with black currant, violet and roasted beef, upheld by tannins that are soft yet steady, with a growing presence toward the finish.

This John Legend-led partnership is a blend of 55% Petite Sirah, 39% Merlot, 5% Cabernet Sauvignon and 1% Petit Verdot. Bright, focused red cherry and cassis meets soft rounded tannin that contributes to a seamless offering of velvety texture.

This is a great change-of-pace wine, rather full in body and rich in texture, but with zesty grapefruit and rose petal aromas and buttery almond-like flavors that are more savory than simply fruity. As if Italian native Fiano wasn't a rare enough grape variety, the winemaker blended in 15% of Coda di Volpe, an even lesser known Italian variety.

This wine's fresh, bright and zesty lime and green pear scents have a lovely touch of nettle. The palate has the sprightly ease of these fresh flavors but also a lovely, grounding element of yeast that adds texture.

This wine is nicely balanced considering how big it is in terms of tannin and body. The aromas ooze blueberry syrup and blackberry jam while the flavors are equally rich. The texture is quite firm and tannic but it feels right and will help the wine age well. Best after 2022.

A touch of smoky, spicy oak flavor gives this ripe and berry-soaked wine a nice twist of complexity. It has strawberry and boysenberry aromas, and full, almost jammy, flavors riding on a smooth texture that shows soft tannins.

Lifted aromas of lemon and grapefruit combine with toasted nuts, green flower stems and a salty, sea spray quality. The acidity in this wine at the moment is searing and texturally it's a little lean and mean, but this fum-style Sauvignon should be an interesting one to watch develop in bottle over the next few years.

Coming from a site in the Rocks District, this wine is lighter in color and brings initially subdued aromas of cassis, herb, medicine cabinet, plum, cherry and spice. The palate is soft in feel, putting a premium on elegance of expression, with the tannins quite supple. It's a very pretty expression of the variety.

Listed at a low alcohol level for a hot vintage and vineyard, this is still and 100% varietal. Its black licorice, sugared plum and exotic spice aromas show a penetrating purity. The palate is all about delicacy and elegance, which it brings in abundance. It's a very pretty expression of this variety, maybe too much so for some tastes, without the variety's typical tannic heft. But for those looking for a sophisticated style of Cabernet, look no further.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this offers aromas of cooking spice, leather and a whiff of violet. The firm palate delivers ripe black cherry, clove and licorice set against closed-grained tannins. Drink through 2025.

Black olive, truffle and a nuanced streak of graphite shine in this softly textured, focused and well-made wine. Cedar and dried herb complement quietly in the background, as integrated oak supports without distraction.
