Aged for three months in barrel, this smooth, rounded ros is both fruity and rich. It has good acidity from the attractive red-currant fruit and an orange tang of zest at the end. Drink now.

Elderberry, wood smoke, charred beef and baked soil show on the nose of this bottling from a region south of Hollister. There is a lot of earthy flavor on the sip, with wet soil adding to the tangy black plum skin and smoke qualities.

Slightly sour cranberry fruit meets with dust and uncrushed peppercorn on the nose of this mostly Merlot bottling. The tangy red-plum-skin fruit shows on the sip too against a backbone laced in dried garden herbs.

A very pale yellow in color, this bottling shows aromatic pear and lime juice on the broad yet sharp nose. The texture is a bit flat on the sip, and the peachy flavors are quite strong, with yellow pear in the midpalate and a slightly vinous touch on the finish.
While this wine is all about fruit, it also has some concentration that gives it a full-bodied character that contrasts with the berry flavors and acidity. It is ready to drink.

Petrol and wild herb notes mask cleaner aromas of citrus and apple on the nose. There's some nice weight to the palate, with bright acidity to match, yet the kerosene note continues to overpower ripe peach and apricot.
This is a well-behaved wine that should please a crowd with its easygoing plummy flavors, smooth texture and soft acidity. It's medium-bodied and fresh-tasting.
This wine has some structure, with an edge of dryness that highlights the ripe red fruits and acidity. A fruity wine from one of the top Burgundy producers, it is ready to drink now.

Aromas of moist soil, new leather and a whiff of dark spice lead the way. The wiry palate is on the lean side, offering hints of sour cherry and dark spice alongside firm acidity and dusty, rather fleeting tannins. Racy acidity keeps it light on its feet. Drink now.

This is basically Sauvignon Blanc, with 10% Carmenre added in for body. As a result, the nose is chunky and smells lightly of pumpkin and squash. A tangy palate is oily in feel, with green-fruit flavors. Popping acidity pushes a salty tasting finish.

Wilting flowersgreen stems and allmeld with soft citrus on the nose. The rounded palate boasts plenty of ripe peach and melon, with loads of more florals dragging along. Mild acidity tries to keep up but ultimately dissipates on a green, geranium finish.
A rich, slight boozy, nose of brandied cherry, cinnamon and bubble gum spice leads to a primary, ripe palate. Medium in weight, with soft tannins, its showy fruit lingers on the finish.

Citrus and grassy aromas are just lively enough. The same can be said for the palate on this basic SB: it's a touch flabby and not blazing with acidity. Melon, citrus and generic green flavors finish quietly and without edginess. Drink immediately.

Stewed berry aromas are a touch murky, while this feels dense, tannic and sticky. Stewed earthy plum and berry flavors come with a note of coffee grounds, while this is herbal and beefy on the finish.

Ripe notes of peach and apricot meld with white flowers and freshly cut grass in this Riesling. There's a nice roundness to the palate, yet the melon and peach flavors lack intensity. Mild acidity leads to a short, yet clean, finish.

A green, herbal streak weaves throughout the ripe plum and boysenberry character on the nose and mouth of this solid, straightforward wine. It's well balanced and easy to like, with soft tannins that frame the vibrant plum and cherry flavors, followed by a short yet clean finish.

Predominately Cabernet Franc, this ros shows a good intensity of ripe strawberry and raspberry on the nose, with tart pomegranate kicking in on the palate. A well-placed balance of acidity keeps the fruit-filled palate in check, making this a perfect easy-sipping glass.

A yellowish shade of pink in the glass, this bottling shows aromas of yellow peach and orange rind. Seared lemon rinds appears on the sip, alongside a touch of walnut in what is almost an oxidative style.

Pas is known for rustic meaty aromas, and this wine, which also contains Moscatel, smells a lot like hot dogs before cooking. A mildly thick palate with floral cherry and raspberry flavors finishes with drying tannins and the taste of rose water.

Stewed cherries, baking spice and cranberry-laced fruit-punch aromas show on the nose of this bottling. Cooked watermelon, plum jam and pomegranate reveal themselves on the plush palate, which lacks a bit of zip.

Tight and lean, this has restrained aromas of moist forest floor, leather, espresso and balsamic notes. The firm palate offers dried cherry, steeped prune and oak-driven spice alongside raspy tannins that leave an astringent finish.
Yeasty vanilla aromas blend with notes of green melon and banana. In the mouth, this is chunky and round, with modest acidity. Yeasty flavors of green banana confirm that this is a mid-level wine.
A bright pink color and unusually toasty spicy aromas are followed by bright raspberry flavors and a heavy layer of oaky spices, like cinnamon and ginger. It's a ros with attitude.
Pomegranate and fennel frond aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The palate has cranberry and more pomegranate, with a crushed slate and gunmetal minerality.

This opens with aromas of sun-baked soil, truffle, used leather and a whiff of overripe plum. The earthy aromas carry over to the no-frills palate along with dried cherry and a hint of ground pepper. Dusty, rather fleeting tannins give it an abrupt, astringent finish.

This opens with aromas of blackberry jam, exotic spice and a whiff of French oak. The palate is tight and lean, offering prune, star anise and a slightly green note of powdered sage alongside astringent, grainy tannins that leave a dusty finish.
Underbrush, tobacco and stewed prune aromas lead the nose. It's hard and lean in terms of fruit richness, offering raw sour cherry and clove alongside an acidic backbone and bracing, grainy tannins.

Syrah and Merlot make up the majority of this blend, which is topped off with pinches of other Bordeaux and Rhne varieties. The aromas are inviting, with notes of blueberry pie, herb and smoke. The fruit flavors don't entirely deliver on this promise, with quite-light plum notes that paint around the edges. Vanilla notes linger on the finish.
Fruity and flowery aromas of black cherry soda, dried strawberry and hibiscus show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is somewhat thin, with flavors of berry jam, anise and a pinch of thyme.

This see-through Pinot with a rusty tint smells of tomato leaf, herbs and mixed spices, while fruit aromas are tertiary and not very ripe. A basic palate is low on energy, while this tastes of gritty plum and pepper. A slight bitterness extends onto a dry finish.
Produced from 60-year-old vines, this crisp, juicy wine is bright with acidity and forward red-berry flavors. Light and fruity, it's ready to drink.

While this wine has some of the tannic structure of Morgon, its juicy fruits and hints of banana give a much lighter character. Fruitiness drives this crisp wine and will allow it to be drunk from mid-2018.
This has a subdued, fleeting nose showing cellar floor, weedy underbrush and used leather. The evolved palate offers mature cherry coffee and a hint of spice around loose, short-lived tannins.

Punchy citrus aromas are within normal parameters for Leyda SB. A tight citric palate is loaded with pyrazines, causing citrus and lemon-lime flavors to come across as tangy and grassy. A finish with a texture of wet rocks is juicy but green in flavor.

This blend of 50% Cabernet Franc and 50% Zinfandel shows pepper, plump purple flowers, candied berries and Concord grape on the nose. There is piquant boysenberry fruit on the sip, as well as candied violets and lilacs, but the wine still tastes very young and needs more resolution.

This single-estate wine is perfumed, lightly structured and full of ripe, juicy red fruits. With acidity and spice in equal measure, it is soft, packed with fruitiness and acidity, and ready to drink.
Aromas of plum, baking spice and Band-Aid lead to a medium-bodied palate with a lightly tacky feel. The tannins bring a sense of astringency and it finishes bitter.

Coming from one of the state's top vineyards and 100% varietal, this has aromas of cherry, cranberry, vanilla and freshly chopped wood which lead to tart cherry flavors that display a bitter note that distracts. Barrel aged for 20 months in 60% new French oak, the wood influence seems heavy, getting in the way of the finish.

Smoky oak, savory aromas of cured meats and a dark extracted color introduce this blend from the Itata and Maule regions. A heavy tannic palate is rubbery and concentrated in feel, while gritty, roasted blackberry and black plum flavors are peppery and finish with scratchy drying tannins.
Aromas of green herb, baking spice, nori, licorice and black cherry are followed by tart dark-fruit flavors that seem bunched up. It falls off on the finish, displaying a light medicinal note.

Dark plum, mulberry, wet river stones and a touch of caramel show on the nose of this bottling. Candied pomegranate and baked red plum arise on the sip, with strong vanilla and baking spice flavors. The tannins are oddly both thin and chalky.

Standard plum and berry aromas are clean and get the job done. This is clampy on the palate, with grapy dark-fruit flavors. Solid fruit character and firm tannins on the finish confirm that this is a good everyday Cabernet.

Sourced from a vineyard on the bluff of Keuka Lake, this is ultraripe in expression, boasting a mix of stone and tropical fruit, blended with a spicy hop character. The palate is off dry in style, with a lush, slightly overblown feel, that leads to a mildly hot finish.

Shades of spicy bramble and strawberry aromas blend with earthier, stemmy tones on the nose of this blend. Light in feel, but with a charming roundness, the palate pleases in boisterous red cherry and raspberry flavors, flecked by peppery spice.

Waxy lemon, green beans, melon and wet stone show their faces, if shyly, in this Kiwi Pinot Gris. The palate is slippery in feel, with a tongue-tingling line of prickly acidity and citrus notes throughout.
High-toned aromas of pencil lead, game, dark plum, fruit leather and green herb lead to plentiful dark-fruit flavors. The fruit seems a bit dried out.
Plum and berry aromas are solid and clean. This has a fresh snappy linear mouthfeel and plum flavors that hold up to scrutiny. Light notes of chocolate and toast lend some richness to the finish.

Fresh cranberry and herbal spice aromas carry to the light- to medium-bodied palate, which boasts a bit of white pepper and violet flavors. Bright acidity and sandy tannins maintain the delicate frame. Drink now.

The nose, with fiery red-fruit scents, includes a hint of latex. This feels full and slightly heavy on the palate, while lightly burnt berry and plum flavors end in blocky fashion, with a note of chocolate.
This wine is pure juicy fruit. It bubbles with red cherries, acidity and a crisp shot of acidity. A refreshing, lightly structured wine, it is ready to drink.

Opaque in color, this dense, rich wine feels nearly impenetrable. Hidden beneath the dusty oak and ripe blackberry flavors lie savory, herbal undertones. There's juicy black fruit on the palate and the tannins are drying but the fruit keeps things just supple enough to be approachable.

Rubbery roasted aromas of burnt leaves and generic berry fruits are fine but not compelling. This Cab has a big jammy outlook. Candied flavors of berry fruits, oak and brown sugar convey ripeness, but the finish is low on acidity and weak on tannins, and thus this ends quietly.
Currant, tomato and grassy scents bring ripeness into question. This feels solid but grabby, while slightly green and oaky flavors of medicinal red fruits carry over to a steady finish.
A gritty nose smells of asphalt, which brings overall ripeness into question. A flat wide palate is resiny and oaky, while this tastes a bit burnt and green, with tarry berry flavors.

Sweet aromas of coconut and vanilla dance over light fruit tones of cherry and strawberry on the nose. This Cabernet Sauvignon-dominant blend shows a playful palate of spice, cherry and anise, with enough tension to keep you coming back for more.

This is a very smooth, gentle wine, offering plenty of lush strawberry and cherry in the aroma and flavor while not going overboard in body. It feels supple and lightly sweet on the palate, and has very mild tannins.

Grassy aromas are mildly citric and show cool, underripe notes of canned peas and beans. A citric bolt adds life to an otherwise fleshy palate, while this tastes of green grape skins, lime and asparagus prior to a slightly bitter finish.

Cola spice, cherry stems and red plum lead the entry of this pleasant Syrah. The lightweight palate is easy and accessible, with juicy red-fruit tones that fill the palate. Hints of baking spice grace the close. Drink up.
Generous oak and tannin dominate around a sizable ripeness of cherry and vanilla in this youthful wine. Tart acidity accents the baked character of the fruit.

New leather, camphor and dark spice aromas take shape on this. The wispy, light-bodied palate isn't as expressive, offering suggestions of tart cherry and ground brown spice alongside loose tannins and racy bright acidity. Drink now.

Crushed asphalt and wet gravel meet with baked black cherry and a slight hint of herbs on the nose of this bottling. Though the acidity is balanced, the tannins are a bit clunky on the palate, where boysenberry, tar, cocoa and coffee flavors arise.

After a few swirls of the glass, you'll detect aromas of fleshy black cherry, leather and culinary spice. On the lean, linear palate, you'll find sour cherry, orange zest and chopped sage set against brisk acidity and bracing, grainy tannins.
A five-acre parcel of Chardonnay is the source of this soft, fruity wine. Wood aging has added extra richness as well as spice to the crisp apple and pear flavors. The wine is ready to drink.
Brawny and rustic, this wine is sizable in tannin and oak, making for a big presence on the palate. Spicy clove is met by leathery tobacco and varietal aspects of cedar and dried herb.

This single-vineyard Cabernet Franc has an interesting nose of dried beef and mesquite over a ripe cherry core. The soft, pillowy palate gives way to sweet vanilla and cherry flavors, balanced by a mild current of cranberry acidity. Oak dust marks the close.

Rustic cherry, rhubarb and turned loam, along with a touch of fresh thyme, show on the nose of this fancifully labeled twist-top bottling. It's a bit thin on the palate, with sour red fruit, bay leaf and anise flavors.
A one-acre parcel of young vines has given this bright, crisp wine. With its flavors of pear and touches of apricot it is both fruity and brightly textured. Drink this wine now.

This wine pulls from all over Sonoma County to create a tannic, oaky and fruity combination of lush black cherry and cassis wrapped around vanilla and dried herb. Bold and brawny, it holds its ripeness in check.
Standard aromas of celery, lime, gooseberry and minerals set up a palate that's not flat but is definitely low on snap and acidity. Lightly vegetal citrus flavors finish soft. Drink immediately.

Wood smoke aromas and flavors give a spicy edge to this full-bodied, moderately tannic and perhaps slightly sweet wine. A toasted oak element is behind the smokiness, and it provides good counterpoint against the almost syrupy fruit flavors.
Cut grass, wet cement and lemon wedge show on the slightly reductive nose of this bottling. The palate is sour and almost bitter with more cut grass and strong grapefruit-peel flavors.

Mild fruit flavors and subtle spices give this medium-bodied wine a low profile. The aromas are vaguely appley and the flavors bring hints of vanilla, while soft acidity and a light buttery finish complete the picture.

Quite aromatic and equally flavorful, this medium-bodied wine has a sense of sweetness from the strawberry and sandalwood aromas to the marinated cherry and maple syrup flavors. The texture is rounded and soft.

Aromas reminiscent of weedy underbrush, overripe berry, roasted herb and a whiff of salted game lead the nose. The gamy note follows over to the evolved, rustic palate along with dried cherry, grilled sage, and clove alongside while close-grained fleeting tannins give it a loose framework. A salty note marks the close.

Rustic leafy aromas are gritty and lean. This light-colored, lighter-bodied Pinot is racy up front, with a sticky note of animal fat on the back palate. Earthy, lightly oxidized flavors finish without elegance.
Vegetables are in the fore of this wine, leading with notes of buttered green beans and mushroomsgrapefruit and lemon tones bring up the rear. The palate is rich and heavy but with searing acidity.

Subdued aromas of underbrush, celery, truffle and a whiff of used leather set the tone. The aromas carry over to the dense, evolved palate along with dried blackberry, prune and evident alcohol. Raspy, fleeting tannins dry out the finish.

Hailing from Antoine Creek Vineyard, the aromas of herb, cherry and spice seem to show some oxidation. Meanwhile, the medium-bodied cherry and raspberry flavors are straight down the fairway, providing enjoyment if not a lot of complexity.

This opens with subdued aromas suggesting underbrush, camphor, oak and a whiff of cured meat. The palate is a bit muddled and rather diluted, offering hints of sour cherry, salt and espresso alongside dusty, somewhat fleeting tannins that leave a mouth-drying finish.

A tropical fruit bowl of pineapple, mango and papaya carries intensity on the nose, with a little grass and white pepper in the background. The palate is less exuberant but it makes for an enjoyable sipper nonetheless.

While oak-driven on the nose, boasting swathes of espresso bean and cocoa nibs, there's a core of ripe cherry and plum that carries the palate. A judicious balance of acid keeps this wine in check, while mild-grained tannins offer further support. A slight note of green stems arises on the midpalate through the astringent finish.

Aromas of underbrush, prune, toast, used leather and a whiff of blue flower emerge in the glass. The short, simple palate offers black cherry and vanilla alongside dusty, somewhat fleeting tannins that leave a drying finish.
Old vines with concentration and light tannins give this wine its intensely fruity character. It has a juicy, crisp edge along with good acidity and a bright aftertaste. Drink the wine now.

Cherry and plum aromas include a note of green. This blend of Grenache, Carignan and Mourvdre is lean and choppy on the palate, with more acidity than body and fruit. Raw plum and cherry flavors finish gritty and underdeveloped.

Slightly raisiny aromas form the opening. In the mouth, this is chewy and full, with abrasive tannins. Saucy flavors of plum, tomato and currant finish dry and woody, with a lasting note of clove that comes straight from the barrel.

Candied, slightly broken raspberry aromas are mildly grassy. This Cab has rubbery tannins and a by-the-glass mouthfeel. Plum and tomato flavors are a bit salty, while this burns with spice notes on the finish.
Whiffs of raspberry and cherry follow over to the extremely simple, light-bodied palate along with a hint of clove. Loose tannins offer relaxed support. Drink soon.
Subtle stone fruit and delicate floral tones lead into a heavier-than-expected palate. There's a touch of residual sugar here amidst the fleshy stone fruit characters, with a brisk, short finish.
Gamay makes an attractive ros, crisp and fruity. With red-currant and berry flavors, the wine is light, bright and lively. It demands to be drunk immediately.

Extremely light on the nose, this wine eventually shows pleasant aromas of nectarine and orange peel. The palate is also inoffensive but mild, with poached apple and pear flavors, a touch of seared orange and the taste of a lemon juice on sweet squash.
This attractively structured wine offers ripe cherry fruit and an edge of firm tannins. It's rich, full of fruit, smooth and ready to drink.
This is a simple, fruity wine, crisp and bright with red cherries. Acidity and light texture make it immediately drinkable. It is a well-made, delicious wine.
Classic Kiwi Sauvignon Blanc aromas of passionfruit, grapefruit and blossoms set the stage for a crisp, easy-going palate.
Withered violet, dried sage and toast aromas lead the nose. The firm, fleeting palate offers dried cherry, orange zest and roasted coffee bean alongside dusty, astringent tannins.

A pumped-up oak and spice character dominates this medium-bodied wine in terms of both aroma and flavor, so it sings a two-note song of nutmeg and vanilla. The texture is smooth and the finish seems sweet from the baking spice tones.
An aroma of coffee puts a blanket over herbal bramble berry tones. There's a savory and almost sour note of tart fruit on the palate, with a thin feel and sharp acidity.

This SB from the southerly outpost of Malleco smells briny and green, which given its cool origins is not a shock. A chunky palate holds vegetal flavors of peas, green onion, fennel and bell pepper, while a lean finish suggests nettle and milkweed.

Aromas of coconut, toast, oak-driven spice and a whiff of prune lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the rather diluted, lean palate along with sour cherry and roasted coffee bean. Astringent, fleeting tannins give it an abrupt close.

Aromas of plum and high-toned dried herb lead to cherry and berry flavors. The tannins bring a lightly gritty feel. The tartness of the acidity adds to the enjoyment, but you'd never peg it for Cabernet.

Rough aromas of road tar and forced oak are most prominent on this Cabernet. A fully extracted palate is tough to process, while roasted blackberry flavors run heavy on the oak and clove. On the finish, a leftover clove flavor dominates.

Scents of vanilla and sweet spice greet the nose upon entry, while raspberry sauce and brambly berry provide a solid grounding for the medium-weight palate. The tannins are soft and the acidity low, with a lingering mocha accent on the rich finish. Drink now.
Black cherry and strawberry notes are a tad muted in this demure, full-bodied red. Soft acidity and tannins lend an approachable appeal but it's best to drink this wine young.
This wine is simple and fruity. Crisp black-cherry fruit is lifted by refreshing acidity while the light texture gives the wine an attractive tangy character. Drink now.
This bright and crisp wine has red fruits, a touch of vanilla and lively acidity. It is a simple, fruity wine that is ready to drink.
Subtle notes of tomato leaf, passionfruit and tropical fruit undertones are followed by a boney palate of tongue tingling acidity. Drink now.
Very shy aromas of red berries and wet mud make for an earthy muddled nose. There is a flash of acid on the sip, followed by dust, more red fruit and a slightly woody spice.
Sweet-seeming oak aromas and flavors grab the attention in this medium-bodied wine, while moderate tannins and rather soft acidity make it easy to sip.
This wine tastes quite mature and savory and feels soft, showing some complexity of sun-baked fruit and earthy undertones.
This soft, strawberry-jam-flavored wine is made from organically grown grapes. It has a pure fruity character just gently touched by tannins, presenting an almost sweet, ripe character. Drink now.

This is one of the more odd-smelling Pinots you'll come across. Aromas of milk chocolate, cherry and mint are candied as a whole. In the mouth, however, this smacks with cool-climate acidity. Flavors of cherry, plum and oak-based chocolate finish with raw tannins.
Leafy berry and cassis aromas are basic. This feels hard and choppy, with no sense of flow to the palate. Generic berry flavors finish chocolaty and a bit oaky.
This straightforward and fruity wine is relatively light bodied, offering juicy black cherry and strawberry flavors and a hint of sweetness. It's soft and easy to sip.

Pleasant notes of baked plum and black-cherry compote present an enticing bouquet to this wine. The palate is sharper and leaner in feel, with tart and slightly bitter fruit-skin flavors that finish clean but quick. Drink now.

Very shy on the nose, this bottling offers dark red fruit and baking spice aromas with patience. The palate is flat and dull yet inoffensive, with flavors of sweet red fruit, herbs and char on the finish.
Assertive oak wraps around substantial richness and body weight in this highly ripe wine that lacks somewhat in structure. Tropical vanilla and coconut linger longest.
From vines that surround the Fessy winery, this juicy, fruity wine also has a tang of tannins. Its acidity and crisp texture are immediately attractive and the wine is drinkable now.
A note of kerosene dominates on the nose of this wine, which carries to a ripe, juicy palate of stone fruit. Medium dry in style, this is straightforward and easy drinking. Drink now.
Soft and almost sweet, this medium-bodied wine has a rose perfume, stewed plum, cherry syrup and nutmeg flavors. It is smooth on the palate, showing little acidity or tannin.

The aromas display an uncomfortable mix of vanilla, dill and smoke, with the barrel influence taking over the show. The wood rides high on the palate as well, making it near impossible to get at the fruit.

Other than that this is made from Pedro Ximnez and comes from a high-elevation vineyard in remote Elqui, there's almost nothing to this basic white table wine. Mild white-peach and yeasty aromas are followed by a bland palate. Lightly oxidized flavors of wheat and stone fruits are salty, while low acidity means the finish is soft.

Wood-heavy aromas of bacon and clove don't allow for much fruit expression. This is tannic and weighty on the palate, with flavors of baked berry fruits, clove and burnt wood. Bacon and clove notes remain out front on a finish that's all about oak.
The aromas bring bright notes of mandarin orange peel, honeysuckle and lime zest. It drinks off dry, with a lightly spritzy palate packed full of ripe peach flavors.
Soupy berry and oak aromas lead to a thick dense palate. Highly herbal plum flavors are drenched in milk-chocolaty oak, while this is sluggish on the finish.
Citrus and green apple take center stage in this medium-bodied Chardonnay. The palate has a mild intensity of these flavors, with soft acidity offering some structure.

Aromas of toasted oak, pressed violet, roasted coffee bean and ground pepper carry over to the wiry palate along with raisin and powdered sage. It lacks fruit richness while grainy tannins leave a raspy finish.
Toasted oak and a huge concentration of tannin dominate in this burly, full-bodied and highly ripe wine, which finishes in a bittersweet and sour taste of leather.

There's a chemical quality to this wine that doesn't seem to blow away. Dusting polish, smoked meats and berries lead into a tightly wound palate of tart red fruit and more polish, with chunky tannins and apparent oak.
Reticent aromas of citrus, green apple and crushed stone carry to a light-bodied, quince-driven palate, with a metallic edge. Spritzy in feel, this is simplistic but enjoyable.

Funky aromas of scorched soil, withered rose, used leather, stewed prune and a hint of barnyard follow over to the overripe palate along with licorice and a gamy note. Dusty, evolved tannins offset the earthy flavors.

This has a shy nose that eventually reveals moist underbrush, oak and a whiff of salted meat. The palate is somewhat diluted, presenting suggestions of dried black cherry, fennel and toasted oak alongside fleeting but drying tannins.
Jammy berry aromas are herbal like desert brush. This is a pulpy wine with a jammy palate. Earthy stewy berry flavors are green and oaky on the finish.
Crisp and fruity, this light, bright wine has strawberry and red-currant flavors as well as a lively background of acidity. It is totally ready to drink.
Fermented with natural yeast, this light wine is crisp with red fruits and acidity. It is a delicate wine, bright and ready to drink.
Aromas of stewed prune and wet underbrush follow over to the evolved palate together with a hint of dried cranberry and clove. Dusty, fleeting tannins give it an abrupt finish.
This is a light wine, just juicy red cherries and bright acidity. The structure is also light, leaving fruitiness and immediate drinkability as the wine's main characteristics. Drink now.
Medium-bodied and pleasant to sip, this unassuming wine has subtle plum flavors and a smooth texture. The mouthfeel is soft and the finish is short.

Coconut, French oak, vanilla and dried sage aromas follow through to the austere, assertive palate alongside firm acidity. Unyielding, close-grained tannins give it an astringent, lean finish. It lacks the fruit richness needed to stand up to the oak.

This wine is a blend of fruit from Antoine Creek and Gingko Forest vineyards. Quite light in color, the aromas show a light volatility, along with notes of raspberry, strawberry and maraschino cherry. The fruit flavors are light, simple and sweet, finishing with peppermint notes.

Neutral aromas lack pungency and instead are yeasty and suggestive of green pepper and mild citrus fruits. A round palate lacks the pop and zest that Chilean SB often shows, while this tastes of grassy melon and white pepper prior to a flat finish.

From a new urban winery located in the heart of Geneva, NY, this Riesling shows toast, smoke and slate notes over a core of citrus on the nose. Round in feel, with a good balance of acidity, the palate shows more fruitpeach and lemon curdthat carries to a crisp, clean finish.

Citrus spray and delicate peach aromas are behind a thin veil of pollen and yeast tones on the nose. The light-bodied palate shows a bit more clarity in its cleaner citrus and stone-fruit flavors, yet ultimately this is a straightforward and accessible semidry Riesling.

This unoaked Chardonnay has a mild intensity of underripe peach and citrus on the nose, with a muddling of white flowers. The palate lags a bit with soft acidity, yet ripe peach chugs along to the finish.
Slightly weak aromas of pomegranate-laced fruit punch, herbs and dust show on the nose of this bottling. Strawberry and fennel flavors are evident on the palate.

Soapy citrus and cantaloupe aromas are rather bland. This is quite high in acidity, while the wine's lean body struggles to support that raciness. Mild stone-fruit and citrus flavors are lightly bitter on a tangy finish.
Soft although with a crisp edge, this wine offers flavors of red cherry and red currant. Plenty of acidity gives the wine its fresh character. It has a tangy, lightly tannic aftertaste.
Bright, brisk and fruity, this is a light wine. Soft tannins contrast attractively with the red-cherry juiciness. Drink now.
Largely neutral white-fruit aromas include a hint of citrus. On the palate, this SB feels a bit flat and fleshy, with mild acidity. Standard apple and orange flavors are salty across a basic finish.

With a straw-gold hue, this is a creamy, full-bodied wine, with an unusual medley of asparagus, tomato stalk, ginger and lemon notes. On the palate, the acidity is nicely balanced but the style is rather brash and odd.

Hickory-cured meat, sweet smoke, mocha, raspberry compote and berry preserves all dance on the nose of this decadent value wine. The palate offers similar concentration, with fine tannins and a strong dose of blackberry-laced coffee on the close. Drink now.

A raw nose with green-herb and bell pepper aromas offers just enough cohesion and fruit to be decent. In the mouth, this is wiry and racy on first impression, then soft. Leafy herbal berry and prune flavors culminate on a vacuous finish.

This extremely dark and concentrated wine has aromas like smoked ham plus peppery smoky flavors that push the limit of style, along with very obvious tannins that leave a drying impression on the palate.

If you're looking for a basic white quaffing wine that's priced to sell but won't wow, this is it. Oily aromas of almond skins come with hints of apple and pear. Modest acidity and nutty, yeasty flavors of salt and bitter melon finish with signs of early oxidation.
A very light nose conveys purple fruit, dried herbs and a bit of bell pepper on the nose of this bottling. Pasilla chile shows on the sip alongside boysenberry, thyme and wood spice.
As simple and fruity as a Beaujolais can be, this is light, bright and full of red cherries. Acidity and tangy texture make the wine totally drinkable now.

Melony vanilla aromas are flat, while this mature SB feels plump and fleshy, but distant. Wheaty bland flavors of white melon lack pop and vitality, while this tastes and feels bready on a tired finish.

A neutral nose shows a hint of citrus but that's it. This feels more plump and flabby than well cut, but it's not outright flat. Chunky melony citrus flavors end with low acidity. Drink this value-priced quaffer with caution.

A definitive green nose smells just short of vegetal, while a round, plump palate with good acidity is a high point for this Elqui SB. A vegetal flavor of canned beans doesn't shed the wine's core green character.

Lightly volatile aromas of baking spice, black licorice, cherry and vanilla lead to sweet, pruney fruit and barrel flavors, with the barrel notes riding high on the finish. It seems quite evolved for its age.
A rusty color and lean, almost grassy aromas set up a tannic but solid palate. Consistency of fruit flavor is lacking as this tastes like leafy plum and pepper prior to a slightly oxidized finish.
Stalky wheaty aromas register as underripe. This Chardonnay feels bland and thin, with yeasty melon flavors that finish without much flavor. Tasted twice with similar findings.
Subdued on the nose, slight indications of ripe peach and pollen carry to a citrus-driven palate. This is light in intensity and complexity, with a sweet-tart notion on the finish.

This starts off somewhat shy and closed, with muted notes of tight black-plum skin, tree bark and black olive. The medium-weight mouth offers a bit more character, with waves of roasted plum and blackberry that finish with a slightly bitter, charred oak edge. Drink now.
Berry fruit aromas are slightly damp and oaky. This feels choppy and chunky, with wiry acidity. Oak and herbal plum flavors finish simply, with a leftover smear of artificial oak.

A true-grit nose smells like you're trailing a road crew laying down asphalt. The palate is rather chunky and beefy, with grilled flavors of meat, pepper and burnt leaves. Fresh fruit is just not part of the package, and that's a problem.

Waxy white-fruit aromas are mild and simple. On the palate, this blend of 60% Chardonnay and 40% Viognier is wide, oily and grainy in feel. Savory salty green melon and banana flavors are lightly oxidized on the finish.
Pale watermelon in color, this wine is straight to the point with its melon and raspberry tones against a slight green herb backdrop. The fresh fruit note turns a bit sour on the finish.

Rusty in color, with tomato, herb and raw-currant aromas, this is shear on the palate and raging with acidity. Flavors of hard spices, lamb fat and herbal red plum just make it to the level of good, while this is tangy and sharp on the finish.
Built to be simple and cheery, at a solid price point, this wine is indeed simple and soft, with flavors of charred oak, soy, black cherry and an intensely herbaceous character.
Oily, slightly vegetal aromas are lacking in pop and purity. On the palate, this is similar to the nose: flat with no cut or angles. A mix of grass and melon flavors finishes mildly bitter.
Named after the village in which the producer has its winery, this wine is all fruit. Red berries and hints of banana give a wine that is crisp, laced with acidity and ready to drink.
Aged 11 months in used French oak, this wine is citrus driven, with a slight toasty edge. The mild acidity carries short flavors, making this a simple pour.
This value wine has an astringency that adds to an overall puckering notion of ripeness and oak. Earthy mushroom and compost underlie red fruit, yeast and cedar.

Earthy notes of carnation, cured game and green peppercorn are pronounced in the bouquet of this wine, with supporting red plum and cherry fruit. The medium-weight palate boasts astringent tannins and fruit-skin flavors that prevail through the grippy close. Drink now.

Aromas of licorice, prune and leather try hard to hold up but fade to herbal and soupy. High tartaric acidity throws the palate out of balance, while this tastes of generic plum and prune. A short chewy finish closes this out.
Earthy cranberry and an herbaceous underbelly ride along this somewhat thin yet ripe wine, which finishes in a bitter twinge of cardamom and oak.

Roasted leafy earthy aromas are less than focused and not entirely fresh. A wide palate is dull-edged, while this tastes woody, earthy and a bit musty, without vivid fruit. Oak-based clove notes ride high on an otherwise bland finish.

A neutral, nearly scentless nose sets up a palate with modest acidity but nothing more. Short citrus flavors see oxidized notes poke through on the finish, indicating that this basic wine from a wet vintage is passing its prime.
A three-acre vineyard of 55-year-old vines has produced this bright, crisply fruity wine. It is juicy with considerable acidity as well as plenty of red-cherry flavors. Drink now.
Lifted aromas of ginger, florals and ripe citrus are somewhat enticing, but the palate is acidic to the point of sourness, with an odd combo of spritz and fruit weight.

A very strong and spicy oak aroma leaps from the glass, and the same dramatic smoke and chocolate element dominates the flavors of this full-bodied wine to the point that any fruity aspects are very muted.

Streamlined aromas of citrus, florals and crisp apples on the nose lead to a richer impression of melon and orange on the palate. Mild acidity and little concentration of flavors make for a simple, straightforward pour.
Apple cider and white-flower aromas are more briny than fresh and perky. This feels plump and oily due to moderate acidity, while salty white-fruit flavors are chunky on a mostly fruitless finish.

A yeasty but light nose with nothing more than a whiff of lime sets up a racy citric palate that's shearing and angular. Tart apple, underripe nectarine and lemon-lime flavors finish long but sharp almost to the point of being sour.

Barnyard aromas and massive, drying tannins really stand out in this unusually raw-boned wine. It smells earthy and smoky, tastes meaty and herbaceous, while the texture is full of potent, gripping astringency on first sip that eventually moderates with subsequent tastes.
Simple fruit and a light texture make for a crisp wine. Red fruits and acidity balance with the light caramel texture and the wine is ready to drink.
This is as simple as Beaujolais can get, all berry fruit, crisp acidity and light tannins. The wine is ready to drink.
This simple wine offers red berry and banana flavors. With its light structure and soft fruit, it is open and ready to drink.
A heavy, sweet-seeming oak coating totally dominates the flavors of this soft-textured low-acid wine. It has baking spices, toasted bread and vanilla, while any fruity component is very subdued.
Flat aromas of yeast, vanilla and animal cracker cookies lead to a palate that's more amorphous than tight. Bitter flavors of green onion and grassy citrus fruits fail to come around on the finish.
This screw cap wine is made to be simple and affordable and it is, with a reduced sensibility to the big amount of oak on offer and a harshness to the waxy apple flavor.
It's not hard to pick out the variety of this wine, with its japaleo jelly and wild strawberry notes. Light in body, with a decent vein of acidity, enjoy soon before the fruit notes drop off.
The cranberry and raspberry aromas show volatility that distracts. The flavors are lightly sweet with a tart finish.
This is a strange wine. The wood aging has taken away the fruit, leaving spice and acidity in its place.
An odd aroma of peanut skin pervades over muddled cherry tones. The palate is light and delicately structured with soft tannins and shots of cranberry and berries.
High-toned aromas of cherry and raspberry are partnered with hints of violets on the nose of this light red. The flavors are fresh, yet fleeting, with a quick finish.
Huge oak and an intensity of ripe flavor give this wine a harsh edginess that's hard to dispel. Compost, coconut and a green hint of bay leaf or cedar mix in a disjointed way.
This mostly colorless ros of Carmenre opens with gritty aromas of orange peel. A tangy palate lacks depth, while this tastes sour and generic, with little virtue to the finish.

An unusual combination of Chardonnay and Sauvignon Blanc has yielded a yeasty-smelling bubbly with little to no fruit on the nose or palate. This tastes mostly like salad, with the vinaigrette and shallots added in. On the plus side, it feels pretty good.

One whiff tells you this ros of Malbec and 10% Petit Verdot is all about pyrazines. A high level of citric acid drives a palate that tastes of orange extract and gritty bitterness. Beyond tang there's not much to a sharp finish.

Rustic gamy aromas of burnt leaves and stewed fruit are sketchy. A raw edgy palate feels tannic and resiny. Stalky berry flavors topped with forced oak end with a mix of wood resin and chocolate notes.
Briny aromas of seashell include notes of petrol and motor oil. A watery palate is just O.K., while this tastes barely of fruit in front of a bitter-leaning finish.
This estate-grown wine carries notes of coconut lotion and melon on the nose. Light in profile, with mild acidity, creamy peach flavors lead to a light sour-butter note on the finish.

Herbal plum and berry aromas are briary at first and then outright herbaceous as this breathes. A heavy, grabby palate sets up berry flavors that are as green as fresh-picked bell peppers. A minty finish confirms that this is an underdeveloped Cabernet.
Bland apple aromas don't stray far from neutral, while this is monotonous on the palate. Oily, slightly bitter stone-fruit flavors deal a green note of scallion on a lightly oxidized finish.
Fuzzy peach, honeycomb and citrus mark the nose and palate. This wine is light in feel, with mild concentration and a brown-sugar finish.

This opens with high-toned fruit aromas of cherry and strawberry that are graced by hits of cedar shavings and balsamic. There's a surprising herbal edge to the palate, which is stalky and linear through the astringent close.
This wine has an herbal pickle-barrel component that won't appeal to everyone. The flavors are on the tart side, like cranberry and capers, and some hard-edged oak sticks out on the finish.
This wine has a funkiness to it that's intensely earthy, with a harshness of oak and tannin.
Honeycomb and wilting citrus blossom notes make up this wine. It's lightly concentrated, with mild acidity and a short finish.

Overtly vegetal, this wine leads with lettuce and green bean characters, with a note of ripe lemon and a sulphuric, struck-match quality. The slippery-textured palate is a little out of whack and it carries a bitter, green vegetal finish.
Heavy oak results in savory, smoky campfire aromas. This Chardonnay is weak in build but goes heavy on the wood, resulting in a wine that lacks in fruit tones.
Cooked blackberries, balsamic vinegar and a hint of pepper show on the nose of this wine, which is over the hill already. Peppercorns, more vinegar and sour berries show on the sip.
A strong smoky, overtly spicy and buttery character swamps any fruitiness in this full-bodied, heavy-textured and seemingly sweet wine.
White-flower aromas carry the nose and lead to a simple palate of yeasty flavors that that are low on fruit intensity.

A soupy, sticky nose is all about milk chocolate. On the palate, this candied, seemingly manipulated Cabernet is choppy and hard. Flavors of cough syrup and Nestl's Nesquik end with drying tannins and a final blast of creamy sweet chocolate.

This ros of Cabernet Franc opens with prickly pyrazine-based aromas. A tight palate is O.K. in feel but offers nothing special or exciting. Bitter flavors of bell pepper and onion fail to find any fruit on the finish.

After many years of calling Pealolen a hidden gem, something is way off with this vintage. Raw oak aromas are chemical, while the wine's herbal blueberry scents are strange. A flabby flat mouthfeel and weedy oak-swollen flavors of mint, alfalfa and wood grain are sketchy. Tasted twice with similar results.
An odd combo of wet grass, charred nuts, wax and grapefruit on the nose lead into a palate that is on the sour side, with mouth-puckering acidity.

This funky sparkling wine hails from Chile's deep south, which is notorious for cool short growing seasons. On the nose, this is oxidized, toasty, yeasty and bready. In general, you can forget fruit with this; it's raw and difficult from head to toe.

Dark and vibrant in color, this is a stellar, jaw-dropping wine, beautiful and powerful, in addition to velvety and complex. It captures a mountain appellation seamlessly, all brawny tannin and lengthy weight. Cranberry, cassis, pencil shavings and wild sage form around a grip of grit and stony mineral.

This is a bright concentrated wine that's velvety in texture and tone. Dried red cherry and cassis complement an undeniably present flirtation of dusty gravel and rock, a taste of terroir that persists and pleases, as medium-bodied weight gives in to a breadth of spicy complexity.

This blends 61% Cabernet Sauvignon, 32% Merlot and 7% Cabernet Franc into a seamless expression of black pepper, garrigue, clove and pencil. Old world in style and in full command of its power, it offers generously layered, intensely robust tannin and concentration that flirts with richness. Half barrel-fermented and half stainless-steel, it shows promise for cellaring; enjoy best 2023 through 2038.

From the iconic site atop the mighty mountain appellation, Rainin is exotic in forest, soy and sage notes, with a powerful and densely layered tannin structure. Black pepper, plum and leather are made all the more complex by a tease of rocky ash that gives the wine a distinct mineral character and earthiness. This is one for cellaring. Enjoy 20242034.

Luxurious in brick, clove and a wealth of black-cherry pie, this is a beautiful succulent wine from the well-farmed site, silky in texture and integrated seamlessly with desirable oak. Saddle leather and black pepper dot the midpalate as a tangle of acidity weaves through, adding freshness and vibrancy. Cellar through 2033.

This is one of the great successes of this vintage. It is generous and rich while also solid and structured. The combination of the essence of black currant and the elegant tannic structure are superb. This is a wine for serious aging and the wine should not be broached before 2026.

This grand vineyard is one of the jewels of Morey Saint-Denis. The structure and density behind this vintage of the wine is generously impressive, with a dark, dry core and fine tannins. To balance this, the wine has weight, opulent fruit and acidity. The result, as it matures, will be a major wine that will age for many years. Drink from 2025.

Produced from vines owned by Louis Jadot, this wine, like all the grand crus in Gevry-Chambertin comes from a vineyard halfway up the slope behind the village. It has the proper structure, but such is the richness of this vintage, the fruit is already sumptuous, full of ripe cherry and berry flavors. At the same time, it is elegant and with such as stylish, smart aftertaste. Drink from 2025.

This is a sumptuous wine as befits a Chardonnay from one of the great white Grand Crus. Intense acidity is spiced by the new-wood aging. A strongly mineral character also marks this powerful wine with generous white and yellow fruits and a zesty, tangy aftertaste. It has a great future. Drink from 2025.

A bright wave of spicy sarsaparilla rides alongside crunchy, vibrant tones of crisp red cherry, pomegranate and dried herbs in this impressive, well-balanced wine from a tremendous site. Medium bodied, it shows grace and strength in equal measure for superb overall balance.

This is a wow wine, half barrel-fermented and half fermented in stainless steel, that impresses from start to finish. Candied cassis and emphatic aromas of violet ride along a soft, delicately layered embrace of pillowy tannin and an expansive finish of pepper and clove. It hints at complexities that are still developing in the bottle.

From one of the series of grand vineyards that line the slope of Gevrey-Chambertin, this powerful and dense wine is packed with tannins as well as beautiful fruit. Its red fruit flavors are supported by a solid structured and concentrated tannins. Despite this power, the wine is stylish, striking a fine balance between structure and fruit. Drink from 2025.

Aromas of strawberry, Mediterranean brush, blue flower, eucalyptus and a hint of new leather carry over to the radiant, elegantly structured palate along with red cherry and licorice. It's gorgeous, vibrant and almost ethereal, with weightless finesse and ultrafine tannins. Drink through 2026.

This estate, now performing on top form, has produced a rich, dense wine. Swathes of black fruits underline the generous structure and intensity. At first taste, the tannins are soft but that turns out to be an illusion. The tannins are just richly cushioned within the beautiful fruit. Drink from 2024.

Incredibly fragrant, this presents an alluring bouquet of dark-skinned berry, cake spice, blue flower, underbrush, crushed rock, exotic spice, spirit-soaked berry and balsamic notes. A combination of finesse and strength, it doles out juicy raspberry, Marasca cherry, licorice and baking spice alongside rounded, velvety tannins that give a smooth texture. It's a compelling wine. Drink through 2029.

This is a powerful wine, with wood aging that adds richness to the dense tannins. Some tough extraction has not detracted from the ripe fruit or structure and will go as the wine matures. It should be ready to drink from 2026.

This vintage was ideal for the rich style that this estate has made its own. This wine is full bodied and ripe with black-currant and dark berry fruits. The tannins fall into the cushioned wine with ease and richness. Of course, the wine should be aged, so wait until 2026.

Smoke and oak commingle on the nose of this bright, crisply underwritten red, with 7% Merlot. Vibrant in red cherry, red licorice and cassis, the flavors are highlighted along a carpet of velvety texture and serious power. Enjoyable now, this should also be lovely and in full grasp of its grace from 20242034.

From the relatively cooler climes of Eden Valley, Henschke's most famous wine focuses on expressing the unique terroir of its 10 acres of 150 plus year old vineyards rather than on power, oak and extraction. This translates to savory and earthy secondary characters at the fore, highlighting herbal notes with licorice, currants and cocoa powder. The palate is silky and savory, and while the toasty oak notes are apparent, they're kept in check with wonderfully balanced acidity. Approachable now, it will morph into a thing of stunning beauty with time. Drink now2037.

This is going to be a rich wine. Although it seems tight and closed at this stage, it is possible to imagine the ripe white fruits with citrus tinges that will emerge. Spice and good acidity are part of the mix of this opulent, succulent wine. Drink from 2023.

This family-owned property at one of the high points in Saint-milion has made a rich, opulent wine, full of perfumed Cabernet Franc and generous Merlot. Ripe blackberries and dark plums are permeated with some serious tannins for aging. Drink this powerful wine from 2025.

This is the new taste for this estate: richly endowed while remaining elegant and suave. Certainly, there is great concentration here as well as rich black fruits. But they are given a sense of style and poise that will remain with this wine as it ages. Drink from 2026.

Structure is the watchword for this wine. With dark tannins and concentration, it obviously has long-term potential. At the same time, the black-currant fruits are ripe and full bodied, giving rich contrast to the tannins. These two elements will allow this wine to age. It will be ready to drink from 2025.

The second vintage release of J. Lohr's Signature wine, first produced to commemorate founder Jerry Lohr's 80th birthday. Rich aromas of stewed black plum, blackberry pie, vanilla, clove and prune cake show on the nose. The mouthfeel is rich overall, but with firm tannins in the background that lend structure to the strawberry and blackberry flavors, graced by hints of wood smoke, peppercorn and licorice. Drink now2029.

This wine is all tannins at this stage, smothering the black fruits. That will change as it matures, revealing dense blackberries and plums as well as keeping its tannins as a base for the exuberant fruitiness. The wine comes from a blend of different parcels that together make up just over four acres of this vineyard owned by Louis Jadot. Drink this wine from 2025.

Exotic and wild, this wine has a funky, floral and herbal core accented in rose garden and whole-cluster crunch. Decadent, the black cherry, blueberry and Asian spice components accentuate a voluptuously velvety texture and miles of black tea and persistent spice.

This wine delivers exactly what old vines should: complexity and intrigue. Delicious sparks of tea and wild strawberry are framed by tightly woven tannins across the broad midpalate, resulting in a velvety texture. The long finish boasts excellent evolution, with underpinnings of cardamom at the end.

Unfortunately, this very tiny vineyard only makes three barrels of Chardonnay, because this bottling is fantastic in every way. The lively nose shows lemon-lime soda, honeydew, gardenia and sea shells, while the palate is framed by a stunning chalky tension and sizzling acidity. Flavors of honeysuckle and green melon meet with salty ocean spray toward the finish.

Powerful and structured, this opulent wine is succulent with fruit and dense with dark tannins. It has power and structure, a strongly mineral texture still bursting with youthful fruit. This grand cru is one of several that make up over half the vineyards in Aloxe-Corton. Drink this wine from 2025.

This grand cru in the village of Morey-Saint-Denis is grandiose, packed with tannins and fruit, powered by both acidity and swathes of rich black cherries. Both juicy and densely structured, it will be impressive as it ages. Drink from 2025.

Interesting and intense aromas of baked bread and coffee syrup combine with deep plum fruit, shaved chocolate, toasted wood and hints of caramel and white pepper on the nose of this excellent Syrah. The palate is framed by suave, chalky tannins, carrying dynamic and delicious flavors of black currant, blackberry, black pepper and roasted espresso beans.

This is from a small block of the proprietor's vineyard and made entirely from one variety. It's gorgeous and perfumed, grippy and hugely structured, with a bright exuberantly complex midpalate of intriguing plum and peppery clove. Gentle and balanced, it's enjoyable now, but will also age. Enjoy best 2024 through 2034.

Vineyards on the hill of Corton are the source for this concentrated wine. The 30-year-old vines give density while also providing great fruit and juiciness. It is an impressive wine, richly endowed with black fruits and layers of dark tannins. Drink from 2025.

Compelling scents of ripe berry, rose petal, exotic spice and a balsamic note of eucalyptus fuse together on this fragrant wine. Structured and loaded with finesse, the concentrated, silky palate delivers juicy red cherry, crushed raspberry, cinnamon and licorice while ultrarefined tannins and fresh acidity lend seamless support. Thanks to the smooth texture and mouthwatering fruit, you won't detect the 15% abv. Drink through 2029.

Always one of Italy's premier white wines, Pieropan's gorgeous 2015 Calvarino sets a new benchmark. Opening with heady aromas of white spring wildflower, citrus blossom, aromatic herb and crushed rock, the savory palate delivers layers of lemon drop, ripe apple, juicy pear and tangy mineral notes. It's concentrated yet elegant and thoroughly delicious. Drink through 2025.

This is a firm wine, bombastic in tannin structure and oak, with a nuanced hint of noble reduction. Youthfully grippy in a thicket of tar, it bristles in black currant, black cherry and sage, dusted in mountain rock, black pepper and a delightful sniff of violet. Entirely barrel-fermented, it should do well in time, enjoyed best from 2023 through 2033 and quite possibly beyond.

This rich wine is full of fruit and structured with layers of tannin. It's also stylish and elegant, with a suave texture that is already attractive. Black fruits mix with the structure to give a wine that will age well. Drink from 2026.

This wine's lip-smacking peach and apricot flavors are slathered with buttery toast notes, yet kept lively by vibrant acidity. Despite the almost decadent flavors, it maintains its precision through a stunningly long finish and gets even better with aeration. Drink now through 2028.

This is a beautifully understated and refined wine, savory in character with complex layers of black olive, lavender and black tea. Secondary characteristics come into play on the silky smooth palate, a mix of old-world cedar, pencil shavings, graphite and gun smoke.

A conservative 4% Cabernet Franc adds floral aroma and subtle herbaceousness to this Cabernet Sauvignon, which bristles on the nose in sandalwood and hibiscus. The rounded rich flavors tend toward red cherry and cassisbig bold layers of concentration supported by well-integrated tannin.

Beautifully oaky and unctuously voluptuous, this is from a tremendously farmed site in the throes of the Petaluma Gap. Richly layered in deep interwoven layers of butterscotch and brioche, its length and breadth are punctuated by sharp teases of wild fennel and nutmeg.

It's difficult to pick a favorite out of the marvelous Brick House 2015s, but this is it. Native yeasts, biodynamic farming and minimal handling all contribute to an old-school method, though it's a cutting edge wine. From the opening aroma, the complexities compound, offering pepper, spice, cranberry, candied rose petal, red berry and cherry notes. Simply a stunning value.

This family-owned estate has produced a structured and dark wine with great concentration balanced by acidity and pure, creamy fruit. It is a wine with a good future. The aftertaste leaves juicy acidity and firm tannins. Drink from 2025.

Luscious notes of pink grapefruit and greengage plum are ripe yet keenly balanced in this invigorating dry Riesling. It's buoyantly fruity and forward now, but nuances of candle wax, spice and sun-baked clay predict even greater depth to come. Beautiful already but likely to intensify further from 20202025.

Profound mineral notes of crushed slate and river rocks differentiate this goldkap bottling from the producer's regular labels. Fleshy white peach and yellow cherry flavors are sweet and plump, but cast in breathtaking layers of shimmering minerality. Electric acidity pierces through a long finish. Although it's a stunner already, it will improve well through 2030 and likely beyond.

This rich, sumptuous wine is both structured and generous. Bold red fruits give it weight, concentration and a good balance between acidity and ripe richness. It comes from a vineyard close to some of the greatest Burgundy grand crus, which explains the wine's structure and potential. Drink from 2022.

The tiny Ribbon Ridge AVA is becoming well known for Oregon Riesling. This succulent, fruit-packed young wine displays impeccably clean apple, peach, pear, apricot and melon flavors. Minerally acidity keeps it lively and fresh, and its intensity and balance suggest it will age for decades. Drink now through 2035 and beyond.

This first effort by Westwood from an Anderson Valley vineyard favored by Copain and Littorai is a stunner. A deft touch of spicy oak lifts the aroma, and meets compelling, intricate notes of red and black cherry, rhubarb and mushroom on the palate. This elegant, memorable wine has great structure due to firm acidity and lightly gripping tannins, which surround and support the wonderful, exotic and complex flavors. Best after 2020.

Entirely barrel-fermented, this deliciously crafted wine is a powerful embrace of grace and beauty, smooth and velvety thick, with a depth of complex layering. Blackberry and black cherry shine brightest amidst a dusty, rocky underbrush of sage and mineral. Built to age with its elegant structure, it will be hard to resist enjoying this wine now.

More like a focused fruit missile than an indiscriminate fruit bomb, this bottling shows flashy, vibrant waves of pure strawberry, red cherry and black raspberry that are edged by hints of dark earth, light spearmint and sweet bay leaf. The sip offers tart and exotic plums wrapped up in an herbal cape of thyme and potpourri. This will please many palates.

There is a tough, tannic core to this otherwise ripe and fruity wine. All to the good, as this will allow the bold, ripe wine to age well. Black-currant fruits are already showing their hand and will intensify, bringing in richness and a dense texture. Drink this wine from 2025.

A sinuous line of tannins runs through this structured wine. It lifts the dark plum and berry fruits and give shape to the spicy, firm wine. As the estate builds in strength, the style of this perfumed, stylish wine will be seen as a benchmark. Drink from 2025.

One of the furthest west of the Saint-Julien estates, this property has been greatly improved with investment from Japanese owner Suntory. The wine from 2015 is dense and impressively concentrated, perfumed black-currant fruits working well with the crisp acidity and solid structure. Drink from 2025.

This vineyard, on the hill above the city of Nuits-St.-Georges, is widely seen as the top premier cru of the appellation. Certainly this rich, structured wine with its great fruit and firm tannins is serious and ageworthy. Ripe, full and concentrated, it needs to age. Drink from 2024.

This aged wine shows the worth of waitingan Old-World expression of balance and grace with plenty of California power. Spicy and exotic on the nose in floral, mushroomy complexity, it has secondary characteristics of cedar and pencil shavings that ride along a gripping yet velvety carpet of texture.

In this vintage, Kelley Fox produced three different Pinots sourced from the Maresh Vineyard. This one is graceful and elegant, showing both old vine gravitas and delicate sensibility. It leads with a complex, smooth and penetrating mix of strawberry, raspberry and cherry flavors and follows with grapefruit, orange peel and cumin hints, which round out its lovely tannins. It even drinks beautifully two days after being opened and should age well.

This is a concentrated and robustly ripe wine, spicy and velvety with a powerful punch of toasted oak. Forest floor elements and a depth of earth provide varietal character as rich interwoven flavors of baked cherry and rhubarb give it a warmth that's expansive across the finish.

This bold, ripe wine is packed with red fruits and balanced acidity. The density and generous tannins are all part of the concentration and powerful texture. Acidity brings necessary freshness to an impressive wine. Drink from 2025.

Extreme amounts of roasted beef and grilled lamb aromas meet with rosemary, bay leaf and crushed rainbow peppercorns for a deliciously savory and spicy nose on this bottling, which uses a touch of Viognier but doesn't offer any overt fruit. Those meaty qualities ride into the palate, where burnt bacon flavors meet with tar, black pepper and a hint of black currant.

This is a powerfully tannic and oaky wine from a warm site and a warm vintage that doesn't deny its ripeness and concentration of flavor. Clove, red currant and pencil shavings wrap around a gravelly core of midpalate weight and power, as specks of dust and pepper reveal themselves on the lengthy finish.

This wine has the structure that is a part of a fine Vosne-Romane. Its dense texture is balanced by the great red fruit and good acidity. Of course, the wine is still so young, its fruit still crisp and not yet mellow. Wait until 2026 to drink this impressive wine.

This expertly blends a majority of Cabernet Sauvignon with smaller amounts of Cabernet Franc, Merlot, Petit Verdot and Malbec, in that order. Grippy, it's quite savory, highlighted in cedar and pencil shavings that dot a sublime, supple core of tannin, seasoned in dried herb.

This elegant estate, with its views down to the Gironde estuary, has produced an excellent 2015. It is properly firm with tannins although this structure is well balanced with the ripe, stylish black-currant fruits and acidity. A juicy finish bodes well for the future. Drink this generous wine from 2025.

Sometimes seen as the junior of the two properties owned by the Barton family in Saint-Julien, this is an impressive estate in its own right, especially in this superripe, smoothly rich wine. Tannins are well wrapped in the generous structure and fruits. Drink from 2025.

This is an expansively rich, generous vineyard-designate from the high-elevation appellation. A wealth of plum, cherry, cassis and cola spice mingle effortlessly around a core of integrated tannin and oak, with handfuls of welcome floral aromas and spicy black pepper.

Intense and ripe, this powerful wine is concentrated and packed with both fruit and texture. The wood aging has been well judged to give some spice and ginger flavors that will become more integrated over the next few months. Then the wine will develop slowly and majestically, probably being ready to drink from 2023.

This is the winery's only non-Dundee Hills bottling, and it brings aromatic notes of earthy stem, leaf and barrel. It's richly layered in red and black fruit, with plum, cherry, pipe tobacco and black tea notes accenting the complex, dark and deep palate. Even in the extraordinary Domaine Serene lineup, this wine overdelivers.

This rich, ripe and structured wine is dense with solid tannins. It is also full of generous cherry and berry fruits that make a great counterpoint to the dry core. These two elements promise well for the future. Drink this wine from 2023.

This dense wine is full of ripe red fruits. Tannins give structure but the main thrust of this rich wine is the sumptuous fruit. The wine is juicy, cut with bright acidity and will be delicious when it matures. Drink from 2024.

This powerful wine is both dense and rich. Its tannins and acidity bode well for aging, while the red plum and berry fruits add to promise for the future. From a parcel close to the series of Grand Cru vineyards, the wine shows the density of this fine vintage and its potential. Drink from 2024.

This new take on Ovum's Memorista cuvethe winery's flagshipis its ripest Riesling. It was fermented in a thousand-liter Austrian cask, with a small percentage of botrytized fruit. It's almost liquorous, with botanical elements that accents its lime, candied citrus and dried papaya flavors. It's potent and packed with flavor yet impeccably balanced.

Unctuous, sun-drenched peach and apricot are glazed with honey, earth and spice in this luminous medium-sweet wine. A silken texture on the midpalate is accented by hits of lime and crushed minerals. Its fruity, forward flavors are stunning already, but there's too much complexity here that's yet to develop. Hold till at least 2021 and it will continue to reward for years to come.

Aromas of raspberry jam, Mediterranean scrub, menthol and a whiff of exotic spice lead the nose on this beautiful red. Concentrated but also boasting finesse, the juicy palate delivers black cherry, blackberry, licorice, clove, and crushed herb alongside firm, ultrafine tannins.

Red berry, crushed violet, dried herb and dark spice aromas take center stage along with whiffs of balsamic and menthol. The elegantly structured, juicy palate delivers crushed raspberry, ripe Marasca cherry, licorice and white pepper alongside smooth, polished tannins. A mineral note energizes the finish.

This generous wine is still young with its firm tannins, although also rich with black fruits and concentration. It is juicy, ripe with blackberry flavors and packed with spice and a dry core. The vineyard, at mid-slope like all premier crus, is named after the rowan trees that were found around the edge. This is a wine with a great future; drink from 2025.

The stunning aromatic profile on this bottling compellingly combines candied fruit with the lift of crushed herbs, while blending cherry and grenadine with mint, bay leaf, a hint of green olive and a touch of crushed gravel on the nose. That lovable core of plush red fruits rides tight tannins on the palate, where bay leaf, thyme and green peppercorn flavors complete the sip.

This is a perfumed wine, rich in black currants and acidity as well as firm tannins. It is concentrated and dense while also elegant. The aftertaste boosts the ripe fruit and balanced acidity. Drink from 2025.

This is a blend from five different premier crus in Beaune to celebrate 50 years of winemaking in Burgundy by the Potel family. Its structure is firm, although the wine itself is succulent and juicy, with a good balance between the acidity and red fruit flavors. Solid tannins back up the dense fruit to give a rich, impressive wine that needs time. Drink from 2025.

Dense and full of black-cherry fruits, this is a richly textured wine. Its concentration and firm tannins are there for the long haul, although it is tempting to drink such a delicious wine young. Resist: this wine will be best from 2025.

Big and rich, this is a juicy wine, ripe with generous tannins and full of berry fruits. It's dense, full in the mouth and impressive in its concentration, richness and crisp texture. Drink from 2025.

This is a beautifully integrated, layered and soft wine, completely fulfilling in its grasp of smoky char, cherry, berry, currant and black licorice. It remains supple and succulent on the palate from start to finish, offering complex acidity and earthiness.

This small vineyard forms part of the Jadot estate. Its rich tannins and black-cherry fruits are sumptuous and already delicious. However there is much more to this structured, tannic and dense wine that will give it a great future. It is broad, rich and likely to be ready to drink from 2024.

From the largest and most famous of the Beaune Premier Crus, this wine is classically soft and generous. Of course it has tannins although these are already beautifully cushioned by the ripe red-cherry and blackberry fruits. With spice and smokiness from the wood aging, this is a complete, delicious wine. Drink from 2022.

Still solid and firm, this wine has impressive potential. Its tannins are a reminder that the vineyard is close to Morey Saint-Denis. Under those tannins runs a seam of ripe fruits that will develop richly as the wine matures. Drink from 2024.

From a spectacular block within the estate Quail Hill Vineyard in the heart of Russian River Valley's Laguna Ridge, this wine is taut and tightly wound, youthfully exuberant in cherry and blueberry compote. Bright and fresh in lifted acidity, it offers length and balance within a velvety complex texture.

This is a tremendous example of a cool-climate Syrah, enhanced by 12% Viognier, with cracked black peppercorn, gamy lamb meat, tarragon, rosemary, soy sauce, mint and black currant all present on the nose. The pepper-crusted meat flavor with blackberry jam shows strongly on the sip, finishing with hints of butterscotch and vanilla.

Explosive floral and fruit aromas leap from the glass in this brilliant bottling, which is bursting with plump red cherry, bundles of rose petals and just a touch of green peppercorn to keep it herbally intriguing. Lively and fresh on the palate, that deep pomegranate and Montmorency cherry picks up an herbally laced line of thyme, oregano, white sage, green cardamom and white pepper.

The ripe fruit that is a hallmark of this vintage at this estate has been maintained along with solid tannins and richness. This has both tannins and concentration although the fruit is the thing, making a wine that will develop relatively quickly. Drink from 2023.

Properly structured and with solid tannins, this is a concentrated wine. Its firm texture is balanced by ripe black fruits, dark and intense. From a vineyard surrounded by some of Burgundy's greatest, this superb wine needs many years. Drink from 2026.

This generous although also complex wine brings in many elements. With lush tannins and concentrated acidity it has a dry, still very young character. The weight of juicy fruit suggests a future that is rich and for the long-term. Drink from 2025.

Crisp yellow stone fruit and pineapple are brisk and bright on the nose of this vivacious dry wine. Spine tingling and taut, but with unctuously concentrated fruit and mineral complexities, there's still plenty of development to look forward to. Hold till 2020 if you can resist.

While subdued on the nose, there's intensity and persistence to be found in this deeply concentrated dry Riesling. White grapefruit and peach flavors are cutting and fresh, edged by layers of slate and crushed mineral. Electric acidity reverberates through a long finish. Hold until 2020, though it's bound to keep improving for years beyond.

Pronounced smoke and earth tones lend savory, shadowy nuances to this luminous, sunny auslese. It's lacy and spry in mouthfeel yet richly concentrated in sweet-tart tangerine, Meyer lemon and red apple flavors. Dazzling acidity pierces through a long, lingering finish and foretells a long, illustrious transformation for this wine as it melds and deepens in complexity.

From a vineyard site in what is known as the reasonably cool Santa Rosa Plain, this is a spicy, oaky and richly concentrated wine. Pomegranate, bay leaf and cardamom flavors are focused, grounded by abundant notes of tart cranberry and strawberry. The mouthfeel is silky, while an herbal underbelly and lingering clove flavor persists through the finish.

Penfold's latest Grange release delivers all of the power, rich fruit and toasty oak Australia's most famous wine is noted for. It is incredibly beguiling though, even in its infancy. Autumnal notes of dried leaves, flowers, sap and dark berries abound, with a raw meat and miso savoriness. The power on the palate is balanced by ultrafine tannins and a finesse that makes this drinkable now with plenty of time in decanter and paired alongside roast lamb, beef, or something equally hearty. Still, it'd be a shame not to cellar for at least the next five years. Revisit in 7, 15, or 30 years.

This is made from a majority of Cabernet Sauvignon from the famous historic site, with 6% Cabernet Franc and 1% Petit Verdot. It startles in beauty and grace, with plenty of power and concentration. It's a charismatic wine, bright in red currant and black cherry and a soft, supple texture that holds an underlying grip and toasty oak spice.

Like the North Block designate, this too is made from 100% Pommard clone. Here, the fruit expression is more lush and full bodied, the blackberry, black cherry, mocha, char and espresso flavors carving deeply into the palate. It's a dense, powerful wine that's beautiful now but structured to age. Enjoy it through the next decade.

The deft hand of winemaker Tyler Thomas, who was hired in 2014 but blended this vintage, already shows in this bottling, which shows aromas of black currant, asphalt, spice cake, lava rocks, loam and a touch of tart black plum skin. The palate is peppery and herbally laced with bay, oregano and crushed pencil flavors, with tense but approachable tannins. Drink now through 2023.

Lemon spray with hints of flint, light smoke, chalk and toasted oak show on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling by Greg Brewer. It's really tightly wound on the sip, with expressive grapefruit pith and squeezed citrus as well as a distinctive Brie-rind note. A light flash of roasted marshmallow pops on the finish.

Tart in cassis, cranberry and pomegranate on the entry, this wine develops a depth of richer rewarding flavor as it goes, leaning more into dark cherry and blueberry. Juicy, layered and delicious, it's well integrated and voluptuously silky on the palate, offering impressive length and breadth.

Made from a majority 49% Cabernet Sauvignon, this blends 27% Merlot, 14% Cabernet Franc, 8% Petit Verdot and 2% Malbec as well. It showcases the site and vintage well, in a ripe powerful mix of tobacco, cedar and plum, finishing savory and cool.

This comes from a small vineyard that lies between Echzeaux Grand Cru and Clos de Vougeot Grand Cru. It has the structure of both, perhaps without quite the intensity. However, its richness and density is very obvious, giving a wine that is solid, dark, ripe and full of black-cherry fruits and tannins. Drink this wine from 2024.

This wine is tight, closed and firm, which shows its youth because it also has great richness and a dense fruitiness that will develop well in the future. The wine is concentrated, as is proper for Gevrey-Chambertin, and densely packed. It will be ready to drink from 2024.

An immense wine, this is bold and rich with powerful yellow and white stone fruits. It comes from one of the Montrachet vineyards that makes the greatest white wines in Burgundy. Under Julie Belland's hand, it shows in the generous, opulent nature of the wine with its balance of fruit and tight texture. Drink this very fine wine from 2023.

This spicy, toasty wine is showing its wood aging as well as plenty of fruit. It is rich and generous, with the natural opulence of Volnay. The red-berry fruits are full of juiciness, backed up by fine tannins. Drink this potentially delicious wine from 2022.

A lovely appellation wine, this has a quiet, floral entry and twisted characteristics of anise, baked apple and vanilla crme brle. Medium-bodied, complex and buoyant in acidity, it offers a wealth of flavor and elegance.

From the site high atop the Petaluma Gap part of the coast, above Gap's Crown, this is inviting in every way. Black raspberry is seasoned in cardamom and forest pine as a tannic backbone provides structure and strength. A hit of citrus highlights the fresh persistent acidity.

Dry and sublime, with undeniable elegance, this is textured, gravelly and integrated with subtle power. Fennel, white peach and lemon rind highlight the toasty oak, making for a complex balanced whole. It would be difficult to find a wine of this quality for this price.

Bountiful boysenberry fruit shows alongside a muddy loamy clay minerality on the nose of bottling, which is lifted further by crushed lavender aromas. The palate's rounded berry fruit is complemented by cherry wood smoke, grippy tannins and strong acidity. The slate and clay character provides a compelling backbone.
