This appellation wine exudes beauty and grace, offering strongly etched characteristics of bacon meat, black cherry, blueberry and spicy cardamom. Succulent and silky, it has a thickness on entry that settles to reveal bright, integrated acidity.

This is classic Puligny, beautifully poised with a superb balance between fruit and acidity. Throw into a pinch of spice from the wood aging and the wine is very complete, rich because of the vintage and crisply elegant. Drink from 2021.

With so many grand cru vineyards in this small village, even the premier crus make excellent wines. This is a case in point, a powerful wine packed with tannins, dense black fruit and a solid structure. The future looks good, with opulent fruit about to come through the framework. Drink this wine from 2023.

Entirely destemmed, this is a cool coastal wine, gracefully restrained and excitingly bright. Tart rhubarb and strawberry join exotic citrus tones and notes of rose petal as spicy acidity lurks within a construct of robust integrated tannin.

A perennial knockout, this wine is juicy and fresh yet somewhat brooding in structured flavors of red cherry, strawberry and plum. With intriguing layers of earth and forest floor framed by tight-grained tannins, it's a sophisticated and complex experience. A deep boysenberry note adds richness on the finish.

Earthy forest and twig support a medium build of integrated acidity and balanced fruit in this blend named for the proprietor. Aged in 55% new oak, blackberry and black licorice dominate the profile against a fine-grained texture of toasty wood and depth.

Aromas of ripe stone fruit, hazelnut and tropical fruit emerge on this savory, structured white. Refined and full of flavor, the palate doles out juicy yellow peach, apricot and a hint of ginger, while almond lingers on the long finish.

The second release of this tte de cuve offering from Roco is two thirds Pinot Noir and one third Chardonnay, and winemaker Rollin Soles (Argyle) seems to have saved his best for it. Matching intense fruit to classic Champagne-style finesse, it's brightly layered with apple, pear and Mandarin orange flavors. It has a fine bead and finishes clean, with citrus and toast highlights.

This spicy wine is rich and full bodied, with a solid, firm structure. From one of the most attractively named of vineyards, the wine has juicy red fruits that contrast with the tannins, giving a ripe balance. This wine needs to age to give space to its great fruit, dry core and acidity that are still coming together. Drink from 2025.

A blend of smoky oak, earth, blackberry and raisin aromas rule the nose on this full-force Rioja that's showing full ripeness despite coming from a cool vintage. Amancio is typically bruising on the palate, with wall-to-wall power and tannins. Dark, hefty berry and plum flavors finish firm and dry, but with plenty of vanilla and oak flavor. Drink from 20202034.

This wine, which sold out via Instagram before it was even released, is a fascinating conveyer of soil flavors. Extremely herbal on the nose, it smells like a freshly dug, muddy hole surrounded by towering pines and mossy ground, with exotic berries in the background. The palate is woody, full of dank mushrooms, wild berries and green peppercorns.

Lingua Franca, a Larry Stone/Dominique Lafon project, offers a challenging, absorbing lineup of Chardonnays and Pinot Noirs. The Avni bottling is tangy and tight, with white peach and melon fruit and hints of toasted nuts and butter. The finish extends gracefully, keeping you riveted.

Lush red cherry and rosewater aromas meet with muddled sage, pepper dust and wild herbs on the nose of this excellent bottling, where rich fruit and herbal intrigue collide. Thyme, dried sage and even broadleaf parsley flavors show on the sip, set against a background of piquant cranberry and tart red currant, with bountiful energy that carries through the entire palate.
This structured wine also offers juicy, elegant fruit. Full of black plums, spice from judicious wood aging and acidity, its core remains to develop. The wine needs to age so drink after 2024.

This generous, ripe wine is filled with fine tannins as well as juicy black-currant fruits. It is approachable in the sense that the fruit is so delicious. However, watch for those tannins that are firm and dense and will allow the wine to age. Best to wait until 2024.

There's a very Gamay-like quality to this bottling, with loads of crushed gravel and schist-like minerality sprinkled atop light cranberry, crushed carnations and slightly ripe raspberry. It hits the palate softly then comes a sharp acidity and then that mellows to allow soil-driven flavors and candied red fruit to combine seamlessly.

Bold ripe fruit flavors find impressive support from firm tannins and refreshing acidity in this natural-tasting and well-structured wine. The black cherry, raspberry and cranberry flavors are vivid and mouthfilling, while a lip-smacking texture keeps them alive on the palate and through a lingering finish.

From a site situated at 900-feet in elevation and located blissfully close to the coast, this vineyard-designate is intensely salty and briny, in firm grasp of stony mineral characteristics. With a depth and breadth of full-bodied concentration, it's complex and layered in Gravenstein apple and pear, the aromas a mix of honeysuckle and apple blossom.

This intensely perfumed wine has great ripe fruits and delicious acidity. It is richly endowed both with tannins and spicy wood flavors that give extra body and density. This will be a very fine wine as it ages, but wait until 2024.

This rich wine is firm with tannins. It has structure and concentration as well as layers of black plum and cherry fruits. Put these elements together and it will age impressively. Drink this wine with its juicy aftertaste from 2023.

Traces of lemon, lime and blossom are subdued on the nose but amass ripeness on the palate of this penetrating eiswein. Plush tangerine and yellow peach flavors are glycerin and sweet yet balanced pertly by pin-point threads of acidity. Pristine honey tones linger on the long finish.

A richness of graham cracker crust and baked pineapple greets the nose of this memorably delicious wine, a tremendous testament to the site. With a backbone of toasted oak and grippy youthfulness, it finishes in bright complex bites of green olive and fennel.

Lingua Franca's Sisters bottling is tight and firm, with buttery apple flavors that suggest partial but not full malolactic fermentation. It was whole cluster pressed and barrel fermented in puncheons, 20% new.

Wholly controlled by the producer, this walled vineyard on the edge of Volnay village has made a beautifully concentrated, balanced wine. Still young, it already has ripe red fruits with shapely tannins and acidity to match. The smoky aftertaste adds to the complexity. Drink from 2022.

Full bodied, fresh and fragrant, this is a successful celebration of the appellation, bringing together the best of several sites. Dark brooding fruit and forested earth complement one another beautifully as a fleshy rounded texture takes hold.

This wine is rich, with great tannins as well as generous red-berry fruits. With its structure firmly in place, it has the potential to be opulent, ripe and generous. Wood aging adds extra weight to the richness. Drink from 2025.

Delicate scents of Mediterranean brush, crushed herb, flint, and balsamic notes of menthol and eucalyptus slowly take shape in the glass. The structured palate shows impressive breeding and class, offering dried Marasca cherry, pomegranate, clove and star anise framed in fine-grained tannins. A mineral-driven finish closes it down. Drink 20192025.

This full and ripe wine with black cherry and plum flavors is firm and rich. Its tannins promise much for the future, while the fruit is already generous and attractive. The wine has a sumptuous character, ripe and with great fruit. Drink from 2025.

Made from pre-phylloxera Nerello Mascalese vines, this compelling wine boasts enticing scents of blue flower, exotic spice, menthol and wild berry. It's dense and concentrated but also elegant, delivering mouthfuls of black cherry marinated in spirits, raspberry compote, licorice and well-integrated oak. Firm, close-grained tannins provide the tight framework. Drink 20192029.

Lavish honey and tropical fruit abound in this light-footed, medium-sweet Riesling. It's a luscious, ripe sip, but deeply complex, shaded by hints of saffron, beeswax and earth. Pinpoint acidity drives a meandering, invigorating finish. Gorgeous already but likely to improve through 2025 and hold years longer.

Not quite as ripe as the 2014 but just as delicious, this biodynamically-farmed estate wine is Rex Hill's top reserve. Its old vine complexity shows in its substantial, full-bodied berry, plum and cherry flavors, a beet root note running down the center. At this time, the barrel aging flavors are a bit hidden, but experience suggests it will continue to improve over the next decade or longer.

Tons of crushed rock and baked earth show at first on the nose of this blend of Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot, and then comes the exotic cola, black cherry and tarragon aromas. There's gravel on the sip as well, where firm squeaky tannins also carry blueberry and green-peppercorn flavors. Altogether, it's a complex yet very quaffable wine.

A 100% varietal wine, this is an impressive effort, mingling together rich and forward flavors of blackberry cobbler and chocolate around a softly layered yet richly woven core of concentration and power. Decadent, it finishes with a welcoming smoky hint.

Just as Winderlea gets these grapes from Adelsheim, Adelsheim gets some Winderlea grapes. Both wineries do quite well with each others' fruit; this 1989 planting is dedicated to Pommard clone, and it has made the ripest of Winderlea's 2015 Pinots. Rich and loaded with black cherry fruit, it's sexy and streaked with cola and clean earth, a sneaky minerality driving the finish.

This stands apart for its complex melding of citrus and berry fruit. Its raspberry and blueberry flavors are accented with floral highlights. At first, it seems almost delicate, yet it gathers strength as it breathes. Ten months in 50% new French oak has pumped up the tannins significantly. Drink now2035.

Ripe and juicy with berries, this structured wine also offers great fruitiness and opulence. The acidity and the tannins promise the future while the ripe fruits show the fine vintage well. This is a wine to age, best enjoyed from 2024.

There's an intriguingly earthy character to the nose of this bottling by Greg Brewer, with snapped sagebrush, dill, green olive and tart pluot aromas leaning into the herbal side of the grape. There's great tension to the sip, which is fresh and flavorful with underripe fig and strawberry, orange rind and a hint of green peppercorn.

From one of the most southerly of the Margaux vineyards, this attractively fruity wine is bright with black-currant flavors. Delicious acidity and layers of spice from wood aging promise a fine, ripe future.

One of two classed-growth estates in Saint-Julien owned by the descendants of Henri Martin, this estate has been renovated and the results show in this well-crafted wine. Ripe tannins are balanced by smoky blackberry fruits and pure, clean acidity. Drink the wine from 2024.

This is a ripe, juicy wine, showing the improvements at this potentially fine estate. Dense tannins and succulent fruit come together to give a wine that is both structured and complex. The black-currant and berry flavors are underlined with a ripe structure. Drink from 2024.

Showing the richness of the vintage behind firm tannins, this wine is tough and solid at the moment although that will change as it matures. The hint of bitter over-extraction is the sole blemish on a wine that otherwise highlights the many improvements at this estate. Drink from 2025.

Brawny aromas of wild boysenberries, bay leaf, black cardamom, wet soil and black tobacco recall a tumble through the rugged chaparral on the nose of this bottling. The palate's black fruit and violet flavors mingle with lavender, chai spice, clove, black pepper and more tobacco, framed by firm tannins. This represents a tremendously complete sensory experience.

This always highly anticipated, nontraditional blend of 56% Syrah, 36% Cabernet Sauvignon and 8% Petit Verdot really shows off Daniel Daou's deft hand in the cellar. Bountiful yet taut aromas of black currant, vanilla, licorice, espresso, black rocks and smoke lead into a firmly structured palate full of black and purple fruit, tar and black olive, with a hint of dank herbs. Extremely complex, it is built to last, though can be enjoyed today. Drink now through 2034.

This wine is rounded, rich with jammy black-cherry fruits that are backed up by the still-young structure. Made from vines planted in 1958, it is perfumed with spice and smokiness from the wood aging. The density promises a wine for aging. Drink from 2025.

Dark gold in color, this is a textured wine with complexity to spare. It's beautifully evolved and integrated, with tantalizing flavors of baked pear, crme brle and fennel. A floral bouquet of spring blossoms leads the nose.

This is a 100% varietal wine from a range of vineyards along the eastern hillsides of the valley. It is hugely concentrated in mocha, chocolate, sage and tar. Toasted oak supports powerful, firm tannins and a plush texture, all beautifully spiced with clove.

This is a well-integrated and composed reserve-tier wine that lives up to its billing. A rich nose of blueberry and baked strawberry-rhubarb give it an edgy, savory quality that's also succulent and velvety on the palate, with long-lasting cardamom spice.

This wine has a strong element of rusticity that's entirely welcoming in its mix of truffled earth and fresh compost. The flavors are lean and sinewy: a tart lingering measure of cranberry and pomegranate perfectly spiked in black tea and cardamom.

This impressive wine has power combined with complexity, as expansive aromas of black cherry, cedar and rose petal lead to a full body, firm tannins and concentrated black-fruit flavors that linger on the finish. Aged in only 25% new oak, it will drink best after 2020.

This ripe and bold wine is full of fruit, tannins and potential. Its juiciness is still crisp with youthful acidity that needs to open out and encompass the red-cherry fruits. This will take time with the dry core still firm and solid. Drink from 2024.

Juicy bright acidity comes through the tannins in this bold, rich wine. A fine line in dry tannins comes from the core, making for a wine with great potential and richness. The aftertaste has crisp red currant and berry fruitiness. Drink from 2024.

The attention-grabbing nose of this dark and brooding bottling shows plenty of ethereal aromas of hickory smoke, violet oil, cola, pepper dust, teriyaki and burnt bacon, all surrounded by the essence of purple fruit. The sip is super savory with loads of crushed pepper, roasted boar, duck fat and charred beef, with lilac on the finish.

Given time to come together, this blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Merlot is deliciously robust and complex. Expansive and richly layered, its flavors lean in to bolder elements of coconut and vanilla as simultaneous wisps of dried currant and cranberry soften the ripeness.

At this stage, this wine is all about tannins and structure. The weight and black fruits will come later. It has potential richness and a generous, rounded texture along with plenty of juicy acidity. The wine will take time, so consider drinking from 2026.

All it takes is one sniff to know that this is in fine shape, because the mix of woodsy spice, toast and dark fruit aromas is ideal. Its lush palate is full but balanced, with black fruit and chocolate flavors that end with mild oak. Tough but yielding tannins ensure that this will last for another 10 years or more.

Thick and dark in the glass, this is a very roasty wine on the nose, with aromas of toasted chocolate, smoked beef, hearty blackberry and a bit of purple-flower freshness. Charred meat flavors make for a savory palate, which is balanced by tart black plum and blueberry flavors and cut by a hint of lavender.

This is an impressive appellation blend, sourcing from the proprietor's Bob's Ranch as well as Gap's Crown Vineyard and others. Earthy compost and forested tea gird a full-bodied concentrated experience highlighted in dried cranberry, raspberry and rhubarb, a leathery hint of sarsaparilla adding creaminess.

Based in the Napa Valley, this brand from Kathryn Hall focuses on Pinot Noir. This release features grapes from one of Oregon's best sitesthe Shea Vineyard, located in the Yamhill-Carlton AVA. It's jam-packed with black cherry and cassis fruit, nuanced by firm streaks of tobacco, espresso and sweet spice. Its density and balance are superb.

Rich and exuberant aromas of black cherry, vanilla and brown sugar meet with a more floral depth as well as crushed gravel on the nose of this bottling by Winemaker Megan Gunderson. Buoyant acidity pops right away on the sip, allowing the silky tannins to present flavors of black plum, dark cherry, loamy earth and dark spices, from sandalwood to allspice.

Second-generation vintner Drake Whitcraft is diligently honing a delicate, fresh style of Pinot Noir, which shows expertly in this bottling. Aromas of crushed violet, under-ripe cherry, tarragon and spearmint decorate the nose. The palate combines raspberry with crushed mint, proving extremely soft and feminine. It would be easy to drink the whole bottle.

Cabernet Sauvignon comprises 60% of this wine to Merlot's 40%, the grapes coming from three different vineyard sites, including Brokenrock. A sanguine thread of cranberry and red currant give the firm structure life and vibrancy, as dusty leather, fig and cocoa powder provide restrained richness. This is a tremendous value for the quality.

This barrel selection is a 50/50 blend of Pommard and Dijon clones, all biodynamically farmed. It's spicy and complex, with cranberry, orange peel and lemon aromas. Those flavors are in the mix, along with black cherry, clean earth, and a dash of cola and sassafras. A glorious wine, it should be enjoyed now through the late 2020s.

This is a vastly improved estate, making impressively good wines in recent vintages. The wine is structured and tannic but also packed with black-currant fruits, good acidity and spice. It will take time to develop, so drink from 2025 at the earliest.

This wine seems to be all about structure and tannins. The fruit comes through slowly and has a way to go in its development. But black currants are there, ripe and promising well for the future. Just don't drink before 2025.

This is an expansive, vibrantly alive and buzzy white that's floral in apple and orange blossom aromas. Its freshness is complemented by richer deeper undertones of baked quince and tangerine, with a gravelly stony quality to the texture that makes it hard to resist.

Although both from the aroma and from the palate, this wine has obviously had plenty of wood aging, it hasn't taken away from the richness of the fruit and its beautiful balance. Acidity and stylish citrus and pear fruits shine through the mineral texture and the toasty flavors. Drink from 2021.

A wisp of citrus and flower aromas open this delicate Riesling eiswein, which boasts bold lime and lemon flavors on the palate. Streaks of acidity and crystalline minerality accentuate its piercing, luminous style. It's sumptuous and honeyed yet impeccably balanced. Beautiful already but concentrated enough to last decades.

Lavish strokes of vanilla, spice and toast lend a slightly aspirational feel to this Pinot Noir, but its undoubtedly a concentrated, solidly structured wine in need of some time to harmonize. Sumptuous red cherry and raspberry flavors are fleshy and deep, invigorated by a crush of cranberry acidity and a cool mineral undertone. Bold, chunky tannins should meld nicely from 2025.
Ripe and juicy, this rich wine has crisp acidity and generous tannins. With its structure and firm core, it's full of potential. The density gives the wine complexity and ageability. Drink from 2024.

The nose on this countywide blend is extremely elegant and lovely, with light rose petals, pressed black plums and crushed violets. There's a tremendously grippy texture to the sip, providing a pure tension that delivers flavors of purple fruit and rosewater. It's a testament to the versatility of the variety.

A salty nudge in this ripe wine gives a tangy edge to the rich apricot and spice flavors. Warm and generous, it keeps an edgy acidity that shows its aging potential. Still tight while fruity, the wine that comes from the westernmost of the grand crus will be ready to drink from 2022.

This wine opens with incredibly floral aromaticsa perfume of rose and lavender that shines along a delicately layered and textured wine. Cherry pie flavors provide juicy succulence and delight. The freshness lasts and lingers, dotted in cardamom and black tea.

A near-neighbor of Vosne-Romane, this premier cru produces structured wines such as this. The tannins and weight derive from the rich fruit as well as the spicy, smoky wood aging. It has power, black fruits, serious tannins and great concentration. Drink from 2022.

This wine's initial baby powder scents give way to a bone dry palate of astonishing intensity. Fermented with native yeast in neutral wood, it has almost feral complexity. Lemon and citrus flavors abound, with grapefruit and orange liqueur accents. The length and detail are outstanding; and what a bargain! Drink now through 2030.

An enviable combination of power and finesse, this wine boasts an enticing bouquet of new leather, ripe berry, exotic spice, graphite and a balsamic eucalyptus note. Full bodied but refined, the juicy, enveloping palate doles out raspberry jam, fleshy cherry, pipe tobacco and star anise framed in velvety, fine-grained tannins. A flinty note lifts the finish while the dense fruit masks the elevated alcohol content.

Alluring scents of raspberry compote, crushed herb, wet stone and scorched earth take center stage on this full-bodied red. Firmly structured with impressive elegance, the palate doles out black raspberry, fleshy Marasca cherry and baking spice alongside velvety tannins. The juicy fruit seamlessly supports the warmth of alcohol. Drink 20212029.

Aromas of wild berry, Mediterranean brush, menthol and dark spice develop in the glass. Elegant and spicy, the structured, focused palate evokes black cherry, crushed strawberry, star anise and clove while a mineral note lingers on the finish. It's well balanced, with bright acidity and firm, polished tannins. Drink 20202025.

This wine opens with a rustic forest element of garrigue, before unleashing its full embrace of crisp red fruit. Rhubarb, strawberry and cherry combine within an oaky, tannic framework of power that falls away slowly in the glass, refreshed in acidity.

Ripe strawberry aromas are a fine setting for this rich and generous wine. Its opulent character is reinforced by firm tannins and broadened out with the red-cherry fruit and acidity. This full-bodied wine will not be ready before 2024.

Thrilling acidity and honeyed stone fruit nectar are pegged with bolts of sun-baked clay, pastry and spice in this complex sptlese. There's still so much tightly wound fruit and mineral tones yet to develop in this spry little wine. Hold till 2020.

Ripe blackberry fruit shines brightly here, backed by bracing minerality. Lighter hints of black olive, dusty earth and espresso add depth and detail as it carries into a long, balanced and textured finish. Good as it is, it should continue to improve with further cellaring.

Homer is the winery's top barrel selection reserve, aged in 71% new French oak. Sturdy, tight and compact, it's packed with black fruit and barrel flavors. Its polished tannins are threaded with cinnamon spice, pepper and coffee ground notes. Drink 20202028.

Lavish aromas of black cherry pie, clove, vanilla, warm brioche, almond croissant and loamy earth show on the nose of this bottling by Etienne Terlinden from the historic vineyard. Hearty and wild blackberry flavors mix with thyme, tarragon, juniper and black tea on the palate.

This is a fully realized, expertly made wine, robust in apricot and peach on the nose. Balanced in richness and concentration, it's gritty and textured, beguiling all around, with additional highlights of vanilla bean, anise and lemon rind.

All the voluptuousness of Volnay awaits in this ripe, full wine. The tannins are richly cushioned by the red-berry fruits and lifted by acidity. It is a beautiful wine, focused on fruit and with just the right amount of structure for it to age. Drink from 2020.

From the winery's Bob's Ranch vineyard primarily, this is a beautiful white wine, and an inaugural release, that is floral and voluptuously creamy in texture. Despite its fulsome nature, it retains balance via a thread of persistently bright acidity amidst rich tones of candied pear, peach, anise and vanilla crme brle. It has length for days.

This is Greg Brewer's appellation blend rather than his single-vineyard expressions, but it's still incredibly dynamic and delicious. A fresh and fruity strawberry-slushie aroma is met with notes of crushed slate and star anise-spiced cookies on the nose. The palate is bright in flavors of slightly tart cherries and ripe cranberries, but then come juniper and pine needle on the midpalate. Acidity pumps into the pomegranate and menthol finish.

This is one of the three biodynamic estates that are owned by Gonzague and Claire Lurton. The wine is generous while also firmly structured in the style of this property. A dense, dry core surrounded by blackberry and black-currant fruit promises great things. It finishes clean, clear and crisp. Drink from 2024.

Dense and dry, this is a richly structured wine. Bold tannins are equaled by the forward red fruits. Together they have produced a dense wine that will need several years aging. The potential is for a concentrated wine that will be sumptuous and generous. Drink from 2023.

Julie Belland, the sixth generation to run the family's 57-acre estate, has produced an impressive wine from this great vineyard first planted in the 15th century. It is packed with ripe apple and quince flavors refreshed by good acidity. It's a wine to age, so don't drink before 2020.

Richly dense, this is a well-structured and rich wine. Its tannins are a part of the opulent black fruits, ripe acidity and wonderful juicy fruitiness. A dark core of tannins will allow the wine to age so well. Drink from 2025.

Hints of freshly cut grass and crisp stone fruit are a surprising contrast to the rolling, rich white peach and grapefruit flavors that flood the palate of this wine. Dry in style yet voluptuously structured, it's an intensely concentrated, juicy wine that lingers endlessly. Bright acidity and a hint of tannins lend firmness to the finish.

Hints of exotic spice perfume this single-vineyard Riesling sourced from red-slate soils. While dry and steely in structure, it's a ripe, intensely concentrated wine full of fragrant freesia, peach and honey notes. Rich and unctuous in mouthfeel, it finishes with length and persistence.

From Barossa's newest generation of superstar winemakers, Ben Glaetzer's Amon-Rahis top wineis the label that's gained him the most glory, and for good reason. It's hugely cellar worthy, with a pretty nose of dark cherry fruit, cola, licorice, cocoa powder and a little meatiness in the background. The medium-bodied palate is juicy and restrained, with muscular but silky tannins and a long juicy, savory finish; The perfect example of the elegant style the latest generation of Barossa producers excel at. While approachable now, it would drink best between 20222032.

Mikael Sigouin extracts the rich side of Grenache in most of his bottlings, and this is an excellent example. Deep and stunning aromas of lilac, cola, red cherries, strawberry-balsamic glaze, black cardamom and sharp sandalwood lead into a palate that's lavish with chai spice, dried ginger and cherry-cordial flavors. Tannins pile up toward the finish and the acidity sings through it all.

Planted around an old abbey, the vineyard has rich soil that gives this wine its open, generous nature. Spicy with plenty of rich yellow fruit and apple flavors as well as toast, this wine is still young. It has great potential with its ripe mineral texture and good acidity at the end. Drink from 2022.

Jadot manages this family-owned vineyard that is situated at the heart of the range of premier crus of Puligny. The wine treads a fine line between elegance and richness, restraint and power. Spice from the wood aging lifts the green and citrus fruits, giving a deliciously balanced wine. Drink from 2021.

This wine offers a great floral aroma with hints of the spice that comes from the wood aging. Its crisp texture and minerality give a pure, clean and fragrant character to this deliciously balanced wine. The tang and zesty character will stand the wine in great stead as it matures. Drink from 2021.

Vibrant acidity shines a spotlight over pristine yellow peach, pineapple and tangerine flavors in this ethereal sptlese. It's lusciously fruity yet spine tingling and spry. The finish is seemingly endless, silky and sweet. This is irresistible already, but it should continue to improve through 2027.

Restrained, subtle aromas of crushed rock, charred earth, Mediterranean scrub and eucalyptus take center stage. The smooth, elegant palate is ethereal and almost weightless, offering succulent strawberry, crushed raspberry, dark baking spice and a hint of anise alongside polished, silky tannins and fresh acidity. Drink through 2025.

Beautifully perfumed, this wine is also concentrated and dense, with a sumptuous, ripe texture that will propel it to great things. Red berries, cherries and balanced acidity are all there along with a serious backdrop of tannins. Drink from 2025.

This blend of Grenache, Syrah and Roussanne by Matthias Pippig makes for a unique, amazingly integrated aromatic profile, much like a cake made of roses, black plum, muddy clay and salumi. The loamy and rose-laced quality extends to the sip, where spice cake, game and hearty purple fruits make for a cohesive quaff.

This 100% varietal wine is dusty and gritty, a showcase of rich full flavor and balanced ripeness. Clove, cedar and red and black currant are prominent and well-integrated within a framework of tight-grained tannins and supportive oak.

Light in color, this wine's beautiful nose shows freshly pressed raspberry, dewy tarragon, fennel and lavender aromasa showcase of aromatic elegance. Immensely fresh and inviting flavors pop on the palate, from tart strawberry and green fennel to rose petals and rosewater, all framed by a long-simmering acidity. It would work well with either white fish or roasted pork.

Scott Sampler sources from White Hawk Vineyard for this bottling, which offers hearty aromas of cooked red cherry, smoked meats, sweet tar, stewed figs and condensed coffee. The palate is fresh with pressed blackberry and violet flavors, but it's the velvety texture that's most compelling. The finish shows spice cake, black pepper and soy.

This structured wine comes from the Sichel family-owned estate. It has tannins and a dry character although this dry core is balanced with ripe black currants. Structure and fruit make this a good wine for medium-term aging. Drink from 2023.

This succulent wine is packed with ripe, rich white fruits, pears and apples that are given a twist by the spice from wood aging. A touch of honey brings out the creaminess of the texture. At the same time, acidity shoots right through this ageworthy wine. Drink from 2020.

This elegant blend of 65% Cabernet Franc and 35% Merlot is still very wound up on the nose, and yet already amazing in aromas of crushed gravel, tar, condensed black currant, black pepper and earthy bay leaf. On the palate, the acidity and tightly woven tannins are pitch perfect for long-term aging, which will allow the black fruit and dark spice flavors to mature. Sit on it until 2019, and drink through 2035.
Spicy and wooded, this is a balanced wine, exotic in tart, tangy cranberry and dialed-high in firm acidity. Supportive supple tannins give it finesse and medium-bodied power.

This 17-acre walled vineyard divided among six growers has a high reputation in the region. The wine certainly is impressive with its rich fruit as well as the tight mineral texture of a young wine. Ripe yellow fruit and the generous character contrast with the potential of this textured wine. Drink from 2019.

Resplendent in youthful reduction, this is an ultimately bright, lemony and beautifully integrated white, complementary in creamy vanilla and baked pear. A thread of honeysuckle adds aromatic intrigue that persists through the lengthy finish.

This bold, rich wine comes from one of the best-reputed vineyards in Pouilly-Fuiss. With a dense texture and rich yellow fruits it is already powerful. The tight mineral texture and firm structure will allow this wine to age. Drink from 2019.

An expansively juicy and soft velvety wine, this delivers coastal influence in droves, balancing earthy cardamom, cola and forest floor with tastes of tea leaf and bright cherry. Light-bodied and silky, it rewards in flavor, texture and complexity.

Rich and with plenty of ripe fruit and generous tannins, this is a rich, smoky wine. It is concentrated, full of red-berry flavors that are layered with black cherries. This dense wine will age well. Drink from 2020.

There's a compelling amount of freshness and vivacity for a Syrah in this bottling, starting with aromas of boysenberry juice, wild thyme, wisteria and sweet peppercorn sauce. Crushed lilacs and lavender meet with black-currant jam and black pepper on the palate, which deftly combines ripe fruit with a savory side.

This crisp, steely wine comes from the cooler left bank of the river in Chablis. It is a tight wine, strong on minerality and tangy acidity, with the steely texture that gives the ability to age. Drink this nervy, crisp wine from 2020.

There's an impressive fresh quality to the nose of this blend of 84% Cabernet Sauvignon, 11% Cabernet Franc and 5% Merlot, with aromas of blackberry, juicy black plum, dill, lilacs and a dusting of vanilla. The fruit-forward palate grabs the attention immediately with black currant, pepper dust, roast beef crust and more purple flowers, with tannins and acidity rising strong on the finish.

This premier cru vineyard lies at the northern end of Nuits-St.-Georges, close to Vosne Romane. That explains the structure and richness of this firm wine. It is dense with tannins that give a dry core to the rich red fruits. With acidity still right up front and with the tannins, the wine needs aging. Drink from 2021.

From a vineyard in the Middle Reach area of the appellation, which is relatively warm, this shows an intensity of earthy forest and black tea as well as cardamom. Velvety thick, it has a freshness of acidity that buzzes along on the palate, prompted by flavors of cranberry, cherry and tangerine.

Sturdy aromas of licorice, black pepper and wild berry fruits are highly encouraging. In the mouth, high acidity reflective of a cool year is the dominant component, meaning this has long-term aging potential. Flavors of dried cheese, vanilla and chocolate come straight from the barrel, while balsamic berry, plum and currant notes carry over to a well-oaked finish. Drink from 20202034.

In this blend, Gewrztraminer owns the aromatics and Riesling fleshes out the palate with rich citrus and stone fruit. In spite of the relatively low alcohol, the flavors are fully ripe, densely packed, intense and compelling. It's hard to imagine a better Oregon white at this price.

This wine, from a unique single-vineyard on steep slopes, has power along with complexity, combining aromas like sun-baked earth and dry leaves with layered cherry, tea and rhubarb flavors and a firm, nicely tannic texture. This will stand up to rich entres very well, and should improve through at least 2021.

The nose is quiet on this sprightly semisweet wine but sunny stone fruit and yellow peach flavors are amplified on the palate. Complexities of saffron, pollen and dusty earth tones extend out the midpalate, finishing on a spicy honey tone. Zesty and composed, it drinks well now but should meld beautifully through 2026.

If you like cassis and blackberry aromas, this Malbec offers no shortage of that. Its lush, seamless palate offers toasty blackberry and chocolate flavors that carry into a finish that's as steady as a freighter on a calm sea. Drink through 2021.

Captivating aromas of Mediterranean brush, crushed herb, Spanish broom, orchard fruit and a hint of hazelnut lead the way on this elegant white. The silky, linear palate doles out tangerine, yellow apple and pear balanced by bright acidity. A mineral note energizes the finish.

Grapy, floral aromas are friendly on the nose. There's all the saturated weight and intensity required of an excellent Priorat, but still Salmos is not demanding or tough. Blackened, toasty berry flavors and a charming finish make this good to enjoy through 2024.

Plump red cherry, rust, dried sage, wild thyme and baking spices show on the nose of this top-end regional wine from Bill Foley. The palate shows cohesive well-woven flavors of strong red fruits, turned earth, brown spice, cracked pepper and a menthol-like finish. The acidity is perfect, the tannins soft but structural.

Very ripe and very lush, this wine oozes opulent black cherry and blueberry from the aroma through the lingering finish. The fruit flavors are concentrated and deep, and a touch of baking spices adds complexity as the wine spreads across the palate and seems to coat the tongue.

Winderlea Legacy is a limited selection from the site's original vines, planted in the mid-1970s. Unusually low in alcohol, it surprises with subtle rose, wild berry, wet stone and tanned leather flavors, all twisted into a marvelous tapestry. It demands your full attention and a bit of breathing time, and should age beautifully. Drink now through the mid-2030s.

Lavish yet acutely balanced, Wittmann's basic-label Sptburgunder offers deep, ripe blackberry and red currant flavors off set by bristling acidity. Layers of bramble, toast and smoke add complexity to nose and palate, along with a reverberating crushed-granite finish. Framed by fine, persistent tannins, its approachable already but should show beautifully for another decade to come.

This is one of the latest releases of soil-designated wines from Andrew Rich, which aim to express the impact of soil type on the finished wine. It shows a penetrating minerality, driving its black currant and black cherry fruit deep into the finish. Hints of smoke and earth add further depth.

Very light in color, this unique wine shows peppery figs, plum paste, rust and star anise spice on the fascinating nose. It's light in body with a great textural grip, offering up a distinct stew of flavors, including macerated orange, plum, Christmas spice, sarsaparilla, coffee candies and a white-pepper-dust finish.

Taking its name from the hill or Cos on which the vines are planted, this wine is dense and full of firm tannins. The fruit is there as well, ripe black currants waiting to come through the tannins. Give this wine time and drink from 2026.

This ripe wine is full of dusty tannins and has a dense structure. These give power to the wine with its concentration and richness. Bright acidity cuts through to give a crisp edge to the ripeness. Drink this dense wine from 2022.

The wine from this estate, owned by one of the great Bordeaux families, is already balanced between fruit and tannins. Black currants from the Cabernet Sauvignon comes through strongly, giving a juicy character to the wine's structure. It is rich and will mature well. Drink from 2025.

Smooth and fruity, this wine is easy to enjoy from the first classic whiff of red cherries and tea to more substantial black cherry and clove flavors. It's medium in body and has light, velvety tannins. Great balance and liveliness thanks to good acidity help lift this wine above the pack.

The structure in this wine with its tannins gives a core of dryness to the otherwise ripe, generous fruit. The wine is tight with acidity, smokiness and a firm character that will allow it to age. Juicy acidity at the end promises much. Drink from 2021.

The tannins in this wine are firm and still prominent, giving both richness and aging potential. The fruit is full, weighty, packed with dark tannins and with firm concentration. This a dark, firm wine needs to age. Drink from 2024.

Crisp, textured and tangy, this is a tight, mineral-textured and very terroir-driven wine from a vineyard close to Volnay. It is an impressive, balanced wine, delicious and likely to be ready to drink soon, from late 2018.

This wine is dry, packed with tannins and has good weight and structure. Concentrated and dense, it will need many years. The wine does have some bitter extraction although this should go as it matures. At the same time, the acidity and the rich berry fruits have good promise. Drink from 2025.

This wine has the rich oaky exuberance of the famous vineyard sitea mix of butter, lemon curd and apple pie. Creamy and layered, it has seasonings of nutmeg and cinnamon, integrated oak and persistent acidity that makes it delicious experience.

Lush, concentrated and richly put together, this coastal, estate white offers a mix of inviting flavors from Bosc pear to pineapple and fennel. Integrated in oak and balanced in ripeness, it'll pair well with a range of foods and be wholly satisfying on its own.

Dark tones of smoke and slate fade with aeration on the nose of this wine, gradually bringing fresh, greengage plum and green floral notes to the forefront. While its apple and lime flavors are piercing and persistent, it's dancingly light in texture with a lingering finish.

Zesty green lime, herb and plum notes on the nose turn riper and sweeter on the palate of this pristine auslese. It's light and crisp yet undulates with rich tides of sweet pink grapefruit, honey and peach. Spine tingling acidity and a fresh mineral undertone keeps the long finish invigorating.

This juicy wine is rich with acidity and red-berry fruits. It is still young, with tannins and a dry core that will allow it to age. The concentration and ripeness suggest power for the future. Drink from 2024.

Situated just to the north of the village of Pommard, this eight-acre vineyard has produced a typically structured wine with firm tannins and a dry core. The wine also has the rich black-cherry fruit of the vintage. Together with the wood aging, the wine will develop richly and powerfully. Drink from 2023.

This utterly delicious dry Riesling has just enough roundness to cut through the acidity. Its lush mix of citrus and stone fruit gathers strength and focus as it roars across the palate. It's instantly accessible yet built for enjoyment over the next decade.

This bottling by Lane Tanner, who used solely clone 667 and employed 50% new Hungarian oak, offers intense cherry on the nose alongside rose petals, carnations, preserved oranges and North African spice. There's bountiful energy to the sip, where bay leaf, thyme and green sage meet with dark red fruit.

From the lovely Petaluma Gap site, this wine is a mix of menthol, forest floor and noble reductiontotally savory in style. Moderately concentrated and ultimately fresh in bright acidity, it has a thickness of wild strawberry and cherry and a length of cardamom spice.

Lime pith, scratched pomelo skin, crushed chalk, a hint of flour and tons of rocky minerality show on the nose of this tightly wound bottlingthe best of this winery's current vintage. There is extreme raciness to the textured and slightly grippy sip, with flavors of lime, chalk and a hint of pluot flesh. It's all about texture.

Ripe and juicy, this is a richly fruity and structured wine. With acidity to keep it crisp, the wine has layers of warm cherry flavors and generous tannins. It has an excellent future, so drink from 2022.

From one of Mornington Peninsula's top artisan producers, the 2015 Pinot Noir is beautiful for sipping now while also being age worthy. Like a warm autumn day, it smells of drying red fruit, dried flowers, earth and a touch of cinnamon and smoke. The palate is juicy and elegant, with silky tannins and lively acidity. An elegant, serious yet utterly gluggable drop. Drink now2024.

Lorna Marie is the winery's reserve-level offeringa barrel selection that mixes lively cranberry, raspberry and cherry flavors with tart suggestions of orange and orange peel. There's a touch of chocolate on the finish from aging 16 months in 30% new oak.

Clean aromas of flint and smoke meet with Meyer lemon pith, a touch of tangerine and white flowers on the nose of this bottling by the new estate of John and Gill Wagner. There's bountiful texture to the sip, where slightly sour lemon and lime flavors are balanced by honeysuckle, wood chip, pecan and rosemary-laced roasted-chicken flavors.

Heady aromatics pierce through a full-figured sensibility of oak and body in this well-made winea partnership between the winery and musician John Legend. A gritty texture makes way for a length of baked pineapple and pear decadence that lingers effortlessly on the palate.

This wine's concentrated fruit is perfectly ripe, with berry flavors and a deep black cherry core. Everything is in proportion and well integrated, a gentle touch of new oak and clean earth underpinning all the gorgeous fruit.

The best Private Stash to date, this pumps up its strawberry and raspberry jam flavors with apricot highlights. It's concentrated and boldly fruity but balanced and long, buttressed with well-matched acids and tannins.

A slightly tradition-bucking blend of Grenache, Syrah, Cabernet Franc and Viognier by Matthias Pippig, this wine shows black cherry, vanilla, dark loam, crushed rocks and dried thyme on the mineral-laced nose. Strong tannins and acidity frame the sip, where berries, anise and vanilla converge. The tannins need a bit more time to integrate.

For the winery's more serious bottling, this is a very fresh and lively wine rather than austere and regal, with boisterous lilacs, violets, smashed plums and boysenberries on the nose. Candied blackberry shows on the sip, which is relatively lighter in texture and body, with hints of hickory smoke as well. These flavors will stay vibrant for years, and merge with time. Drink 20192030.

This classy wine is sourced from one of the finest vineyards in Oregon, with a proven track record of ageability. Bright raspberry fruit flavors extend into the mineral-driven finish, which opens to reveal more subtle textures and layers as it breathes. Aged in 35% new oak, it has a touch of coconut on the nose and finish also. Drink from 2020 to the early 2030s.

This limited-production top-tier cuve is high-toned, with bright raspberry fruit set against ample, minerally acids. Aging in 50% new French oak has given it subtlety and balance, though there's a slight suggestion of heat on the finish. It will unquestionably benefit from a few more years of bottle age, so drink from 2020 to 2025.

Sourced from the original (1990) planting of Pommard clone vines, this shows thick black cherry fruit, scattered with multi-seed bread and wet hay notes. The flavors are persistent and full, with streaks of coffee and chocolate from having aged in 30% new oak. It's astonishing that Doug Tunnell can offer such glorious wines at such mild prices.

This robust medium-bodied vineyard-designate is complex and lengthy, a showcase of reduced oak, black cherry and berry and well-defined aspects of white pepper, Asian five-spice and black tea. The finish brings some heat that settles on the palate to show power and grace.

Extra-long macerations by winemaker Scott Sampler add intriguing complexity to his wines, including this bottling from Larner Vineyard. The nose combines a wide array of herbs with white pepper dust, gamy meat, condensed purple flowers and dark fruit. There's a touch of balsamic to the sip, where coffee, black currant and blackberry flavors meet with leather and roasted beef.

This is a strongly mineral wine, rich in ripe apricot and pear fruits and well balanced. Acidity and generous fruits offset each other well for richness and crispness. From one of the most familiar of the premier crus in Puligny, it has great potential. Drink from 2021.

The second wine of Pape Clment, named after the papal crossed keys, this bottling well reflects the top wine. It has the same ripe, dusty tannins and juicy acidity, rich while structured, and likely will age well over the medium term. It will be a delicious, rich wine as it matures. Drink from 2021.

Firm and structured, this is a dark, concentrated wine. It has a solid character, rich and ripe with black plums and berries that come through the dry core. This wine is certain to age well; drink from 2022.

This dry, firm wine is currently all about tannins, with a backdrop of rich berries and spice from wood aging. Produced from a small portion of the Aux Perdrix Premier Cru, it does have the weight to show its potential as it ages. Consider drinking this wine from 2025.

Lush, rich and lovely on the nose, this bottling shows vanilla, black currant, chocolate cake, cola and teriyaki aromas. The texture and flavors are much softer and mellower than expected from the bombastic nose, with smooth black plum, sweetened espresso and purple flowers.

This ripe, wood-aged wine is beautifully structured, with vibrant acidity that cuts through the richness of fruit and oak. A taut edge provides an ageworthy build. It comes from a vineyard at the northern end of the village, next to Meursault. Drink from 2019.

John Duval's wines are rarely timid and rarely simple, although they do require some time for brooding. The 2014 Eligo offers plenty of attractive blue fruit, dark cherry, florals and cedar to ponder over. The palate is full bodied but elegant, with savory, tight-grained tannins. This should cellar beautifully. Drink 20192037.

This attractively named vineyard has produced an equally attractive wine. With its good mix of ripe fruits, acidity, nutmeg and spice from wood aging and a generous texture, it is an opulent wine although it still needs aging. Drink from 2021.

Enticing whiffs of brioche, biscuit, lemon and lime introduce this lovely brut-style sparkling. It's bracingly fresh yet bursting with juicy tangerine and yellow peach flavors. Filigreed in structure and with pin-point, persistent petillance, it's a convincing argument for Champagne lovers to drink more sekt, especially considering its price.

Dusty and chalky tannins and oak grasp robust black fruit and licorice in this full-bodied well-made wine, aged for two years in 100% new French oak. Leather, tobacco and clove contribute complexity to the lengthy finish.

Each of John House's Rieslings is differentiated by AVA and fermentation vessel; this may be the most unique of his stellar lineup. Sourced from the Cedar Ranch vineyard in the Illinois Valley, this is fermented with native yeasts in a concrete egg. Its complexity and detail is astonishing, with baby powder, orange peel, pink grapefruit and Meyer lemon. Long, dry and truly off the grid, if not over the moon.

Lovely black raspberry, hints of sage, sandalwood, soil, sweet dill, tarragon and fennel make for a very expressive nose on this single-vineyard selection. The palate deftly combines dark but tart plum, pluot and black raspberry fruit with notes of baking spices. The texture is pitch perfect, with judicious acidity and structural tannins.

Orange blossoms and lime zest perfume this lively sweet-tart sptlese. It's intensely juicy in rich, ripe yellow peach and tangerine nectar yet sheer in feel. A textbook Mosel sptlese that should maintain its freshness through 2023.

This is a well-integrated reserve wine, enjoyable in its complex plushness and characteristics of clove, cassis and red cherry. Leather, tobacco and soy come in midway, adding to a robust, softly spoken finish.

There are strong hints of smoke and flint at first on the nose of this bottling, but then comes a tighter mandarin orange pith character and a warming sandalwood spice. It's very fresh, tightly wound and bright on the palate, with pink grapefruit, squeezed lemon and lime skin toward the finish.

Rustic red cherry, baked earth, pretty rose petals, candied currants and a bit of sweet oak show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard just east of Cambria. The herbally tinged palate places fresh thyme and dill against a backdrop of light cranberry and pomegranate, proving lightly bodied but extremely energetic with acidity. Vanilla pops on the finish.

Crushed mint, exotic spice, Mediterranean herb and wild-berry aromas slowly emerge on this wine. It's elegantly linear, taut and still tightly wound, offering oak-driven spice, espresso, grilled herb and dried cherry alongside firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink 20232030.

Brown sugar and Asian spice components make this wine warm and invitinga strong, powerful expression of the variety that's concentrated in flavor and body weight. Tart cranberry and raspberry are seasoned in elements of dried herb, adding complexity.

Dark as night in the glass, this lavish take on Pinot Noir, which would work great in a steak house, shows black cherry, licorice, black sage and crushed asphalt on the nose. Lush tones of black cherry and creamy caramel also show on the sip, but there is earthy minerality, roasted meat umami tones and vibrant spearmint touches as well.

This is a delicate spicy wine despite its robust ripeness and brawny underside. Compost and brambly brush combine with blackberry and an undeniably delicious streak of white pepper, making for a complex, complete wine that's enjoyable from start to finish.

Mimi Casteel is the grower, hence the cuve name. A full 70% included whole clusters, foot-stomped and barrique-aged. That new oak shows minimally, and the fruit, at least for now, is somewhat subsumed by stem and leaf flavors. It's a demanding style that will reward long-term aging. The texture and complexity begin to emerge after many hours of aeration. Drink 20222035.

From the highly sought-after site a stone's throw from the producer's own estate, this white is lovely and invitingly floralits aromatics undeniable. Unctuous and boldly ripe, it offers intertwined flavors of baked pear and pineapple with a persistent lift of fresh stony acidity.

Brawny and expansive in dusty minerality, this dry wine is velvety thick and floral in violet aromas. Blackberry, cherry and an herbal undercurrent of menthol work together seamlessly to provide complexity and bold swathes of persistent flavor.

This spicy wine shows how far the estate has moved from its over-use of new wood. In this bottling, the wood is subtle and doesn't mask the rich fruit and the juicy acidity. It still has the structure of a Saint-Estphe while keeping everything in good balance. Drink from 2024.

Soft, ripe and juicy, this is an immediately attractive wine. Its tannins are already well integrated into the black-currant fruits and rich berry flavors. The wine will mature relatively quickly and should be ready to drink from 2021.

Initially smooth and sophisticated, this wine then reveals a dark core of tannins. It is rich, structured, full of juicy red fruit as well as a fine line of acidity. The vineyard is south of the city of Nuits-St.-Georges. Definitely ageworthy, the wine has density, concentration and a powerful future. Drink from 2023.

Deliciously well-integrated, this is a rich, vibrant and intense wine that is lengthy and broadly expansive in baked strawberry, rhubarb and dark cherry. Cardamom and black tea make appearances within the fruit and brawny oak.

Lemon cream, beeswax, sea salt and chamomile tea aromas combine for a very compelling and complex nose on this bottling. The palate is creamy at first and then sizzles with sea salt and lemony acidity, finishing with more ocean spray flavors. It's savory, yet fresh.

This richer, Bordelaise-like take on Sauvignon Blanc is a compelling change of pace for a region that leans more toward fresh and racy. Aromas of ripe nectarine, lemon oil, yellow flowers and marzipan are set against a steely core on the nose. The palate offers oak smoke, creamy pear flesh and distinctive butterscotch on the finish.

The typical firm, tannic structure of a Gevrey-Chambertin is very present in this young wine. The tannins are balanced with the juicy red-berry fruits, crisp acidity and minerality. Together these elements make an impressively dense wine that will age well. Drink from 2022.

The tannins of this wine are classic Nuits-St.-Georges. Under the weight of this dry, toasty core, rich fruit will allow the wine to mature well. It is concentrated and dense with a rich potential. Drink the wine from 2024.

From a site expertly farmed by the Martinelli family, Burnside is leathery and earthy, a deep dive into mint, cedar and pine as well as pungent rose garden. Spicy cardamom and black tea are supported by a grip of oak and tannin that tastes bold and big, yet finishes in balance.

Toasty oak and saddle leather aromas lend complexity to a dark-fruited nose with minerality. This feels snappy, which is what you might expect from a high-end 2013 from Rioja. Oaky black-fruit flavors come with more than enough spice and earth notes, while this is toasty on the finish and also dry and firm in feel. Drink from 20192030.

Appealing aromas of mint, charred pine and forest floor decorate a core of mulberry and dried cherry fruit on the nose of this wine by Karen Steinwachs. Similar flavors show on the sip, where pine needles and moss meet with minty black raspberry, presented on a lighter fresher body.

Both structure and ripe fruits mark out this wine. It has richness, a tannic structure and generous red berry and black-cherry flavors. With these elements, the wine is certain to age well. Drink from 2023.

A blend from numerous blocks on the estate, this is a lovely and classic expression Oregon Pinot Noir. From the rose-inflected aroma to the brambly blue fruit and polished tannins, it's a knockout bottle. Barrel aging adds a sexy touch of mocha to the long, delicious finish.

This outstanding effort offers intense lemon tea and citrus blossom aromas. Citrus and melon fruit flavors follow, showing lovely balance while keeping the aromas in play. Despite its 20 g/L of residual sugar, it has plenty of underlying acidity to keep it poised and refreshing through its graceful finish.

Very rich and lush aromas of black currant that are zesty rather than overripe meet with hints of chaparral, cherry wood smoke and sweet lavender on the nose of this wine. There's a strong sagebrush quality to the sip, with blackberry sauce and peppercorn husks in the midpalate. The acidity is prime, the tannins are just sticky enough. Drink now through 2030.

From a 1982 single vineyard planting, this thick, meaty and substantial wine includes 5% Syrah. Its plush fruit tones of black cherry and plum are compact and full bodied, with notes of black olive, sweet earth and toast that also factor in. The color is blood-black and the tannins are ripe and polished.

Layered and intricate, this plush and complex wine is a beauty. It starts with enticing aromas of black cherry and clove, while more cherry and spice character unfolds on the palate and a broad, rich texture coats the mouth. Everything is smooth, well integrated and tasty.

Guardians of some of Barossa's oldest vines, the next generation of Shultzes are now at the helm and are steering Turkey Flat in a promising direction, focusing on organic practices in the vineyards and a lighter touch in the winery. The 2015 Shiraz is a great example of this, utilizing partial whole-bunch fermentation for lifted blue and black fruits, stalks, cinnamon and an earthy core. The palate is medium bodied, plush and juicy, with elegance, not richness, and a wonderfully savory finish. Drink now2032.

For fans of rich and lavish Pinot Noir, this appellation blend gives a taste of what Winemaker Megan Gunderson is all about, without the soaring price tag. Black cherry, chocolate chip cookie dough, crushed slate and light mint show on the nose while the soft, lush palate is creamy in black-plum pudding and coffee cream flavors as well as hints of bay leaf, black tea and juniper.

The grapes for this excellent wine were sourced from the Carabella, Hyland and Thistle Vineyards. It's supple and tangy, with orange, grapefruit, lemon pith, apple and gooseberry flavors, all framed by a gentle touch of oak. This is a classy, sophisticated and impressive wine.

This wine, from Frankland Estate's renowned Isolation Ridge, is a wonderful example of the greatness that cool-climate Great Southern Shiraz can achieve. Medium bodied and elegant, this enchanting shows red cherry, raspberry, florals, cracked pepper and herbs, with an orange peel tang and a hint of meat and earth in the background. The palate is full of crunchy red fruit, florals and dusty, fine-grained tannins that lead to a long, pepper finish. Drink now2027.

Juicy, firmly structured and with great fruit, this wine will need aging. With black cherries and juicy red currants, it is both ripe and crisp. Drink this wine, with its excellent potential, from 2024.

Ripe and full bodied, this wine is also succulent and juicy. Red fruits show strongly in the concentrated texture and the richness. An impressive wine to age, it will not be ready to drink before 2023.

It's a shame only one barrel was made of this wine from Glenrose Vineyard, for it's a lavish and delicious wine. Aromas of coffee, espresso and dark chocolate meet with black cherry, lilacs and caramel on the nose. Deep yet bright black-currant fruit shows on the sip, along with zesty blood orange before finishing on the richer coffee-cream notes.

The 2010 harvest will go down as one of Rioja's greats, and that means wines like this $25 Gran Reserva can be excellent and affordable. It has a nose of mocha, smoke and earthy berry fruits. The palate is layered and texturally complex, while flavors of root beer, baking spice, dried cherry and plum spread out on a smooth finish that is just right in terms of residual tannins and acid. Drink through 2030.

Ripe and spicy, this wine comes from an estate on the western edge of Pauillac. Young fruit, toast and fine tannins are combining well into a rich wine that is likely to develop relatively quickly, very much in the style of this property. Drink from 2024.

This property, owned by the Cazes family of Lynch-Bages in Pauillac, has produced a structured wine. Its tannins show most strongly at the moment. Sustained by black-currant fruit, they will keep the wine firm although with a rich, generous style in the future. Drink from 2025.

The producer's second release from this famous site, this wine is beautifully balanced and bright, with nuanced layers of depth. Cherry, cola spice and forest floor mingle effortlessly in the glass, as the palate remains silky soft.

This ageworthy wine is full of fruit as well as tense and textured. Coming from this ripe vintage, it offers yellow fruits, ripe acidity, hints of the wood aging and a ripe, rich texture. The minerality is cushioned by opulent fruit that is so enveloping. Drink this fine wine from 2021.

Richly juicy, this wine, from one of the finest of the Gevrey Premier Crus, is already attractive. It has great fruit, rich tannins and a spicy character from the wood aging. At the moment, the acidity and crisp texture dominate, although this will change to bring out the richness of the wine. Wait to drink from 2024.

This beautifully structured wine comes from one of the highest vineyards in Puligny-Montrachet, adding to the texture and minerality. With its outstanding fruitiness and excellent balance of fruit, spice and acidity, the wine is set for long-term aging. Don't drink before 2021.
This new offering from purchased grapes is a doozy. Loaded with dried cherry, orange peel, almond paste and sea salt chocolate notes, it offers nonstop pleasure, with a toasty finish.
Bright, tart and very tasty, this ultraripe cuve brings lush apple sauce, peach cobbler and Meyer lemon flavors. It's vivid, detailed and framed with toasty new oak.

Cherry blossoms, guava and grapefruit abound in this lavishly perfumed sptlese. Fresh and fruity yet deeply penetrating on the palate, it's balanced and zippy, with a subtly green-floral finish. Lovely already but structured enough to show pristinely through 2027.

Bracing whiffs of orange zest and blossom brighten this gorgeously honeyed Riesling. It's light and spry on the palate, yet unctuous and juicy, bursting with sweet white peach and guava flavors. Stark lime acidity and crystalline mineral tones leave the finish fresh and revitalizing.

Aromas of sweet tangerine and peach are spiced with cardamom on this sun-drenched, semisweet Riesling. It's breathtakingly perfumed, yet deeply concentrated in stone fruit on the palate. Laser-like acidity and a crystalline finish lend upright structure. Gorgeous already but likely to improve through 2025.

Flawlessly ripe yellow cherry and peach pulse from the core of this feather-light, perfumed eiswein. Spine tingling lemon-lime acidity jolts the senses, balancing a delicate glaze of glycerol silk on the midpalate. The finish is endless and meandering. Gorgeous already but structured enough to last decades.

Hearty black plum and blackberry sauce show on the nose of this excellent bottling along with black pepper, lilacs, black cardamom, lamb and rosemary. It's soft and polished on the palate, with a creamy texture that tightens toward the finish, showing black currant, plum skin acidity and leathery game flavors.

Layers of crushed stone and earth juxtapose honeyed peach and nectarine in this complex, deeply mineral wine. It's sweet and slick on the palate yet dancingly light, catapulted by racy acidity. The finish is endless and lip smacking.

This well-made wine tastes of berry crumble, lifted by a persistent freshness of acidity that's welcomed and welcoming. Dusty tannin adds to elements of black pepper, leather and cigar, finding a balance between fruit and undeniable power.

There is enough going on in this complex, age-worthy Shiraz to keep a wine geek waxing poetic for days about its savory, meaty and vegetal profile: Grilled green peppers, Dr. Pepper, bramble fruit, violets and a tangy note of sumac. The palate is full bodied and powerful, with plush, juicy fruit, big drying tannins and a fantastic acidity to freshen things up. Drink now2032.

Released a year later than other premier crus, this is a flagship wine for the producer. Close to the magnificent grand cru slope, the vineyard has produced a ripe wine offering yellow and melon fruit accented by vanilla and spice. While rich, it also has great poise with a good streak of acidity and minerality. Drink this wine from 2020.

A block selection from vines planted in the early 1970s, this shows the herbal side of Pinot Noir, with stem flavors that suggest some whole-cluster fermentation. It's young and still a bit stiff, with sour cherry and sassafras flavors. It has excellent concentration, and more bottle age should lighten up the still-chewy tannins.

Bold and ripe, this wine traffics in earthy wild raspberry, strawberry, mushroom and nutmeg. Ethereal despite its weight and breadth, it's made in a classic style and is deliciously varietal, a showcase of a great site in a great vintage.

Very intriguing aromas of cinnamon, cedar, garden herbs and tight raspberry show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard on the eastern side of the appellation. The palate is extremely elegant and tightly wound, with bay leaf, Earl Grey tea and potpourri elements flavoring the pomegranate background.

Mediterranean scrub, wild berry, dark spice, new leather, dried herb and a whiff of menthol take shape in the glass. The juicy, linear palate shows finesse and great fruit, doling out succulent red cherry, crushed raspberry, star anise and flinty mineral alongside silky tannins. Best through 2023.

A lovely wine, this is soft and layered with complex notions of raisin cake, cranberry and dried cherry. Soft and supple in texture, it has a lasting grip of leather and coffee. Full bodied, it holds its ripeness well, showing complexity and balance.

Dark, tarry chocolate and blackberry aromas lead to a full-bodied and fresh palate in this wine. Its toasty black-fruit flavors are nicely spiced, finishing with peppery and toasty notes of coconut and chocolate. Drink through 2028.

This is a consistent favorite among the increasing number of fine traditional-method sekt available stateside. Laser-edged and deeply mineral, it's enriched by hints of caramel, nut and brioche. Flavors of lime, lemon and tangerine are bold and piercing yet cushioned by a mousse that's fine and delicate. The finish is long and subtly honeyed.

Spine tingling acidity lends vitality to this silky, voluptuous sptlese full of white peach, lychee and honeydew flavors. It's concentrated in wet stone and lemon zest notes that linger beautifully on the finish.

Quite dark in the glass, this appellation blend combines dense layer of mulberry and black plum on the nose with aromas of wet loam, packed rose petals and a hint of mint. Layers of rose petals and purple hibiscus show on the earthy sip, where a soft texture presents dark fruits and slight hints of caramel and vanilla toward the finish.

This outstanding effort opens with concentrated raspberry, plum and cherry fruit. There's a thick vein of coffee liqueur in both the scent and flavor, and the mouthfeel is sappy and slick, dominated by that luscious, liquorous character. Think ripe fruit dappled with Christmas spices, and you've got this nailed.

This rich, oak-aged wine is impressive and concentrated. With a spicy wood character and ripe apple, green plum and citrus fruit tones, it is intense and dense. The mineral texture, tight and tangy, and fresh finish marks the wine as one ready to age. Drink from 2020.

This Cabernet-Malbec-Petit Verdot blend smells smoky and rich, with lemony oak notes. But in the mouth, it's tight as a drum, with an unbreakable structure. Dark spice and clove notes accent ripe berry fruit that's not jammy and which has absorbed its oak well. Its firm, tannic finish will stand guard as it ages for a decade or more. Drink 20202030.

Hard to believe this isn't Vasse Felix's top Chardonnay, but instead lies in its middle tier. It's complex, rich and age worthy. Notes of melon, stone fruit, butter and toast march straight into a tangy, toasty palate that is both opulent and elegant. And the salty, briny finish is seemingly endless. Drink now2025.

Showcasing the richness and velvety texture often associated with wines from Savigny, this also highlights the ripeness of the vintage. The result is a wine in which ripe red fruits and a smooth texture overtake the tannins that lend a subtle structure and will help it age. It is a delicious wine that will be ready to drink from 2022.

Very chalky on the nose in a Chablis-like style, this bottling, which is made in a warehouse just blocks from the beach in Santa Barbara, shows aromas of lemon blossom and Gravenstein apple. It's extremely tightly wound on the sip, with a savory salt character as well as lemon balm flavors. It's texturally intriguing and compelling.

Mulberry, forest floor, moss, thyme, incense and rainbow peppercorns show on the dynamic nose of this bottling by second-generation vintner Drake Whitcraft. Rounded boysenberry fruit meets with herbal freshness on the palate, which is slightly richer than many of his bottlings but still very much in the lighter house style. The tannins are sturdy.

Vibrant on the nose and expertly put together, this is a well-made appellation wine, expansive in dark cherry, pomegranate and plum. Generous in oak and tannin in its youth, it shows a full-bodied finish that settles smoothly into velvety waves of cardamom and rose.

A lovely, lush melding of berry, citrus and cherry fruit flavors, this appeals from the moment the cork is pulled through the second day. The fruit is nicely framed with light herb and stem highlights and touches of brown sugar and sassafras.

With its licorice root, cassis and plum aromas, this juicy, tight Malbec shows a firm grip and racy acidity. Its raspberry and red plum flavors are fully oaked and spicy. On the finish, it's intense, prickly and acid driven. Drink through 2032.

This substantive, well-structured wine has a classy, light French oak aroma and plenty of Bing cherry on the palate as well as firm tannins and good fruit acidity to make it feel lively. Its concentration and grip bode well for pairing with roast birds or beef.

Lean and strong, with a well-hewn balance of pungent compost, pencil shavings and dried herb, this Merlot-driven blend contains all five red Bordeaux varieties. Graceful and elegant, it's ready for the table, finishing in a twinge of tobacco and fennel.

This wine can be deceptive, as it doesn't burst forth with glorious fruit. What it does have is texture and detail, and the start-to-finish experience rewards your full attention. Layered with forest floor, earth, rock and wild berry notes, it's underscored by ample acidity. The finish goes on and on.

Concentrated red cherry and grenadine aromas meet with essence of red rose and carnations on the nose of this bottling by Scott Sampler. Soft and polished tannins carry flavors of tart yet dark cherry, black plum skins, thyme and rosemary, making for a palate that's full of perfectly dried fruits and herbs.

This rich, luscious wine is balanced well between acidity and ripe, generous fruit. The rich citrus and spice flavors are enhanced by the mineral texture, the wood-aging toastiness and by ripe white fruits. The wine is delicious but needs to age. Drink from 2020.
This excellent bottle pulls Bing cherry, kirsch and orange peel flavors into a full-bodied whole. Aged in French oak for 18 months, it adds a layer of dark chocolate to the finish.

Beautiful seductive fruit aromas and flavors make this wine practically irresistible, and a soft silky texture reinforces its luxuriousness. Red and black cherry notes mingle with mild vanilla and cinnamon on the palate and finish.

Reduced oak settles in the glass to unleash juicy flavors of Gravenstein apple, lemon, grapefruit and white flower. Gravelly texture gives it context and complexity that buoys the full-bodied frame and allows for persistent acidity.

The old vines in this densely planted vineyard date back 67 years. This wine has great concentration, tannins and juicy red fruits. Its structure emphasizes the straightforward character of Nuits-St.-Georges, so it will take time to mature. Drink from 2023.

Reflecting the vintage, this ripe, smooth wine is sumptuous, full of yellow fruits and ripe pear. Acidity gives everything a lift although it is the richness of the wine that shows most strongly. Drink from 2019.

Generous and ripe, this smooth wine has hidden strengths in the tannic structure that lies underneath the rich fruits. The berry and black-cherry flavors are prominent, giving a juicy character to this rich, full wine. Drink from 2022.

Shiraz from the cool climes of the Great Southern region of Western Australia is a far cry from their rich, sunshine-infused South Aussie counterparts. Frankland Estate is one of the leaders of this more restrained, medium-bodied style. Their estate Shiraz is bursting with ripe blue fruit, vanilla, smoky cedar and baking spices. The palate is silky and elegant, with juicy fruit and savory tannins.

This is an aromatic, pretty Shiraz from Margaret River. Dive into ripe strawberry, rhubarb, pepper, toasty spice and a little meatiness on the nose. Then wade in juicy fruit and a silky smooth texture on the medium-bodied palate which finishes on a grip of savory tannins.
Lamadrid has upped its game with this Gran Reserva Cabernet. The smoky nose carries to a dense, chewy palate, layered with red plum and cassis flavors and massive tannins. Drink through 2026.

From a low-yielding, rocky site, this is a well-structured wine with compelling minerality. Its immaculate raspberry fruit is etched with well-modulated streaks of stem and leaf. It was aged in one fifth new barriques.

This 2013 is the current release. Its lovely floral highlights distinguish the aroma and carry into the flavors. Sourced from 40-year-old vines from the Brooks and Sunnyside vineyards, it was fermented entirely with native yeasts to almost complete dryness.

While the 50-year-old vines do bring concentration, they also deliver delicious swathes of ripe, juicy fruit. This is a ripe, black-cherry-flavored wine, strengthened by tannins and with a crisp edge of acidity. Drink from 2020.

This wine's initial cola and menthol aromas transition to ripe plum and berry notes with extended airing. Its full, chewy, tannic palate is a bit rough. Ripe, jammy cassis and spiced berry flavors are the story, with massive tannins and a ton of spice. Drink through 2025.

Outstanding fruit shines brightly here, with a beguiling mix of Northwest berry flavorsboysenberry, loganberry and blueberry. It's juicy and tart, with polished tannins that carry a pleasing touch of clean earth. Drink 20202030.

Tight aromas of blackberry, lilac and tar meet with burnt toast on this blend of Syrah, Grenache and Roussanne. There is a solid grip to the sip, where blackened blackberry flavors combine with tar, juniper, soy, pepper and caramel on the finish. Savory, this also has a strong acidic energy.

This atypical blend of Chardonnay and Marsanne presents a very smoky nose reminiscent of roasted poultry but cut by rosemary, yuzu, green tea, pomelo pith and fortune cookie aromas. Sandalwood, pluot, yellow melon and saffron flavors show on the exotic palate, which is tense with acidity and tannins and utterly distinctive.
This is a luscious, oaky and smoky red wine, with firm integrated tannins. Spicy acidity provides a freshness against the ripe fruit, leaning floral on the nose and offering plenty of length.

This is a medium-bodied Barossa Shiraz that shows restraint and finesse. Plummy, raisiny fruit, charred meat and a herbal, earthy backbone are supported by soft, sandy-textured tannins, lively acidity and a savory finish. Yum. Drink now2025.

This suave and complex wine has all the classic flavor characteristics like red cherry, black tea and cinnamon along with light oakiness and a luscious texture, a full body and a lingering finish. It feels on the soft side in terms of low acidity and light tannins, but its concentration is impressive.

Full body and very ripe fruit flavors give a lot of impact to this deeply colored and concentrated wine made from the heritage Martini clone and aged in 50% new oak. It packs in the black cherry, blackberry and clove flavors, wrapping them in a firm blanket of fine-grained tannins and good acidity, so that it should improve with age. Best after 2019.
