This is the top wine from this sparkling-wine specialist based in northern Burgundy, close to Chablis. Fruit and richness come from long aging before disgorgement, adding a full texture to the citrus and apple fruitiness. It is a blend of 50/50 Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, ready to drink now.

Penetrating stone fruit, melon and guava flavors permeate throughout this sprightly, feather-light kabinett. Electric acidity and a sheen of crushed-stone minerality add to its breathless, captivating style. It's delicious already but should hold well through 2028.

Rich, ripe passion fruit, berry and guava tones resound from nose to finish in this unabashedly tropical Riesling. While medium-sweet in style, it's refreshingly composed, marked by spine-tingling acidity. A sugary lace meanders long on the finish. It's approachable already, but structured enough to cellar through 2028.

Pretty pink grapefruit and red berries extend from nose to finish in this kabinett. Equal parts sweet and tart, this is a delightfully juicy sip, emboldened by crystalline strikes of minerality and acidity. The finish is honeyed and seemingly neverending.

Very woody and herbal aromas of wild thyme, sagebrush and bay leaf meet with rust, orange rinds, blistered tomato and crushed hibiscus on the spicy nose of this clonal selection. Wild red currants and cranberry-orange compote make for a sour tangy sip, with minty herbs in the background.

Owned by Henri Lurton, one of several Lurtons to own property in Margaux, this estate is performing in high gear. Its second wine is rich and concentrated with solid tannins as well as generous blackberry fruits. It will be impressive as it ages. Drink from 2020.

This wine has a very toasty style, with spice and wood tannins that give an extracted character with some bitterness. That contrasts with the fruit that is developing, and it seems that the wood will integrate over time. Drink from 2025.

Both pretty and complex, Clairault's Cab is a heady mix of cranberry and tart cherry, florals, peppery herbs, pencil lead and some raw meat in the background. The palate is medium bodied and rustic yet elegant. Tannins are big but they seem a product of the skins rather than the oak, and there's a lovely savory, peppery finish. Drink now2025.

This wine's dark, opaque color and jammy, sun-baked aromas are typical of Salta's best Malbecs. It's a saturated, hefty and intense red from some of the highest vineyards in the world, yet it's neither fiery nor aggressive. Its lush, fully developed flavor profile includes cassis, blackberry and chocolate notes that persist into the finish. Drink through 2024.

Aromas of citrus zest, yellow stone fruit and crushed rock follow over to the vibrant palate along with Golden Delicious apple, white peach, white cherry and nectarine. A honeyed almond note closes the finish while bright acidity and a refined perlage provide the vibrant, elegant backdrop.

The 2015 vintage in Savigny-ls-Beaune brings out the smooth richness of the appellation. In this wine it is enhanced by a core of tannins and juicy red-berry acidity, making for a ripe, generous wine that will also age well. Drink from 2021.

This hillside vineyard with its eastern exposure has produced a rich wine in 2015. Structured with some firm tannins from fruit and wood aging, it also has plenty of blackberry and juicy black-currant flavors. Acidity gives a fresh character to this delicious wine that will be ready from 2022.

A rich wine from this 57-acre family estate, this is ripe with black-cherry fruit balanced with juicy acidity. A fine core of tannins gives both structure and aging potential. Drink this generous wine from 2021.

This structured single-vineyard wine has plenty of rich red cherry and berry fruits along with a dry core of tannins. Together they make a wine that needs to age to realize the potential for great fruitiness. Drink from 2023.

This 47-acre domaine, dating back to the 18th century, is lucky to have a portion of this grand cru vineyard. It has produced a generous, still-young wine. Packed with red plum and berry fruits, it is densely textured and concentrated. The wine's future is excellent; wait to drink until 2020.

Luscious raspberry and red-cherry flavors abound in this lavish, full-bodied Pinot Noir. Framed by soft, pliant tannins and bright acidity, it's fruity and forward in style but nuanced by hints of crushed granite and river rocks. The finish is marked by wisps of smoke and nuts. Drink now2022.

Exuberant cherry blossom and grapefruit aromas perfume this sprightly dry wine. Crisp green plum and lime flavors are tart and fresh, catapulted by spine tingling, persistent acidity. It's a breathtaking, vivacious sip to enjoy now through 2022.

Pencil shaving aromas kick off this winery's top-shelf bottling, and then come hints of char, delicate but strong purple flowers and a core of blueberry on the nose. There is a tarry grip to the palate, where flavors of charred boysenberry, lilac and burnt caramel are very clean and elegant.

Ripe and smoky, this full wine is juicy and packed with both fruit and tannins. It's concentrated, with perfumed red-berry fruits showing strongly along with the tannins and firm structure. Its future looks good. Drink from 2023.

This is named for the white flowers that grow between the the vineyard's rows. It opens with soft cumin and fivespice scents, building toward clean raspberry and lollipop-like cherry fruit. A wet rock minerality adds a zing of freshness. The word charming comes to mind, from the first zippy sniff on through the light, pretty finish.

From one of Margaret River's leading Chardonnay producers, the 2015 Prelude doesn't disappoint. It's a nutty, smokey, toasty, melony beauty. Perfectly in balance, with a chalky texture and medium to light body, it wears its heart on its sleeve and is drinking perfectly now, but will gain more even more complexity with a few years in bottle. Drink now2022.

Earthy wisps of rose garden and wild strawberry invite one into this estate wine, that's brawny and strong in imprint. Concentrated and extracted fruit dominates with highlights of cranberry, raspberry and tan bark with a nod of cola and cardamom adding spice.

This vintage blends Pommard and 777 clones, and the black cherry fruit is a bit more forward than in 2014. Cola, mineral, tar and char notes come into play, with an energetic feel. Subtle suggestions of pine needles emerge as the flavors slowly fade. It drinks beautifully on the second day.

Winemaker John House is exploring several different AVAs for his Rieslings; Elkton is a tiny, out-of-the-way spot with a cool climate. Hence, this bone-dry, elegant wine boasts crystalline acidity that tastes like liquid rock. Celery, grapefruit, lemon peel and orange flavors combine on its complex and compelling finish.
This wine is vibrantly bright and coiled in acidity. Leather, cola spice and dark cherry mingle effortlessly on a light, smooth and silky palate, ending in balanced nuance.

Sophisticated and hearty, this is a well-made 100% varietal wine, juicy in black cherry, with a nice waft of wood-fired-oven smoke. Thick, it finds a smoothness of velvety texture as it opens, offering a length of leather, tobacco and black pepper.

Radiant and refined, this white opens on aromas of Spanish broom, white flowers and Mediterranean brush. It's savory and racy, offering apple, pear and orange flavors alongside bright acidity. A salty mineral note lingers on the finish.

Alluring scents of white and yellow flower, stone fruit and a whiff of Mediterranean herb take center stage on this silky, savory wine. The luminous palate mirrors the nose, offering ripe apricot, crushed herbs and lemon drop flavors accompanied by a mineral vein and fresh acidity.

This excellent wine leads with aromas and flavors of citrus, melon and green pineapple. It's vividly tangy and refreshing, with a saline quality and impressive focus and length. You'll want a case of this one.

Lavish plumes of jasmine, white peach and grapefruit perfume this light-as-a-feather sptlese. Despite its diminutive frame, the palate is piercing and expansive. Racy lime acidity and a waxy sheen of honeycomb elongate the finish.
Smooth and rich, this young wine has exceptional texture and mouthfeel. It's a seamless mix of ripe stone fruit, with a touch of vanilla and a hint of butter.

Intriguing aromas of rust, kirsch, dusty leather, crushed star anise, white pepper and li hing mui spice make for an earthy spicy nose on this reserve bottling. It's light in body and delicate in structure on the sip, combining baked earth, red fruit and a strong oregano touch on the finish.

This is a great buy for those that crave creamy, ripe wines. Aromas of black-cherry syrup, pie crust, salted caramel, snickerdoodle, brown sugar and maple syrup prove intoxicating. The palate is soft, thick and saucy, with more dark fruit flavors alongside vanilla, star anise and roasted cocoa.

Once again Treos nails this wine, and in 2016 the alcohol is down and the acids up. Bracing, lemony, and drenched in lip-smacking minerality, this wine overdelivers. It's definitely for acid lovers, but with its extraordinary detail and length, it goes well beyond just tart.

While tannins give a dry core to the wine, it also has ripe red fruits and plenty of them. Along with structure there is a sense of richness and potential opulence. Drink this wine, with its concentrated, juicy aftertaste, from 2021.

Rounded strawberry and blackberry flavors show on the luxuriously soft palate, giving a sense of richness and power. Accented in cedar and leather, it has an herbal underbelly that balances well against the ripe fruit.

A premium Chardonnay at an affordable price from one of Margaret River's leading producers. Unmistakably Western Australian and reflecting proximity to the ocean, Woodlands's Chardonnay smells of sea breeze and brine. It's smokey, nutty and lemony on the palate, with a hint of wild mint and a lean, tight feel of flinty minerality. Drink now2025.

Cola, baked black cherry, crushed gravel, spice cake and root beer aromas make for a very inviting nose on this bottling from one of Paso Robles' cooler regions. A baked-goods flavor starts the sip before crisp, tangy fruit, penetrating acidity and chalky tannins take hold.

This wine is well structured and nicely balanced. It feels elegant on the palate and has an enticing array of complex aromas and flavors. Raspberry, wood smoke and tea scents are followed by nuances of plum, cedar and cinnamon, while fine-grained tannins and good acidity keep the mouthfeel fresh.

This is pure Sauvignon Blanc from one of the few wineries in Oregon that produces it. It's fragrant and compelling, with grassy gooseberry aromas, and rounds out nicely in the mouth. The lip-smacking lushness of its ripe citrus fruit comes with terrific concentration and texture.

Long aging in the deep cellars of the winery and late disgorgement gives this wine its richness and maturity. A blend of 95% Pinot Noir with some Gamay, it is generous, ripe and full of almond as well as red berry fruits. This is a complex wine, now fully mature.

Strawberry, red plum and dried rose petals float atop a very rocky core on the nose of this old vine expression, where wet gravel and crushed river stones serve as a backdrop. The palate is bouncy and fresh with wild raspberry set against crushed-concrete minerality.

Fine aromas of brandied cherry, spiced plum and cool earth get this reserva from a great vintage off to an impressive start. A layered palate is lively but showing maturity, while this tastes of black currant, brown sugar and myriad spices. A peppery, chocolaty, dry finish is beyond nice; drink this well-priced overachiever through 2025.

From one of the top vineyard sites in Pouilly-Fuiss, this wine is rich and textured, with the tight minerality typical of the appellation. It also has ripe fruit, juicy apricots and acidity. It's rich and crisp at the same time. Drink from late 2018.

A small parcel of vines, less than an acre, has produced a rich, structured wine. Its tannins and black-cherry fruit are integrated with the firm wood flavors and acidity. This is a wine for aging, so drink from 2020.

Winemaker Nick Goldschmidt is behind this thick tannic wine, blended with nearly 17% Cabernet Franc. With big shoulders and a depth of extraction, it shines in forest pine, dark plum and dark chocolatethe oak toasty and robust.
Earthy, spicy, leafy aromas accent gritty berry scents in this dense, full-bodied wine. Its minty, herbal berry flavors are peppery and drying on the finish. Drink through 2024.

Made entirely with Merlot, this elegantly structured wine has enticing aromas of cassis, purple flower, dark spice and Mediterranean scrub. The firm palate offers wild cherry, blackberry and licorice alongside polished tannins and bright acidity.

Undeniably spicy, this wine is tart and tangy in acidity, toofocused and full of tension. Notes of dried herb, black tea and cardamom punch first, before allowing room for the fruit, which presents itself as an irresistible combination of cherry and pomegranate.

This block-designated bottling is tightly wound and a bit restrained at first on the nose, but then aromas of flint, peach, ash and white lily begin to elegantly arise. The palate is tart, tense and taut with flavors of lime skin, orange rind and an ashy Brie cheese rind element that makes it very distinctive.

Freshly pressed blueberries, tar, violets and baked blackberry cake show on the dense nose of this bottling by a winery in Texas. The sip is surprisingly delicate at first, with extreme floral flavors that are cut by black-currant cookies, char, black pepper and tar. The acidity rises into the finish.

As the name suggests, this wine is indeed big and powerful, but it's elegant and classy too. Heady notes of violets, red berries, smoked meat, white pepper and licorice are entwined with tightly wound, fine-grained tannins. One for the cellar. Drink 20192032.

Perfumed in cherry, vanilla and cassis, this wine offers dusty brawny tannins that surround a silky supple palate of pronounced texture. Sticky on the finish, it has room to age. It is enjoyable now in its firm grasp of ripe fruit and layered depth.

The nose on this bottling is extremely ripe and rich with black cherry syrup, milk chocolate and butterscotch aromas, proving very inviting, if slightly dessert-like. Those elements extend to the sip, where blackberry pie, candied blueberries, caramel and vanilla prove very tasty and perfect for those seeking a whopper wine.

Freshly cut melon and white lily flowers meet with pear skins and wet clay on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard in the mountains east of Salinas. The palate is rounded at first, with ripe nectarine flavors, but then a powerful acidity slices down the center, carrying tart lime skins, lemon rind and yellow grapefruit elements.

Clean aromatic lines of squeezed lime, seared orange rind, white flowers and plaster show on the nose of this bottling from the winery's first estate vineyard. The oak flavors are present but restrained on the sip, where Meyer lemon cream and ocean spray ride a steady acidity deep into the finish.

There are prominent hints of pine needle and menthol that ride atop the core of bright red cherries and rusty alpine strawberries on this single-vineyard bottling. The palate seamlessly integrates those juniper, dill and mint notes into the cranberry, raspberry and pomegranate juice flavors, all presented on a soft texture.

This bottling is one of the most reliably delicious Pinot Noirs for less than $30 each vintage, and this year is one of the best. Warm, even buttery aromas of brioche, strawberry jam and baking spice prove immensely inviting, leading into an approachable yet complex palate where fruit-punch flavors are lifted by clove, tart plum skins and vanilla on the finish.

Peppery, soft and supple, this blend of Cabernet Franc, Zinfandel and Cabernet Sauvignon is brawny and full bodied. It is a strongly concentrated wine with highlights of dried cherry, baked plum and dried herb.
Ripe strawberry, raspberry, cranberry and red plum flavors, all bright and balanced, impress in this snappy, vibrant wine. The impact of minerally acids outweighs the 25% new oak, at least for now.

Though the name may strike some as a bad pun (recalling fum), the winery explains it's Chinese for rich and beautiful, honoring the mother of one of the owners. This white version of Pinot Noir has a chunky mouthfeel, but it's nuanced with delicate citrus rind, flower and honeycomb details. It continues to develop as it opens, offering a layered mix of citrus and stone fruit balanced with hints of fresh-picked herbs.

There's a strong smoky character to this bottling, with pork roast and hickory smoke rising above the cranberry compote and orange rind aromas on the nose. The smoke extends to the sip as well, but there's also a strong and tangy pomegranate and sour cherry-flavor profile.

Savory and fresh, this opens on alluring aromas of white flower, orchard fruit, citrus and a whiff of crushed rock while the palate offers creamy white peach, apple and lemon drop. A saline mineral note lingers on the finish.

Alluring scents of yellow peach, apricot and Mediterranean brush continue to the savory, mouthwatering palate along with chopped herb and nectarine drop. Tangy acidity gives it a bright, refreshing finish while a saline note lingers on the close.

The fruit from this biodynamic vineyard has a grippy, earthy character that underscores the complexity in this wine. It's tannic and muscular, with black cherry fruit and subtle tanned leather, licorice, black pepper, coffee grounds and dark chocolate highlights that persist through its long, captivating finish.

Despite showing a touch of damp earth and desiccation on the nose, this mystery red blend gets off to a good start. In the mouth, it's plush and fleshy, with more than enough body. Deep berry, plum and coconut flavors finish with forceful acidity, creating length but also texture. Drink through 2025.
Brambly fruit flavors show prominently in this vintage, including purple berry, underbrush, clean earth and a hint of stem. It's complex, per usual, and built for cellaring. Drink now through 2030.

Robust, ripe stone-fruit and candied berry tones lend unctuousness to this sun-kissed kabinett. It's silken and plush in mouthfeel but calibrated neatly by zesty acidity. The finish lingers on a pleasant bite of lime pith.

The humble veteran Bruce McGuire has been making Syrah for decades, and this bottling offers stunning value. Lively aromas of tart black plum skins, white pepper, tar and rainy asphalt lead into a refreshingly acidic though complex sip with flavors of lavender, potpourri and blackberry juice that float across the palate.

This potent red begins with rich blueberry and cherry fruit paired with ample barrel flavors evoking caramel, coffee and dark chocolate. Young, tight and focused, it may be enjoyed immediately (if decanted), or cellared for up to a decade. Drink 20202030.

Aromatic, textured and quite tasty right out of the bottle, this Columbia Gorge vineyard designate has appealing lightness without sacrificing complexity. It's a deft mix of brambly berry fruit with cola and mocha highlights.

Dense aromas of woody blackberry, hints of bay leaf and thyme and a dusting of crushed graphite show on this elegant blend of 80% Cabernet Sauvignon and 20% Petit Verdot. It's a very regal wine on the palate, with firm upright tannins conveying flavors of black plum, leather, tobacco and black pepper.

More delicate than many of the winery's 2014 Pinots, this displays subtle tobacco notes around fragrant strawberry and red fruit flavors. Dried straw and chocolate highlights add welcome complexity. This cellar-worthy effort may be consumed immediately or tucked away for up to a decade.
Austere in elegant restraint, this wine is floral and focused, in brightly effusive layers of tart apple and pear. A thread of toasty oak and anise contributing beguiling side notes.

Broad aromas of Asian pear, yellow flowers, Stargazer lily and wet stone show on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers nectarine and Pink Lady apple, and it remains very tightly wound long after opening, which indicates a long life ahead.

This savory wine bursts with plum, cassis and chocolate aromas that follow through to the taut, elegant palate alongside hints of bell pepper and black pepper. It's fresh and still tightly wound, with firm, velvety tannins. Drink through 2024.

This robust young wine is slightly smoky, with concentrated black cherry and juicy purple and black fruit flavors. A streak of clean earth underscores the tannins, and there's a residual grape soda flavor that accentuates its youth.

Juel fits comfortably in an emerging era for Oregon Pinot Noir. Native yeast fermentation adds texture and depth, and the wine's alcohol and oak aging reflect a deft hand at the controls. Its ripe fruit suggests jammy strawberry, and the acidity and tannins are perfectly balanced. The lovely mouthfeel brings tobacco, herb and grain details, completing the sophisticated picture.

Forest-floor mushroom and pine add spark to a rustic framework of restrained ripeness and savory spice, most definitely cardamom. Medium in body and oak, its fruit is satisfyingly elusive, a mix of rhubarb and pomegranate.

A veil of crushed slate permeates through layers of honey, stone fruit and citrus in this ripe, intensely concentrated kabinett. It's delicately textured, spine-tingling and fresh, finishing on meandering notes of caramel and saffron.

This is a coferment of 56% Syrah and 44% Mourvdre, the grapes grown in Bennett Valley. It possesses grace and style within a brawny shell of spice and leather. Violet aromas dance around the entry, as complex earth tones tease in black olive, cured meat and berry pie.

Produced from organic grapes, this textured wine is rich with the potential to be deliciously fruity. It has toast, spice as well as a strong mineral texture. Alongside that the pear and melon fruits are developing, giving the wine great potential and richness. Drink from late 2018.

Pale gold, almost green tinged, this is is an excellent example of why Margaret River excels at Chardonnay. It's complex, with notes of lemon zest, orange peel, butter and exotic spices that last all the way through to the finish. It's rich with a chalky texture and is age worthy, with enough acidity to take it long into the future. Drink now2027.

A steep vineyard with a south-eastern exposure is just right for the ripe fruit that goes into this wine. It is full bodied, rich with red-berry and red-cherry flavors touched by spice from the wood aging. Developing well, this wine will be ready from 2019.

On the slope above Santenay, this vineyard has produced a richly structured wine, firm with tannins and spice from wood aging. Rich red and blackberry fruits, juicy acidity and elegance give this wine a great future. Drink from 2021.

Blossoms and berries abound in this vibrantly composed Pinot Noir sparkling. It's fresh and fruity while also nuanced by hints of caramel and crushed stones. A lavishly textured mousse and fine, persistent bubbles extend the elegant finish.

This very pretty wine is scented with rose petals and powdered fruit. It has a lovely cherry core with distinctive and unusual cumin and saffron accents. It seems to gain intensity in the glass, continuing through an elegant, extended finish.

Purple flowers, blueberry cream and a caramel richness live on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from one of the newer properties in the region. The mouthfeel is dense, the tannins are stiff and the acidity is bright, carrying flavors of charred meat, purple flowers, black pepper and extremely dark berries. It's still young, so drink 20192029.

Very chalky, tightly wound and mineral-driven on the nose, this expertly restrained bottling also shows Key lime, slight white peach and a whiff of daffodil on the nose. Zippy as can be on the sip, flavors of lime and pink lemon are overshadowed by chalky tensions and limestone flavors, much like licking a white rock.

This juicy, fruity wine, perhaps named after the stony soil, is bold, rich and structured. With firm tannins and acidity, it is definitely a wine for aging. The promise is there with the generous acidity and crisp, bright aftertaste. Drink from 2023.

This clos is a walled section of the En Caradeux Premier Cru. It produced a beautifully perfumed wine, juicy with a core of tannins and ripe red-berry fruits. The structure and acidity will allow this cool, poised wine to age well. Drink from 2022.

This well-balanced wine pushes cherry fruit front and center, underscored by refreshing minerality. The tannins are polished and firmly set on the finish, with a cinnamon kick that resonates long after the last swallow.

This well-known and widely-admired vineyard doesn't disappoint in this wine, delivering lovely cherry fruit touched with a citrusy edge. The concentration builds gracefully, with tasty highlights of chocolate-covered orange peel and roasted coffee.

Despite humid conditions in Mendoza in 2015, this old vins Malbec shows a fine combination of blackberry, smoke and mocha aromas. It's in tip-top shape on the palate, although the acidity is a bit wiry. Oaky flavors of vanilla and mocha work well with its black cherry and blackberry fruit, which is unwavering on the finish. Drink through 2022.

This is a well-balanced offering from Marqus de Grion's. Forward but controlled cassis and blackberry aromas are earthy and suggest cocoa. A stout palate shows modest flexibility and elegance, while this blend of Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot tastes of spicy cassis and raisin prior to finishing rock steady. Drink through 2024.

This opens with aromas of ripe plum, leather and cooking spice. The savory palate offers black-cherry jam, mature blackberry and a hint of tobacco while fine-grained tannins provide the framework. Enjoy through 2023.

A careful hand is clearly at work here. A blend of Coury and 777 clones, it spent 18 months in half new oak, but it's the minerality and overall austerity that impress the most. Precise veins of stem, mineral and caramel flavors inflect its mysterious palate, which is marked by stiff, tight red berry fruit. Though labeled Willamette Valley, it would be surprising if this were not McMinnville AVA fruit.

Sourced from the Gerber vineyard's 40-year-old vines, this bone dry and aromatic wine is perfumed and styled with Old World elegance. It avoids the sometimes off-putting, cloying perfume of the grape, proposing instead more tangy fruit and dry extract. It was fermented in neutral wood with native yeasts and left on the lees for nine months.

This is a classic example of an aged Eden Valley Riesling. Pale gold in color, aromas of lemon curd, kerosene, crme brle and dried herbs carry the nose. The palate is rich but balanced by mouthwatering acidity and a herbal finish. There's plenty of life left. Drink now2027.

This wine is rich with supple tannins and layers of red berry fruits. Its structure and ripeness are immediately attractive even if the wine will needs to age. It is concentrated and likely to be ready to drink from 2020.

Creamy, fresh and crisp, this opens with aromas of dried wildflower and ripe orchard fruit. The rounded palate delivers pastry dough, white peach and yellow apple with fresh acidity. A lemon drop closes the lingering finish.

Featuring a juicy backbone of blackberry and dark cherry (highlights of a seamless structure), this wine shines in additional flavors of vanilla and leather. Full bodied, it holds its weight and breadth in check, delivering voluptuous within a classic framework of style and complexity.

This wine's complex fruit flavors run the gamut from orange marmalade to cherry pie and are bolstered by underlying minerality. It's still very young and will benefit from another year or two of bottle age, after which the tannins will soften and the fruit flavors will unpack themselves.

A classic light color and complex aromas like rhubarb, forest floor and raspberry precede lively red cherry, pomegranate and mushroom flavors on a lean and appetizing texture. This outstanding wine makes a great change of pace from the ponderous fruit-and-oak bombs.

Intriguing and complex, this full-bodied wine combines bright elements of orange zest and pineapple with richer flavors of toasted almond, salted peanuts and dried figs. It is ripe in feel, but good acidity lifts it up and keeps the taste refreshing through a long finish.

Past releases of this wine were sourced solely from Antiquum vineyard; here, there is an additional source. The quality remains quite high despite the substantially larger production and lower price. Win, win, win! Raspberry, cherry, sassafras, cola and mocha flavors are in play. The inclusion of 20% whole clusters and aging in neutral barrels have added light touches of flavor.

Enticing scents of mature orchard fruit, bread crust and toasted almond take center stage while the linear, focused palate doles out Barlett pear, yellow apple and lemon set against crisp acidity. A mineral note lifts the lingering finish.

This is an especially good vintage of this blend from the Winderlea, Weber, Maresh and Murto vineyards. Beautifully fragrant, it's a delicate potpourri of rhubarb and wild berry, with a streak of barrel toast. Darker notes of espresso and cocoa emerge on the extended finish.

This 100% Pommard clone wine delivers sweet and tangy cherry fruit in abundance. It's bedecked with grapefruit, orange rind and almond highlights, and the finish comes with a burst of refreshing minerality.

Aged in Burgundy oak barrels, this refined, balanced and ultimately delicious wine features strawberry-preserve flavors wrapped in toasty oak. Leather, cigar box and a bite of cedar add to its complex whole, its texture soft, fulsome and richly layered.

Quite lovely aromas of rose petals, raspberry framboise, gravel, baked earth, vanilla and caramel show on the inviting nose of this bottling. There is an intriguing peppery spice and herbal character of thyme, bay leaf and oregano on the sip, all set against a backdrop of exotic cherry.

Bread crust, dried fruit, crushed herb and acacia aromas carry over to the enveloping, savory palate along with creamy yellow peach, tangerine zest and a hint of toasted almond. Vibrant acidity and an elegant perlage provide energy and finesse. A honeyed nut note and a touch of salt wrap up the dry, lingering finish.

This Cabernet Sauvignon has small percentages of Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. Spicy clove rides atop full-figured waves of black cherry and blackberry fruit. It's balanced and well-integrated within its ripe fruit frame, with structured tannins and a deep, rich concentration.

Impenetrable in color and very nearly in style too, this wine is a deep, dark well of cherry chocolate cake, cola, raspberry, and spice. Juicy plush fruit on the palate is balanced by powerful yet silky tannins and a savory finish. This full-bodied wine is in it for the long haul. Drink now2042.

Violet and bramble tones perfume this lavishly floral red. Brisker and brighter than Germany's warmer-climate Pinots, this Mosel Pinot Noir offers concentrated but crisp black cherry and berry flavors rimmed by a fine edge of bitter tannins. It's silky in texture, with a long, lingering finish. Drink now through 2025 to enjoy its freshness.

Smoky aromas of roasted chicken, sandalwood and oak are cut by strong Meyer lemon rinds on this bottling, which appeals to those with a fondness for rich toasty flavors. It's super zippy on the palate, with orange oil and lemon skin flavors cutting through the toasted pecan nuttiness and hickory smoke.

Candied black cherry, smoked pork, cola and crushed asphalt show on the complex, inviting nose of this smaller-block bottling from the estate's large vineyard. The flavors are deep and dark yet not rich or heavy, with hints of tar, black pepper, wild blackberries and black plum, all hung from a firm zippy structure.

Under the same ownership as Pichon Longueville Comtesse de Lalande in Pauillac, this estate has produced a concentrated wine. Dark and firm, with the tannins up front, the wine will take time to develop. Wait until 2025.

From vines in the lee of the dramatic rock of Solutr, this wine has great minerality as well as crisp, clean impressive fruit. It is textured, still a little tight but also full of great citrus, crisp apple and apricot flavors. Drink this refreshing and structured wine from late 2018.

This wine is rich, full in the mouth and with good concentration. Its youthful, mineral character gives it texture as well as good acidity. With its potential and ripe yellow and citrus fruit, it is likely to age for several years. Drink from 2019.
Owner Laurent Godard has made superbly ripe wine, rich in yellow fruits and orange-peel flavors. Generous and full bodied, it is open and ample. Drink this opulent wine from late 2018.

Tannins are firm and concentrated in this richly textured wine. With this good structure, all it needs is for the dark plum and black-cherry fruits to come through. The weight of the wine assures that, giving it both potential richness and a ripe character. Drink from 2023.

Luxurious guava, grapefruit and red berry aromas perfum this intensely fruity, sun-kissed sptlese. It's wispy and spry on the palate but penetrating acidity guides a long brambly finish. Approachable already but structured enough to stay pristine well through 2025.

This is an elegant, austere wine, balanced, crisp and clean. Lemon, quince and fig ride along a grainy integrated texture of supportive subtle oak. This is a fine companion for the table, vibrant and versatile with food.

Very light in color, this tightly wound bottling shows aromas of crisp Asian pear, chilled Pink Lady apples, sharp green melon rind, wet stone and a definite grassy quality. The palate is a study in wound-up freshness that's on the verge of bursting, with more Asian pear and hints of pluot riding an extremely pithy texture.

Vanilla and crisp minerality play together in this ripe wine with steely core. It has intense acidity, a lively, bright texture plus a flinty edge that will allow it to age. The wine, still young, will be ready from 2020.

Here's a plump, comfortable wine reflecting the warm vintage for whites. It is rich and soft, although with plenty of toast and spice from the barrel fermentation and aging. This generous wine needs a few more months to allow the fruit to speak. Drink from late 2018.

Candle wax, lime zest and honey lend lavish accents to crisp but concentrated tangerine, apricot flavors here. It's just a shade off dry in style, with a vibrant mineral finish. A fantastic value for such an elegantly composed Riesling. Drink now through 2022.

With 12% Petite Sirah, this old-vine wine is dominated by candied plum on the nose and mouth, with additional notes of ripe black fruits on the palate. The palate is bold yet well-integrated, with a velvety texture and graceful structure.

Smoky char meets noble reduction in this medium-bodied tightly wound wine. Youthfully grippy, it unravels slowly to show aromas and flavors of dark cherry, chocolate mint and forest floor, finding a balance between power and grace.

Whispers of green florals and lime zest on the nose extend into the palate of this invigorating kabinett. Just a shade off dry, its sweetness is countered by cutting citrus, green herb and mineral refreshment. The finish is pristine and persistent.

Rich fruit flavors are accented by brown sugar and vanilla in this seductive and easy-drinking wine. It has a smooth soft texture, lots of ripeness and low acidity for a melting mouthfeel and sweet-seeming finish.

Breakfast tea, grapefruit and orange peel scents and a hint of spiced pumpkin come out of this well-priced sweet wine. With 67 g/L residual sugar and 12% alcohol, it's not shy by any standard. The acid is sufficient to balance out all that sugar, and it's rich enough that one half bottle can provide a dessert sip for a party of four.

This warm-climate Chardonnay smells smoky, creamy and smooth, showing hints of seashell and mineral through its oaky veil. Its full-bodied palate is rich and moderna mix of overt oak flavor with apple, pear and salty melon notes. There is a smooth, oaky essence on the finish. Drink through 2019.

This flagship wine showcases the estate vineyard's complex, biodynamically farmed, old vine grapes. It's a well-matched mix of red fruit and citrus flavors, with palate-cleansing minerality. A light suggestion of toast from 11 months aging in 20% new French oak highlights the finish.

A 100% varietal wine from a high-elevation site, this dark wine is herbal and soft, supple in texture despite considerable ripeness and power. Violet aromas mellow a fistful of dark chocolate and baked plum, as smoky oak wanders by.

One in a pair of soil-designated wines from Andrew Rich, this is the more fruity and forward of the two. Its tangy orange and raspberry fruit is aromatic and fresh. There's a touch of cherry lollipop on the finish, along with clean tannins.

Although not labelled as such, this Blanc de Blancs comes from similar chalky soil to neighboring Champagne. Crisp acidity, mineral texture and pointed acidity are given extra life by citrus fruits and a relatively dry aftertaste. Drink this delicious bottling from 2018.
Smoky and big-boned, this is a robust, complex and enticing wine, aged in French oak (28% new). Strawberry and balsamic notes are joined by black tea, cardamom and cola on the medium-bodied palate.

This deep ruby wine has a nose of blackberry, strawberry, sage and thyme. It is soft on entry, with a nice balance of fruit and spice flavors, in particular black cherry, dark plum, fennel, sage and mocha. The tannins start off very mild and gradually increase in intensity, lingering through a licorice and cherry finish.

Clean fruit, dried autumn leaves, balsamic vinegar, black olives and cola notes all lead into a full-bodied palate that's chewy with savory, earthy tones and big, well-structured tannins. There's a fair lick of oak here but it should soften with time in cellar. Drink 20192032.

This producer does not believe in much oak aging (in this case 3%), but even that small amount brings out richness while leaving the delicious fruit right in place. From one of the top, ripe premier crus in Chablis, this wine is rich, creamy while never losing the proper tang of citrus and bright acidity. Drink from 2019.

The old vines add their concentration to this ripe wine. It is smooth, smoky from wood aging and offers ripe red-berry and black-cherry fruits. It already has a delicious juicy character that will be enhanced as it ages. Drink this rounded wine from 2020.
Still closed and tight, this crisp, mineral-textured wine has acidity and citrus fruits that still need to show their real potential. It needs to age; drink from 2020.

An impressive, textured wine, tight and mineral in character, this is also rich and has a great future, shown by its tangy acidity, steely edge and potential fruitiness. Dense and full bodied, it's likely to be ready to drink from 2019.

This wine's brambly raspberry fruit has a distinctive, sharp edge. It's tightly framed with peppery tannins. Extended aeration reveals some barrel toast and warms up the finish. It was sourced from select barrels and should age nicely for up to a decade.

Savory cardamom and cola ride along a bright fresh core of fruity cherry in this well-made and balanced wine. Forest floor and a dash of white pepper contribute additional complexity and spice. This is a lighter take on coastal fruit.

Hugely concentrated, this wine has power to spare, within its full-bodied richness and fruity succulence. Blackberry, black cherry and milk chocolate combine effortlessly to provide a pleasurable experience of complexity met by supportive acidity and exotic spice.

This comes from the producer's own estate and from its top blocks of old vines. Spiced, it's also herbal in cedar and sandalwood, in addition to black licorice. Thick and spicy, it has enough acidity to brighten denser pockets of blackberry and black cherry. It shows plenty of structure for long-term enjoyment.

A great example of a beautiful, focused wine, this medium-bodied offering from one of Anderson Valley's stalwarts has wonderful pure fruity aromas, a rich texture that's well supported by moderate tannins, and expressive red and black cherry flavors accented by cinnamon and all-spice.

Stewed cherry, sarsaparilla, shoe leather and incense aromas show on the nose of this clonal selection from a vineyard in the middle of the appellation. The palate is dominated by eucalyptus oil, pine needle and dewy juniper flavors, set against dark cranberry and black raspberry fruit. The finish is redolent with menthol and cedar.

Initial oak-driven aromas of grilled and smoked meats don't allow for much fruit expression on the nose. A jammy, plush palate is solid but not too hard or tannic. Spicy, toasty flavors of plum, raisin and licorice expire with mild heat and burn on the finish. Drink through 2032.

Generous in oak and quiet tannin, this is a ripely bold and fruity wine that manages to also be balanced and savorythe texture grainy and gritty. Cardamom, dried herb and cola play well against black cherry and rhubarb.

There are only a few white wines made in Beaune, coming from small parcels dotted across the appellation. This open, rich 18-month wood-aged wine is generous and ripe with creamed apple and spiced pear. It's a toasty wine that retained its fruit. Drink from 2020.

Smooth and rounded, this wine has spice from wood aging as well as rich white and yellow fruits. The wine is concentrated from low-yielding old vines as well as richly endowed with acidity and minerality. Drink from 2020.

This is made from half Syrah and smaller parts Petit Verdot (35%) and Cabernet Franc (15%). Barnyard rusticity overwhelms at first before allowing other savory elements to speak. Leather, mushroom and cigar ride atop black currant and plum as generous tannins struggle successfully to soften by the finish.

Dark gold in color, this is a creamy, full-figured wine made with supportive oak. Lively acidity provides fresh contrast to its richer tendencies, as a length of apple spice and fennel pique interest on the thick palate.

Fresh aromas of licorice-laced plum, chaparral herbs and pristine alpine strawberry show on the nose of this single vineyard expression. The clean palate balances tart and ripe flavors, with firm tannins veiling the fruit and spice, and a flash of thyme showing on the finish.

Sourced from the Blue Rock Vineyard, this contains 8% Cabernet Franc, an addition that contributes violet aromatics. Crayon wax, plum and juicy cherry-blackberry are wrapped within integrated tannin and plenty of lasting power seasoned in black pepper and clove.

This is a broody, dense and muscular wine. Ripe dark fruit, chocolate, dried oregano and vanillin oak lead into a rich, powerful palate laced with high-end French oak notes. The tannins are fine grained and tightly wound. Throw this in the cellar and forget about it for several years at least. Drink 20202032.

Meant to be brawny explosive wine, this blends 25% Syrah, 22% Grenache, 20% Petite Sirah, 17% Carignane and smaller drops of Zinfandel, Alicante Bouschet and Tempranillo in a classic field-blend style. Juicy and expansive on the palate, it has meaty tannin and leather as well as licorice, violet and pepper,. A lengthy streak of black pepper finishing things out.

Blended with 12% Petit Verdot, this is a thick, extracted young wine, full of black cherry, chalky tannins and a gritty, grippy texture. Hugely present in power and oak, it will do well in the cellar. Enjoy best 20242034.

This appellation blend allows a more affordable taste of the Talley family's Chardonnay excellence. This bottling shows aromas of Meyer lemon skins, warm nectarine, sea salt, tangerine pith and wet sidewalk. Rounded salt and stone fruit flavors show on the sip, but the citrusy acidity is persistent, cutting through the slight butter warmth. Caramel pops on the finish.

Tight citrus peel and peach aromas show a leesy side on the nose. This excellent rendition of Albario feels round and juicy, but not sharp. Pleasing peach and melon flavors dry out and suggest white pepper on the finish.

Toasty and supple, this melds ripe strawberry fruit with ample streaks of mocha and sea salt chocolate. The barrel flavors are big and forward but undeniably delicious, making for a thick, full-bodied and appealing wine.

Currant, clove, cinnamon, cola, and sun-baked earth form this attractive nose, which leads into a medium-bodied palate that has mineral and medicinal herb characters along with more cinnamon and currant. The tannins are tightly grained yet silky. A wintery Cab that could be cracked open now with food or cellared through 2027.

This juicy four clone blend bursts with tart raspberry and strawberry fruit. Excellent concentration, a lively mouthfeel and textural details all contribute to its fine value. It spent 11 months in 30% new French oak; hints of pepper dot the finish.

The small appellation of Auxey-Duresses, tucked into the hills behind the main Cte de Beaune, often offers good value for a Burgundy. This ripe wine, full of soft red fruits, is a case in point. Its generous texture and soft tannins are attractive already, giving a full, smiling wine. Drink from 2019.

Pinot Gris continues to be at the top of this winery's releases, as this vintage bursts with exceptionally ripe, fleshy fruit. Tangerine, Meyer lemon and sweet orange notes combine in a juicy mix that leaves a sweet and tangy impression as it unwinds on the palate.

Rich and ripe to the point of tropical, this bursts with lush citrus, peach, banana and papaya notesa fruit salad of fresh flavors. It offers more than just ebullient fruit, though; excellent structure, balancing acidity and a nice long finish complete the picture.

Made from 100% varietal grapes, the wine aged 22 months in 65% new French oak.This is a robustly crafted, powerfully concentrated experience, thick and hugely extracted in black fruit and black pepper. Leathery in texture, it has a fistful of oak that should settle down with cellaring. Enjoy best 2024 through 2034.

Aromas of dried cherry, iron and smoke are set against a mineral-driven backdrop of volcanic soil, wet gravel and slate on the nose of this bottling. The palate is a bit like sucking on gravel at first: very schist-driven and flint-like. Then come waves of pomegranate, carnation and, on the finish, vanilla.

Fermented in a concrete egg, this fascinating wine stands apart from any standard Oregon Pinot Gris. Its texture and subtle details speak to why winemakers are fascinated by these particular fermentation vessels, which are neither cheap nor easy to master. Its solid pear fruit is dappled with bread, pollen and powdered lemon notes.

A true old-vine bottling, this comes off the original block of a vineyard planted in 1968 by Oregon pioneer Dick Erath. It's a complex, spicy and balanced amalgam of berry, cherry and plum fruit. As is often the case, it rewards aeration and attention. The acid/tannin balance is just about perfect.

Ken Wright oversees production for Angela Estate, bringing his 30-plus years of Oregon experience to the task. This lovely bottle is smooth and supple, the fruit a mix of ripe raspberry, red plum and cherry jam, with a gentle touch of chocolate. It's seamless and delicious now but should age nicely though 2026.

This ripe while also crisp wine has just over half Chardonnay in the blend with Pinot Noir. It is crisp, tight with citrus and apples as well as a pure line in refreshing acidity. This is a food wine, ready to drink now.

The nose on this bottling dials in strongly to a crushed chalk aroma, which is peppered over the lemon pith and rainy sidewalk scents. It's very fresh and tightly wound on the palate, with lime spray, beeswax, a touch of petrol and a slight botanical element.

A bit dark in color for the variety, this wine brings fruit-forward aromas of cherry, forest floor and assorted spices. The fruit flavors are ripe and bold yet show a delicious sense of purity. There's no mistaking the warmth of the vintage with its 13.8% alcohol, but there's still a lot enjoy here.

This wine pays homage to a historic revolt in Sonoma in 1846. Waves of dark cherry and vanilla surround a strong core of integrated oak and supple texture in this well-made wine. Ripe, full-bodied and well-balanced, this wine will please many a palate with ease.

A lovely sunset rose shade, this delightful wine is spicy and loaded with orange peel and clove highlights. Its pretty watermelon and strawberry fruit carries into a lush finish, with a full-flavored, highly satisfying mouthfeel.

This wine's dark, smoky berry aromas include a reedy note. A selection from the rockiest part of the Adrianna Vineyard in Tupungato, it's so racy and bright that it's sharp and tangy on the palate. Its toasty red berry, plum and spice flavors finish with unusually high acidity. Drink through 2035.

Fresh-pressed boysenberry meets with jammier plum-sauce aromas on the nose of this blend of 40% Merlot, 24% Petit Verdot, 21% Cabernet Sauvignon, 11% Cabernet Franc and 4% Malbec. This wine offers light herbal, spice and wood aromas while the palate proves very versatile and lively, with bright, tart pomegranate flavors and a touch of purple flowers.

Rich and hearty black cherry, clove, star anise and vanilla team with a bit of crushed slate minerality on the nose of this block-designated bottling. Dark berries, cola, chaparral herbs and white pepper show on the sip, where squeaky tannins arise toward the finish.

This is a rich wine from a rich year, giving it density as well as an opulent, ripe character, packed with apricots and white peaches. Acidity gives the wine crispness as well as a bright edge that contrasts with the intensity of the fruit and texture. Drink the wine from late 2018.

A beautifully ripe wine, this is textured and packed with fruit at the same time. It shows a classic mineral character of Pouilly-Fuiss along with generous yellow and citrus fruitiness. Produced by the Dutron family, who have been growers since the 19th century, this wine could age. Drink from 2019.

The second release under this new label from Spindrift Cellars is a sharp, focused expression of crushed raspberries, the flavors ripe and jammy. That lovely fruit is framed by skin and stem phenolics. The tannins are solid, suggesting it will benefit from another year or two of bottle age.

Half of this wine was fermented with whole clusters and native yeasts then aged for 18 months in 41% new French oak. Its dusty raspberry aromas lead to a midpalate rich with crushed red fruit flavors. It finishes with a savory suggestion of chicken stock, along with well-modulated, drying tannins.

This is Cristom's entry-level Pinot, and it over-delivers in every regard. The texture, depth and detail of higher-priced vineyard designates are all here, matching brambly berry fruit and streaks of char and coffee grounds. Drink now through the early 2020s.

The second release from this site from this producer, Hudson provides bold, rich flavors of cherry coulis and blackberry, and a hint of chocolate-covered orange giving it both a decadent feel and a hit of freshness. Rose petal aromas add a pretty profile to the length and balance of acidity.

Owner Benot Eschard is the sixth generation to run the family estate that includes this wholly owned premier-cru vineyard. This wine is soft, ripe, full of spice, black-plum fruits and integrated acidity. Its softness is balanced by the core of tannins that promise some aging. Drink from 2021.

While this wine is ripe and generous, it also has a strong mineral edge as well as refreshing acidity. The blend of crispness and full yellow fruits give both balance and a delicious character to this attractive wine. Drink from late 2018.

This opaque blend of Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon, Petit Verdot and Tannat smells deep and dense, like prune and black currant. Like with many high-end 2014s, its saturated palate is tough and tannic, needing air. Blackberry, cassis, toasty oak and chocolate flavors lasting on its intense finish. Drink through 2024.

The organically farmed Frankland Estate in the Great Southern region once again delivers in spades when it comes to the complexities of terroir expression combined with drinkability. This red blend offers attractive blue fruit notes, Dr. Pepper, coffee beans and cedar. The medium-bodied palate is herbal and stalky, with drying but beautifully structured tannins and a tangy, savory finish. Drink now2027.

Powerful in nature, this wine is full of raspberry, red cherry, earth and floral notes, with some charred wood in the background. There's some heat on the palate alongside overt oak and chewy tannins, but the acidity is there, as is the fruit. This just needs time in the cellar. Drink 20202037.

Deep red violet in the glass, this wine features aromas of blackberry, licorice and lavender. The tannins come in strong but recede within moments, revealing flavors of dark plum, blackberry, baking spices and chocolate. A note of bright cranberry near the finish is followed by mouth-drying tannins that linger with a touch of spice.

This is a soft, smooth and decadent wine, gritty in texture and firm in structure. Candied cherry pie is seasoned in cinnamon and clove with dried herb adding a savory twinge between the medium-bodied layers.

Brawny and fully ripe in knock-down layers of tobacco, leather and baked dark fruit, this wine succeeds in its embrace of thick concentration and velvety luxuriousness. Richly robust, it finishes dusted in black pepper and cinnamon toast.

Unlike the rich, powerful Shirazes of South Australia, Western Australia's cooler climes produce wines more reminiscent of the Northern Rhne. Leeuwin's version swirls and twirls with notes of tangy orange rind, bright cherry, meat, cola and cumin spice. Light to medium bodied, it's silky and elegant but with some power too. Juicy fruit and savory tannins complete the package. Drink now.
This wine is predominately Zinfandel, with 10% Carignane, 6% Petite Sirah and 3% Alicante Bouschet. Smoky bacon, cherry, citrus and watermelon all meld in this broadly structured, full-bodied red.

Cherry compote, warm cinnamon bread, plump raspberry and a hint of star anise make for a rich and spicy nose on this bottling. The palate shows similar character, with plush, soft and warm tones of red cherry and light clove spice.

Spine tingling acidity juxtaposes juicy, ripe tangerine and stone-fruit nectar in this dry-style Riesling. It's a keenly balanced wine offering loads of concentrated fruit, with a cool, alpine touch that's invigorating on the finish.

Aged 11 months in one third new French oak, this bright and spicy bottle is priced a bit lower than the single vineyard offerings from Rex Hill. Its raspberry, blackberry and cola flavors combine with a dash of peppery herb.

This 100% Wadenswil selection from Block 7 delivers ripe strawberry and cherry fruit flavors. The fruit has a pleasing brambly quality that shows on both the nose and palate, with lightly lemony acids that carry a hint of minerality.

This barrel blend combines all the different red wines in Sineann's expansive portfoliopredominantly Pinot Noir, Merlot and Zinfandel, with smaller amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. Blueberry flavors abound, along with cherry pie fruit. It's concentrated, fruit-driven and absolutely delicious.

There is an intensity of oak that greets the nose of this wine, leading to baked-fruit flavors of apple and pineapple, with and nutmeg offering nuance. Bright, persistent acidity cuts through the rich palate and complements its creaminess.

Notes of earthy, clove and all spice carry the nose. This is full, juicy and popping on the palate. Flavors of raspberry, mixed spices and exotic tea finish with red-berry leftovers and even more spice notes. Drink through 2028.

Oak notes are prominent on the nose, with aromas of shoe polish and ash. This is a big Cabernet Sauvignon that still need time to settle. Its dark, oaky flavors are bolstered by a core of berry fruit. A loud finish suggests this is best for those who favor bold New World reds. Drink 20192028.

Chunky, slightly raisiny aromas mark the nose of this blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec and Cabernet Franc. On the palate, it's saturated and a touch heavy, with oaky, chocolaty black fruit flavors. The medium-length finish is mellow and dense. Drink through 2020.

Named for a David Bowie song from 1979, this wine has a nose of apple and brioche. Medium straw in the glass, it offers delicate bubbles and flavors of Granny Smith apple, pear, pink grapefruit and freshly baked bread. The finish offers a burst of tangy grapefruit flavor.

The AVA Series comprises small-production, single vineyard wines that showcase particular Willamette Valley terroirs. This onesourced from the Lichtenwalter vineyardcaptures the complex opulence of Ribbon Ridge. At this young age, its toast and caramel flavors from aging in 30% new French oak are front-and-center. Other highlights include whiffs of cherry tobacco and coffee. It's smooth and appealing and may be cellared for up to a decade.

This limited production, single-vineyard clonal selection is balanced and surprisingly moderate in body, given its high alcohol. Its firm raspberry jam flavors suggest very ripe fruit, and its tarry tannins come with ground coffee notes.

A vibrant, youthful garnet hue imbues this wine, which is fragrant with rose petal scents and lush with tart cranberry and red currant fruit. At this stage, it remains tight and astringent, but it should improve further with bottle age. The Murto vineyard dates back to 1978, though some replanting has been done since.

This wine, made from old Pommard clone vines, hails from a site previously known as the Ana vineyard. It showcases the clean, crisp style that typifies all Winderlea Pinots: pomegranate and raspberry fruit and a juicy, acid-driven mouthfeel that amplifes its refreshing minerality.

Soft, round and approachable in its fruit-forward succulence and full-bodied richness, this is a well-made complex wine. Red cherry and vanilla dominate secondary elements of cedar, leather and cola, finishing with a length of clove.

Aromas of ripe black-skinned fruit and exotic spice are front and center on this delicious red. On the fresh palate, tightly knit, polished tannins carry mouthwatering black cherry, blackberry compote, mocha and cinnamon. Enjoy through 2024.

Alto Moncayo's mega Garnacha is this smoky, roasted smelling monster. Aromas of plum and currant are straight from the smoker, while this feels full and massive but tempered by acidity. Resiny oak flavors of clove and campfire are stronger than the wine's plum and berry notes, while this tastes savory and extremely woody on the finish. Drink through 2022.

This sweet (88 g/L residual sugar) wine is a pretty shade of copper, and its unctuous flavors are somewhat mitigated by prominent acidity. Its flavors suggest grainy rock candy, maple syrup and honeycomb. Drink now through 2020.
With 21% Malbec, this is a robustly impressive wine, smoky in oak, with teases of brick, cola and baked plum. Softly plush, it offers lasting acidity and freshness within a context of ripe power.

There are ample amounts of cola, stewed black cherry, star anise and sarsaparilla spice on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard deep up the Santa Ynez River. Black currant and violet flavors kick off the sip, which is framed by firm, sticky tannins and lifted by crushed Tellicherry peppercorns.

A hearty, generously full-bodied and concentrated wine, this has an intensity of oak that works against the ripe fruit. Gravenstein apple speaks loudest, accented in wild fennel, salty air and nutmeg.

Salt, slate and lime accent pristine grapefruit and green plum notes in this bracing off-dry Riesling. Strikes of acid and minerality reverberate long and lean on the finish. It's a thrilling kabinett to enjoy now2028.

Broad aromas of melon, warm nectarine, light lime and melted butter make for a creamy nose on this single-vineyard expression. There is a compelling tightness to the sip, where the acidic zing cuts through richer flavors of campfire-roasted lemon and prominent oak smoke.

This is an earthy wine interwoven in blueberry and tangy cranberry and pomegranate fruitiness. Light in texture and approach, it's as earthy as it is fruity, with subtle offerings of rose petal, cedar and sage. A citrus-like squeeze of acidity hits on the finish, a welcome goodbye.

Extremely pleasant aromas of caramel-laced honeydew cream and light cashew show on the nose of this bottling that's focused on a specific block of this historic vineyard. The palate zings with freshness and acidity right out of the gates, and then allows fatter notes of melted butter, orange peels, mandarin slices and clotted cream to consume the midpalate.

A new project from the owners of Spindrift Cellars, this features old vines and French oak-aging. It's lightly musky, with animal hints and plenty of ripe raspberry fruit. The full-flavored midpalate glides into a pretty, chocolaty finish.

Pear and grapefruit aromas are prominent on the clean and easy nose of this bottling from Spanish Springs Vineyard, as is a sweet floral touch of Stargazer lily. The flavors are crisp and strong with more white flowers, and the grippy chalky texture and solid acidity make for a lovely wine altogether.

Still firm and tight, this structured wine at the moment is about tannins rather than fruit. Don't worry, the fruit is there, giving weight to the wine with its rich berry character. Just allow it time and drink from 2021.
Cherry aromas and rich spicy fruits make this an accessible wine. It has delicious rich fruits, a light layer of tannins and an open texture. Drinkable soon, this wine will be ready from 2019.

With richness from wood aging, this ripe, smooth and creamy wine is ready to drink. Citrus and yellow fruits contrast with the strong mineral texture typical of the appellation. It's a ripe wine, ready now and until 2024.

With dense fruits and tannins, this is a warm, rich wine. Its tannins are comfortably ensconced in the generous berry fruits and balanced acidity. It is a juicy wine, plump and likely to age well. Drink from 2022.

This full-bodied, rich wine is open and ripe. Delicious layers of yellow fruits are sustained by the mineral texture and crisp acidity. Although this wine is good to drink now, it will be much better if aged further, so wait until late 2018.

Fresh green florals, lime zest and yellow plum are tart and invigorating in this wine. Showing a bit of a lime-and-mineral cocktail, it's spry in texture yet penetrating and juicy. The long finish is softly honeyed. Lovely already but should drink well through 2027, likely beyond.

This complex wine neatly weaves blue and purple fruit flavors, with soft leather, dried herb, cannabis and smoke accents. It's drinking quite well and should remain in peak condition for another half decade. Drink now through 2025.

A dense wine that is still young, this is full, textured and with plenty of both fruit and spice. A creamy vanilla character fills out this ripe wine and gives an extra dimension. Drink this rich wine from 2019.

This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec is plush, deep and chewy. Its earthy, spicy plum and berry aromas show a hint of eucalyptus and mint. Matching the nose, it tastes of roasted blackberry touched up with leafy spice notes. An herbal tea- and pepper-inflected finish offers a nice conclusion. Drink through 2025.

Dark licorice, anise, blackberry and prune aromas set this up a for rough palate with sandpaper tannins. A blend of Malbec and Cabernets Sauvignon and Franc, it tastes of dark, toasty black fruits with herbal shadings. Its chewy finish fades slowly. Drink through 2026.

Tightly wound in its youth, this is a spicy integrated wine that offers black tea and baked strawberry-rhubarb flavors alongside bold aromas of rose petal and forest floor. Moderate structure supports the moderate ripeness and expansiveness on the palate.

This opens with a pretty nose that mixes floral scents with baby powder notes. A flavorful melding of bergamot tea, lemon and honey keeps it interesting on the palate, with enough acidity to keep it tasting dry.

Boysenberry compote, wet asphalt, black peppercorns and dried thyme make for a classic and compelling nose on this countywide blend. Rustic sagebrush and wild thyme flavors show on the sip, set against dark red plums and a gravelly minerality.

This dense and tannic wine, from the lower slope of the village, is firm and solid. It has a powerful core of tannins as well as rich black fruits that are developing behind the structure. Concentration and dryness mean the wine needs to age, so drink from 2021.

Plump, dark strawberry, lavish kirsch, along with cola, cinnamon and allspice show on the nose of this rich bottling from a vineyard on the small appellation's northern end. Vanilla, caramel and cherry-jubilee flavors show on the ripe sip, where a solid tannic tension arises on the finish.

A deeper shade of pink, this bottling shows raspberry, rose petal, crushed gravel and wet slate on the impressively mineral nose. There is a complex texture to the palate, which is loaded with crushed rock and chalk, and also shows candied raspberry and cherry flavors.

A slight hint of hay yellow in the glass, this bottling shows a clean line of cantaloupe, plumeria, daffodil and vanilla-spiced pear sauce on the nose. The palate is grippy with lemon skin tension, offering richer yellow-peach-cream flavors against that pithy texture. Great combo of ripeness with restraint.

There is a strong floral character to the nose of this single vineyard bottling, with pungent carnation and violet as well as red currant, black raspberry and incense. The sip is energetic with tart acidity, yet the mouthfeel is soft, creamy and nearly chalky, showing cranberry and cherry tomato flavors.

Concentrated aromas of black cherry, earthy rust, cedar and warm vanilla make for a very pleasing and standard nose on this bottling. There is a lot of baking spice on the palate as well as plums, black cherries, sandalwood and a hint of cocoa, making for a complex sip.

This wine has a fresh carbonic liveliness on the palatea burst of bubbly cherry and pomegranate flavor that is supported by sturdy tannins. Toasted oak is complemented by Asian five-spice and pretty aromas of rose.

This wine is juicy and broad in tannin, with a gritty layered texture of black cherry, blackberry and minty menthol. Cola spice rides along the palate with ease, providing a savory touch within a light-bodied weight.

This blends together the grapes of several vineyards within the appellation, including single-vineyard sites like Leras, Peters and Nunes. Brightly layered, it shines in strawberry and pomegranate tanginess, complemented by fresh acidity and a persistence of rose.

Set at the eastern limit of Santenay next to Chassagne-Montrachet, this vineyard produces structured wines that reflect its neighbor. In this vintage, Valrie and Philippe Jeannot took advantage of rich red-cherry juiciness with a touch of pepper and almost refreshing acidity. Drink this succulent wine from 2021.
Red berry, licorice and exotic spice aromas follow through to the smooth palate along with raspberry compote and menthol. Polished tannins provide supple support. Drink through 2021.

Perfumed, this 66% Cabernet Sauvignon and 34% Syrah blend showcases both varieties well, allowing a generously succulent, fleshy mouthfeel to impart flavors of cherry, vanilla and smoky oak. Made in a rounded approachable style, it retains acidity and complexity, nods to its mountainous beginnings.

This blend of Petite Sirah and Syrah is beautifully structured and complex, robust in black cherry, blackberry and a bite of lasting tannin. Succulent secondary characteristics linger into black leather, pepper and earthy root.

Fleshy and plump compared to this producer's more mineral medium-sweet kabinett, this bottling is a glorious fountain of lusciously sweet yellow peach, apple and tangerine flavors. It's still zesty and spry in texture, with riveting pin points of acidity that linger on the finish.

This is a clear, fresh, downright pretty wine, though not as powerful as the 2015. Its lovely cherry fruit comes with a hint of underbrush, and the finish carries a streak of cola. This is a wine to enjoy young, so drink now through the early 2020s.

Smashed blackberry and mulberry mingle with black pepper and beef char on the nose of this bottling. It's still extremely young on the palate, not quite ready to release its bounty, but flavors of seared beef, tar, crushed marjoram, white pepper and forest floor indicate a compelling future.

Dark and toasty barrel flavors frame tight black cherry fruit in this wine. It has herbal highlights that bring cannabis to mind and dark chocolate notes that wrap up the finish. It's a blocky, substantial wine best consumed now through 2022.

Scents of yellow flower, ripe orchard fruit and aromatic herb lead the way on this round, medium-bodied white. On the savory palate, an underlying mineral note reminiscent of oyster shell underscores mature pear, yellow apple, fennel and a hint of honey. A hazelnut note marks the close.

Zesty lime and lemon notes reverberate from nose to finish in this delightfully spry, sweet wine. Lush white peach and honey notes are lip smacking and juicy but calibrated deftly with acidity and subtle nuances of earth and mineral. A remarkable value for such an elegant wine.

This Shiraz from Penfolds's original Magill Vineyard, located just outside of Adelaide, is ever so slightly less rich and muscular than its RWT counterpart. Notes of raspberry, black cherry, dust, earth and slight meatiness are very nearly overwhelmed by powerful oak tannins at the moment, but they're fine grained and balanced by crisp acidity. Needs time in the bottle. Drink 20192037.

While sun-kissed peach perfumes the nose, just a trace of sweetness rims the palate of this taut, mineral-driven kabinett. Sweet-tart tangerine and lime flavors are spine tingling and persistent, leading a long, salt-and-lime finish.

This unique wine, labeled ros, is a lovely rose-toned copper. But is it really a ros, or just a rich, phenolic white? However you label it, call it delicious; its rose petal, bee pollen and strawberry scents and flavors are concentrated and creamy. It spent six months on the leeshalf in stainless steel and half in neutral oak.

Given nearly two years in 30% new French oak, this aged wine is thickly wrapped in blackberry bramble and solidly built tannins, with a baked quality to the fruit. Robust oak leans into full-bodied concentrated flavors of tobacco, clove and mocha.

This aromatic wine is the ripest of the winery's fine lineup of 2015 Pinots, with a sweet, soft, round and smooth entry. Its pretty strawberry and cherry fruit is swathed in mocha, proving supple and immediately appealing. The still slightly stiff tannins suggest further improvement awaits over the next five years.

Delicate whiffs of exotic spice accent luscious tangerine and peach flavors in this off-dry Riesling. While ripe and lip smackingly honeyed, it's a briskly textured wine, with cutting lemon-lime acidity. Lime zest lingers through a long, lingering finish. Drink now through 2025.

This wine smells toasty and creamy. Like all of Catena's 2013 Malbecs, it's wiry in feel, with screaming acidity. That electric feel carries into its plum and currant flavors, which have oaky, wood spice accents.Drink through 2035.

The blueberry and boysenberry aromas in this blend of Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah include tea and cardamom notes. Its jammy, pulpy palate is thick and chewy, tasting of herbal blue fruits, blueberry in particular. Minty on the finish, it deals dashes of nutmeg and cardamom for a hint of the exotic. Drink through 2024.

This is the winery's reserve-level Chardonnay, and just three barrels were produced. It offers extra concentration and a silky mix of apple and pear fruit, with a touch of minerality. The finish, which is long and balanced, is enwrapped in almond flavor.

Sonja Magdevski is exploring what Grenache can do across Santa Barbara County, and this appellation blend is a bit more simple that her single-vineyard expressions, but gives a great sense of what she is up to. Purple hibiscus, light mulberry, rooibos tea and exotic cherries show on the fresh nose, while the palate is delicate with hints of plum, black raspberry, star anise and vanilla dust.

Quite light, cloudy and blood-orange colored in the glass, this oxidative bottling from Thompson Vineyard, which spent 140 days on skins, is unlike any Grenache on the market. Aromas of plum, fig, pepper, strawberry wine and balsamic vinegar lead into a palate of sour red plum and white pepper. Fascinating for wine geeks, though perhaps too weird for most.

This is one of two wines made by Saint-Julien Chteau Beychevelle from vines in the Haut-Mdoc. It has the rich, generous fruit of this vintage, with ripe plum flavors and concentrated tannins. Perfumed acidity and a dry core will allow the wine to age further. Drink from 2020.

This 11-acre, family-owned property has produced a generous, opulent wine. A blend of 75% Merlot with Cabernet Franc, it shows the ripeness of the fruit in this vintage giving a rich, dark plum-flavored wine. Tannins lie at the core of this cushion of fruit. Still young, it needs time and will be best from 2020.

An excellent vintage of this east-facing block-sourced wine, it seems to have ripened gracefully. It's flavorful and concentrated, with raspberry and cherry fruit. There's a hint of chicken stock on both the nose and palate and firm, astringent tannins that balance out the finish.

Lightly honeyed, this citrus-flavored wine comes a vineyard southeast of Chablis. It is all fruit although strong mineral texture gives it shape as well as sustaining the lemon acidity. Drink this wine from late 2018.

Earth, smoke and slate contrast sweet, juicy bursts of white peach, raspberry and grapefruit in this spry kabinett. It's unctuously fruity yet zesty, finishing on a long, chalky mineral tone. While integrated and irresistible already, it's likely to maintain fresh appeal till at least 2025.

Dark tar and asphalt aromas are more than an accent to this wine's bold berry and coffee scents. Its plump, chunky palate is more static than lively, with baked plum and spiced cherry flavors. The finish is tannic and a touch heavy, with low acidity. Drink through 2019.

Here's a solid, polished effort from winemaker Tom Fitzpatrick. It neatly weaves together blue plum and black cherry flavors, highlighted with pipe tobacco and a hint of caramel. Its smooth tannins are framed with light composted earth notes.

This is an impressively made wine, offering a tart red currant around savory notes of fresh tobacco, clove, cedar and graphite. Robustly built up front, it shows balance through the midpalate and a firm control of its ripeness, dotted in baking spice and pepper.

Savory smoke and earth notes blow off with aeration revealing zesty green plum and herb tones. Electric shocks of acidity and a deep slate undertone accentuate its lean, lithe profile. The finish is moderately long but invigorating. Drink now through 2022.

This wine starts shy but after some time in glass reveals bramble berries, cooked meat and wild herbs. More bramble fruit bursts onto the palate morphing into big, drying tannins that are balanced by a good lick of acidity and a long, herbal and cherry-cola finish. Drink now2027.

This stand-out wine is not showy, and has nice fresh fruit flavors shaded by baking spices, a good, lightly gripping texture due to moderate tannins and supportive acidity, and a lingering finish. It's well balanced and not at all tiring to keep sipping.

A strong shade of yellow in the glass, this bottling shows aromas of whipped cream, preserved lemon peels and a hint of smoked white meat, all honed in by a citrusy sharpness. The palate proves fresh, bright and tense, making the mouth water with a hint of sea salt along with creamy cherimoya and a touch more smoke.

This creamy and smooth wine tastes of mashed apple, papaya and pear. Almost half was aged in new oak, which contributes to that silky mouthfeel and to its butterscotch-laced finish. A hint of minerality infuses the acidity. Though young, this first-time effort is delicious and ready for immediate enjoyment.

Young and showing primary fruit flavors of cranberry and raspberry, this wine isn't shy about incorporating stem and grape skin flavors. It's a style that favors longterm aging over immediate accessibility and will reward decanting and/or cellaring. Drink 20202030.

This wine is a good representation of this appellation. It is structured with tight, dry tannins as well as juicy red fruits that shine through in this vintage. Give this wine more time and drink from 2019.

Lovely cherry lollipop flavors introduce this smooth and tasty effort. Its juicy and irresistable sweet fruit is highlighted with sliced orange and lemon peel notes. A streak of coffee runs through the finish, and the wine is substantial enough to cellar for another half decade or longer.

The first-ever vineyard-designated Riesling from Love & Squalor, this is bone dry and as tart as lemon juice. Its green apple fruit shows excellent concentration. For acid lovers, this will be a revelation. If acid isn't your thing, look to the winery's regular Riesling instead.

This mineral, crisp wine offers concentrated acidity and lemon flavors. It is rounded, rich with yellow fruits and with a tight texture that will allow the wine to age. Produced from vines up to 62-years-old, it will be ready to drink from 2019.

This is a rounded wine, a blend of many different parcels from across Nuits St.-Georges. With its tannins and red berry fruits well intact, it has a dry core as well as bright acidity to balance, giving a wine that will become generous as it ages. Drink from 2021.

There is plenty of toasty oak on the nose of this reserve bottling, but it's judiciously applied and cut by lemon balm, Asian pear, hot croissant and pecan oil aromas. The sip also shows a savory oak-smoke character, but the midpalate is all about lemon cream and butter-basted apple pie, with a touches of vanilla, cinnamon and cashew riding into the finish.

Light in color, this bottling shows suave pomegranate and piquant cranberry on the nose alongside subtle potpourri, bay leaf and juniper. The palate packs in wild forest flavors of sage, thyme and more bay leaf, with a slight hint of green olive giving complexity to the tart red fruit.

A wonderful combination of spices, fruits and good structure make this an outstanding wine. It has a spicy, lightly smoky aroma that also includes black cherries, leading to deep cherry and berry flavors accented by cinnamon and clove. The texture is silky, supported by mild fine-grained tannins.

From a north-facing, late-ripening section of the estate planted to 100% Pommard clone, this brings a juicy mix of spicy berry and cherry fruit.
