There's a suggestion of chocolate malt as well, and a mineral touch in the underlying acidity. Among the winery's sensational 2015 releases, this might be the lightest.

A blend of barrels sourced from Sineann's impressive single vineyard program, this offers ripe plum and black cherry fruit in a smooth, supple package. Its polished tannins fill out the finish, adding a light hint of chocolate.
Reduced, this wine is supple and succulent in raspberry, plum and cherry-like cassis. Firm, integrated tannins give it structure to spare and a place to hang its ripeness.

Lush aromas of coffee cake, cappuccino and caramel meet with both bright red fruit and a hint of kirsch on this twist-top ready-to-drink blend of 43% Cabernet Franc, 28% Petit Verdot, 22% Cabernet Sauvignon and 7% Merlot. Juicy black plums and cherries show on the palate, which is relatively light on its feet with a firm enough structure, finishing on more cocoa, mocha and latte flavors.

This wine's resiny oak and lemon aromas require some time and air to settle. It's full and round in feel, even a bit pulpy. Salted apple and wood spice flavors last on the finish, with good acidity and a buttered popcorn note that's not overwhelming. Drink through 2020.

This wine leads with roasted cashew scents and follows with tart raspberry and cherry fruit and a light dusting of cocoa. Although aged 10 months in 20% new French oak, it emphasizes minerality and minimizes the influence of the barrels.

It seems trite to call an Oregon wine Burgundian, but in this instance it fits perfectly. Elegant from start to finish, it combines lemon and grapefruit flavors with minerally acidity, driving the palate forward with sleek, racy freshness that calls a particularly excellent Mcon to mind. Roughly one third was aged in clay amphora, the rest in neutral oak.

There's a lot to like in this wine: raspberry, cherry, baking spices, mocha, violets and milky coffee lead into a medium-bodied palate complete with raisiny fruit and satiny tannins. A warming wintery red perfect with a roast.

A broadly defined, soft round red wine made with the utmost attention and time in French oak, this estate-driven effort is impressive in strawberry, cherry and blueberry cobbler goodness, rich flavors that wrap around substantial tannins. The persistent sensibility on the nose is floral in violet and mountain sage.

Dark violet in color, this wine has aromas of black cherry and fennel bulb. A network of silky tannins supports well-integrated flavors of blackberry, plum and anise that culminate in a surprisingly bright cherry finish.

So named because Counoise takes to long to ripen that it makes winemakers' collective blood boils, this bottling from Glenrose Vineyard is a great example of a lighter red wine from Paso Robles. Red cherry, rust, crushed gravel and dried herbs show on the nose, while the palate carries oregano, marjoram and a touch of cardamom against light red cherry and cranberry flavors. It's lively and fresh.

This wine's potent grass and grapefruit scents greet you, and similar flavors follow. It would be easy to mistake this for New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, given its intensity and aroma. In the mouth, it's immaculately fresh and crisp, with steely acidity. Citrus rind flavors continue through its long finish.

Maybe it's the fir tree branch and cone on the label, but there seems to be a hint of pine needle in this wine's aroma. That scent sneaks into its rhubarb and black cherry flavors, along with a touch of root beer and beet root. Those components may sound disparate, but they blend nicely, with a pleasantly chocolaty finish. Give it a couple more years of bottle age for optimal drinking.

This rich and dense wine is maturing well. It has a solid texture, touches of dark chocolate as well as juicy blackberry flavors underlined by wood aging. The tannins need to soften further; drink from 2020.

The inaugural release of this wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (57%), Syrah (34%) and Malbec. The aromas pop with plum, cherry, herb and barrel spice notes. The palate is broad and incredibly pleasing.

Although not a premier cru, this village wine has plenty of the firm tannins and sense of structure that give Pommard its reputation. The wood aging shows through in spice and toast while the wine has plenty of black-cherry fruit and acidity to allow it to age well. Drink this wine from 2020.

This rich wine has beautifully integrated tannins and ripe fruit. With a generous character and succulent fruit over a base of firm tannins, it has excellent potential. Its tannins need to soften more for the wine to be ready to drink, so wait until 2023.

This wine comes from a single vineyard site on a south/south-east facing slope. It is rich in everything that a Saint-Vran should have: ripe fruit, balanced acidity and a generous full texture. With acidity to match, this is developing into a fine wine. Drink from late 2018.

Glimmers of dusty mineral on the nose amplify into an anchoring core of salt and stone throughout this delicately sweet kabinett. Light footed yet firmly balanced, it juxtaposes juicy white peach and grapefruit against invigorating hits of lime and salt. It's approachable already but should maintain its fresh, primary style well through 2022.

This is a reserve-tier wine that blends in Cabernet Sauvignon from both Diamond Mountain and Mount Veeder, in addition to 8% Cabernet Franc (Mount Veeder) and 3% Merlot (Diamond Mountain). Made in a tiny amount, it speaks in rich rapturous tones of chocolate-raspberry truffle wrapped in coconut, oak and soft rounded tannin.

This wine is youthfully coiled and shy, a full-bodied expansion of brawny root, tar and bark flavors. Mild in tannin and structure, it offers aromas of rose garden and lavender, with a tangerine-like lift of acidity.

There's a touch of gamy meat alongside purple flowers and candied rosemary on the nose of this blend of 60% Grenache, 23% Syrah and 17% Mourvdre. It would be the perfect wine for any weekend table, with versatile and food-friendly flavors of violet, lilac, charred beef and tart purple fruits.

Dusty mineral tones are delicate yet persistent in this invigorating off-dry Riesling. Crisp, tart green plum and apple flavors are racy and spry, accented by tingly lemon-lime acidity and a hint of spice. It's a refreshing wine to enjoy now through 2021.

A dense luxurious nose introduces plummy chocolate mocha flavors in this soft well-integrated wine from the producer's estate vineyard. High-elevation grippiness defines the serious tannin profile, suggesting further time in bottle or time to develop in the glass.

Full bodied and full flavored, this substantial wine combines intense fruit flavors with bold, buttery and spicy accents. It feels mouthfilling and rich but has enough good acidity for liveliness and balance. Fine print on the label says this is made from Albario, and it's a most unusual and enjoyable example of the Spanish varietal.

Wet clay, squeezed lemon and lightly toasted pecan show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard located just south of Highway 246. There's ripeness to the lemon-juice-driven palate as well as a rounded cashew cream character. The acidity is striking, nearly piercing by the finish.

Petit Verdot makes up the majority of this blend at 58%, joining 38% Zinfandel and 4% Cabernet Sauvignon. Powerfully ripe and rich, it offers integrated oak and tannin around a juicy core of raspberry, blueberry and blackberry, the mouthfeel luxurious and soft.

Creamy and luxurious in nature, this wine tastes of caramel apple, baked pear and pineapple. With a depth of vanilla oak, it offers body and weight, with a bright hit of freshness on the lengthy finish.

This wine is earthy in tobacco and forest tones, with a bright thread of acidity within its more robust tendencies. Graphite, sage, leather and pepper meet firm, supportive tannins and a toasted oak tone.

This wine is lean and initially austere. With dominant tannins and great concentration, it is firm but has the fruit weight to match with the extracted texture, so the wine will age well. It needs time for that structure to soften. Drink from 2025.

Not much Chardonnay is produced at this winery, which is a shame. This spicy, toasty, well-rounded effort is clean and fresh. It mixes grapefruit, green apple and white peach flavors with zippy acidity. Drink now through 2025.

This wine has density and richness. With ripe berry fruits and generous tannins, it strikes a chord between fruitiness and richness. It is structured as well, allowing room for aging. Drink this wine from 2022.

The red fruit on this Margaret River red takes a back seat to secondary characters like earth, meat, black olives, coffee and herbs. The palate is medium bodied, with well-structured tannins and more earthy, meaty, and herbal goodness. Drink now2024.

This is a highly impressive wine that's 100% varietal and blissfully well-priced. Dusty blackberry cobbler comes first to mind, held in check by robust tannin and powerful structure. A wine that will appeal to Cabernet Sauvignon fans, it balances that power with a soft side embedded in peppery clove.

This wine's compact black cherry fruit carries some stemmy hints due to the inclusion of 30% whole clusters. It has substantial grip and is hard and tight at this young stage. Give it ample breathing and/or some extra years of bottle age.

This is a structured, firm wine with a dry core of tannins, which bodes well for the future as the rich fruit comes slowly through the structure. It has weight and juicy potential. The wine comes from a walled vineyard wholly owned by the producer. Drink from 2021.

Beeswax, paraffin, petrol and orange pith show on the light but resilient nose of this dessert wine. There's an intriguing ashy and Brie cheese rind quality to the smoky sip, where the honey and peach syrup sweetness is obvious but plays more to the background. This is quite dynamic.
Buttery, rich and creamily lush, this wine is robust and in tropical and stone fruit flavor, with a side note of green olive that makes it intriguing and memorable.

This bottling is the perfect introduction to the biodynamic wines of Brick House. It has generous herbal scents and flavors, which may account for its entry-level pricing. But its pretty cherry fruit, complex aromas, cola-like touches and textured tannins all reflect the same care and substance as the rest of the portfolio.
With a breath of matchstick on entry, this wine is ultimately juicy and gritty in texture, with a persistent backbeat of toasty oak. Ripe apple and papaya mix well to offer a tropical creaminess.

This wine is tough and extracted, with dark-chocolate flavors as well as tannins. Its hard outer shell is rescued by the ripe black-currant fruits of the Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. Drink from 2025.
This wine is full of crisp fruit, perfumed wood and red-berry acidity. Perfumed Cabernet Franc gives extra complexity to the juicy Merlot to offer a balanced wine that will be ready from 2019

Aromas of cherry and baking spices pave the way for flavors of black fruit, pomegranate, anise and thyme. This inky, garnet-colored wine is soft at first sip, with tannins that intensify as fruit and spice flavors fill the mouth and continue into a spicy, dry finish.

This is a pretty yet serious Riesling from a historic Barossa winery. Melon, peach, lime, wild mint, flowers and a hint of kerosene all flow onto a light, delicate palate, with well balanced acidity and an attractive, spicy finish.

This wine's bold black fruit aromas are a touch clipped. Its saturated palate offers a massive mouthful of berry fruit and tannins and chocolate notes. On the finish, it's peppery, toasty and stout. Serve this always reliable Malbec blend with grilled beef in the Argentino style.
Baking spice and red-berry aromas follow over to the linear palate along with licorice and other oak-driven spices. Refined tannins provide polished support.

This wine is quiet on the nose, but comes to life in its fistful of brawny, thick black fruit and gritty, leathery texture. A touch of black pepper and cinnamon play off each other on the long, resolved finish.
Deftly handled, this wine sidesteps the variety's characteristic heat and bitterness. Instead, it's loaded with spicy, gin-like botanical highlights and juicy, fresh lime and citrus fruit.

Little Chardonnay grows in Nuits-Saint-Georges but Les Bousselots has both Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. This is a rich wine with a core of tannins as well as rounded, ripe yellow fruits cut with attractive spice and acidity. Drink this wine from 2020.

A well-structured wine, this is rich and smooth. Under this sheen, the wine offers a tight texture with minerality and zesty orange. These two elements make for a wine with both instant pleasure and richness and potential. Drink from late 2018.

With small amounts of Syrah and Zinfandel, this Pinot swings for the fences in spicy raspberry, cherry and cardamom, with just a touch of mint nipping at its nose. Robust oak and a ripe body give it power and weight.

This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec, Petit Verdot and Tannat is rich yet it well balanced. Its jammy berry aromas are creamy but also a touch reedy. On the palate, dark black fruit flavors show their herbal, peppery side. It finishes plush. Drink through 2021.

The second vintage of this Dundee Hills-grown cuve from winemaker Dominique Mah is sharp and spicy on entry. That sharpness yields to tart cranberry, raspberry and cherry pie flavors, with streaks of stem and herb. Native yeast fermentation seems to have contributed extra texture. Tuck this away for another year or two before drinking.

This deep red violet colored wine features aromas of plum, black cherry and violet. Velvety tannins provide a backdrop for a good mix of fruit and spice flavors that include black cherry, raspberry, vanilla and licorice. The long spicy finish wraps up with a burst of cranberry flavor.

Part of a new reserve-level series from Goodfellow, this was made from 100% Durant Vineyard fruit, half fermented using whole clusters. It shows more fruit flavor than the winery's other 2015s, offering plum and cherry notes supported by refreshing acids. Orange peel, pink grapefruit and Meyer lemon accents keep the palate lively.

Sourced primarily from calcerous soils in Rheinhessen's Spiegelberg vineyards, this dry Riesling offers surprising elegance for such a reasonably priced wine. There's a mineral richness to the palate that lends an expansive feel to plump white peach and tangerine flavors. The finish wraps up with precision. Drink now through 2020.

Apples, wet stone and a little honey lead into a refreshing palate, with plenty of acidity and a hint of richness to tip the scales into balance. A pleasing apple finish makes you want to keep going back for more.

Still in its infancy, Howard Park's blend of Cab from Mt. Barker in the cool climes of the Great Southern and the slightly warmer Margaret River region, has a generous nose of dark cherry, mocha, pencil lead, mint and oak spice. There's plush fruit and herbs on the palate but it's still very tightly wound and the oaky tannins are big and drying. Give this a few years to even begin to show its true colors. Drink 20202032.
This wine is fermented in stainless steel and French oak. It's a big, brawny red, with plenty of black fruit, tobacco and leathery tannin around an intensely powerful core.

This bright and spicy wine tones down the grape's propensity toward grassiness, showing instead peppery white melon fruit and a phenolic bite. Production has increased in recent years, making this rare Oregon example of this classic Loire Valley grape more widely available.

Dusty tannins are at the center of this boldly ripe, brawny wine, which offers soft plush texture and a depth of rich plum. Dark chocolate waves are complemented by a savory twist of cigar box and pepper.

This wine's well-ripened yellow and green fruit flavors come with fruit skin and herb notes. It's a sleek, stylish and medium bodied, showing a light touch of toast from aging in a mix of new and one-year-old French oak.

This single vineyard wine is complex and ageworthy, with a fair bit of wet stone, copper penny, and salty minerality along with lemon, melon and some toasty oak characters. The acidity dominates on the palate at the momentthe oak is apparent toobut this wine is really just starting its life. Drink 20182027.

Leeuwin's Prelude combines some of the region's characteristic Cabernet traits: currants and graphite, with floral and savory notes and a tangy, elegant mouthfeel. The tannins are silky smooth and the finish is long and fruity. Drink now2025.

This is a ripe wine with good structure as well as generous fruit. It has acidity, tannins and a smoky aftertaste while emphasizing the rounded red fruits that will make it delicious in a few years. It comes from vines on the flat lands stretching out into the Sane Valley. Drink from 2019.

A nose of plum, raspberry and toast sets the stage for flavors of strawberry, raspberry, vanilla and tomato leaf. This wine is full in the mouth, with slightly chalky tannins that are offset by an overall sense of softness and a refreshing finish.

Red fruit aromas are at the fore in this wine, with pleasing raspberry and Red Vines notes, along with spice accents. The palate shows remarkable restraint, refinement and balance considering the warmth of the vintage, and its firm tannic core should allow it to evolve nicely for a few years in the cellar.
This wine's soil, black cherry, herb and spice aromas are followed by elegantly styled fruit flavors that show pretty balance. Despite the warmth of the vintage, this one is all about elegance.

This is an extracted, lightly woven together wine that's ethereal in style. Candied orange peel and strawberry-rhubarb mingle softly on the palate, as seasonings of Asian five spice and cola wander by.
Dry, tangy and appetizing, this wine has lightly floral, appley aromas and flavors, great acidity to cleanse the palate and a sense of brightness and clarity that's refreshing to taste.

Whiffs of dusty mineral, orange peel and honey intensify on the palate of this delightfully silky wine. It's dry in style but flavors of tangerine and peach seem glazed with caramel and crystallized honey. Zesty acidity balances out the finish neatly.

This is an attractive Pinot, bright in cherry and strawberry fruit, with vanilla and a hint of orange tang on the nose. The flavors are more in the dried red fruit and leaves spectrum but there's lightness and bounce to keep things ever so gulpable.

Clean and slightly restrained on the fresh and vibrant nose, this single vineyard expression shows lime syrup, citrus zest, wet stone and chalk aromas. There is great lime skin tension to the sip, where bright, lemony flavors meet with hints of guava and crushed slate.

This wine's ripe blackberry and cassis aromas come with mild game and toast notes that lend a wild edge. Its grapey, saturated palate is a touch choppy and acidic, but the depth of fruit more than compensates. With its meaty, toasty black fruit flavors, it seems to grow even darker as it finishes.

Thyme-laced pomegranate juice aromas, enhanced with baked earth, white pepper and tarragon, makes for an intriguing entry to this bottling. The texture is light and delicate, combining dried garden herbs and buoyant red-fruit flavors, and finishing on clove. This is an easy afternoon sipper.

This fruit-forward wine offers pretty blue fruit flavors, such as blueberry and plum, along with a touch of blackberry. Aged for 17 months in French oak, it finishes with mocha and sweet spice highlights and astringent tannins.

Creamy and textured, this lively wine shows a tasty mix of lime, peach and tropical fruit highlights, along with a light touch of vanilla. It was aged on the lees for seven months in 17% new French oak.
Well-balanced, this coastal wine is deftly integrated in acidity and floral aromas of apple blossom. Its exotic flavor profile leans into quince, fig and classic Gravenstein apple.

By Barossa standards, this Shiraz is on the elegant, lighter side. There's juicy cherry, blue fruit, beef jerky, BBQ smoke and a hint of herbal oak spice on the nose. The first sip bursts in your mouth like a firecracker, with more juicy fruit and a silky, plush texture. Fine tannins are smokey and savory. Drink now2025.

This wine's blackened berry aromas are rooty and smoky. Despite drying tannins and overall roughness, it's a lush Cabernet with deep black cherry, dark plum and blackberry flavors. On the finish, it emphasizes even darker toast and coffee flavors. Drink through 2020.

This is a smoky, spicy and robust red, full of oaky brawn and ripe bluster. Cedar, graphite and wild sage play into bold notes of black cherry, blackberry and cassis, as wisps of tobacco and chocolate wander by.

Fresh and creamy, this palate-cleansing wine offers a well-integrated mix of lightly spiced pear and citrus rind flavors. Green herb, wet rock and sea salt details come into play, adding further length and interest.

Crisp lemon, tangerine and green apple are zippy and thirst quenching in this dry Pinot Blanc. It's an intently mineral wine, boasting deep veins of crushed stone and mineral. The finish is brisk but pristine. Drink now through 2021.

From vines planted around 1893 on a high bench on the south-eastern edge of the appellation, this 100% varietal wine shows plenty of power and concentration, teasing bold cherry, cinnamon and pepper out of its substantial core.

From the eastern edges of the Napa Valley, this is a bright and effusive wine, balanced in red fruit. Small percentages of Petite Sirah, Petit Verdot and Grenache Blanc are included. It was barrel-aged for 18 months in French oak, 25% of it new. The wood is integrated and the texture softly layered.

All the secondary characters that come into play as a wine matures are really working for this Merlot. The fruit is heading into raisin territory; there're earthy, vineyard floor and horse saddle notes. The palate is silky and savory, although the oak is still a little obvious. Drink now with autumnal cuisine.

A heavy application of charred oak might be too much for some, but if that's to your liking then you should enjoy this Garnacha's smoky, spicy nose. A stout, full-bodied palate is full of resiny oak with a balance of acid. Saturated, woody flavors of roasted berry fruits finish toasty and resiny. Drink through 2020.
This is an exotic, elegant and restrained coastal wine, that is tart with lemon and lemongrass. Light and bright, its texture is fluffy and creamy, with a lingering hint of biscotti.

This aromatic, elegant 2015 is better balanced than its predecessor, while adhering to a similar style. Cherry blossom and rose petal aromas mark the nose, and lean, tart red fruit defines the palate. Short aging in 30% new French oak has brought in a light dusting of cocoa. Drink 20182025.

There's a rather extreme minerality in play on this old-vine bottling, with wet gravel, scree and crushed slate leading the nose alongside crushed carnations, rose petals and touch of dark-plum fruit. Muddy chalky clay tones carry that vibe into the sip, only allowing a slight berry flavor to rise above.

Earthy whiffs of crushed mineral and toast belie the fruity core of tangerine and grapefruit that await on the palate of this wine. While dry in style, this is fresh and forward from the bright acidity. Touches of spice and herb linger on the finish. Drink now through 2021.

Grainy oak aromas dominate a nose with black-fruit, spice, balsam wood and barrel notes. This crianza is intense, with strong tannins and blazing acidity. Toasted, blackened berry flavors are under control on a bold finish. Drink through 2022.

Red-fruit-driven, this is a light, elegant version of the variety, unexpected in tight tannin and with a grainy dry carpet of texture. Cranberry and currant dominate and maintain a fresh tangy quality to the taste.
Aromas of black cherry, raspberry and violet lead you into flavors of fresh cherry juice and black plum. This Hungarian red blend has grippy tannins and a pleasant tart-cherry finish.

This exceptional vintage of Plowbuster is solidly built and packed with blackberry and cherry fruit. It has a sea salt chocolate component also, which adds both texture and flavor. This is not a keeper, but with its quality to price ratio, it's certainly a drinker.

Drilling aromas of graphite and balsamic dark fruits open this intense, pulling blend of 50% Carignan, 25% Garnacha and 15% Merlot. Roaring berry, chocolate and pepper flavors get brushed aside by the tannic roughness of the finish. Give this plenty of air before pouring; drink through 2024.

This wine is named after former Canoe Ridge Estate vineyard manager Mimi Nye. Its high toned, pretty pear, yellow apple and barrel spice aromas lead to crisp, focused, well-balanced fruit flavors that linger on the finish. It's a spot on example of this variety and style.

One of the top wines from one of Margaret River's leading producers, Cullen's 2014 Kevin John is certainly opulent, but the full malolactic fermentation and eight months in new oak seem to be masking the beautiful, biodynamically farmed fruit. Notes of butterscotch, pineapple and melon rind lead into a rich, toasty, nutty palate, with balanced acidity to keep things fresh. Drink now2024.

Don't let the label mislead you; this is a well-made, well-ripened wine that deserves a classier package. Its mix of sweet blueberry and black cherry fruit is set against polished tannins. Those flavors carry seamlessly through a smooth, lightly toasty finish.

This single-vineyard wine shows considerable potential. It offers a touch of spice as well as open, ripe and full yellow fruits. With just the right amount of acidity and a tangy orange and lemon zest texture, it is maturing well. Drink from 2019.

This is a blend of two well-regarded vineyards, Lucky Well and Silver Eagle, both farmed by Ulises Valdez. It casts a considerable shadow of brawn and beauty, balancing strawberry-puree flavors with an earthy undertone of forest pine. Big-boned, it alternates between richness and freshness.

Orange blossom and raspberry notes shine against zesty lemon-lime acidity in this light-footed kabinett. It's lip smackingly honeyed yet not at all cloying. The finish is pristine and mineral. Drink now through 2021.

Wisps of licorice, bramble and smoke mingle into ripe black cherry throughout this juicy, fruity Pinot Noir. Fleshy and full on the palate, it's approachable and primary, but fresh in acidity and nuanced by a touch of bitter herb on the finish. Drink now2020.

Tart, sappy raspberry fruit defines this focused, young-tasting wine that's structured for medium term aging. There's a touch of truffle in its phenolic notes of stem and herb. Well-modulated, it lingers through a graceful, balanced finish.

Textured in baked apple and pear flavors, this wine is ultimately creamy and lush, with a rounded approach to oak. A tautness in structure helps keep it fresh, with a lovely floral undertone on the bouquet.
Buoyant red cherry and raspberry flavors burst from the glass of this vibrant, crisply structured ros. It's forward and juicy but elegant and spry, finishing with a kiss of blossoms. Drink now.

Juicy pink grapefruit, honeydew and blossoms shine brightly in this perky, off-dry Riesling. It's vibrantly fruity but anchored by lines of fresh green herb and lime acidity. The finish is crisp and clean.

Dark in color and consisting of considerable oak, this wine is sublime in texture, with aromas of matchstick and floral apple blossom. Savory in apple pie and cinnamon, it has elegance and impressive length.

Still a baby and therefore rather shy in the glass, a few good swirls eek out aromas of cherry cola, sweet spice and dusty oak. The tannins are big but integrated, with vibrant acidity and herbal, medicinal flavors. This is a rich, powerful style, but give it time and watch it shine. Drink 20192032.

This wine strikes a great balance between freshness and concentration. It smells clean and minerally, tastes crisp at first like lemon and jicama but also concentrated and layered in notes of rich pear and fig.

A blend of fruit from both the Saar and the middle Mosel (vineyards surrounding Piesport and Bernkastel) this lovely value Riseling darts and dances on the palate with Margarita-like kicks of salt and lime. Just a shade off dry, its delicate sweetness lends balance to zesty acidity and a cool, mineral finish. This cuve is also labeled under the Gryphon Crest brand.

There's a barnyard funk to this that some will love and some might squirm at, but there's also plenty of ripe strawberry fruit, chocolate, earth and smoke. The palate shows plenty of drying, savory tannins balanced by fresh acidity. Everything wraps up with an earthy, savory finish. Drink now.

Give this Great Southern Cab some time in glass or decanter to open up, but once it does it reveals notes of cherry cola, cranberry, florals, black pepper and an earthy core. The palate is rich and riding a line between full and medium bodied. It's currently tightly wound, with savory oak tannins that should mellow out with time. Drink now2027.

Swarthy aromas of cooked black cherry, root beer, vanilla, cinnamon, clove and shaved eucalyptus show on the nose of this bottling. The flavors are very minty with sweet bay leaf, juniper and more eucalyptus, proving quite a mouthful.

Smooth and delicious, this opens with inviting scents of red berry, chopped Mediterranean herb and dark culinary spice. It's bright and focused, offering Marasca cherry, strawberry, star anise and white-pepper flavors. Firm, polished tannins and fresh acidity provide effortless support. Drink through 2025.

This is a rich unctuous blend of 38% Syrah, 31% Cabernet Franc and 31% Merlot, with aromas of baked plums in a buttery crust and hints of scarlet roses. The flavors are presented elegantly with a soft mouthfeel that shows violets, blueberry, oregano and pepper, with a long-lasting acidic backbone.

This is a firm, juicy wine, full of dark tannins. Acidity and black-cherry fruits are also part of the mix although they are still in the background. It's a wine with potential, with the freshness of the year and the weight of the appellation. Drink from 2025.

Quite rich in texture and generous in flavor, this medium-bodied wine has notes of black cherry, toasted baguette and pomegranate. These flavors mingle with the broad mouthfeel, offering depth and layering that leads to a lingering finish.

There's bountiful red cherry on the fruit-driven nose of this bottling, alongside loamy soil, dried sage and mint. The flavors are fresh and bright, with red fruit and lifting herb tones that are completely integrated so that no component stands out above the others. The tannic structure arises on the finish.

Brawny red fruit savory in pomegranate and cranberry highlight an earthy core of light-bodied ripeness and quiet richness in this clone-specific wine. The texture is crisp and velvety on the palate. The vineyards involved include Bucher, Peters and Leras.

This wine offers a significance of herbal undertones and wild exotic brush, a nod to its mountain growing location and this particular appellation. Pencil shavings, flowers and leathery texture bookend strong firm tannins and smoky oak, the core braced in black currant and cassis.

Aromas of red berry, grilled herb, balsamic notes, sea breeze and a whiff of wet flint lead the nose. The elegantly structured palate delivers crushed raspberry, strawberry, star anise and a saline mineral note alongside refined tannins.

There's a strong amount of newer wood aroma to these early releases from this new project. This bottling shows ample charred oak as well as roasted cherries, damp earth and crushed slate on the nose. Dark berries reaveal themselves on the sip alongside oak smoke.

Though unabashedly earthy, this is packed with red plum, cherry, citrus rind and cut tobacco components. Such complexity is rare in a budget-priced Oregon Pinot. It glides gracefully into a mineral-drenched finish.

Portlandia made a pair of ross in 2016, this one entirely from Shepherd's Valley Vineyard Pinot Noir. It's tight and focused, with lovely citrus blossom and rose petal scents. Flavors follow, adding strawberry, watermelon and minerally acids to the mix. They persist through a long, fresh finish.

Pristine and pert, this zippy dry-style Pinot Blanc offers loads of thirst quenching refreshment. Tart tangerine and lemon flavors are fresh and juicy on the palate. The finish is brisk but nuanced by hints of earth and blossom. Drink now through 2019.

Invigorating lemon and sage aromas contrast plump pink grapefruit and guava on the palate of this delicately sweet Riesling. It's a rounded yet elegant wine, with soft, sunny acidity and a crystalline mineral finish. Drink now through 2019.

This deep purple-hued wine is fragrant with crushed blackberry notes. The fruit is outstanding, and the tannins are ripe and smooth. Drink now for its exuberant youth or cellar for a few years and drink closer to maturity.

Dusty and peppery, this big-boned wine leans into tart red-fruit flavors like cranberry and strawberry, with a thickness of tannin at its core. Leather, coffee and cinnamon swirl around adding seasoning to its overall length and breadth on the palate.

This wine takes some vigorous swirling to open up, eventually offering notes of dark and red berries, tang, earth, and a herbal component. The palate is raisiny and chocolatey, with plush fruit and a juicy tang amidst a medium to full body and plenty of crisp acidity to indicate a long life ahead. Drink 20192037.
Waxy white blossom, grapefruit and lime are delicate in concentration but juicy and fresh in this off-dry Riesling. Light-bodied and thirst quenching, it's a sweet-tart sip that's ready to drink now.

Veteran winemaker Rich Cushman made this wine, and his extensive knowledge of Columbia Gorge vineyards and styles shows through. It's fresh and juicy, with crisp apple and tangy gooseberry fruit, ample acidity and a pleasingly crunchy mouthfeel. It rolls on through a clean and bracing finish.

There're a few years of age on this wine but it's still very much in its infancy. The nose is a heady mix of cherry cola, ripe blackberry, black olive, balsamic reduction and graphite, while the palate is plush and full bodied but well balanced, with savory, oaky tannins. Drink now2027.

This is a juicy exploration of the coasta well-made effort that showcases notes of forest floor, black tea and savory pine. The black cherry and currant fruit leans dark and brooding, with an impressively balanced, medium-bodied hold on the palate.

Roasted berry aromas include a leafy note and a hint of grilled meat. This is a muscled-up blend of Tempranillo, Graciano and Mazuelo, and the secondary players add punch. Raw berry flavors are helped by a dash of brown sugar, while this feels plush and bullish on the finish. Drink through 2028.

Hannah is a block selection from the upper portion of the Tualatin estate vineyard. Rich and rounded, it shows preserved strawberry, cherry compote and chocolate flavors. A full degree higher in alcohol than the 2014, it's just on the edge of showing some heat. But with its big, forward fruit, it's spot on for immediate enjoyment.

This cuve underwent 100% whole cluster fermentation using natural yeast and spent 16 months in French oak, just 10% new. It's compact and a bit subdued, as though the flavors are in hiding. Tart raspberry fruit shows through, with a suggestion of wet cement. Give it ample aeration or tuck it away for a couple more years.

Made with native grape Durella and re-fermented in the bottle, this slightly sparkling, savory wine opens with yeasty aromas of bread dough, orchard fruit, citrus and a whiff of crushed stone. Bright and savory, the linear, fizzy palate doles out ripe yellow apple, bread crust and tangerine zest alongside tangy acidity. A bitter almond note softens the bone-dry finish. It's incredibly fun and refreshing.

This earthy Malbec offers savory, roasted berry aromas, with a hint of horse hide. Its tight, compact palate feels clipped, with salty plum and currant flavors. The finish is tight, oaky and a bit condensed.

Full bodied and rich with red fruits and crisp acidity, this wine, made from 100% Pinot Noir, shows a ripe character and a firm texture. Its bright fruit and tight texture suggest a few more months aging would do it no harm. So, although it is ready drink to now, drink from 2018.

This is the lightest of the winery's single vineyard cuves. Its strawberry and pale cherry fruit has hints of barrel toast and pepper, and there's a cleansing minerality to the mouthfeel. It thins out a bit on the finish and should be consumed now through 2022.

This is a complex and delicious drop from the cool climes of the Adelaide Hills, offering up notes of pineapple, ground ginger, grapefruit and lime blossoms. The mouthfeel is lovely and long, with a slippery texture, balanced acidity and a zingy, white-pepper finish.

From a small appellation next to Pouilly-Fuiss, this is a ripe, full wine. It is all white stone fruit, pears and green plums, given structure by the zesty, mineral texture. It is a rich single-vineyard wine from vines up to 70 years old. Drink from late 2018.

A numeric score on this wine is almost silly, as it's about as bizarre as wine gets. A shade of yellowish orange in the glass, this bottling shows aromas of vermouth, wood varnish, cherry and, yes, blood orange on the nose. The palate combines iron, sour peach, walnut oil and pine much like a Sherry. Fascinating, though not for the mainstream.

Under the same ownership as Chteau Rauzan-Gassies in Margaux, this estate is in the north of Haut-Mdoc region. It is dense with solid tannins and black fruit. A touch of black coffee hints at toasty wood as well as some extraction that needs to soften. The wine has potential; drink from 2021.

Old vines give concentration to this wine, although its main character is of rich red fruits. The tannins are in the background while right up front are fruit, acidity and an attractive touch of spice. This smooth, rounded wine will be ready to drink quickly, certainly from late 2018.

Aged for 12 months in wood, 30% new, this rich, full wine is packed with black fruits, spice and tight tannins. A strong juicy character comes from the acidity and the blackberry fruitiness. From one of the 17 acres of premier cru owned by this producer, the wine will be ready to drink from 2021.

Bringing out great warmth and soft richness, this is an open wine. A touch of wood aging gives a toasty edge, balancing the ripe apricot, creamed apple and spice flavors. Drink this rich wine from 2018.

Zesty green apple and crisp stone fruits are electrified by spine tingling acidity in this invigorating sekt. It's fresh and primary in style, with just a hint of cookie crumbs that linger on the midpalate. Tiny, vigorous bubbles dissipate elegantly on the finish.

Zesty whiffs of cut grass and greengage plum contrast sunnier notes of apricot, berry and tangerine on the palate of this luminous kabinett. Delicately honeyed and silken in texture, it's a light-footed delight that meanders sweetly on the finish.

Traces of chalky mineral and zippy lime acidity highlight sweet pink grapefruit and honeydew in this fruity, fresh wine. It's delicate in texture but vibrant and punchy, finishing long on a tart tangerine note. Drink now through 2021.

Loads of lemon and lime acidity offset juicy red berry and pink grapefruit in this easy quaffing kabinett. Balanced sweetness and fresh floral notes linger on the finish. It's an approachable yet elegant wine that's ready now but should hold tight through 2023.

Subtle yet complex characters of lemon, stone fruit, flint, and wet stone minerality are woven into a creamy textured palate. Bright acidity keeps everything in balance, with a savory, toasty note on the finish. Drink now2022.

Made with 80% Corvina and 20% Rondinella, this opens with aromas of red-skinned berry, spring blossom and tangerine zest. The juicy, vibrant palate doles out raspberry, red cherry and nutmeg alongside fresh acidity and round tannins. Enjoy soon to catch the fruit richness.

A mix of clones is at work here, giving a dark, smoky wine with brambly berry fruit. Its tobacco, burnt toast, stem and slate scents and flavors are textured and detailed. It's a solid Oregon Pinot that can stand up to blackened salmon, roast pork or lamb.

Fruit for this wine comes from the oldest vines in this appellation, planted in 1975. The aromas are reserved, recalling baking and barrel spices, along with herbal and medicinal notes. The black fruit flavors are deep and rich, seeming ever so slightly dried out. Tightly wound tannins provide support. Give it a couple years in bottle.
Leather, cedar and juicy blackberry fruit combine with force in this expansive, concentrated wine. Chocolate toffee layers provide additional richness and complexity, as the finish ends smooth.

The Pinot Noirs from this new project from Evening Land founders Larry Stone and Dominique Lafon are intellectually challenging and palate-stretching in their austerity. Evoking rhubarb and citrus on the nose, this wine emphasizes citrus on the palate, particularly grapefruit, along with refreshing minerality. Like all the winery's Pinots, it rewards extended aeration and your full attention.

More mineral than fruit, this dry white is a fantastic value, expressing Riesling's most crystalline character. Tangerine and green apple flavors are crisp and concentrated, showered in streams of lime acidity and cool mineral sensations. Drink now through 2020.

In a rich vintage like 2015, Puligny-Montrachet gives a wonderful broad, elegant and ripe expression of Chardonnay. In this wine, the balance is just right, both crisp and rounded with great citrus and white fruits. Drink from late 2018.

This concentrated and richly structured wine has good acidity as well as firm, solid tannins that support the red currant and red cherry fruits. It also has a dry core that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2022.

Baked black plum and cassis aromas are dark and rich on the nose. The palate is bold in baked blackberry and plum flavors, with a chocolate and toast note that lingers through the finish. Drink through 2025.

Dark purple in color, this has brooding vanilla, barrel spice, flower and purple fruit aromas. The flavors are light, tart and focused, with tightly coiled tannins providing support. The acid shines through, calling for food to show at its best.

Merlot makes up just over half this wine, with the balance in Cabernet Franc (34%) and Cabernet Sauvignon (15%). The aromas are high toned out of the gate, leading with cigar box, cedar and herb notes. They're followed by plum and piercingly pure cherry scents that becomes more prominent over time. The palate has elegantly styled fruit flavors surrounded by tightly coiled tannins. It needs a couple years in bottle to come into its own but is a very pretty wine.

Well structured and full of ripe fruit, this is already a very drinkable wine. But there is more to come and this wine will show great swathes of fruit, balanced tannins and acidity, and a rich character as it matures. To enjoy it at its peak, drink from 2020.

A textbook Valpolicella, this opens with aromas of strawberry, red currant and a whiff of chopped aromatic herb while the bright palate doles out red-skinned berry, cinnamon and white pepper. Fresh acidity and velvety tannins provide the polished framework. Enjoy through 2020.

Well defined and medium bodied, this offers strawberry lollipop and cherry fruit flavors. Pretty upon first taste, it gains substance as it breathes and will reward decanting and some additional cellaring. Drink now through 2022.

This is a juicy, full-figured white, with a core of minerality that persists effortlessly on the palate. Wet stone, anise and green apple combine for maximum flavor within tones of well-integrated oak.

This Petit Verdot carries aromas of dark berries and baking spices. The saturated, chewy palate offers equal parts thickness, acidity and tannins. Spicy blackberry, cassis and chocolate flavors finish solid. Drink through 2019.

Sourced from a number of non-estate vineyards, this is sleek and precise, marrying toasty oak to crisp tree fruit flavors. The ample acids add a touch of grapefruit and the 16 months aging in 20% new French oak rounds out the fruit perfectly.

Made with organic grapes, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, porcini mushroom and a hint of nutmeg. The juicy, mouthwatering palate delivers fleshy black cherry, licorice and white pepper alongside velvety tannins. Enjoy through 2020.

Though pushing 14% alcohol, this retains lovely aromas reminiscent of flowers, fruit and barrels. Its cherry candy flavors, lightly dusted with dried herb notes, set it down a delicious path. It's perfectly balanced and has the clarity and acidity to age another half decade or longer.

On first taste, this wine shows mouth-puckering acidity. But after some time in glass it chills out and the flinty, toasty, mineral notes start to creep in. Flavors of white pepper, bruised apple and wet stone meld with a bit of textural weight to slightly balance all that acidity. Still very youthful, this wine is clearly in it for the long haul. Drink 20192027.

Butterscotch candies, lime spritz, concentrated honeysuckle and strong praline aromas show on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate combines salted butter, orange rind and white peach, with hints of white pepper, chamomile and smoke.

Gorgeously peachy from nose to finish, this vibrant, fruity Pinot Gris offers wide appeal along with a gentle price tag. Dry on the palate and refreshingly zesty, it's an elegantly balanced sip. A touch of stony minerality lends complexity to the finish. Drink now through 2019.
Brushy in forest floor, this is a soft, velvety and bright red wine, with well-integrated oak that never takes over. A taste of cherry, blueberry and graham cracker combine nicely.
Aromas of fresh-cut grass, wet stone and apple are mild on the nose. A round palate with zesty acidity is in full health, while flavors of apple, melon and pineapple last on the finish. Drink now.

This wine needs a bit of swirling in the glass to open up, but when it does it carries aromas of apple blossoms, wild strawberry and melon, with some stoney minerality and a lovely prickly texture. It's light and refreshing, with a long, mouthwatering finish.

This tightly-focused, stylish wine offers raspberry and pomegranate fruit as it opens. The acids are generous and natural tasting, with a fresh snap that brings orange juice to mind. Thirty percent whole clusters were used.

Orange blossoms and lime pith perfume this full-bodied Pinot Blanc. Juicy grapefruit and lemon flavors are plush on the palate, but there's also a deep mineral core. The finish is pristine and pure. Drink now through 2019.

Blended from several appellations across the county and adding in 14% Petite Sirah, 6% Carignane and 3% other black grapes, this wine succeeds in combining brambly black fruit ripeness with black pepper spiciness, expanding across the palate with grace and power.

From the historic site on the eastern edges of the valley, this wine is juicy, soft and layered in cranberry, cherry and vanilla. Expansive and robustly concentrated, it benefits from the addition of 19% Petite Sirah and 5% Carignane, seasoned in cinnamon and black pepper.

Among the few wineries to make a varietal wine of this grape, better known for blending, this is a smoky robust effort that's velvety and luxurious in texture. Full bodied and confident in oak, its flavors lean into strawberry, mint and bay leaf.

Big oak and a touch of reduction show through on the nose of this appellation wine, as full-figured flavors of crme brle, pineapple and Gravenstein applesauce play along a gravelly texture. Highlights of nutmeg and ginger spice the fruit well.

Supple, buttery and forward, this is full of lovely caramel-dipped apple flavors. Around that tasty core are hints of crisp herbs and citrus fruits. It's well-built, well-balanced and fine for immediate consumption. It was barrel fermented in 100% French oak, one eighth new.
Tart and spicy, this sports vivid acidity and spicy pear fruit. It's supple and almost electric, with abundant green berry, lemon and grapefruit flavors. Enjoy this while it's fresh and racy.

From a vineyard that is on the slope right above the river Garonne, this wine has a good mix of richness and black-currant crispness. Its structure is generous, with fully integrated tannins. Ripe and warm while also having balancing acidity, it will be ready to drink from late 2018.

Very light in color in the glass, this bottling shows fragrant touches of clean tropicality, including creamy cherimoya, light tuberose, refreshing apple blossoms and sliced Gala apples on the nose. There's a bountiful sizzle of acidity to the sip, where crisp pear and apple flavors meet with honeysuckle and Key lime spray.

Made with dried Malvasia and a touch of Corinto Nero, this dessert wine opens with aromas of dried apricot, crushed almond and jasmine. The savory, structured palate offers chestnut honey, dried fig and a hint of Mediterranean brush.

Gorgeous ripe fruit flavors blend with baking spices in this high-toned but full-bodied and opulent wine. Nuances of peach, honeydew melon, honey and flowers are carried by a mouthfilling, nicely viscous texture.

An approachable, accessible and high quality wine, this offers flavors of crme brle seasoned in anise. It is a rich round expression of the variety that has an additional depth of baked apple and toasted oak.

This solid wine is classic Nuits-St.-Georges, with the addition of sumptuous fruit, making it a ripe wine with a core of dark tannins. The vineyard, just south of the city, sits on a steep slope with great exposure. Drink the wine from 2023.

Earthy clay and crushed slate permeate throughout this dry, crisply structured Riesling. It's medium bodied and crunchy in texture but plumped by tones of nectarine and tangerine on the midpalate. A hint of pleasant bitters lingers on the finish. Drink now through 2021.

This offers oak and mocha aromas, recalling char, leather, blackberry and green herbs. It's a five-grape blend that includes 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, and in a cold year like 2014, that translates to angular acidity and heavily herbal plum and berry flavors. Decanting or long airing can only help this rugged amalgam. Drink through 2025.

This wine shows ripe red raspberry and currant fruit, with an orange tang, a hint of florals and herbal oak. The body lies somewhere between medium and full, while the ripe, almost sweet fruit reminds you that you're still in big Barossa territory. Drink 20192027.

This is a fascinating wine in a non-fruity fashion that smells like almonds and golden olive oil, tastes figgy and feels mouthfilling. From a veteran, consistent producer, the wine is medium to full-bodied and has a smooth and rich texture.
Deep hay in color, this wine is full bodied and creamy, with well-integrated layers of pineapple, papaya and green olive. Toasted oak supports the fruitiness and floral aromas.

Made with 100% Nerello Mascalese, this lively, polished sparkler opens with heady aromas of apple, citrus and toasted bread crust. The aromas follow over to the crisp palate along with a hint of almond set against zesty acidity and firm, continuous bubbles.

This tastes of savory bitterroot, cedar and pencil. The wild exotic flavors are met by fruity black cherry and black licorice. Generous in tannin, the wine is soft and layered a charming block-designate that shows complexity and length.

There's plenty of complexity in this bargain wine. The nose leads with ripe blueberries, florals, mocha, wet earth, dates and sumac. It's plush and juicy on the palate, with silky tannins, a medium body and a long, tangy finish. Drink now.

Cheeky labeling aside, this vivaciously zesty dry Riesling is an easy candidate for an everyday quaffer. Delicate peach and yellow plum contrast bold strikes of lemon and lime on the palate. The finish is long and refreshingly crisp. Drink now through 2019.

Crisp and fresh on the nose, this bottling offers lime skin, lemon juice, crushed flint and graphite aromas. It's tightly wound and zippy on the palate, but with ample flavors of Asian pear flesh, grippy chalk and a Key lime twist.

Intense black plum and cherry perfume juxtapose savory tones of smoked nuts and wet earth in this fresh and fruity yet composed wine. Plump black fruit flavors are broad and rich but framed by brisk acidity and a trace of mineral complexity. A fantastic introduction to German Pinot that's surprisingly easy on the wallet.

Dark garnet in color, this wine offers aromas of black cherry, vanilla and violet. It is smooth on the palate, with soft tannins and flavors of blackberry, cherry, vanilla, juniper, lilac and anise. The spicy finish is marked with a touch of tartness.

At first, this high-altitude Chardonnay comes across as massively oaked, as if extracted from a wood pile. With time, it sheds its heavy oak blanket and shows secondary notes of spiced apple and melon. It's dominated by wood throughout, and if that's not your thing, this might not be for you. Full and generous, yet balanced; drink through 2020.
Bramble fruit, charred meat, earth and dusty oak lead into a medium-bodied palate that's got plenty of chewy, drying tannins but also a good deal of acidity to back things up.

The fruit flavors in this young wine are fresh and forward, suggesting raspberry and cherry over a mineral base. The nicely textured palate carries wet stone flavors along with the fruit, and a streak of cola adorns the finish.

This is a chewy, nutty, punchy wine with a solid core of apple and melon fruit. Its acidity lends a generous citrus tang, and the flavors smooth out nicely through the finish, with a burst of caramel.
This lovely rosato has alluring aromas of red cherry, ripe raspberry and cake spice that follow over to the savory palate. Bright acidity provides balance while a hint of mineral adds depth.

This big bold wine is highlighted in raspberry, vanilla and smoky oak. Its texture is velvety smooth and rounded, while the flavors boast black licorice, black juicy fruit and a foundation of graham cracker crust.

Aromas on this wine suggest underbrush, dried Mediterranean brush and exotic spice, with balsamic notes. The rounded, full-bodied palate shows cherry, strawberry compote, star anise and the warmth of alcohol alongside fine-grained tannins.

This will take a few years to start to show its potential. At the moment, it's shy. This shows cherry, blackberry, vanilla, cocoa powder, cedar and floral tones. It's tightly wound on the palate, with dusty tannins and balanced acidity. Drink 20202037.

From Elk Cove's sister label, this incorporates a fair amount of estate fruit, and it's very well made for its everyday price. Deliciously fruity and vibrant, it's packed with apple, pear, nectarine and snappy grapefruit flavors. Drink over the next year or two, while it's at its freshest.

Aromas of white rose, citrus and yellow stone fruit are front and center on this dry, vibrant white. The tangy palate doles out apricot, grapefruit and a saline note alongside crisp acidity that gives it a quenching close.
Deep tawny gold in color, this full-bodied, fruit-powered beauty bursts with ripe peach and papaya flavors. Blended with 4% Pinot Blanc, it's fresh and delicious now, so don't wait.

Racy acidity sends jolts of electricity through delicate white blossom, lemon and lime in this refreshing dry Riesling. While moderate in fruit concentration, it's sheer, cutting mouthfeel is invigorating. Drink now through 2019.

Made a Demeter-certified blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, this wine offers a tight-grained tannic structure, with notes of dusty clove, cassis and violet. A rocky mineral quality lurks beneath the full-bodied richness.
This tasty wine is full bodied and powered by fruit. Varietal purity is on display, as it offers rich apple, pear, peach and apricot flavors. A lovely hint of lemon oil accents both scent and flavor.

Candied lemon peel, walnut, cashew and balsam aromas show on the rich nose of this bottling from a vineyard just east of the Pacific Ocean behind Cambria. The palate is viscous with flavors of lemon syrup and orange rind.

This proprietary and undisclosed blend is tart, astringent and aromatic. Notes of raspberry jam, squeezed lemon and coffee syrup take center stage here. It spent 22 months in half new French oak, and it's ready to go.

A delicious touch of honey in this otherwise dry wine gives extra richness to the generous texture with its gentle spice from wood aging and juicy acidity. Ripe but crisp, the wine will be ready from 2019.

Luscious, sun-ripened blackberries and cherries are boldly concentrated in this easy drinking but elegantly composed Pinot Noir. Fresh acidity and fine-grained, pleasantly bitter tannins make it an approachable introduction to German Pinot with a gentle price tag. Drink now through 2020.
Vibrant raspberry and white peach aromas introduce this perfumed Pinot Noir ros. While dry in style, it's juicy and thirst quenching. Subtle hints of herb and spice lend complexity. Drink now.

This is a peppery, plummy wine with plenty of grip on the palate. Structured and meaty, it rides its ripeness with ease, showing a taste of vanilla soda on the finish. Mixed black grapes account for 25% of the whole and originate from vines planted around 1900.

This blends 55% Sangiovese, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Franc, the grapes sourced from both Atlas Peak and Howell Mountain. Smoky barbecue char wraps around tart tangy red fruit and powerfully soft and supple tannin.

Isolation Ridge has long been the darling single-vineyard wine of the Frankland River subregion of Great Southern, and the 2016 succeeds in upholding this reputation. Lemon curd, apple and delicate florals are wreathed in a prickly palate that comes with a lick of creamy weightiness and plenty of acidity. A highly mineral, wet-stone finish is the cherry on top. Drink now2032.

Very light on the nose, this bottling from 37-year-old vines shows squeezed lemon wedge, chilled Asian pear, hints of jicama and white rose petals on the nose. The citrusy palate is driven by a grapefruit pith flavor and enhanced with a touch of chalk. The texture is compellingly grippy.

Fresh and broad aromas of strawberry and red currant meet with peppercorns and crushed oregano on the nose of this bottling of old-vine Zin from southern Santa Clara County. It's a lighter style on the palate, with bright red plums, crushed river rock and a good helping of herb flavors.

This richly oaked selection from the high-elevation Adrianna Vineyard in Tupungato smells of berries, red currants and maple. It's angular on the palate, with acidity so high it's downright citric. Red berry, red plum and wood grain are the dominant flavors, and they're tarter than they are lush. Tannin is a noticeable element on its otherwise racy, high-acid finish. Drink through 2035.

This is a juicy and full-bodied white, tightly woven in oak and butterscotch. Expansive on the palate, with a depth of apple pie and nutmeg, it offers a balance of fresh acidity that complements well.

Threads of citrus, cherry, cola and chocolate weave through this tasty wine. It's medium bodied, focused and immediately accessible. The blend includes seven different clones of estate-grown fruit, and it was aged in French oak for 16 months.

Made following the principles of biodynamic viticulture and with natural yeasts, this savory red opens with aromas of ripe strawberry, violet and chopped herb. The light-bodied, juicy palate doles out raspberry jam, clove and white pepper alongside fresh acidity and velvety tannins. Enjoy through 2019.

Like all the Cristom Pinot Noirs, this was made with native yeasts and a significant amount of whole clusters. Although three fifths new oak was used, it has had little affect on the aroma, with no noticeable toast or caramel accents. It's tight and minerally, with wild raspberry fruit and a steely frame.

Hearty and rather complex aromas show on the nose of this bottling, including black cherry, vanilla, cocoa dust, hickory smoke and coconut. The palate is dominated by baking spice and gingerbread flavors, set against a blackberry and caramel backbone, but the impressive part is the chalky firm tannins that hold up the flavors quite nicely.

This is a soft wine, smooth and full with apricots and melons. Toasty wood flavors are balanced by the ripe fruit, the rich texture and light minerality. This opulent wine needs only short aging. Drink from 2020.

Packed with fruit, this young wine is already delicious. Acidity, crisp texture, zingy orange and lemon-peel flavors all contribute to a ripe, refreshing wine. It has the lift of the vintage, bright and full of fruitiness from start to finish.

Spicy and rich, this generous, single-vineyard wine is full bodied, creamy and ripe. Yellow fruits are balanced by bright acidity and a tight mineral character. It is still structured, with wood aging flavors and a juicy crisp aftertaste. Drink from 2019.

From one of the most familiar of the Santenay premier crus, this wine still has its structure and a dry core. Around that are red cherry fruits, juicy acidity and a light touch of wood. The wine is developing well and should be ready to drink from 2019.

From the lower slope of Pommard, this richly fruity wine is smooth and generous. It has a layer of tannin as well as full black fruits and a solid character. The wine is still young and needs aging. Drink from 2020.
Vintage dated and made in the classic Champagne method, this tasty brut is a pretty shade of copper-hued rose. It has lovely cherry fruit and ample length. Overall, a very tasty effort.

This is a sanguine Old World-style wine, rounded in tannin and generously soft. Coconut, bay leaf, cherry and vanilla give it a yin and yang quality that flirts with both savory and rich flavors, finding balance despite its full-bodied concentration.

This wine is light straw in color, with soft yet surprisingly persistent perlage. A nose of grapefruit and clementine leads the way for flavors of lemon, pineapple and grapefruit that fade into a soft brioche-flavored finish.

A blend of fruit from both the Saar and the middle Mosel (vineyards surrounding Piesport and Bernkastel) this lovely value Riseling darts and dances on the palate with Margarita-like kicks of salt and lime. Just a shade off dry, its delicate sweetness lends balance to zesty acidity and a cool, mineral finish. This cuve is also labeled under the Hooked brand.

A blend of 77% Cabernet Sauvignon, 14% Cabernet Franc, 6% Petit Verdot, 2% Malbec and 1% Merlot, this is a hearty sanguine red wine, with highlights of eucalyptus, peppercorn and billowy tobacco-laden tannin. Well integrated, it shows plenty of oak and inky concentration.

This is a floral wine, ripe and creamy. It has spice and toast from wood aging along with good acidity and impressiver richness. The wine is full-bodied, spicy, full of yellow and pear fruits. Drink from 2019

In this vintage, the wine itself is as catchy as Mar de Frades's signature blue bottle. Aromas of green melon, apple and lees are spot on for the variety. Flavors of pineapple and citrus finish with modest complexity carried by the presence of lees.

This wine's blackberry, maple and creamy oak aromas introduce a tough but deep palate that's loaded with fruit and tannins. Its wild berry and plum flavors are raw, finishing with cheek-drying astringency. Give it lots of air upon opening and serve with meat or pasta. Drink through 2021.

Rugged licorice and black fruit aromas include a note of barnyard animal in this wine. How tolerable the palate is depends on your ability to process rock-hard tannins. Its blackened berry and toast flavors are compact, feeling rough and heavily toasted through the finish. Drink through 2025.
There is plenty of crisp acidity in this wine, with bright red fruits that come through the tannins. That makes for a juicy, firm wine, crisp and with a dry core. It will be ready to drink from 2024.

Very light aromas of pomegranate, vanilla dust and sweet pastry show on the nose of this bottling. The flavors are also quite subtle, with red currants, a touch of bitter cranberry and dried garden herbs.

This wine is a blend of Cabernet Franc (37%), Cabernet Sauvignon (34%), Merlot (15%), Malbec (9%) and Petit Verdot. Its aromas are still locked up, including its cinnamon, cedar and nutmeg notes and its brooding dark fruit. The palate packs a mouthful of black fruit flavors that show the ripeness of the vintage yet retain a sense of balance.

Made with 35% Corvina, 35% Corvinone, 23% Rondinella and 7% Oseleta, this opens with aromas of blackberry, graphite and a touch of cedar. The concentrated, savory palate delivers red plum, carob, white pepper and a hint of rhubarb alongside polished tannins. Enjoy through 2023.

Electric acidity lends vitality to this zesty and refreshing dry Riesling. Pristine white grapefruit and tangerine flavors are cutting and spry on the palate, lingering on an edge of salty minerality. Enjoy now for its exuberant freshness, but it should show brightly through 2020.
This is an impressive wine at the price point, sanguine and meaty, with medium-bodied density and highlights of cassis. Bright and well integrated, it's food friendly and ready to please a crowd.

After 18 months in barrel (75% new), this was the last of the winery's 2014 Pinot Noirs to be released. The color is dark and vibrant, and it opens with orange peel, berry, spiced cherry and smoke notes. The expected barrel flavors are hiding, and the wine seems to dissipate rather quickly. It warrants another couple of years in bottle before drinking.

Light in the glass, this bottling is a decent example of a more restrained Santa Lucia Highlands wine, with aromas of crisp raspberry, hibiscus and cranberry notes alongside warming hints of vanilla and thyme. Fresh and lively flavors of tart red fruits are dusted by herbs and spice cake on the palate.

This wine has density and richness. With ripe berry fruits and generous tannins it conveys the fruitiness and richness of a Gevrey-Chambertin. It is structured as well, allowing plenty of room for aging. Drink this wine from 2022.

You can taste a bit of all of the varieties in this Bordeaux-style red blend. This shows red currant and raspberry notes, smoked meat, coffee, cigar box and some dusty oak. The palate is medium to full bodied, with more tangy red fruit and cigar box spice. Tight yet silky tannins wrap up this powerful yet easygoing red.

This blend is made from 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Petite Sirah and 15% Merlot. It works in its dusty bramble of succulent black cherry and licorice, ultimately presenting a satisfying, likable wine that's full bodied and richly round.

Mountain-like tannins make for a robust, powerful and concentrated palate that shows a leathery texture. Sage, black pepper and black currant spice up richer elements of dark chocolate and caramelized oak.

When Cobos gets its heavyweight Malbecs right, they're some of the best in Argentina. But in a year like 2014, when the end of the vintage was cold and rain-plagued, many of the big wines seem stunted. With its fully oaked mint, smoke and spice aromas, this delivers nothing but power. Toasted flavors of blackberry, cassis and raisin mark the hard palate, finishing short and with some heat. Age this until 2020 for best results.

Made with 90% Nerello Mascalese and 10% Nerello Cappuccio, this has aromas suggesting scorched earth, brimstone, charcuterie and dried Mediterranean herb. On the linear palate, hints of licorice, clove and a smoky note accent a core of dried black cherry. Fine-grained tannins provide support. Drink through 2022.

A blast of chocolate and mocha rises up on this heavily oaked Monastrell and Cabernet blend before those aromas change to char and toast. A chewy, heavyweight palate deals flavors of licorice, blackened oak and char along with dark fruit that's more canvas than paint. Drink this modern red with steak or roast lamb and it will show best.

This is a delicate, light Chardonnay with age is on its side. Ripe red apples, melon, vanilla and some toasty oak aromas lead into a more floral and citrus palate. There's a good lick of acidity but it's relatively in balance with some textural weight. Still tightly wound, there're plenty more years left. Drink now2027.

Glazes of honey and caramelized sugar lend sweetness to unctuous guava and white peach throughout this fruity, forward sptlese. Racy lemon-lime acidity lends keen balance on the palate, extending a citrusy freshness to the finish. Drink now through 2025.

The AVA Series comprises small-production, single vineyard wines that showcase specific Willamette Valley terroirs. This one, sourced from the outstanding Alloro vineyard, is a delicious mix of red fruit, charred wood, caramel and sea salt. The 30% new oak is right up fronttoasty and quite tasty.

Dry as indicated, with substantial alcohol for a Riesling, this is a tart and juicy explosion of Meyer lemon, grapefruit and pineapple fruit. There's a succulent snap to the finish, which ties in just a hint of residual sugar to round it off a touch.

Cherry chocolate cake, mint, and beef jerky make up the primary aromas on this red blend from one of Margaret River's top producers. The palate is medium bodied, with dusty, drying yet elegant tannins and a salt and cherry finish. Drink now.

Meaty blackberry aromas smell of soy sauce and game. A widespread palate comes with grabby tannins. Mint, oak and herbal berry fruit flavors are more sauvage than polished, while this blend of Tempranillo, Cabernet and Petit Verdot is tight on the finish, with rugged residual tannins. Drink through 2022.

Altocedro likes to pile on the creamy oak, and this Malbec has that in spades. Wood spice and lacquer aromas weigh down its blueberry, blackberry and green scents. Chunky weight and creamy oak define the palate, as do burnt wood, resin and grassy berry flavors.

This spicy, fiery smelling Garnacha shows bright plum and berry aromas. In the mouth, this is tough and tannic, with raw acidity and a mild burn. Dark, spicy berry flavors are blackened, while this tastes peppery and feels hot on the finish.

This pleasant wine is aging rather quickly, already a light rose hue with early bricking. It's in its prime drinking window, with sour cherry and plum flavors and hints of stem and bitter herb, all in proportion. Drink now through 2022.

From the oldest section of the estate vineyard, this offers rounded strawberry and Bing cherry flavors. It's appealing, though not quite as interesting as some of the other 2015s, and should be enjoyed within five years of the vintage.
This toasty, tasty wine balances its apple, peach and banana fruit with barrel flavors and sweet toast scents. It was barrel aged for 15 months in 20% new oak.

From vines that lie behind the main Cte de Nuits, this rich wine shows how even the cooler vineyards have made sumptuous wines in 2015. The wine is soft, gently tannic with plenty of red fruits. It is likely to develop quickly and will be ready to drink from 2019.

This bold, rich wine is full of fruit while also having a tight texture that will allow it to age. It comes from a blend of different parcels that together give a precise and nuanced picture of Saint-Vran. With its edge of minerality, this wine should age, so drink from late 2018.

The Maladire vineyard has given a structured wine full of dark tannins and concentrated black fruit. With acidity to match and a dry core, it is a rich wine with considerable potential. Drink from 2022.

This salmon-pink ros is made from Kkfrankos (Blaufrnkisch) and has aromas of raspberry, strawberry and white peach. Red fruit flavors continue on the palate, detailing strawberry and plum, before a light, gentle finish.

Honeyed tangerine and yellow peach accent exotic spice throughout this zippy dry Riesling. It's a pleasantly tart, briskly textured wine, highlighted by layers of lime and lemon acidity. Drink now through 2021.

This reserve level Iris Vineyards wine gets a special name and faux wax capsule, along with time in new oak. It's then blended and aged in a neutral puncheon, making it soft and easy-drinking, its spicy pear and peach fruit swathed in a light mix of butter, caramel and toast. Give it a slight chill and drink now through 2021.

This soft, creamy wine comes from old vines close to the Brocard winery. It has the proper crispness and citrus character of the vintage plus riper yellow fruits and melon. Drink this attractive wine from late 2018.

Fresh lemon and bramble notes on the nose open to plush white peach and honey in this straightforward yet irresistible auslese. This is both ample in fruit yet briskly balanced. The finish is long and sweet, edged by a hint of caramel.
Thick and dusty in cedar and a touch of smoke, this robustly ripe wine leans into thickets of brambly black currant and blackberry dipped in chocolate.

This village wine comes from a number of growers who supply Jadot on a regular basis. It is bold and ripe with citrus and white stone fruits as well as plenty of acidity. Its rounded character will show more strongly as it ages. Drink from 2020.

The vines of Ladoix are at the base of the Corton hill but much less well known and therefore better value. Juicy acidity and the core of tannin suggest a wine that is ageworthy, while the black-plum fruits give richness now. Drink from 2019.
This is a well-balanced wine with crisp acidity, steely texture and delicious citrus fruits. It has a bright, lively texture and will be ready to drink from summer 2018.

The nose on this sleek bottling by Doug Margerum manages to combines both the grape's telltale grassy tones and tightly reductive qualities with fresh passion fruit and kiwi flavors. There is a great sizzle of acidity to the sip, where lime skin and white rock flavors shine.

Made with selected grapes from a single vineyard, this opens with alluring aromas of white stone fruit, tropical fruit, pressed wildflower and a hint of toasted almond. The fresh, tangy palate offers white peach, citrus and green melon alongside crisp acidity.
Aromas of white stone fruit and spring flower lead the nose while the bright palate delivers green apple, Bartlett pear and citrus alongside a steely mineral note. It finishes clean and crisp.

The nose on this bottling is extremely subtle, with hints of stone fruit and citrus. The palate is extremely crisp and clean, with Asian pear, lime peel and hints of oak smoke. The focus is tightly wound texture more than overt flavors.

Crisp and steely, this wine tastes absolutely fresh from the light herb and green-apple aroma to the lemon-lime flavors, lively acidity and clean snappy finish. It's light to medium in body, has good balance and an especially appetizing character.

This reserve-level wine was assembled from barrels representing six different vineyards. It's aromatic, with berry and cherry scents that carry into the midpalate. It was aged for 10 months in 40% new oak. Cellaring for another year would certainly be advised.

This wine's cherry fruit is framed by aggressive phenolic notes. They bring a definite bite to the flavors, and the tannins remain stiff and rather hard. Additional bottle age and/or aggressive aeration are recommended, as the wine improved significantly after being open for a full day.

This deliciously rich and ripe wine is full of generous fruits with great depth of flavor. The concentration and the warm white fruits are intense with acidity and crispness. This is a wine to age a little longer. Drink from 2019.

This barrel-fermented Tempranillo Blanco is low in intensity on the nose. However, in the mouth it is linear and shows strong acidity. Oxidized, old-school flavors of dry white fruits and oak finish long and mellow. Drink this classic white Rioja through 2020.

A dark shade of rusty pink, this bottling shows red cherry, wet stone, muddy loam and baking spice on the unique and dynamic nose. Cherries shine on the sip as do clove, fennel and baked good flavors. Rather complex for a pink wine.

Bright lemon and orange rind aromas meet with sea salt, nectarine and a yellow grapefruit pith on the nose of this bottling by Karen Steinwachs. Tightly wound on the palate, this single-vineyard expression shows fresh and lively flavors of citrus pith, yogurt and Brie rind. Could use a bit more time in bottle to fully shine.

Aromas of apple and freshly cut Bartlett pear carry the nose, while flavors of white peach and pear juice mark the crisp palate. Bracing minerality and a slightly astringent finish help maintain balance.

This was sourced from vines planted in 1978a rarity at this price. It's floral on the nose, with light baby powder scents. Pretty plum fruit, sweet spice and a streak of cola add texture and complexity. It's drinking nicely, so don't wait.

Aromas of raisin, porcini mushroom and tobacco leaf are front and center. On the juicy palate, velvety tannins carry ripe black cherry, nutmeg and a hint of candied orange alongside fresh acidity. Enjoy through 2023.

Aromas of Spanish broom, Mediterranean herb, orchard fruit and crushed stone come together on this vibrant rosato made entirely with Nerello Mascalese. The racy palate delivers red cherry, apple, citrus and mineral notes plus tangy acidity.

Opaque in color, this wine is dense in blackberry, dark chocolate, cola and vanillin oak aromas. A hot, full-bodied palate is full of plush dark fruit and more oak. This is a powerful, ultra rich red that's seen a lot of sunshine. Drink 20192037.

Co-fermentation with 10% Marsanne has added flesh and white peach flavors to the green fruit of this Vermentino. Despite its youth, it's smooth and well-integrated, with a touch of vanilla cream on the finish.

This is a single-vineyard wine, although not a Premier Cru. It is ripe with plenty of strawberry fruit. Still young though, it is also filled with tannins and tight, juicy acidity that need to soften into the fruits. The wine is potentially warm and ripe. Drink from 2021.

All the white wines from this budget-friendly label managed by Joe Dobbes are simply excellent values. In this new vintage, the Pinot Blanc stands out for its tart, racy mix of citrus, apple and white peach fruit. It's exactly the sort of white to drink on a weeknight with a simple pasta or chicken dish.
Plum, red-skinned berry and a hint of white-almond aromas take center stage. The refined palate shows black cherry, clove and white pepper alongside polished tannins. Enjoy through 2022.
There's no mistaking the variety in this wine, with its lychee and white flower aromas. The palate is dry and broad in feel, with bitter notes on the finish.

This is designated as a reserve-level cuve, and its dark fruit and overall ripeness confirm that ambition. A smoky, earthy component adds depth, and the tannins remain quite astringent. Blood orange and black raspberry flavors stand out at first but fade quickly on the palate. A subtler wine than the previous vintage.
