This pink wine shows plump white peach, watermelon, wet cement and a twist of lime on the nose. There's a flash of sweetness on the sip, with ripe melons, but then it dries up, highlighting rosewater and soft pink-fruit flavors.

Production of this cuve has increased dramatically under the winery's new ownership, making it widely available. It's smooth and balanced, with mixed red fruit flavors cut with an herbal edge. The finish is tart and tight, calling for a hearty decant before serving.

With the addition of 14% Petite Sirah, this delightful old-vine wine is lightly spiced with a taste of black licorice. Vanilla, blackberry and white chocolate add layers of complex, welcomed flavor and succulence to the full-bodied whole.
This full-bodied blend combines a majority of Merlot with Syrah, Petite Sirah and Cabernet Sauvignon. Tannic and tight-grained, it's rustic in leather, black cherry and tart soy.

Black-fruit aromas with accents of road tar and spice turn more herbal with airing. A tight, crisp mouthfeel is built around smacking acidity, while plum and berry flavors come with peppery spice notes. An herbal character returns on a ripped, juicy finish. Drink through 2021.

Long a staple of the Silvan Ridge lineup, this lightly fizzy Muscat is off-dry, fresh and aromatic, with orange candy scents and flavors. Serve it as an apritif with soft cheeses or use it to spiff up your Sunday mimosas or Bellinis.
Aromas of baking spice and black-skinned berry lead the way. The straightforward palate offers vanilla, black-cherry jam and tobacco alongside velvety tannins. Enjoy through 2021.

Though designated a reserve, nothing really sets this apart from other Spindrift Pinot Noirs, other than a slight increase in price. Black cherry fruit, a streak of cola, and a suggestion of cold coffee come through. It's drinking well and should be consumed over the near term.

This wine has a throwback label celebrating Chateau Ste Michelle's 50th anniversary. Upfront aromas of clarified butter, peach and spice are followed by medium-bodied stone fruit flavors. It's a varietal crowd-pleaser.

Aromas of red plum, baking spice and white pepper set the tone while the savory palate delivers raspberry jam, clove and tobacco. It's already accessible and easygoing, with polished tannins. Enjoy through 2020.
Aromas of ripe black-skinned berry, tilled soil and cooking spice lead the way while the dense palate evokes prune, cocoa and a touch of cinnamon. Supple tannins provide the lithe framework.
Zesty lemon-lime acidity and succulent peach and pineapple flavors collide in this easy-sipping, off-dry Riesling. Light-footed and fruity, it's not a complex wine but widely appealing. Drink now.

This wine's dark, rooty black fruit aromas are more cool and earthy than bright. In the mouth, it's dense and sort of flat. That theme is echoed in its flavors, which recall prune, chocolate and mocha. It finishes with heavy berry notes and not many subtleties.
This is a tart lively wine complex in forest floor, black tea and tangy flavors of cranberry, rhubarb and strawberry. It retains a medium-bodied weight that gives it breadth.

From grapes grown in Carneros and Oak Knoll, this wine combines nearly equal parts Merlot and Cabernet Franc, with smaller amounts of Malbec and Petit Verdot. Tart and tannic, it offers structure and a lightness of oak around old-school elements of red currant and cedar.

Earth and herbal notes fade with aeration, exposing prettier notes of honeydew, grapefruit and peach. Brisk acidity and plump, juicy stone-fruit notes lengthen a fresh, honey-glazed finish. Drink now.
This is a toasty, smokey, nutty and slightly peachy Chardonnay from Margaret River. The palate is rich, with a viscous texture and balanced acidity, but the oak is a little prominent on the finish.
This wine bursts with mango, peach and passionfruit, with a touch of cut grass. There's plenty of tongue-tingling acidity on the palate and some textural weight, likely from the Smillon.

This wine's edgy, feral berry aromas are accented with clove and mint. Its tight, choppy palate is saturated with plum and baked berry flavors and a mild green note of mint. It holds onto that herbal quality on the finish.

This wine's aromas are light but intriguing, with peat, cigar box, herb, flower and game notes. Its cherry and raspberry flavors are fresh and transparent, showing little apparent new oak influence. Put it on the dinner table to see it at its best.
This is a bright and expansive wine, brick in color, with aromas and flavors of bread, black cherry and leather. Grippy and powerful, it has a whiff of violet and plenty of length on the finish.

This is a very cerebral wine that will be too bizarre for many. The blend of 55% Grenache, 23% Mourvdre, 10% Roussanne, 7% Cinsaut, 3% Carignane and 2% Grenache Blanc was allowed to sit in glass tanks in front of the sun for nine months, which gives the resulting wine a Sherry-like qualities: yellow-orange in color, with aromas and flavors of smoked walnuts, sour oranges, beeswax, honey and wood oil.

The best of the winery's current release white wines, this offers fresh and well-defined apple and tart melon flavors. It seems to have spent some time in barrel, but the acidity balances the oak flavors well.

Melon aromas of honeydew and cantaloupe meet with crisp stone fruit and Key lime pie on the nose of this bottling. There is a chalky grip to the sip, with mellow flavors of Meyer lemon juice and Asian pear.
Opening aromas convey raisin, cocoa, a hint of bell pepper and earthy whiff of game. The firm palate shows fig, cassis and dried sage alongside tightly wound tannins. Drink through 2022.

Dried rose petals, concentrated red cherry, anise, thyme and caramel show on the nose of this blend of Tempranillo, Grenache, Cabernet Sauvignon and Petite Sirah. The palate is dominated by a rustic sagebrush quality, with earthy red berry and crushed slate adding pleasant complexity.

Run by the sixth generation of the Belland family, this estate has vines in Santenay and other Cte de Beaune appellations. This wine, rich with generous red cherry fruits, is lightly tannic with great swathes of acidity and fruitiness. Drink from 2019.
Full-blast mocha, blackberry and cassis aromas announce a fruity, extracted red. Its pulpy palate has bold, candied black fruit flavors that end rather quickly.

Dry red berry aromas and spicy oak notes make for a good opening in this wine. It's a bit creamy in texture, with commendable overall balance. It offers ripe raspberry and cassis flavors, with a touch of milk chocolate on the smooth finish.
Thick and moderate in structure, this wine is fleshy, lush and tropical in nature. Swirled in butterscotch, vanilla and caramel, the oak is toasty and supportive.
This is fresh and lively, with apple and pear fruit flavors. It's simple, clean and enjoyable, with a light dusting of cinnamon spice. The vineyard sources included Rickreall Estate and Erratic Oaks.

More steely than the Isolation Ridge, the nose offers plenty of floral notes combined with pineapple, stone fruit, apple and yeast. This leads into a tightly wound yet fruity palate, with crushed stone and a poise and structure that sets this up for plenty of years of cellaring. Drink 20192032.

Intensely perfumed, this wine is full of peachy soap and potpourri, along with passionfruit notes and a hint of spice. The bombastic fruit and floral notes continue on the palate which is balanced and light bodied. Drink now.

Sunny tangerines and lemons abound in this full-bodied dry Pinot Gris. Yielding acidity and plump fruit amplifies its rich, rolling mouthfeel. While moderately concentrated on the palate, it's a pleasant, easygoing sip with wide appeal.

A recent addition to the winery's single vineyard offerings, this has a strongly acidic profile, but the fruit suggests cherry rather than leaner berry flavors. The tannins are stiff and astringenta result of 50% whole cluster fermentation.

This wine's aroma brings notes of vanilla, woodspice and baking spice in addition to its bright tangerine scents. The palate is elegant yet creamy in feel, with stone fruit and barrel flavors throughout. It pulls up a bit short on the finish but is otherwise a lovely wine.

This wine was sourced from Clos CheValle Vineyard. It shows primary fruit aromas that bring a lightly candied quality and herbal accents. The palate is a bit clunky, losing some of the variety's delicacy but still delivering enjoyment.
Very shy at first, this wine eventually shows dark raisiny fruit, vanilla and toasty oak. There's plenty of richness and heat, that meld with grainy, tightly wound tannins and plush fruit.
Ripe stone fruit, lemon-lime popsicle and blossoms lead into a palate of crisp acidity. Acid hounds will dig this fairly simple but likable drop.
Medium gold in color, this wine has aromas of pear and talc. It is slightly off-dry, offering flavors of pear, gala apple, toffee and apricot, with a soft mouthfeel and a light, floral finish.

This wine's vanilla and herb aromas are high toned. The palate brings abundant fruit and barrel flavors, with lively acidity providing the frame. The tannins seem a little coarse at present. Give them some time to settle.

This wine is well balanced, with ripe apricot and peach fruits that contrast with the crisp, tangy lemon. Together they give a wine that is juicy and bright while also full bodied and rich. Drink from 2018.
Aromas of rose petals and raisins carry to a compact palate that is chewy and tannic. Blocky plum and berry flavors are slightly flat on a finish with scraping tannins. Drink through 2021.
This 100% varietal wine shows high-toned baking spice and red fruit aromas that lead to ripe but well-proportioned cherry and meat flavors. Fruit and barrel notes interweave on the finish.
This Moldovan Cabernet Sauvignon has aromas of smoked meats and black fruits. In the mouth it is pleasantly astringent, with flavors of tart cherry and blackberry.
A fresh nose with a whiff of briny apple sets up a palate of green pear and crushed stone. Lime and apple flavors are lasting and pure across the crisp finish.
Aromas of red-skinned berry and graphite lift out of the glass. It's savory, doling out raspberry jam, clove and a touch of cinnamon alongside pliant tannins. Enjoy through 2020.
This wine is juicy and crisp, with bright red-currant and cherry fruitiness. The fruit dominates, with plenty of acidity and a core of tannins to support it. It should be ready to drink from 2022.

This blend was made to showcase grapes from a variety of ancient soils. The new vintage lacks the concentration of the 2014 but still expresses mild hints of rock, slate and shell under soft plum, cocoa and toasted grain flavors.
Underbrush, game and black-plum aromas lead the way. On the earthy palate, close-grained tannins support prune, vanilla and tobacco. Drink through 2022.
This is a testament to oak, having aged in 80% new French barrels for 15 months. Ripe and intense, it melds tart black olive and clove with plush rounded layers of caramel and coffee.

Well structured due to firm tannins and acidity, this full-bodied wine is also a good value. It will pair well with the richest proteins and has lightly earthy and spicy aromas, vivid and taut flavors like fresh blackberries and a nicely gripping mouthfeel.

As aromatic as expected of the variety, this has orange blossom, tangerine and orange pulp scents and flavors. With 21 g/L residual sugar, it's definitely off dry yet balanced with moderate acidity and low alcohol.
Muted in leathery tobacco, this is a thick wine sticky in woody tannin and dusty stoniness. Decadent and concentrated, it offers layers and layers of blackberry and chocolate.

Cabernet Franc edges out its companion Cabernet Sauvignon 54% to 46% in this light-bodied quietly ripe wine. Sage, cedar and fresh herb provide a vegetal underbelly that will appeal to fans of those flavors and style, with a juicy underbelly that's marked by a tartness of cranberry.

Pert, sunny red cherry and strawberry on the nose turn to bolder shades of black cherry and berry on the palate. It's a ripe, concentrated Pinot Noir, with a slightly earthen, savory character and strident, slightly bitter tannins on the finish. Drink now through 2019.
Aromas of dried black fruit, tobacco and carob lead the nose while the savory palate delivers prune, blackberry jam and a licorice accent. Velvety tannins provide polish. Drink through 2022.

Offering a bit more concentration than the regular Willamette Valley bottling, this carries the winery's citrus-tinged acids, along with light raspberry and Bing cherry fruit. There's a hint that it's spent some time in new oak also. Aerate aggressively for optimum drinking.

A light touch of cut grass leads to lemon rinds, citrus spray, Gala apples and a touch of guava on the nose of this widely available wine. It's clean and crisp on the palate, where stone fruit and apple flavors reign, set against a chalky texture.

Made with 70% Corvina, 20% Rondinella and 10% Sangiovese, this offers aromas of red-skinned berry and dark spice. The soft, bright palate doles out red cherry and black pepper alongside lithe tannins. Drink soon.
Vibrant candied cherry, herb and baking spice aromas are followed by medium-bodied fruit flavors in this wine. The tannins bring a bit of grit to an otherwise enjoyable palate.

Delicate aromas of apple skin, spring blossoms and lime zest carry the nose of this wine. The palate is a different beast all together, with far less fruitiness and far more mineralitytightly wound and chalky in texture. It's drinking well now, but would also be interesting to see it in a few years' time. Drink now2020.
This full-bodied, rather blocky wine delivers generic tree fruit flavors of the sort often found in Chardonnay. Brief aging in once-used barrels has added a touch of vanilla and toasted hazelnut.
Aromas of lime and dried mango are quiet on the nose. This Albario has the feel of pulpy citrus fruits, while a mix of briny tropical fruit flavors turns a bit green and peppery on the finish.

Merlot makes up over two-thirds of this blend, with the balance in Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Malbec and Petit Verdot. Baking spice, vanilla and plum aromas are at the fore. The tannins seem bunched up, however, and it lacks the generous fruit associated with the warm vintage.

Blending four varietiesPinot Noir, Chardonnay, Gamay and Aligotthis wine shows both rich fruitiness and a crisp texture. Citrus and apple dominate this tangy wine that finishes with attractive acidity.

This wine's aromas lack clarity, with wood spice and butterscotch notes at the fore. The palate is full of lip-smacking, medium-bodied dark fruit flavors. Baking spice and coffee notes linger on the finish.

Light strawberry aromas meet with pink lemon and tangerine rinds on the simple nose of this bottling. The palate shows pleasant touches of strawberry and lemon as well as a touch of peat and pine smoke, but is missing some acidic boost.

This basic, medium-bodied wine has straightforward plum and berry aromas. Its cherry, currant and mild chocolate flavors hum along, with little to no change on the finish. This may be simple, but it works.

Peach, mango and crushed-stone aromas lead to a cidery, streamlined palate. Salty stone-fruit flavors lead in this barrel-aged Tempranillo Blanco, a fairly rare wine even for Rioja. On the finish, this is plump but lacking in structure. Drink now.
Savory earthy accents complement ripe melon flavors and a generous texture in this pale-colored, medium-bodied wine. It has good heft on the palate, and is rich enough to keep the flavors lingering.

This has delicate aromas of baking spice and red-skinned berry. Mirroring the nose, the no-frills, enjoyable palate offers red plum, vanilla and a hint of white pepper alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2020.
This coppery gold-hued wine is soft, round and dry and suggests early oxidation. Its simple tree fruit flavors bear a touch of lemon and honeycomb, though the finish is completely dry.
Subdued aromas suggest prune, vanilla and baking spice while the ripe, straightforward palate presents fleshy black plum, toast and a hint of pipe tobacco. Smooth tannins lend easygoing support.
Subdued aromas suggest Spanish broom and chamomile flower. Reflecting the nose, the lean, linear palate is also restrained, offering citrus, lemon zest and a hint of beeswax.
Aromas of tilled soil and black plum lead into the straightforward palate along with prune, bitter almond and a note of baking spice. Round tannins offer support. Drink through 2019.
There is some good concentration in this ripe, structured wine. With its core of tannins and its surrounding red-berry and cherry fruit, it is rich and needs a little more time. Drink from late 2018.

This wine seems anxious, with an unfocused, nervous energy. Acidity, berry flavors, chalk and other mineral elements collide rather than combine. It may or may not improve with more bottle age. Two bottles were tasted, with comparable results.
This is a voluptuously lush white wine awash in pineapple, honeyed pear, vanilla and toasty oak. Moderate acidity supports its rich ripe fruit-forward nature.

Earthier notes on first whiff dissipate with aeration to expose prettier aromas of strawberry and peach. The palate of this Pinot Noir ros is distinctly citrusy with unexpected hints of vanilla and cream. Drink now.

Jammy berry aromas are more gritty than smooth. This feels chunky and on the heavy side, with power but little finesse. Extracted blackberry and cassis flavors finish with overt oak, related chocolate notes and rough tannins.
A nose of grapefruit and lemon with a hint of thyme sets the stage for flavors of lemon-lime, pineapple, vanilla and white flowers. This wine is bright from first sip until lingering citrus finish.

From Heart of the Hill Vineyard on Red Mountain, this leads with vanilla, clove and baking spice aromas and follows with tart, tangy fruit and barrel flavors. Cranberry notes linger on the finish, along with interesting acidity.

This wine all comes from Oasis Vineyard in the Yakima Valley. Its red fruit, baking spice and medicine cabinet aromas are a bit difficult to tease out. The flavors, meanwhile, are at once lightly styled and jammy, finishing short with cranberry notes.

Floral yet flat aromas are leafy and a touch green on the nose. This 100% Sumoll ros feels peachy and simple, with stone-fruit and berry flavors. Mild raspberry notes lend a red-fruit character to a wide but shapeless finish.

There's a touch of fizz to the glass in this twist-top bottling, which shows light peach, yellow melon, sliced apple and orange-cake aromas. The flavors are subtle but the texture is decent with acidity and grip, allowing ripe pear and a touch of lime bitterness to arise slowly.

The nose on this bottling is quite shy at first, and then slowly arise aromas of citrus pith, sliced Gravenstein apple and a mushroomy, woody component. The palate's citrus rinds, pomelo pith and hints of tangerine are presented on a well-wound frame.

This Malbec-led blend has black fruit aromas with hints of Band-Aid and licorice root. It's chewy and dense but also a bit flat. Its plum and berry flavors are moderately oaky, showing rubbery tannins and an herbal aftertaste on the finish.

From an up-and-coming vineyard, this exudes light green herb, macerated cherry, violet, citrus and barrel spice aromas. On the palate, full, slightly green dark fruit flavors are backed by tart acidity. The tannins are a touch dry, but there's promise here.
A rich, fruity wine, this is rounded and ripe with white fruits. It shows a crisp edge and a touch of spice from oak aging. It will develop quickly to give an attractive wine from late 2018.
Sourced from Art Den Hoed and Gunkel vineyards, this wine has high-toned red apple and barrel spice aromas and ripe, sweet red raspberry flavors. It's interesting, albeit cloying.
Aromas of orange and vanilla turn more burnt and smoky as this Pinot Noir-Parellada brut ros opens up. The highly foamy mouthfeel carries rustic, spicy citrus flavors.
This wine's aromas are a bit disjointed, its rose petal and spice notes seeming dried out. The palate is quite sweet, without the acidity to back it up.
Mild white-fruit aromas carry the nose of this Biodynamic Sauvignon Blanc. Angular, tangy flavors of gooseberry and green plum carry the flavors and finish crisp and clean.
Mellow aromas of pear, rainy sidewalk and nectarine show on the nose of this bottling. There is bountiful acidity on the sip, with cut grass and apple skin flavors.
Aromas of orchard fruit and white flower lift out of the glass while the tangy palate offers citrus, yellow apple, saline and a hint of bitter almond. It's racy, with vibrant acidity.
This opens with delicate aromas of baking spice and black-skinned fruit. It's easygoing, offering black cherry, red plum and vanilla alongside round tannins. Drink through 2020.
Fresh black cherry and plum are ripe and forward in this easy drinking Pinot Noir. It's a soft, sunny wine, with delicate acidity and plush tannins but refreshingly fruity. Drink now.

Earthy mineral notes are brightened by whiffs of white blossom and grapefruit in this subtly sweet Gewrztraminer. Soft acidity and feather-light texture add to its delicate feel. Drink now through 2019.
Opening aromas suggest black-skinned berry and cooking spice. The firm palate shows ripe black cherry, nutmeg and cocoa alongside chewy tannins. Drink through 2020.
This opens with aromas of red plum, cooking spice and a hint of nutmeg. The no-frills palate shows black currant, clove and a black pepper note alongside smooth tannins. Enjoy soon.

This excellent vineyard designate usually shows better, but here, the awkward, chalky acids overtake the cherry fruit. It may need more time in bottle, or may simply have required a different approach to acid adjustment during the winemaking process.
Aromas of toast, tobacco and a hint of black-skinned berry meld together on this wine. The dense, robust palate delivers prune, vanilla and star anise alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

Troon makes a pair of Vermentinos; this is the one with the red label. It's a spicy, peppery white with a funky kick to the finish. A mix of cucumber, lime and apple fruit, it carries a rather surprising leathery scent and flavor. Some tasters will consider that a plus.

This unusual blend of Nebbiolo and Malbec feels compact but hard. Its reedy, stalky berry aromas are fiery, earthy and herbal. On the palate, spicy, herbal plum and berry flavors finish with peppery, minty notes.

Two bottles of this wine were tasted, with vast differences. The first was dominated by a leathery, tack room aroma, which carried into the palate and obliterated the fruit. Some tasters attribute this to terroir, but it's in fact a flaw. The second bottle was much improved, showing black cherry fruit and proportionate tannins. The score is for that bottle, but beware the possibility of extreme variation.
This wine's cherry-like fruit is plenty ripe, and the acidity has fresh-squeezed orange juice appeal. The only off note is a hint of plastic on the nose that carries into the palate.

Out of the gate, this wine's oak is far out front, with vanilla and baking spice notes that obscure the fruit. The palate shows more of the same, though it settles down a bit with significant time open. It's a style, albeit over the top.

Like many austere, power-packed 2014 Malbecs, this offers an intense attack. Its cool cola and blackberry aromas include a note of fennel. And its berry flavors are fiery and aggressive, with a long, drying, tannic finish.

Hugely oaky, this wine also features a dustiness on the nose and palate, alongside woody tannin. Black olive and dried herb give it an herbaceous quality that belies its full-bodied richness and ripe core.
This wine is full bodied, very ripe tasting and has a soft expansive mouthfeel. Touches of earth and barnyard join stewed plum flavors for a rustic but enjoyable taste profile.
Light although sweet red-cherry-syrup aromas meet with iron and crushed sage on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling. The sip is simple yet tangy with tart red fruit, proving very easy to enjoy.

This structured wine has a dense texture as well as red-cherry fruits. It is crisp, still young, with spice as well as some firm tannins. With this bright, fruity and young character, it will take some aging. Drink from late 2018.
Denis Dutron has made a wine that is bright with acidity as well as warmer tropical-fruit flavors. Soft, easy and fruity, this delicious, crisp wine is ready to drink.

Brooding aromas of dark plum, vanilla and spice lead to easy-drinking blue and black fruit flavors in this blend of 63% Syrah, 33% Merlot and 4% Viognier. It's a bit generic but delivers enjoyment all the same.

Aromas of black-skinned berry and cake spice float out of the glass. The straightforward, medium-bodied palate offers black cherry, white pepper and hint of cinnamon, with firm tannins. Drink though 2019.

This unoaked version of the variety, released quite young, is tightly wound and unyielding. Its jicama, apple and green melon fruit flavors are concentrated, belying the listed alcohol, which is evidenced only by some heat on the finish. Give it ample aeration or decanting.

Basic wood smoke, plum and berry aromas are solid enough to mask some of this Cabernet's greener components. Its dense palate is pillowy, tasting of herbal blackberry and spice cake. Leafy berry notes and a touch of chocolate mark the finish.

Aromas of orange peel and tarragon are spunky and a little green on the nose. This fresh, lean Garnacha Blanca shows moderate acidity and short flavors of green melon and almond skins. A bit of saltiness is present on a dry finish.

This blend of Malbec, Bonarda and Syrah offers earth, leather, latex and berry fruit aromas that are mildly aggressive. In the mouth, generic berry flavors come with a hint of herbal green on the finish.
This wine's extremely tart berry fruit seems barely ripe, hinting at wild raspberries. It's a high-acid, stiff and herbal style, which seems to be intentional, as it was made with 50% whole clusters.

From vines a quarter century old, this distinctive offering features fresh Mediterranean herb, apple and pear skin notes and a core of white peach, apple and jicama. Don't look for ripe fruit; the style here emphasizes subtle texture and herbal characteristics.

You may find tasters divided on this wine; for some it will be delicious, for others overripe and alcoholic. It's definitely big in style, with quite ripe, almost raisiny fruit flavors, a hint of plastic on the nose and astringent tannins.

Heavy oak and related char, chocolate and mocha aromas make up the nose of this dark, grippy Cabernet Sauvignon. There's plenty of oak flavor, along with herbal berry notes, but it finishes raw, tannic and scratchy, with a hard texture.

Rich blackberry and candied black-cherry aromas meet with strong cedar, roast beef, smoke, olive, soy and a tarry quality on the nose of this bottling. It's very dry and sticky with tannins on the sip, which relegate the flavors of red cherry and roasting herbs to the background. The 100% American oak treatment remains prominent, so this may evolve more favorably with time.

The aromas in this wine aren't entirely harmonious, with high-toned herb, spice and mineral notes. The palate, however, brings plenty of intrigue, with velvety-soft, mouth-coating red fruit flavors and savory herbal hints that linger on the finish. Unfortunately, the two don't sync up.

The Smillon really takes the fore in this SBS blend. Wet wool, bruised citrus fruit and white pepper lead into a restrained, almost austere palate. The acidity is in check but the fruit is lacking. It all ends with an intriguing salty, copper-penny finish.
This floral, aromatic wine is light, bright and enticingly fruity. Its light acidity and crisp, brisk texture are all attractive parts of a wine that is already very drinkable.
Florally perfumed in orange blossom, this plush, medium-bodied white is awash in pineapple and a strong taste of cinnamon stick, its oak pronounced and supportive.

Varietally familiar aromas of snappy citrus fruits are feline in nature. This is light in body, refreshing and citric. Flavors of lime and tangerine are stony and show a hint of green herbs, while this is lasting on a fresh finish.
Black cherry, tobacco and baking-spice aromas lead the nose while the soft, ripe palate shows prune and white-pepper accents. Pliant tannins give it an easygoing nature. Drink soon.
This clean and simple wine is a textbook example of Oregon Pinot Gris. Its lightly spiced pear and apple fruit is fresh and varietally correct, making for a pleasant sipper.
This is a wide open, fruity wine, with upfront berry and citrus notes backed by chalky acids. It's a good, quaffable red but lacks the complex meat and compost notes often found in Northwest Syrahs.
This long-established negociant house, based in Santenay, has made a generous, ripe white Burgundy. It is soft and smooth, with ripe red apple and quince fruit. Drink the wine now.

This was harvested at low brix and fermented principally in French oak. It's a soft, floral take on Viognier, with scents and flavors that suggest baby powder. Because of its Meyer lemon and other candied citrus notes, odds are either a small amount of Gewrztraminer was blended in or some residual sugar remains, though neither is indicated. Drink now and over the next two to three years.

This leads with flat, earthy raisin and prune aromas. The palate is bulky, thick and syrupy, with stewy cassis and berry flavors laced with coconutty oak. It's dense and slightly overdone on the finish.

This is stiffly tannic, with red plum and spicy cherry fruit. It's a hard, chewy wine that could use some time to soften, but its rusticity is undeniably flavorful. Pair it with hearty winter stews or coq au vin.

This new entry in the budget Pinot Noir market is perfectly fine, if ordinary. It offers tart berry, pomegranate and light herbal highlights. The tannins are proportionate, and everything is in balance. A fair wine at a fair price.

This wine comes from just outside Meursault, giving both richness and juicy fruitiness. Apricots and ripe melon add to tastes of citrus and crisp apple to offer a wine that is fruity, soft, lightly buttery and ready to drink.

Largely tannic and generous in oak, this is a blend of Merlot, Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot, Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon and Zinfandel. Plum, currant, bread dough and leather are among the more powerful components, with a rich rounded mouthfeel providing approachability.

This wine's plum and currant aromas are raw and wild, with a hint of animal and not a lot of overt ripeness. It's medium bodied and rubbery in mouthfeel, with a mix of salty and woody flavors and moderately ripe plum notes. On the finish, it tastes mostly of spicy oak and mint.

Girardin, based in Meursault, has made a ripe, fruity red Burgundy that reflects the generous red fruits of the vintage. It is juicy, soft and rounded, with attractive acidity and light tannins. Drink now.
This lightly vanilla- and spice-flavored wine is deliciously creamy. Flavors of apples and citrus burst out of the glass ripe, full and ready to drink.

Consider 2015 an off year for this estate wine. Its thin red berry fruit comes with citrus flavors, high acidity and dry, astringent tannins. Some appealing cherry candy flavors emerge as the wine breathes, but it doesn't seem to have the depth to age. Drink now and over the next two to three years.

The immediate and lasting impression is that this is a mighty peppery wine. Tart pomegranate fruit eventually kicks in, until it thins out into an astringent, and yes, peppery finish. It was aged in 35% new oak for 13 months.

This blend of 50% Syrah, 30% Petite Sirah and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon offers a very rich nose of licorice, black currant leather, tobacco and potpourri. The palate is a tad sour and dried out, with black plum skins, purple flowers and peppery spice.
This wine is spicy and earthy, with brawny, rustic and ripe waves of cherry and vanilla at its core. Simple in structure it's robust in tannin and oak, aspects that persist on the finish.
Yeasty white-fruit aromas carry the nose. In the mouth, this basic Godello is fleshy and pulpy. A mix of citrus and nectarine flavors holds steady on a fresh but simple finish.
This offers aromas of black plum and cooking spice while the firm palate shows blackberry jam, tobacco and black pepper. Closed-grained tannins provide the framework. Enjoy through 2020.

Subtle apple, lime and a sulphuric vegetal note combine in a refreshing wine that is restrained in nature. A slippery texture carries along these quiet notes to a stone-fruit and apple finish. Needs time to emerge from its shell. Drink 20192022.

Aromas of creamy oak and corn stalk are oily, rich on the nose. In the mouth, this Chardonnay from Navarra is broad but with ample acidity. Woody, creamy pineapple and orange flavors finish steady and oaky.

From an up-and-coming part of the Walla Walla Valley, this has barrel spice, raspberry and dried cherry aromas followed by somewhat elegant red fruit flavors that taper toward the finish. It doesn't all quite come together.
Aromas of lemon rind, pineapple and cantaloupe pave the way for flavors of white flowers and melon. This finish is pleasant but overall a bit too perfumed.

This wine is a blend of 51% Cabernet Sauvignon, 27% Merlot, 17% Syrah and 5% Petit Verdot. The aromas are fruit-forward, with blackberry jam and other black fruit notes. The palate is more reserved than the aromas suggest, with drying tannins. It has a bit of a hole in the middle, but there's still enjoyment to be had.

This leads with maple and burnt oak aromas and follows with crushed fruit scents that turn earthy and herbal with air. It's a big but plodding Cabernet with spicy baked blackberry flavors that end with power and rough tannins.
Ripe raspberry and black-pepper aromas take center stage here. This wine is straightforward, offering black-cherry jam, licorice and a note of white pepper alongside smooth tannins.

Young and still showing a yeasty aroma, this crisp white wine mixes green apple and green melon flavors with a touch of jicama. It's ready to go and should be consumed over the next year. There's a light hint of cracker on the finish.

This wine's saucy wild berry aromas are accompanied by herb, spice and meat notes. Its choppy, tannic palate is grippy to the extreme, tasting of herbal berry fruits, savory spice and peppercorn. On the finish, a dark foresty note enters the picture.

This blend of Mourvdre, Grenache and Malbec is dark and slightly minty, with sweet cherry fruit at the core. The acidity is moderate but firm enough to keep it upright, and a light touch of leather runs throughout.
This opens with aromas of red plum, underbrush and cooking spice. The medium-bodied palate delivers ripe black cherry, star anise and a touch of licorice alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

This crisp wine has a creamy background, making for a ripe, fruity wine with tangy orange and lemon flavors along with touches of vanilla. It is still young and could do with a few more months, so wait until mid 2018.

Sour grapefruit pith, wet clay, cut grass and a hint of white flowers show on the slightly reductive nose of this bottling, which opens up with a bit of patience. The acidity gives zip to the sip, where wet concrete and lime skin flavors shine.
Tannic and rustic, this is a straightforward presentation of ripe rich plum and oak, along with sizable seasonings of pepper and leather.

This unusual blend is two thirds Pinot Noir, the rest split between Pinot Gris and Pinot Blanc. The white varieties seem to dilute the red, without contributing much else, leaving heavy tannins intact. Along with black fruit, there are thick, chewy tannins.
This crisp, fruity wine is lively, with considerable acidity as well as red berry fruits. The tannins are still young, forming a solid core that will soften. Drink from 2021.

The 2016 is a crisp vintage in Chablis and this bright, tangy wine reflects it. It has plenty of lemon acidity, orange zest and liveliness that has been partially smoothed out by some wood aging. Drink this wine from late 2018.
This wine's grapey berry aromas are clean but basic. It has a focused, sinewy mouthfeel and lightly salty plum and berry flavors. Touches of herbs, spice and salt are present on the finish.
Spicy mint and tobacco leaf linger around a lightly structured wall of tart earth and cola in this site-designate wine.

Yeasty aromas of Animal Cracker cookies and vanilla mask fruit tones on the nose. This vineyard-designated Albario shows flavors of briny apple and stone fruits, with a slightly bitter, monotone finish.

Dry, earthy aromas suggest brick dust, red fruit, cardamom and cinnamon in this Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah blend. It's raw and wide, with edgy tannins, exotic spice, berry and minty oak flavors, and a scratchy finish.
Tart, tight and unyielding, this wine's apple flavors aren't exactly thin, but they seem charmless. Acidity lends a lemon juice flavor, and time in 50% new oak has had little impact.

This wine was aged in half French and half American oak, 60% new. Wood spice, vanilla, plum and herb aromas lead to a broad palate that mixes fruit and barrel in equal parts, the two persisting on the finish.

Pops of sweet, juicy yellow cherry, honey and caramel burst on the nose and palate of this robust off-dry Gewrztraminer. It's ripe and clingy on the palate but balanced by sunny tangerine acidity. Drink now through 2019.
Cocoa, woodspice, licorice and cherry aromas are out in front in this wine, accenting light-bodied dark fruit flavors. The tannins seem a bit gritty, but it otherwise provides appeal.
Deep gold in color, this opens with aromas of beeswax, chamomile, acacia and mature yellow stone fruit. The lean palate offers dried yellow apple, lemon and saline alongside bright acidity.

Shy at first, several swirls in the glass reveal notes of sour cherry, florals, cocoa nibs and some oak spice. The palate follows with more ripe, tangy fruit and florals. It's medium bodied with balanced acidity. Drink now.

This is a 100% varietal wine, aged for 20 months in French and Hungarian oak. Tart and plushy, it has a level of rusticity that serves it well. Thick tannins meet a smoky oaky core of wood and dried herb.

With a buttered-toast aroma, this rich wine is spicy, creamy and ripe. It is buttery, smooth and generously textured. It comes from the son of a Chablis producer who has set up his own negociant business. Drink this superripe wine now.

Light black cherry aromas meet with a bit of rose petal, vanilla and pie crust on the rustic nose of this bottling. It's easy sipping on the palate, where roasted red berries meet with hot earth and a touch of charred beef.

This leads with minty herbal aromas like juniper and eucalyptus. Upon airing, dark fruit notes emerge, along with some oak. On the palate, it's more rough than smooth, holding herbal black currant and chocolate flavors. By the time it finishes, its berry flavors are on par with its strong herbal notes.
Aromas suggesting black-skinned berry and almond unfold in the glass. The dense palate shows fleshy black cherry, baked plum and a hint of cinnamon alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2020.

Delicate aromas of apple, nut and a whiff of acacia mingle together while the rather subdued, light-bodied palate shows suggestions of pear and citrus. An almond note gives it a pleasantly bitter close.
This opens with aromas suggesting prune and underbrush while the straightforward palate evokes blackberry jam, raisin and a hint of chocolate. It's already accessible, with supple tannins.

A dash of Carignane contributes to the whole of this easygoing likable wine. Softly layered baked plum and prune flavors are given additional heft and roundness from a richer undertone of caramel and brown sugar.

This has generic berry aromas, with a strawberry candy note. Its saturated palate hits with drying tannins, while clove and bitter chocolate flavors accent stewed berry notes. Oak and toast dominate the finish.

This is the first vintage of this estate-grown Tempranilloa rare grape in the Willamette Valley. It's a bit high-toned and right on the edge of vinegary. Roasted flavors of charred red fruit and a hint of smoke come through on the finish. This is a love-it-or-leave-it wine with no middle ground.
This opens with aromas of oak, blackberry and baking spice. The dense, taut palate shows black currant, toast and vanilla alongside tightly wound tannins. Drink through 2020.

Vincent's Pinot Noirs are fermented with native yeasts in a mix of once-used and older barrels. This bottling opens with fresh strawberry and raspberry flavors, lemony acids, and an underpinning of wet stone. It's on the lighter side and was made (and priced) for everyday enjoyment.

This reserve-level Pinot Noir spent 17 months in neutral oak yet carries strong scents and flavors of vanilla and toast. Those elements accent a core of preserved strawberry fruit. If that hits the mark for your palate, you'll want to drink this while it's young and fresh.

Delicate aromas of black-skinned berry and baking spice introduce this easygoing red. The straightforward palate offers red cherry, cinnamon and a hint of white pepper alongside round tannins. Drink soon.

White blossoms, yeast, apple, and peach and something a little sweaty proceed towards a palate that is almost gritty in texture, with more floral and apple notes and the region's characteristic searing acidity.

Relatively elegant aromas of black currant, blueberry, loam, oregano and thyme show on the nose of this widely available bottling. The palate is simpler, with cocoa dust, black cherry, pepper and tannins that tighten into the finish.
This soft and creamy wine has a gentle mousse and ripe white-fruit flavors. Its open, rounded character and warm aftertaste make it ideal as an apritif.

This opens with aromas of underbrush and black-skinned berry while the straightforward palate offers vanilla, black cherry and a touch of almond. It's easygoing, with round tannins. Drink through 2020.
Plummy flavors and a broad, soft texture make this wine taste ripe and plush. It blends lightly smoky and oaky nuances with butter and jam that accentuate an almost sweet character.

Aromas of white-fruit and yeast is mild on the nose. On the palate, this brut nature is lean and acidic, with a mouthfeel defined by lime juice and wet stone. Green-fruit flavors are slightly oxidized on a quick-fading finish with green-herb notes.

Half Barbera, half four other red grapes, this features a handsome black dog on the label. It's blood-black in the glass also, with plum, chocolate and leather flavors in equal proportion. Depending upon your tolerance for leathery reds, it may surprise or disappoint.
Pleasant fig and pear flavors fill out this medium-bodied and rather subtly flavored wine. It tastes ripe enough, but not overly rich, has good concentration and an earthy component
Aromas of cedar, black-skinned berry and a whiff of tobacco lead the way. The firm palate shows ripe black cherry, vanilla and a hint of star anise alongside mellow tannins. Drink soon.
Soft and accessible, this opens with aromas of vanilla, mature blackberry and exotic spice. The mellow palate delivers ripe black plum, cinnamon and white pepper alongside lithe tannins.

This wine pulls from across the wider appellation to combine cool-climate grapes with warmer regions. Round and easygoing, it offers fleshy fine flavors of pineapple and peach, its oak integrated and unobtrusive.

Extreme lawn clipping and green bell pepper aromas show on the nose of this bottling, with slightly rounder hints of guava, passion fruit and struck flint also arising. It's a bit riper on the sip, with yellow pear, Key lime, rainy cement and wet hay flavors.

Light and fruity, this gently creamy wine is cut with tangy acidity. This balance gives the wine a delicious, crisp present and the possibility of a few more years aging. It is all fruit, with no sign of wood, and will be ready from mid 2018.
Crisp and simple, this is a bright, citrus-flavored wine. Acidity and a clean, clear character give it liveliness. The wine is all fruit with no sign of wood, so drink early from summer 2018.
A heavy coating of oak dominates over mild fruit tones on the nose. This old-vine Garnacha Blanca is textured, with briny white-fruit and resiny oak flavors.

This spent 17 months in barrel, which has substantially softened the mouthfeel, with suggestions of early oxidation. Its lightly spicy apple pie flavors seem a bit faded, heading past their prime. Drink soon.

An abundance of white flowers and sweet grassiness (along with some ripe pear) shows on the nose of this bottling from a newer property in Temecula. Apples and nectarine flavors reveal themselves at first on the sip, which then grows more sour with cut grass and apple rind elements.

Very clean aromas of Pink Lady apple, ripe Asian pear, squeezed Meyer lemon and a touch of wet stone prove refreshing on the nose of this bottling. There's a hint of peach and Key lime pie ripeness to the sip, yet the wet cement minerality also shows through. It could use a touch more zippy acid.
Peppery and herbal, this is a lightly spicy mix of rhubarb and strawberry fruit. It does not express the general ripeness and fruitiness of the vintage but will drink well over the next few years.
This perfumed wine is ripe and packed with red fruits. Its soft texture, generous fruits and acidity are balanced to give a smooth, rich wine that will be ready to drink in 2018.
Crisp and creamy, this wine is light, poised and ready to drink. It has a tangy edge with a steely core to balance the smooth fruit. Drink now.
From southern Burgundy vineyards, this ripe and creamy wine is soft and packed with fruit. Its acidity and crisp texture contrast with the apple and pear flavors. This forward wine is ready to drink.

Soft, creamy and full of ripe yellow fruits, this smooth, unctuous wine reflects the rich vintage. Its acidity fits well with this juicy fruitiness giving a balanced, easy wine that will be ready to drink from late 2018.
The shy nose eventually reveals ripe black fruit and raisin aromas. Dense and robust, the palate shows blackberry jam, prune and white pepper alongside supple tannins. Drink soon.
Briny, bready aromas suggest sourdough on the nose. In the mouth, this is solid but shows mild complexity. Orange and nectarine flavors include a spot of yeast, leading to a clean, dry finish.
Ripe aromas of prune and blackberry come with a hint of green. A dense, tannic palate holds rich flavors of prune and plum. A toasty, oaky finish is spicy but short.

This shows that classic aged Riesling petroleum character along with lemon-lime citrus. While the fruit is absent on the palate, texturally it's still lean and laser sharp, indicating it's still an infant. The low alcohol is a bonus too. Drink 20192027.

This wine's cherry and blackberry aromas are basic. It's firm and tannic on the palate, with minimal depth. Dry, salty plum and berry flavors show a touch of oak. A blend of 70% Malbec and 30% Cabernet Franc, it's rough on the finish.

Cured meat and oak add richness to an otherwise light-bodied expression of the grape. Floral in apple blossom aromas, it follows through with additional flavors of Gravenstein apple, pear and a lemony hit of freshness on the finish.

Sourced from an experimental block planted in 1978, this is a compact wine with clean apple fruit and toasted hazelnut scents. It's not yet showing all its complexity, so decant or tuck it away for a couple more years.

Six barrelsone each from six vineyardscomprise this cuve. This vintage is on the earthy side, with soil, skin and bark flavors alongside light plum and berry fruit. The acids, as in most of the winery's Pinots, leave a chalky aftertaste.
Medium in body and high in acidity, this herbal wine shows a tartness of sour cherry and baked rhubarb flavor, held tight within a subtle casing of oak.

The best of Vincent's vineyard designates, this shows riper fruit than the others, with red plum, cocoa and dried herb notes in the mix. An impression of Red Hots candy comes across on the nose and adds a hint of spice to the palate.

Though 18 months in neutral oak is indicated in this wine's technical notes, it has an arrestingly toasty scent and flavor, which may indicate some other form of oak addition. It shows pretty, though simple, red fruit and is pleasantly appealing. Drink over the next year or two.
Toasty and tart, this is a straightforward Chardonnay with clean varietal character. There's nothing to distinguish it, but for the price it offers fair value and decent flavor.

Pungent lemony notes are followed by vanilla, butter and some vegetal character in the background. The buttery texture on the palate is classic oak-aged Chardonnay, with fleeting fruit flavors that race along the mouth-puckering acidity. Try this again in a few years' time when the acidity will hopefully have calmed down.
This wine's cantaloupe, apple, grapenut and pear aromas pop. The palate is upfront, dropping off considerably on the back end. Yet, it still provides enjoyment.

Alta Alella's entry into the natural wine world comes via this Mataro (Mourvdre) from Catalonia. Reduced, raisiny aromas push the nose to the outer limits of acceptable ripeness, while this feels saturated. Prune and grapy fruit flavors simmer on the finish.

A peach aroma mixes with notes of lees and crushed stone on the nose. The palate is citric and streamlined, with lean tangerine flavors that turn a touch oily and fleshy on the midpalate, but ultimately racy on the finish.

This blend of Malbec and Cabernets Sauvignon and Franc has generic ripe berry and cassis aromas. On the palate, it's medium bodied, with tomatoey acidity. Its herbal berry fruit and oak flavors persist on a steady finish.
This wine's birthday cake, baking spice, herb and licorice aromas lead to plentiful dark fruit flavors backed by slightly green tannins. It doesn't quite seem to have fully ripened.

Apple and citrus aromas are starting to show some age-based corn and wheat notes on the nose. A solid palate is compact and narrow, while apple and stone-fruit flavors exhibit mild bitterness. The finish is tangy, with a modest burn. Drink now.
This opens with aromas of carob and spirit-soaked cherry. The straightforward palate delivers ripe black cherry, nutmeg and a touch of fig alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2020.
Aromas of yellow apple, wet stone and baked bread lead the nose and carry over to the bright, light-bodied palate along with hints of dried herb and lemon drop. A saline note fills in the finish.
This comes from a vineyard 1,400-feet elevation, and it is blended with 14% Petite Sirah. Thick tannins surround a core of extracted red cherry and blueberry fruit; the texture is mild and fleshy.

This is a ripe wine, fruity with blackberries and black plums. Juicy acidity and tannins work just right as a core of structure. Belonging to the same family for six generations, the estate is in the Entre-deux-Mers region. Drink from late 2018.
Charred oak and slightly overripe aromas make for a bullish nose. On the palate, this delivers a jolt of acidity along with oversize tannins, while ripe plum and cassis flavors.

Fresh lemon and lime zest aromas are sharp in the nose of this bottling, cutting into the oak smoke character. The mouthfeel is round and creamy, with more oak as well as melted butter, apple and lemon flavors. It is a solid midweek Chard.

Soft and fruity, this attractive wine reflects the generous 2015 vintage in red wines. It is full of red-cherry and red-currant fruit, cut with just the right acidity and ready to drink from mid 2018.
This is a smooth, ready-to-drink wine with attractive acidity and crisp pear and quince flavors. With bright, orange zest accents and mineral texture, the wine is totally refreshing.

This single-vineyard wine is already mature with juicy red fruits now evolving into secondary flavors. An earthy character gives the wine density and weight. The aftertaste has acidity and softness. Drink now.
This wine, which includes a small amount of Gewrztraminer, is off dry, with powdered sugar, lime, Meyer lemon and orange creamsickle flavors.

This wine is predominantly Cabernet Sauvignon (70%), with equal parts Cabernet Franc, Malbec and Merlot. Despite the even growing season, it doesn't seem to have fully ripened, with jalapeo pepper, baking spice and plum aromas. The flavors are light to medium bodied and drop off on the finish.

Lots of whole bunch stalkiness happening here, showing notes of Big Red gum blended with cherry cola. The intense cinnamon and red fruit characters continue on the palate where there's a tannic grip and good amount of acidity. While winemaking technique overpowers terroir here, this is nevertheless a fashionable style plenty of people will enjoy.

Minty wintergreen scents lead the nose of this wine and carry into the flavors. Other fresh herbal notes are also in play, with a tight core of crisp apple flesh and skin. It's a rather austere style that might pair well with shellfish.

Fresh Key lime aromas meet with touches of guava, plumeria and lemongrass on the steely nose of this bottling. There's a great sizzle of acidity to the sip, leaning a bit more toward Sauvignon Blanc than Chardonnay, with flavors of guava gum, green papaya, lime and grass.

This is a promising wine for SoCal Chardonnay, starting with aromas of lemon peels, sea salt, cream and honeysuckle. The palate is a tad sweet, with apple syrup and candied lemon flavors, but the mouthfeel is creamy and the acidity is good.

A bit disappointing, this tannic wine spent 17 months in half new oak. Its light rhubarb and berry flavors are overtaken by astringent tannins that leave a bitter aftertaste. More bottle age may help smooth them out.

This wine's aromas aren't entirely settled, with dried cherry, spice, herb and game notes. Its cherry flavors are ripe, full and dry but dip in the middle. It has pleasing components, but they don't all come together.

This wine's melon and stone fruit aromas are a touch briny. It's linear on the palate, lacking depth and volume. With salty, oaky apple flavors, it leaves a lasting briny impression on a finish led by oak.
This soft and fruity wine brings out all the succulent red-fruit flavors of the vintage. Light on tannins, rich in juiciness, it is ready to drink.

With fruit from Les Collines, McKinley Springs and Elephant Mountain vineyards, this offers coconut, vanilla and baking spice aromas and full-bodied fruit and barrel flavors. The oak influence is pretty intense.
This opens with aromas of black cherry, bitter almond and graphite. On the palate, blackberry jam, vanilla and cinnamon accompany chewy tannins. Drink through 2020.

This wine's cool, earthy aromas are low on fruit and heavy on oak, recalling resin and maple. The palate is laden with blocky tannins, showing spiced plum, mincemeat pie and dry oak flavors that lead into a raw finish.

This is a fruit bomb of a ros, packed with rhubarb, strawberry and cherry flavors. Though made in stainless steel tanks, it has a whiff of white chocolate also. It finishes dry, though rounded off with enough sweetness to smooth out the acids.

Reflecting a hot and dry vintage, this blend smells a bit raisiny and overripe. In the mouth, hard tannins make for a rough and rugged palate, while flavors of tomato, green herbs, prune and spice finish similarly baked, herbal and tomatoey. This is a blend of 55% Tempranillo, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon and 15% Merlot.

This barrel-fermented Navarran Chardonnay is gold in color, with a matte finish and a resiny mouthfeel. Woody, spicy flavors gleaned from copious oak dominate a flavor profile of creamy melon notes. Lasting oak carries the finish.
This wine offers plenty of funk notes: raw meat and barnyard with cherry notes far in the background. The palate, however, is another beast all together in its red fruit and searing acidity.

Freshness is the story in this lightly herbal Malbec-Bonarda blend. In the mouth, it's snappy and tight, with generic but racy berry flavors that stay juicy through the finish. Consider chilling this prior to pouring.
This opens with aromas of tilled earth, ripe black-skinned fruit and underbrush. The straightforward palate delivers mature black plum, vanilla and nutmeg framed in polished tannins.

This wine is principally Merlot and Syrah, along with a dash of Cinsault. The aromas are high toned out of the gate, with red fruit, vanilla, plum and spice notes. The palate is soft and elegant in style, with a spice-filled finish. It's a straightforward, easy drinker.

Extremely vigorous bubbles want to explode with the slightest swirl of the glass on this bottling, which is pretty solid for the price. Aromas of candied strawberry, yeast and cherry Starburst candy show on the nose, while the palate carries flavors of stewed strawberry and a hint of yeast. It's slightly sweet but not overbearing and will please a diverse crowd.

This is a pretty sunset rose color and offers gentle, somewhat muted flavors of rhubarb and bramble berry. Meyer lemon and orange peel highlights accent the midpalate, which opens up with a flash of cherry pie flavor.

Rather reserved on the nose, this 50-50 blend of Syrah and Tempranillo shows light aromas of black cherry, vanilla, purple flowers and cola. The palate starts soft and mellow, with more cherry, vanilla and slight clove flavors that ride a steadily rising acidity, and finish on vanilla.

This wine's berry and plum aromas are standard and don't offend in any way. It feels a bit lean yet is fresh and crisp. Its spicy plum and currant flavors are mildly reedy, while spice notes and dryness drive the finish.

The label displays asterisks between G, S and M, perhaps because the blend also includes 13% Sangiovese. It hasn't yet come together, with various components sticking out. Baking spice, leather, blackberry, dust and vanilla notes are some of the puzzle pieces that don't find a seamless fit.

This wine's dark, blood-like color and oaky, resiny aromas don't scream Pinot Noir. In the mouth, it's full but drying. Resiny oak flavors are more prominent than fruit, and a final note of raisin marks the heavy finish.

Saint-Bris is the only appellation in Burgundy where Sauvignon Blanc is grown. The style, as in this wine, hints at herbal while going more for riper fruits. Tangy acidity and attractive rich fruits come together in a crisp wine that is ready to drink now.
This opens with aromas of prune, tobacco and toast. The simple palate offers blackberry jam, vanilla and star anise alongside round tannins. Drink soon.
Aromas suggest black-skinned berry and clove. The simple palate offers wild cherry and a white-pepper note, with easygoing tannins. Drink soon.
This wine's roasted aromas are more rooty and reedy than ripe, with a leathery note. Its firm palate contains stalky berry flavors that hint at smoked meat and herbs, especially on the finish.
This has plenty of ripe, tart raspberry fruit, accented with pretty spice. A strong leathery scent and flavor mutes it somewhat, and the tannins dry out the finish.
This Malbec is wide and full, lacking in cut and structure. Its chunky plum and berry aromas are a bit spicy, and its plum and herbal berry flavors finish round, with spice notes and dry tannins.

Oaky, charred notes cover most of the dull black fruit aromas in this Malbec-Syrah blend. The palate feels ripe in the middle but raw around the edges, with raisin, prune and baking spice flavors that seem heavy and stewed but not entirely lost to overripeness.

Among a range of terroir-driven Burgundies from Florent Rouve are his Maons. This soft, simply fruity wine is ready to drink. With attractive acidity as well as crisp apple fruitiness, it is bright with citrus and zest at the end. Drink now.

Earthy in rose petal and forest floor, this wine is medium bodied and somewhat tannic, with a finesse of raspberry and strawberry flavor. It shows well and is made in volumes that provide affordability and accessibility.

This wine is an unusual blend of 30% Petit Verdot, 21% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Tempranillo, 17% Syrah and 12% Merlot. Aged in 50% new American oak for 40 months, it offers baking spice, garden herb and red cherry aromas, followed by a somewhat green and gritty palate. A tart, bitter note distracts on the finish.

Jumpy aromas of blackberry Kool-Aid are common for a joven. In the mouth, this feels chunky and grabby, with punchy acidity. Salty berry and plum flavors come with abrasive tannins and an aftertaste of oak.
Heavy bubbles and aromas of apple and pickle juice are intense. Round in mouthfeel, flavors of tart citrus are offset by mealy notes. This tastes mostly of briny, salty orange on the sizable finish.

Vinified in stainless steel, this is a fresh-tasting though rather generic white wine. Its delicate flavors conjure up cucumber, gooseberry and white melon. It's a simple sipper that might best accompany a no-frills poultry dish.

A simple but appealing Merlot. Ripe red and black fruit, chocolate and some herbal oak notes are followed by a plush, fruity palate. The alcohol is a little hot but this is nevertheless an easygoing weeknight red.

Call this a confounding Cabernet Sauvignon, which is proving not to be Pulenta's best grape. It's tomatoey and earthy on the nose and heavy and cloying on the palate, tasting at once overripe and weedy. Compelling one moment and off putting the next, this is no easy wine to process.

This wine reaches the extreme end of the buttery scale, showing toasty, oaky aromas, butter and vanilla flavors, a very creamy, rich texture and very full body. It has little overt fruit expression but plenty of complexity and savory character.

Soft, delicate perlage and plush tropical fruit tones lend a sunny, easy feel to this sparkling blend. It's brut in style, with zesty acidity lending balance to more dulcet flavors of banana and apricot preserve. Drink now.
Raisiny aromas are obvious but not over the top. This basic Toro is expansive but a touch heavy in fell. Raisin and black plum flavors are more baked than fresh, while this is compact on the finish.
Cooked aromas of raisin and prune make this feel heavy and off balance. Its dark, minty raisin and prune flavors lack clarity and focus, even on the stewed finish.
This offers aromas of green pepper, tobacco and black-skinned fruit. The palate is soft and ripe, with dried black cherry, prune and white-pepper accents. Drink soon.
Subtle aromas of baking spice, mature black plum and vanilla slowly come together on this. It's quite simple, offering flavors of blackberry jam and nutmeg, with round tannins.
This simple wine shows strawberry cotton candy, candy corn, chocolate malt and herbal notes, all very light. Drink up.
Fresh aromas of green apple and melon meld with a note of yeast on the nose. A solid palate holds mild citrus and green-herb flavors that lead to the straightforward finish.

Wood, sweet spice and plum aromas are out front in this wine. The palate is broad, with abundant plum flavors and astringent tannins. Baking spice notes linger on the finish. It's not obviously Merlot, but there's enjoyment to be had.

The nose on this bottling is very showy with aromas of apple blossom, cut Anjou pear and guava. The palate skews tropical, with green papaya and underripe banana flavors, and a decently fresh acidity.

Mealy berry aromas are stewy and topped with a heavy load of oak-based carob and cocoa. In the mouth, this Garnacha feels sticky and dense. Dried dark-fruit flavors finish woody and medicinal, with heat and excess weight.

Made from an unusual white grape rarely seen in Oregon, this was partially fermented in new French oak. That's counterintuitive for such a generally crisp, high acid white wine with cucumber notes. More bottle age may smooth it out a bit.

Light and fresh on the nose, this bottling has aromas of black olive, chile pepper, red cherry, cranberry and crushed pencils. The herbal character shows loudly on the palate, alongside cocoa, tart red cherry and cooked olives.

Honey, lemon blossoms, orange oil and the slightest hint of petrol show on the nose of this dessert wine, which smells a bit syrupy. That viscosity is evident on the sip, which is extremely sweet and rich, though there is a background of lime zest and lemon-verbena-powered acid to give depth.

This wine is a blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Franc. The barrel influence is way up front, recalling vanilla, wood spice, baking spice and green herbs. The palate comes off as quite woody as well, with blocky tannins and a vanilla-filled finish.
Subdued aromas of baking spice and black-skinned fruit guide the nose while the dense palate offers clove, ripe black plum and vanilla. Round, closed-grained tannins provide the framework.

This Bordeaux blend is from a notoriously wet and cold South Aussie vintage. The result is a vegetal wine, with notes of cooked green beans, charred meat, and dark raisiny fruit. While the nose appeals, the palate is on the oaky side, with angular, muscular tannins and a rather funky-filled finish.

Roasted plum and berry fruit aromas along with a touch of oaky latex open this blend of Malbec and Syrah. The palate is fresh and choppy but also tannic. Plum, raspberry, rubber and salt flavors carry into the finish.
Stiff, herbal and tannic, this wine seems reluctant to offer much fruit. What it has in abundance are stem and skin flavors, which may be intentional but offer little pleasure.

Frankly herbal in flavor, this wine smells reduced at first, like garlic and onions, but mellows to celery, cucumber and lemon on the palate. It's medium to full in body, has a rich texture and lingering veggie finish.
White-fruit and citrus aromas are mild but clean on the nose. This has a light-bodied palate and tart flavors of orange and lime. A juicy finish hangs around for a few moments then dissipates.
Mineral-driven on the nose, the palate of this Verdejo is citrusy in feel, with a grippy texture. Flavors of nectarine and peach are mild on a fresh finish.

From a site high atop Glen Ellen's eastern edge, this estate-grown wine is brawny in leather, with a touch of sweetness to the oak. Robust wood flavor and tannin combine to emphasize the force and concentration of this wine, which has a puckering sensation of cedar and violet.

Subtle dark-berry aromas meet with hearty spices, including pepper dust, cigar box and wood varnish. The oak is prominent throughout, with flavors of pine, bay leaf, eucalyptus oil and dried cherries on the sip.

Very light in the glass, there is a subtle but growing tropicality on the nose of this blend of 40% Roussanne, 40% Grenache Blanc and 20% Viognier, with papaya, banana flower sap, candied honeysuckle and a bit of tuberose. The palate is clean with decent acidity, but those candied tropical flavors are overpowering, with mango, guava and banana syrup.

This blended ros is comprised of 56% Pinot Gris, 25% Pinot Noir and 19% Grenache (from the Rogue Valley). Watermelon and tart strawberry fruit flavors combine, with a sour tang to the finish. Drink this chilled or try it in a sangria.

This wine's odd name would seem to indicate there's Chardonnay in the blend, but in fact it's only Pinot Noir. Although technically a white, the color and flavor say ros. Light rhubarb and strawberry fruit comes forward, with a round, pleasant mouthfeel. Drink up.
Soft red cherry and plum flavors are smooth in this ripe, fruity red. While a touch reedy and woody, it boasts pleasant licorice and spice notes, along with feather-light tannins. Drink now.
This is a full-bodied white rich in buttery oak and baked apple, with a tang of lemon and a yeasty nose of baked biscuit.
This wine's bright blueberry syrup, boysenberry and vanilla aromas lead to soft, plump, easy-drinking blue fruit flavors that persist on the finish.
Fermented in stainless steel and barrel aged, this hearty wine is soft and simple with a juiciness of Kool-Aid-like flavors and dusty leather.

Resiny oak is the dominant aroma on this barrel-fermented Godello. That heavy oak character carries straight to the palate, which tastes severely resiny. Oak and hidden white-fruit flavors are about all that's present on the finish.
Generic berry and plum aromas come with notes of rubber and latex in this Cabernet Franc-Petit Verdot blend. On the palate, it's blocky, with minty, spicy berry flavors and drying tannins.
Sweet spice and raspberry flavors get this wine up and running, but the winery's propensity for leathery reds once again mutes the fruit. It finishes with a bitter and astringent aftertaste.
Tight and crisp, this wine has red-currant fruits and plenty of acidity. It is crunchy, structured and very fresh. It will take time to soften and open up, so drink from 2021.
This Cabernet's woody red fruit aromas lead to a soupy palate with tomato-like acidity. Tomato, herb and plum flavors carry into a steady but unexciting finish with residual oak.
This wine is ripe with full-bodied tropical-fruit flavors that are cut with lime acidity. It is a warm, open wine from a rich vintage, full of fruit and without any wood aging. Drink now.
This is a simple, fruity, quaffable wine with light baked apple and cinnamon flavors. It's balanced and soundly made, though insubstantial.
Very light in the glass, this wine shows fresh honeydew aromas along with sweet peach, honeysuckle and slightly tart orange rinds. The easy simple flavors include peach and ripe apple.
This smooth, ripe and creamy wine offers rich vanilla and apple flavors. It is open, full of fruit and with a tangy texture. The acidity is a good support for a generous wine that's ready to drink.

This salmon-colored wine offers a bouquet of strawberry and white peach. Flavors of pomegranate, clementine, passion fruit and vanilla are set amid moderate tannins that afford rich mouthfeel before fading into a bright tangerine finish.

Bob Pepi is listed as the winemaker for this tightly woven, understated effort, which shines in red and black currant as well as blackberry succulence. Smoky, it finishes in warmer richer tones of bacon and leather.

Sweet-seeming shadings of oak complement substantial fruit flavors like black cherry and blackberry in this fresh concentrated wine. It has good acidity and mild tannins for that welcome grip on the palate.

Syrah comprises 55% of this blend, followed by 36% Cabernet Sauvignon, 6% Petit Verdot and 3% Merlot. Smoky oak encases compressed, meaty blackberry and big notions of tannin and oak. The finish flirts with overripe heat.

This is a rich, toasty wine showing notes of chocolate, blackberry, vanilla and pea shoots. The palate is a little hot and dense in dark berries, auspicious oak and a savory finish. Drink now with food until 2025.

This wine's herbal berry and tomato aromas are as wild as the high desert it hails from. In the mouth, it's loud, with currant and plum flavors that finish with a note of fiery heat and residual acidity.
Fresh pear and apple aromas are light, simple and clean. Like almost all Txakoli, this is acidic and highly citric in feel, with flavors of lemon and underripe pineapple.
Gritty, with explosive power midpalate, this has a tartness of acidity that stands up to a softness of texture and tangy red fruit.

Very ripe fruit flavors and a sweet brown-sugar impression make this medium-bodied wine showy in the vein of a red blend. It feels rather soft on the palate and a hint of sweetness carries through on the finish.

From a challenging vintage, this wine is quite light, with barely ripe strawberry fruit. It spent 18 months in French oak, and the barrel character dominates. It tastes mostly of mocha and caramel and should be consumed over the next year.

This wine's scents and flavors suggest cracker and dried grain, while its tangy, herbal fruit suggests peashoot and grapefruit. It shows varietal character, but it's almost like drinking it through gauze; it's already fading.

Bitter peach pit and burnt orange aromas open this tan-colored Cava. A soft, lightly citric mouthfeel could use more acid, while this tastes of grape skins and stale grapefruit. A short finish introduces green-herb notes.
With bright red fruits and crisp acidity, this wine sums up the fruitiness of this vintage. A dry edge balances the red-currant fruit and acidity. Attractive now, it will be better from 2018.

Briny, funky aromas of cured ham, stone fruits and salt water are unique for the area. This blend of Viura and Garnacha Blanca is linear and acidic, with lightly oxidized, barrel-driven flavors of boiled ham and dried apricot.
This is a soft wine, smooth and creamy. The simple apricot and ripe pear flavors and easy style make it ready to drink. At the end, a tang of crisper acidity comes through.
This wine is crisp and perhaps too full of acidity, giving it a red-currant character that is juicy and tightly fruity. It needs to soften over the next few years. Try again from 2020.
This wine's rubbery, leafy berry aromas are forced and strained. Its raw, choppy palate tastes of peppery currant and plum, while its tight and narrow finish tastes a touch green.

This Oregon winery consistently makes solid, affordable Pinot Gris. The new vintage seems a bit subdued and perhaps needs more bottle age to fully open up. Thin apple fruit and a hint of celery come through, with yeasty accents on the finish.
Traces of yellow peach mingle into fresh herbs and green plums in this delicately concentrated Pinot Grigio. Medium bodied in style, with soft, yielding acidity, it's a quiet but pleasing wine.

Quite dark in the glass, this bottling is a good stab at lesser ripe fruit from Temecula, although the aromas are still very primary, with Concord grape and grape seed most prominent. Black-fruit flavors meet with black licorice and clove on the palate.
This blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon has a resiny aroma ont the nose. The palate boasts lemony acidity, with vanilla, tobacco and currant flavors, while the finish is choppy and tangy.

Lush and accessible aromas of ripe cherries, strawberries, lilacs and cigar box show on the boisterous nose of this bottling. The palate is a bit more simple, with dark red fruit, sandalwood, a hint of star anise and a purple-flower flavor that's a bit over the top.
Raspberry aromas are mild on the nose. This hails from Bellmunt, a warm, lower-lying section of the Priorat. In the mouth, it's rough and gritty, with narrow plum and cherry flavors.
This sparkling red wine has aromas of raspberry, cassis and sweet cherry pie. The palate brings flavors of black currant and cherry juice, with a slightly sweet finish.
From a high-elevation site, this wine opens mildly before a fierce grip of tannin and power take hold. Sticky black fruit, cedar and somewhat harsh tannins give it a brawny rustic quality.
This is a plush, rustic and somewhat impenetrable wine in terms of tannins and ripeness. It offers a strong taste of tobacco, leather, earth and dried fruit.
This opens with delicate aromas of baking spice and black-skinned fruit. The simple palate offers blackberry jam and a star-anise note alongside easygoing tannins. Drink now.

Hints of clay and spice lend savoriness to sweet-tart apple and pear in this value icewine made from a blend of Ortega and Optima grapes. It's slightly cloying in sweetness but a straightforward dessert option. Drink now.
Vivid celery aromas and flavors ride a moderately crisp texture in this medium-bodied wine before a hint of sweetness completes the picture.

There's a slight effervescence to this bottling, which shows fresh banana, mango, wet stone and a subtle yeast on the nose. There is decent energy to the palate, where the tightly wound flavors of lemon juice and chalk arise.

This wine has a distinctly strong element of cured meat and salami on the nose, before it lunges wholeheartedly into chocolate, cedar and tobacco tones. Soft significant tannins wrap around the flavors in an impenetrable way.
Aromas suggest tilled soil and black-skinned fruit. The easygoing, simple palate presents clove, orange zest and red-skinned berry alongside rounded tannins. Drink soon.

With the alcohol barely topping 12%, this might have made a better ros than full-fledged Pinot Noir. Its strawberry and citrus flavors are dilute, though clean and fresh. High, citrusy acidity is the prominent characteristic.

Oak-derived aromas of clove and charred berry fruits are the first act in this unusual Malbec-Carmenre blend. Its weighty palate delivers high acidity and rough tannins. Short, choppy plum and leafy flavors feel pointy on the finish.
This wine is slightly spritzy, with forward flavors of strawberry soda pop. It drinks like a much less expensive bottle and should be consumed chillednow through 2019.

Dusty, dried black fruit aromas lead the way in this astringent, oaky wine. Its barrel flavors, from aging in 30% new American oak, suggest raw lumber rather than pretty toast. More bottle age may help smooth it out.

Dry herbal aromas of oregano and thyme dominate the nose of this minty, spicy Cabernet. The palate has a raw exterior, without much stuffing, tasting of coffee grounds, fennel, cured meats and spiced cherry. Dryness is the overriding theme here.
This wine's spicy plum and berry aromas lose freshness quickly with air and turn mulchy. It's chunky and acidic, with saturated plum and berry flavors and a loud-ringing finish.
This opens with subdued aromas of scorched earth, baking spice and black-skinned berry. The simple palate offers dried cherry, vanilla and a hint of clove. It's easygoing, with soft tannins.

Situated in the heart of the Entre-deux-Mers, this estate, one of several owned by the Ducourt family, has made an easy, crisp blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Smillon. Acidity and touch of herbal flavors are balanced by the tropical edge that comes from the vintage. Drink the wine now.

Like a sampler box of chocolates, this label of D'Arenberg blends four Spanish and Portuguese varieties: Tempranillo, Grenache, Tinta Co and Souzo. Unfortunately 2011 was one of South Australia's toughest vintages on record and this wine doesn't quite make the grade. It's dense and oaky, with barely ripe plum, raspberry and vegetal notes. The palate offers some juicy fruit and the tannins are powerful and drying.

This wine's spicy blueberry and plum aromas are scattershot and unfocused. It's a wiry, high-acid Malbec with plum, currant and herb flavors. A high-toned and front-loaded, it fades quickly on the finish.
This wine is packed with fruit flavors and has a lightly tannic texture to carry them along. Focused raspberry and sour-cherry notes are accented by dashes of wood smoke and pepper.
Light aromas of mowed lawn, ripe peach and wet concrete show on the mellow nose of this bottling. It's fairly simple on the palate, with ripe pear and seared lime flavors.

A heavy coating of resiny oak sits on top of reedy berry fruit aromas. Reduction and jamminess offset each other on a tight palate, while there's a prickly, slightly herbal quality to the plum and berry flavors in this Monastrell.
Plum, baking spice and licorice aromas lead to lightly styled fruit flavors in this wine. The wood influence seems quite intense, distracting from the fruit.
