Herbal aromas announce the 100% Sauvignon Blanc in this wine. It is crisp, although touches of tropical fruit and citrus bring out the Bordeaux origins. Drink this fruity wine now.

Though this cuve is far more limited (and expensive) than the winery's regular release, it's imbued with strong coffee and vanilla flavors that overwhelm the fruit. Its tannins are hard and the fruit rather generic. Another year or two in bottle may bring it into better balance.
This wine's stewy, herbal berry aromas are not very ripe or compelling. Its rough palate offers minty, herbal berry and carob flavors, finishing slightly hot and abrasive, with green notes.
A heavy obvious oak component meets good ripe fruit flavors in this full-bodied mouth-filling wine. The aromas are charred and smoky, leading to almost jammy blackberry flavors.

This combines grapes from St. Helena and Yountville appellations, as well as 15% Petite Sirah. Dull on the nose, it has an herbal persistence of cedar and sage backed by plenty of tannin and planks of oak.

Green, grassy aromas announce a wine with ripeness issues. In the mouth, this feels raw and tannic, with hard-pumping acidity. Oaky, chocolaty flavors accent plum and berry fruit, while this feels and tastes riper on the finish than it does early on.
This wine's lightly volatile black fruit and baking spice aromas lead to dark fruit flavors backed by firm, grippy tannins. It doesn't all come together, and the variety seems lost.
Made entirely from the Xarello grape, this brut smells is mildly funky on the nose. A solid palate holds briny peach and bready flavors, while this is steady on the moderately complex finish.
This wine's lightly ripened fruit flavors suggest pear flesh and pear skin. There's not much to it, other than a touch of orange candy as it fades away.

This soft, rich wine is a delicious reminder of the great fruit in this vintage. It has broad red fruits with balanced acidity and a crisp edge. This wine that comes from vineyards at the southern end of the Cte de Beaune is ready to drink now.
Pear skin scents and flavor highlights accompany the straight-ahead pear fruit in this wine. There's some residual sugar, which rounds out the mouthfeel and keeps the alcohol low. Drink up.
Apple cider aromas set up a tight palate with moderate acidity. This tastes briny and mildly bitter, with grassy white-peach flavors. On the finish, this doesn't change much or improve.

This aromatic wine exudes smoky spicy oaky aromas that continue on the palate, joining good cherry and blackberry flavors and mingling on a smooth texture. It's overtly oaky but has enough fruit to provide counterbalance.
White peach, caramel and browned butter aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is soft and easy with flavors of roasted apple and cinnamon, though it could use a more acidic boost.

On the nose, this Malbec blend is heavily oaked and smells like latex and plastic. On the chewy, tannic palate, it tastes largely of burnt oak and gummy berry fruits. Heat and chocolate flavors drive the finish.
Aromas of baking spice and black-skinned fruit lead the nose while the palate offers clove and black-cherry jam. It's easygoing, with round tannins.
Aromas of cedar, baking spice and mocha lead the way while the simple palate delivers prune, coffee and a hint of clove. It's already accessible, with pliable tannins.

This wine's light cranberry fruit suggests that the grapes were barely ripe or perhaps sourced from young vines. The flavors are pretty but quickly dissipate, leaving residual tastes of stem and bitter herb. Give this another year or two of bottle age.
This brut is sound on the palate, but low acidity results in a flat sensation. White-fruit and green melon flavors are lightly oxidized on a yeasty finish.
This wine, from unspecified sources, drinks like a less expensive Cabernet. It's chewy and rustic, dominated by vanilla scents and flavors and finishes with hints of black tea.
Light orange in color, this wine brings sweet cherry and herb aromas. It drinks dry, with broad, fat-feeling but lightly concentrated fruit flavors.

Green, leafy aromas accent this wine's generic berry notes. Its raw, pinched palate is dry and tannic, tasting of minty green herbs and berry fruit. Acidity and leafy flavors are at the forefront of its herbal finish.

Soy sauce, grilled meat, red plum and currant aromas give an impression of underrripeness in this wine. It feels linear, with no give to the palate, and its savory, herbal berry flavors dry out on the finish.
Aromas of fresh pumpkin and dusty peach are clean but bland on the nose. This blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Airen shows briny melon flavors, with notes of spent yeast and wheat on a low-acid finish.
This wine is spicy, with a bitter edge that hides some of the fruit. It does have a citrus character followed with acidity, giving the wine the potential of a fruity future. Wait until mid 2018.
Light aromas of white fruit greet the nose in this Chardonnay from red-wine country. The plump palate is simple and low on acid, while this tastes of lightly oaked melon and apple.
This is a light wine with red-currant fruitiness and a crisp texture. It has a light tannin edge as well as juicy acidity, bright and fruity at the end. Drink from late 2018.
This medium-bodied wine could pass for a cherry cola, with its fruity aroma, rather tart balance and flavors like cinnamon and cola.
This smooth wine has a soft texture, candylike fruit flavors and an earthy element that stretches from the first whiff to the lingering finish.
A gold color and round melony aromas are friendly on the nose. Dry apple flavors are lightly oxidized, while this isn't offering much on the finish.
Sweet berry-cherry flavors meet a fleshy rounded midpalate in this simple and easygoing red that has a substantial taste of dried fruit and leather.
Tart berry flavors bordering on sour show in this wine, with unripe cherry notes mixed in. Aged a year in neutral barrels, it offers a faint suggestion of mocha as it fades.
Subtle aromas of baked earth and pomegranate are very shy on the nose of this bottling. A slightly tart red-currant flavors pops on the sip, along with a touch of cinnamon.

Roasted campfire and herbal blueberry aromas lead the nose of this wine. The palate lacks substance and structure. Its herbal, oaky berry flavors are green and stewy, finishing with unabsorbed oak and mint notes.

This is from a site 2,000-feet high in elevation, and made in tiny amounts. It opens with a massive concentration of plum and up-front tannin, imparting heady oak aromas and power. The finish is simple and bright in cassis.
This wine's scratchy plum and tomato aromas lead to a slightly creamy palate. Its salty plum and berry flavors are raw and a touch green, finishing short and flat.
This wine is citrus-driven on the nose, leading to a streamlined palate of apple, green melon and almond skin flavors.

Berry and plum scents suggest powdered drink mix. A narrow palate feels austere, while this tastes of tart black plum with mineral tones. On the finish, this dries out quickly as it leaves grating residual tannins.
This wine pops with notes of ripe strawberry, cherry, herb and melon aromas. These notes carry to the palate, yet are restrained, and the tannins bring grittiness.

This wine's sugar beet and raspberry aromas are reedy like sweet grass. It dries out quickly on the palate due to rubbery tannins. Herbal berry flavors fill it out, feeling slightly astringent and begging for food.
This crisp, fruity wine by a Chablis-based producer comes from northern Burgundy. Shining acidity and fresh citrus flavors give an easy, ready-to-drink wine.
This tastes off-dry, yet that sweet fruit doesn't quite mask a bitterness that lingers through the finish. The light pear and pear skin flavors seem like an afterthought.

This wine's dark fruit aromas are neither complex nor serious. It's a basic Malbec, soft and a bit overweight, with generic black fruit flavors and a hint of blackened toast on an otherwise innocuous finish.
A blend of 63% Sangiovese, 32% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Merlot, this wine tastes slightly overripe, with a candied nose of rustic fruit and thick heated tannins.
Scented with spice and built on thick, grainy tannins, this wine offers little varietal character. The dilute red fruit could be almost anything from anywhere.
Spicy, peppery, herbal berry and plum aromas lead the way in this wine. It's dry as a bone and tannic, with woody plum and tomato flavors, finishing oaky and a bit salad-like.
This is a fairly green and astringent wine, with full-bodied concentration and thick tannin.
This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec has raw berry aromas. It's generic on the palate, with berry and tomato flavors and little depth or breadth. It has a lightly herbal, inoffensive finish.
This Viognier/Marsanne blend from southern Oregon is perfumed almost to a fault. Its light citrus fruit is overpowered by floral baby powder scents and flavors.

This vineyard designate must have stood out during the winemaking process, but at the moment its better qualities seem to be hiding. Neither place nor variety show with any particularity; it's just a light, generic red wine.

A few wineries in the Pacific Northwest are experimenting with this Portuguese grape. Here, it just tastes like a thin, generic red, and the fruit is buried in aggressive just-sawn wood flavors from aging in 30% new American oak.
Jammy black currant aromas are rooty and medicinal. This young Tempranillo is hard and smacking on the palate. A forced-oak flavor of clove is dominant, while this is drying and raw on the finish.

This tan-colored brut nature opens with yeasty aromas of brioche and oxidized apple. A foamy palate lacks clarity and smoothness, while this tastes like it smells: briny, yeasty and mildly oxidized. A fruitless finish is simply dry and bready.
This wine has a grip to it that hits hard on the palatea somewhat astringent turn to the tannins. Red fruit and violet work hard to integrate within a full-bodied concentration.

Merlot makes up half of this wine, and Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Petit Verdot make up the balance. The aromas are unique, with high-toned black tea, green herb and vanilla notes that aren't entirely settled. The palate brings blackberry and plum flavors that are a bit disjointed. It drops off on the finish.
Sweet-seeming oak aromas and cherry-jam flavors dress up this bright, pleasant and rather light-bodied wine.

This has evolved aromas of prune and tilled soil. The warm, simple palate shows fleshy black plum, vanilla and a candied almond note alongside pliant tannins. You'll also detect the heat of evident alcohol. Drink soon.
This wine's stewy, medicinal plum aromas are chunky. In the mouth, it's plump and bouncy, lacking spine. It concludes with tea and stewed berry flavors on a drawing, hefty finish.
This wine is smooth and soft, with a gently juicy character. Its fruit and attractive acidity make for a generous wine that is ready to drink.
White-fruit aromas are quiet on the nose. Despite a shearing mouthfeel that's typical for Txakoli, the palate leans sour and citric in feel.

Produced from Chardonnay grown in the Beaujolais region, part of a greater Bourgogne appellation launched in 2012, this is a soft and fruity wine. It has a tang of lemon acidity, a creamy texture and a fresh, crisp aftertaste. Drink this easygoing wine now.
This is scented with an odd mix of mint and bubblegum, and those flavors continue onto the palate. It's a candy-like wine with a sugary finish.
Rough and grainy, this is a tannic, earthy wine with a bit of rustic charm. It's not typical of the grape variety but could stand up to a burger and fries. Drink soon.
Syrupy oak flavors dominate modest fruit notes in this medium-bodied, ripe and almost sweet wine. Tart cherry and raspberry flavors underneath give some fruity support.
Softly tannic, this is a simple juicy wine, lightly ripe in blackberry and black currant. Secondary flavors come to the fore in the midpalate, dipped in milk chocolate and soy.
Don't look for any familiar Pinotage character in this wine. It's a thin, nondescript, lightly peppery red with a whiff of chocolate.
This wine's aromas are light, with herb and spice notes. The palate is on the lighter side of medium bodied, with lemony fruit flavors and no apparent new oak influence.

This is a blend of two barrels and it contains a strong lingering notion of cured meat and Italian delicatessen. Thick green tannins spark ongoing flavors of cedar and tobacco within a full-bodied concentrated package.
Fans of old-school Cabernet Franc might also like this leafy, grilled-smelling Cabernet Sauvignon. Its tannic, abrasive palate holds spicy plum flavors that finish mildly green.

It's difficult to review wines that show significant bottle variation, like this one from Vista Hills. Here, the first example had a leathery dryness that killed any impression of fresh fruit, with a final glue-like note. The second bottle was better, with raspberry fruit and none of the tack room scents and flavors of the first. But bitter phenolics and drying tannins suggest it should be consumed soon.

Aromas of stone fruit, apple and pumpkin announce a palate that's dilute but holding onto some punch. Briny citrus flavors suggest orange peel, while this blend of Palomino and Torronts tastes slightly bitter on the finish.
Still tight, this offers pomegranate and not quite ripe raspberry fruit. It's a thin, acidic wine, which may have been overcropped or picked too early. It might have made a nice ros.
This Cava shows a citric palate, with notes of celery and lime. The finish is mild and short on a crisp mineral note.
This is yet another unconventional and unsuccessful wine from Casarena. Its wild, oaky aromas are harsh, chemical and herbal. Its tight, drawing palate is framed by green, oaky flavors.
This blend of Garhacha Blanca and Viognier is round in feel. Briny nectarine and citrus flavors are sharp on the palate and turn green on the finish.

This fruity wine, a blend of 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon, is stalky with light tannins and plenty of black-currant fruits. Crisp and with acidity to balance the fruitiness, it is ready to drink.
Straw colored in the glass, this sparkling wine has aromas of green apple and yeasty bread. In the mouth it has flavors of apple and white peach with a very bubbly finish.
A blend of 67% Syrah and 33% Petit Verdot, this wine is robust and brawny in tobacco leaf, bitterroot and an intensity of tannin. The majority grape contributes savory bites of cigar and leather.
With only 5% of Pinot Noir in the blend, this is essentially a ripe, cherry-flavored Gamay. As such it is fruity, soft in the tannins and bright with acidity. Made to be drunk young, it is ready now.
This strawberry-flavored wine offers attractive light fruits and acidity. Forward and fruity, it's a simple Pinot Noir with an easygoing character. Drink from late 2018.
This is a lightly ripe wine, possessed of pungent compost, black tea, sandalwood and mushroom aromas that follow through on the palate. The end is simple and tannic.
Smoke, red cherry and a hint of rubber show on the nose of this bottling. There is a tangy black-plum flavor on the palate, with hints of dried chile pepper and beef jerky.

As this blend of 60% Malbec and 40% Merlot opens, its floral raspberry aromas seem soapy and artificial. Its lean palate is acidic, with salty raspberry and red plum flavors that carry into the lightweight finish.
Disparate aromas of chocolate, herbal black fruits, stalky field greens and animal fur just barely pull it together. In the mouth, this is highly acidic, with salty, tart plum and berry flavors.

This wine's grassy aromas include a note of green tobacco. Its full, chewy palate turns rubbery and jammy the longer it sits. Generic black-fruit and oak-based flavors dominate, while its chocolate-tinged finish is thick with tannins.
Apple and apricot aromas lead to a simple but healthy palate. Stone fruit and citrus flavors are ample but flatten out on a low-acid finish.
Mild stone-fruit aromas are quiet on the nose. This feels plump on the palate, with dry citrus flavors that are a touch green and bitter.
This opens with light aromas of ripe black plum, toast and a whiff of baking spice. The extremely simple palate shows prune, cinnamon and a hint of cocoa alongside flexible tannins.
Mild fruit tones hide behind yeasty aromas. Plump in feel yet not overly intense, the palate deals briny flavors of almond skin, peach pit and melon. On the finish, this lingers with a hint of salt.
Deep apricot in the glass, this wine features aromas of grapefruit and guava. Made in an off-dry style, it is refreshingly sweet, with flavors of peach, apricot and honeysuckle and a tangy finish.

Quite oaky in style, this wine starts with menthol and charred-wood aromas followed by flavors like smoked meat and marinated black cherries. It has full body and a thick texture that helps it cling to the palate.
Apricot and carrot aromas show on the nose. This aging Albario is pulpy and round in feel, with prickly flavors of melon, bell pepper and bitter pyrazines.
An assertive butter and spice overlay makes this otherwise lean wine a little off-balance, but it's not hard to enjoy the vanilla and cedar aromas and crisp spare fruit flavors.
This light to medium-bodied wine has a piney aroma, light cherry and blueberry flavors and very soft tannins. It's a pleasant, pop style of wine with a suggestion of sweetness.
Restrained aromas recall baking spice and dried dark-skinned fruit. Mirroring the nose, the simple palate offers prune, clove and a hint of tobacco alongside astringent tannins.

This wine's black color and concentrated currant and blackberry aromas lead to a palate with a modest volatility issue. Its stewy, herbal berry flavors are clunky and finish with a latent note of bacon.

Thin blueberry and other blue fruit flavors are in evidence here, but they're quickly overshadowed by drying, tea leaf flavors. The aggressive tannins may be due in large part to aging in 30% new American oak.

Mulberry and blackberry fruit combine nicely in this wine, but it doesn't quite come together. There are disparate threads of tannin and acid, a hint of plastic and some residual bitterness on the finish.

Casarena's wines are always unique, for better or worse. This Malbec's earthy aromas of stewed berries and Hoison sauce are funky. It's narrow and raw, with herbal flavors of juniper, eucalyptus and overripe blueberry. On the finish, it lacks structure.
This wine's stalky berry aromas bring its ripeness into question. Fairly hard on the palate, it offers creamy oak and salty berry fruit, finishing flat due to low acidity.
This wine's peach Jolly Rancher and white flower aromas lead to lightly sprizty, off-dry stone fruit flavors. It shows a good bit of heat on the finish, throwing the balance out of whack.

This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec has raw, herbal licorice root and red plum aromas that fall short of ripe. In the mouth, it's grippy and rough, with minty roasted plum flavors that plod into the finish.

Funky aromas of bath soap, sugar beets and spiced berry fruits lead the nose of this wine. Although the palate is grating, it delivers interesting spiced fruit and rhubarb flavors. Burnt notes rise up on the finish, recalling the texture of grape skins.
This has a funky edge to the aroma, which carries over into the somewhat leathery flavor. The fruit seems to reflect a mix of underripe and overripe grapes.
A yeasty, floral aroma leads the nose. This dilute Viura has little substance on the palate, while bland flavors of white fruits finish yeasty and slightly briny on a hint of melon.
This wine is still lean, with more tannins than fruit. Its dry character gives an edge of bitterness that is not quite counterbalanced by the red-currant fruits. The dryness may well remain.
This thin, weedy wine offers hints of rhubarb but nothing else in the way of fruit. Its tannins are stiff and earthy.
Slightly pyrazinic aromas are green and gruff. The palate is simple and streamlined, with flavors of melon and peach. A briny tasting finish closes out this standard Viura.
Aromas of lanolin and citrus peel lead on the nose. The medium-bodied palate holds a bitter flavor of stone-fruit pit that leads to a clean, short finish.
This wine shows an extracted palate with flavors of raisin and toast, while tartaric acidity creates a fiery finish with a grapy aftertaste.
Creamy aromas of apple and candy corn show on the nose. Flavors of citrus fruit carry the streamlined palate.

A light rusty color and herbal red fruit, tomato and spice aromas announce this rough and tumble Malbec-Cabernet blend. Especially tannic at the edges, it tastes peppery, dry and heavily spiced. Its short finish stifles any ripe fruit.
Candied cherry and charred oak flavors tumble through this jazzed up medium-bodied wine along with cherry-syrup flavors and a candied impression on the finish.
This thick-textured wine has light melon aromas and muted fig flavors. It feels full bodied and emphasizes an oily mouthfeel.
A smoky dried-meat aroma and rich fruit flavors make a bit of an unusual combination in this medium-bodied smooth-textured wine. It has an element of oak spice and a hint of sweetness too.

Red-berry aromas control the nose of this hard-pounding Malbec. Its oversized palate is built on high acidity and hard tannins, with loud berry and plum flavors. Dry on the finish, its fruit disappears quickly.
Wet concrete and Anjou pear rinds show on the nose of this bottling. Ripe apple flavors and cut green grass show on the sip, where the flavors are a bit wild and sporadic.
This wine's wood spice, Mounds bar and coconut aromas also include notes of acetone. Woody flavors dominate the palate and persist on the finish. The oak obscures the fruit.
Baked red cherry, brown spice, wet gravel and sweet vanilla show on the nose of this bottling. The flavors trend toward muddy clay, bay leaf and light red currant.
The aromas don't seem entirely harmonious in this young wine, bringing herb, glue and light volatile notes. The red fruit and floral flavors are light, simple and not fully integrated.
This wine shows prominent volatile acidity, which overpowers its red apple, cherry and baking spice aromas. The palate has lightly styled, smooth-feeling plum flavors backed by astringent tannins.
Really flat on the nose, this shows aromas of black cherry and cedar. The palate offers bland cherry and blackberry fruit with a hint of pepper and leather.
This offers raw, lean earthy red berry aromas. It's a light-bodied and fresh Malbec, with herbal red fruit flavors. Its drawing finish tastes of herbal red fruits and plum skins.

Aromas of vanilla, yeast and frosted doughnut are slightly grassy and green. This Verdejo-based sparkler from Rueda is more wine-like than bubbly. Underripe nectarine and white-grape flavors are yeasty, while this tastes of white bread on a finish that lacks fruit and complexity.
This wine's plain apple fruit comes with an off-putting leathery flavor, which is odd given it's sealed with screwcap. The finish is short and bitter.
A soapy scent of cleanser combines with this wine's basic berry and mint aromas. In the mouth, it's raw, choppy and tannic, with herbal berry flavors that finish peppery and a touch green.
This is a leathery wine, a bit thick yet soft in texture, with a full-bodied ripeness of cherry and oaky vanilla.
A neutral nose shows a briny streak, while this feels acidic on the palate. This blend of Treixadura and Godello shows white-fruit flavors, with a wheaty tasting finish.
Prickly, fairly green aromas suggest cactus and citrus. A punchy, citric mouthfeel is lean, while this Viura tastes of lime and thyme.
Plush and round, this is a simple wine, offering ripe flavors of melon, sweet pear and green olive.
This wine is a bit flat in black fruit and moderate structure,. It is soft and round but lacking somewhat in varietal character.
This wine feels alive due to typical Txakoli acidity, but there isn't much body or structure to it. Tart green-apple flavors are waxy and inexact.

Charred cedar, peppercorn and hints of pasilla and ancho chiles show on the nose of this bottling. The pyrazine-powered chile-pepper flavor is very strong on the sip, ranging from crushed green peppercorns to mole sauce, set against a background of plum, boysenberry and coffee.

Aromas of white fruits, oak and grape skins are mild on the nose. A resiny, sticky palate leads to ripe white-fruit flavors that are oak-covered. Low acidity and heavy oak on the finish make for a cloying end.
Bold berry aromas suggest full ripeness and a certain level of ease. In the mouth, however, this feels heavy. Grapy flavors of blackened berry fruits finish chunky and with little energy.
This wine offers an herbaceous nose of dusty gravel, bell pepper and thick black cherry, the body somewhat thin and simple in structure. The tannins pierce through on the finish.
Beefy in body and also in flavor, this full-bodied wine brings aromas like singed rosemary and flavors like maraschino cherries and barbecue sauce. It has moderate tannins for a grippy mouthfeel.
Highly aromatic on the nose, notes of flowers and soap carry the lead. In the mouth, this is oily in feel yet with a strong vein of acidity. A quick blast of lychee flavor finishes short and bitter.
Soft and semi sweet, this wine has jammy, cherry-candy flavors and a smooth texture accompanied by moderate tannins.

The color of this winean almost golden yellowseems to suggest some oxygen exposure given its youth. The aromas bring corn on the cob and spice notes, leading to a lightly creamy palate that falls flat on the finish.

This is 100% varietal. It was given time in oak for two years in a combination of French and American barrels. A sweetness from the oak is noticeable, as a taste of root beer combines with juicy blackberry, the fruit ripe and round.

The white wines in the Wine by Joe portfolio are fresh and well-made and offer exceptional value. This budget Pinot Noir tries hard but offers in-your-face vanilla and cola flavors, suggesting some sort of oak chip treatment. There's plenty of flavor here, but not much Pinot Noir character.

A yellow color with luster announces maturity in this Chardonnay, while flat aromas of spiced pumpkin and melon are mellow. Mature, lightly oxidized flavors of salted corn, apple and squash are preserved on the finish by moderate acidity.
A nose of yeast, salami and overripe white fruits leads to a round palate with little vitality or energy. Yeasty stone-fruit flavors become shaky on a low-acid finish.

Aromas of herbs, lemon and blueberry show a bramble and green character on the nose. This is a minty Petit Verdot that's been padded with a lot of oak. The end result is a mix of woody flavors that are bitter and finish like mint-infused coffee.
This is a simplistic wine driven by citrus and green, stalky flavors. The palate lacks precision and finishes on a slightly bitter note.
This wine tilts heavily toward extremely oaky aromas and flavors that have a smoky, concocted flavor and nearly overpower any fruit components that might be underneath.

Scratchy, reedy aromas of berry fruits, oak grain and green herbs show on the nose. This Garnacha is pulling and narrow on a rubbery, tart palate. Sour plum and berry flavors fail to come around on a raw finish.
This is beyond light; it's almost invisible. Some hints of cola, bark and tannin come through on the palate, with plenty of astringency. But where's the fruit?

Dusty aromas of tropical fruits and melon are ample on the nose. This varietal Albillo, a grape that's rarely seen, feels round but amorphous. Salty, bitter flavors of pineapple and pyrazines leave nothing but mild bitterness on the finish.
Not much from this label has been encouraging, this raw, raspy Cabernet included. It leads with underripe aromas and follows with reedy, lightly green plum flavors.
This entry-level wine has green aromas on the nose, while the palate is pinched and tannic. Jammy berry fruit flavors blended with green-herb notes and rough tannins.
Soapy stone-fruit aromas are yeasty on the nose. This is foamy on the palate, with vinegar-like acidity. Mealy peach and apple flavors are bitter on the finish.
This is a hugely extracted wine that traffics in earthy mushroom and a streak of greenness that comes off as somewhat disjointed and harsh.
This is a mature, ready-to-drink wine with a brownish tinge in the color, and an aged aroma like cola and cedar with a touch of barnyard. The flavors are earthy and rather lean.

Medicinal aromas of latex blend with creamy, candied berry notes in this wine. The palate feels jammy and wide, lacking focus. Cheesy oak and berry fruit flavors are herbal and tomatoey through the finish.
Yeasty aromas of corn and saline water lead to a briny palate of white-fruit flavors. This is low in intensity and wobbly in stature. Drink now.

A mulchy nose with stalky aromas gets this off to a shaky start. It's light on the palate, with a mix of woody and bitter flavors. Overall, it has a decent mouthfeel but lacks substantial aromas and flavors.
This nonvintage cuve incorporates grapes from 2013 and 2014. It's dull tasting, flat and herbal, with a whiff of sweat. The tannins are potent and earthy.
This wine shows lively acidity and the sensation of resiny oak, while flavors of salt, barrel spice and baked apple show on the finish.

A nose driven by punchy pyrazine-based aromas is sweaty and not encouraging. Other than spunky acidity, the palate on this Sauvignon Blanc is dilute. Briny flavors are raw and green, while the finish is hollow and tangy.
This wine is steeped in eucalyptus and bay leaf, with a floral aroma that's hard to pin down. Its structure somewhat flat.

Stewed, mealy berry fruit aromas are lacking in clarity and quality. This Garnacha from a cool year feels lean and raw, while berry flavors are sour, weedy and devoid of ripeness. A scratchy, earthy tasting finish is not of help.
This wine has a distinct metallic note, which distracts from its already light spice and apple aromas. The palate has an untoward gardenia note.

This Garnacha smells like a smoldering campfire. A tannic, heavy, overoaked palate tastes mostly of burnt wood and hamburger, while a hint of bacon arises on an all-wood finish. This is not a well-balanced wine; it's too oaky, too heavy and just not good.
Aromas of lees and chemicals are mild on the nose. This Viura has an oily feel and a salty flavor profile that shows mild fruit tones.
This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec and Petit Verdot is not entirely in balance. Its mix of oak, residual sugar and roasted plum flavors barely make it drinkable.
At first, the palate on this Verdejo is spritzy, but then it goes flat. Chunky but dull white-fruit flavors give way to bitterness on the finish.

This wine's grassy red fruit aromas border on weedy and show a streak of oak. It's far from ripe on the palate, with dilute red fruit flavors and oaky notes of clove and mint. Its hollow finish tastes more of clove than fruit.
This Malvasia shows a narrow palate of salty, oxidized flavors. On the finish, this is bone-dry in feel.

Briny aromas lead the nose. This feels tight on the palate, boasting a streamlined texture. Nutty, salty flavors are devoid of fruit, while this Macabeo (Viura) is briny and tastes like almond skins on the finish.

This is beautully concentrated and full of great richness yet seems closed at the moment. Its apricot jelly and dried fruit flavors, acidity and botrytis are in perfect balance, developing intensity as it opens. A full, generous wine with a great future. Drink from 2023.

Powered by intense botrytis, this wine is opulent and ripe, with spice, yellow fruit and honey flavors. It has just the right balance of acidity to maintain its shape and proportions. It's likely to age well over many years. Drink from 2024.

This impressive wine has great intensity and superb apricot and orange flavors. Acidity mingles with its botrytis core and rich, concentrated fruit, striking a fine balance. It will become delicious as it matures. Drink from 2024.

This ethereal Tokaji Asz is golden in color, with aromas of delicate acacia flower, honeysuckle, fresh peach and tinned apricot. The flavors come alive on the palate, showing luscious apricot, floral honeycomb and fresh pear juice. The acidity is perfectly balanced to prevent this delightful wine from being too cloying.

The estate wine from Moucho is always a great wine. This latest release, almost black in color and five-years-old, is hugely rich, powered by black fruits and juicy acidity. Made principally from Alicante Bouschet, it shows the power and the aging potential of this variety in the Alentejo. This wine, foot-trodden in open stone lagars, is destined for much longer aging. Drink at the earliest in 2021.

Here's another stunning offering from this fantastic estate. Elegant, structured and restrained, it opens with enticing Nebbiolo scents of blue flower, perfumed berry, dark spice and a light balsamic note of eucalyptus. The luminous palate delivers juicy red cherry, raspberry, licorice and cinnamon while vibrant acidity and firm, polished tannins provide seamless support. Drink 20232043.
With its apricot and honeyed flavors, this is a rich wine. It has intense, ripe fruit and layers of spice and botrytis. A dry core gives it its great richness and aging potential. Drink from 2024.

This wine has great richness. Along with its spice and honey notes, there are orange and lemon fruit flavors that give it lift. Beautifully balanced and ripe, it has the potential to be a superb wine. The botrytis core is what gives it its great aging potential. Drink from 2024.

A booming but expertly balanced wine, this blend of 54% Syrah, 18% Petite Sirah, 18% Zinfandel and 10% Grenache shows aromas of black currant, black olive, black cherry, sweet woody spice and powdered hot cocoa. Elegant mocha and cappuccino notes thrive on the palate, which is brightened by penetrating acidity. It boasts perfectly polished tannins and ripe fig flavors, with a flash of dark chocolate on the finish.

Aromas of mature iris, blackberry, tobacco, crushed mint and baking spice lift out of the glass on this gorgeous Barolo. Despite the scorching heat, the Scavino made a supremely elegant wine, boasting black cherry, crushed black raspberry, menthol, star anise and ground clove framed in fine-grained, velvety tannins and fresh acidity. A gorgeous wine. Drink 20202031.

Robert Mondavi winemaker Genevieve Janssens makes this wine, a small-production solo project that's worth seeking. The 83% Cabernet Sauvignon is sourced from Hendry Ranch and the 17% Cabernet Franc from Detert East Vineyard, a stone's throw from To Kalon. Impressively concentrated and lengthy, within a wealth of power, it is nuanced in black cherry, leather saddle and crushed rock, with the scent of violet never far behind.

This bottling from the San Francisco-based producer is about as Burgundian as California gets. Aromas of honeydew rinds, Meyer lemon pith and honeysuckle meet with briny chalk, chiseled marble and a touch of almond warmth on the nose. The extremely fresh, clean and chalky palate shows stunning texture as well as rounded lemon blossom, sea salt and the faintest butter flavor.

Intense and ripe, this is a superb wine from a top Sauternes estate. It has all the expected elements, including concentrated botrytis and honeyed flavors. Seville orange and lemon notes provide contrast, as does its acidity, which is just as intense as the honey character. It will age well, so drink from 2025.

Straw colored with gold reflections, this delightful sweet wine has aromas of dried pear, fresh apricot and yellow peach. Flavors of fresh Bartlett pear, acacia honey and tinned apricots unfold on the palate. The finish is sweet, with just the right amount of acidity.

One of a series of releases by this Port producer, this Colheita, or Port from a single harvest, is beautifully poised between red fruits and mature almond and an old gold character. It has intensity, a product of the aging in wood that has just concentrated the wine. Like all Ports of this type, it is ready to drink.

This marks the debut of consulting winemaker Matthew Courtney's take on the estate site. It dazzles in complex notes of exotic Asian spice, lavender and crushed rock, while focused acidity provides a context of substance and depth.

Noval, one of the showpiece estates of the Douro, releases vintages in most years. This wine gives a fine reflection of what is, in fact, a great vintage which was almost a general declaration. It is impressive, ripe with generous black fruits and a fine balance between the spirit and the rich structure and fruit. It is going to mature quickly in the sense that it can be drunk within the next five years. It will also age for several decades.

This top wine from a major Cahors estate shows the potential of great Malbec. With its dense tannins, rich black fruit flavors, acidity and restrained power, it is a major force. Even with all its weight, it's stylish, complex and ageworthy wine. Drink from 2021.

Since taking over a family estate in 1998, Cathy and Daniel Fourni have focused on making great wine with the help of their expert neighbors. This is the result. Produced from organic, low-yielding old vines and wood aged for nearly two years, the wine is concentrated and dense. Mint flavors show the new wood and give a polished edge to the black fruit. Powerful tannins and juicy acidity back up its fruitiness. This is a wine for long-term aging. Drink from 2023.

This blend of Quinta del Mar and Drum Canyon vineyards makes for a very powerful and attention-demanding wine. Sultry aromas of roasted red cherry and caramelized berry meet with well-integrated clove and allspice on the potent nose. The palate explodes with ripe but acid-cut blackberry and raspberry syrup flavors, with thyme, star anise and more dark spices rounding out the power.

Created as an homage to the traditional powerful black wines that set the reputation of Cahors in Medieval times, this wine follows the old practice of heating the grape must before fermentation. The result is enormous concentration, seriously tannic ripe black fruit and considerable acidity. These are all elements that demand aging, and even at four years old this wine is just starting out. Drink from 2021 at the earliest.

Produced from old vines on the schist slopes of the upper Douro, this is an impressive wine from Carla Costa Ferreira and winemaker-daughter Rita Marques Ferreira. Dark tannins in this still-young wine bring out bitter chocolate flavors as well as enhancing the dense black fruits. Along with the rich structure and concentration, this superb wine has a sense of restrained authority and certainly the ability to age. Drink from 2021.

This is a show-stopping blend of 71% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Petit Verdot and 9% Malbec by veteran winemaker Kevin Willenborg. A deep shade of mauve, the wine coats the glass and unleashes intense, lavish aromas of cassis, fig paste, mint and tarragon. It's as soft as it looks on the palate, where baked black cherry, roast beef, turned earth and lilac flavors ride luxurious yet firmly structured tannins.

With a persistence of lightly-toasted oak, this youthful wine offers intense luxury. A gritty, stony texture complements its delicious aspects of lemon rind and anise. Green apple, ocean spray and an underlying streak of dried herb provide additional complexity and length.

A scent of French butter offers an immediate invitation to this excellent wine. Austerity on the palate gives way to a juicy core of invigorating tangerine and white peach flavors. The gravelly minerality on the midpalate finishes softly and with ease.

Wound up aromas of blackberry, roasted beef, damp forest floor and balsamic reduction show on the muggy damp nose of this bottling by Ruben Solorzano. The palate is redolent with eucalyptus, pine, tarragon and fresh rosemary, proving herbal without being vegetal, thanks to a core of elderberry and polished tannins.

What a fabulous vintage for this fragrant, radiant wine. Opening with alluring scents of iris, rose, culinary spice and perfumed berry, the focused palate delivers crushed strawberry, red cherry, cinnamon and star anise. It's loaded with finesse, thanks to firm ultrarefined tannins and bright acidity. Drink 20222033.

The vineyards of this producer in the heart of Do, close to Viseu, the capital of the region. This generous wine with its powerful structure and rich texture from the fermentation in stone lagars, is shot through with ripe black plum and damson fruits as well as acidity. It should age further, so drink from 2019.

Aromas of red berry, blue flower, menthol, exotic spice and a whiff of French oak take shape on this impeccably balanced radiant red. The palate is vibrant and focusedalmost etherealdelivering raspberry compote, Marasca cherry, star anise and cinnamon framed in elegant tannins. Weightless and loaded with finesse, it's an incredible result for what was a cool wet vintage in most of Italy. Drink through 2024.

Dedicated to the current owner's late grandfather who founded the estate, this elegant red opens with alluring aromas of blue flower, dark spice, herbs and new leather. The savory palate doles out juicy Marasca cherry, raspberry compote, clove and licorice framed by polished tannins. It's already approachable, but will offer fantastic imbibing for another decade. Drink through 2027.

Plump aromas of lemon mousse, meringue, wet limestone, white flowers and ripe key lime show on the nose of this excellent bottling. The palate bursts with flavors of cool cream, sea salt and lemon pith, set against a chalky texture. A mysteriously compelling experience.

The top wine from Romaneira shows the power and the richness that can come from this property. Aging for 14 months in wood has just enhanced the opulent black fruits, ripe tannins and acidity. It is an impressive wine, made for aging and not likely to be ready until 2020.

Ppa was the family's nickname for grandpa. The winery, run by grandson Stphane Ferreira, is the grandkids' tribute. This richly perfumed wine, by consultant Luis Pato, comes from a field blend of 21 grape varieties. Old vines with an average age of 82-years-old in a single parcel have given the wine huge concentration and rich swathes of tannins and black plum and damson fruit. The wine has power while also retaining plenty of elegance. It is an impressive wine, just approaching its peak and ready from 2018.

Classic Nebbiolo aromas of wild berry, rose petal, baking spice and an earthy whiff of truffle emerge in the glass. The elegant vibrant palate mirrors the nose, delivering juicy Marasca cherry, raspberry compote, pipe tobacco and cinnamon alongside firm, refined tannins and fresh acidity. It's a textbook Barolo that will benefit from a few more years in the cellar. Drink 20232033.

This wine is undeniably floral and voluptuous and hard to resist on the nose alone. Honeysuckle, lemon peel and flint tease and please around a focused core of oak and gritty texture of stone. Full bodied, it's lush and slightly reduceda compelling statement on power and grace.

Combining 76% Pinot Noir and 24% Chardonnay, this wine has a depth of richness and focused, supportive acidity that work well to complement each other. Stone fruit, vanilla biscuit, cherry kirsch and green apple are all within the spectrum of flavors here, finishing with grace and a hint of spice.

Beautiful in peach color, this blends 73% Chardonnay and 27% Pinot Noir. Dry and crisp, it tangles together vibrant flavors of grapefruit, tangerine and cherry, as aromas of rose petal whisper by. A stony mineral component adds complexity and invitation to the texture.

Fragrant blue flower, woodland berry, dark spice and pine forest aromas lead the way. It's racy, focused and loaded with chiseled finesse, delivering juicy red cherry, crushed cranberry, cinnamon and star anise. Tightly knit, refined tannins and firm acidity provide the backbone. Drink 20232033.

This remarkable wine offers soft luxury between its balance of fresh red cherry and cassis and the velvety grip of tannic concentration. Spiky persistent acidity guides a freshness of forest floor, sage and tobacco, the power entirely graceful in the glass.

Though still exploring the zesty acid-driven side of Pinot Noir, Marc Piro adds depth and richness to this bottling. Red cherry compote and cordial meet fennel, dill, tarragon and tapenade on the nose. The extremely lively and fresh palate unleashes an array of flower petals, just-pressed tart berries and Kalamata olives. A deep structure and thorough acidity complete the picture.

Despite amazingly luscious aromas of star anise, stewed black cherry, black currant pie and coffee cake, this bottling still offers a prominent line of wet gravel and river stone minerality on the nose. Exotic mulberry and black cherry flavors ride atop the soft tannins and an underlying acidity, while white pepper dust and menthol unfold on the finish.

Originating from a small, new producer based in the Napa Valley, this shows crushed stone and golden oak. Its essential succulence is that of high-toned citrus and apple kissed in caramel. A tease of lingering acidity makes it undeniably fresh and deliciously crisp.

Gorgeous and smooth, this elegant, 10-year-old red boasts aromas of new leather, tilled soil and pipe tobacco. The polished and structured palate delivers creamy black cherry, star anise and clove framed in refined tannins. It's a remarkable performance for what was an extremely hot vintage. Best through 2023.

What a rare, complex and spectacular wine. Well-aged and fortified wines like this are uncommon in California but this full-bodied and very sweet example proves it's possible. It has gorgeous aromas of apricot, honey and toasted nuts followed by expansive, ripe-and-spicy fruit flavors transformed by the aging process. The mouthfeel is lavish and full, enabling a wonderful finish that lasts for minutes.

Classic Sangiovese aromas of new leather, wild berry, baking spice and a whiff of menthol lead the way on this full-bodied red. It's juicy and delicious, delivering crushed raspberry, fleshy black cherry, cinnamon and pipe tobacco framed in polished and velvety tannins. Drink now through 2027.

Valdivieso's nonvintage mystery blend is always one of Chile's most curious wines, and #16 happens to be superb. An opening of rich black-cherry aromas tips towards spice cake with raisins. A lush, saturated palate holds delicious flavors of chocolaty black fruits, while on the finish a dark smokiness takes over. Drink now2023.

This is a stunning Pinot Noir, especially from a Syrah-focused winery. Beautiful aromas of lavender, thyme, wild mint and dewy spring sage meet with crushed graphite and fresh raspberries on the nose. The palate coalesces those elements expertly, with red cherry and strawberry syrup dusted by herbs and finished by licorice, all presented on a soft yet engaging texture.

This late harvest wine from Hungary is comprised of Furmint, Hrslevelu and Muscat. It has aromas of acacia flower and pear, with flavors of apricot, pear juice and dried rosemary. The finish is pleasantly sweet without being too cloying.

This vintage is the first that was under complete control of winemaker Tyler Thomas, and his studious touch shows magically. There's a powerful density of ripe but not sweet black fruit on the nose of this bottling, along with hints of violets, turned earth and leather. The structure is firm, dense and chalky but with a vivid acidity, offering ethereal, supple flavors of black currant and cocoa on the finish. Drink 20182034.

Made entirely from the famous vineyard named for its stony soils, this resplendent wine is powerfully crafted and bold. Coconut shavings and chocolate provide a luxurious flavor profile that meshes perfectly with the wine's lush grip of tannin and velvety mouthfeel. Dark cherry and cassis round out the flavors, accented in black pepper and clove.

The very intriguing nose of this bottling by a winery that explores all types of Pinot Noir sites and styles shows sarsaparilla, sandalwood, incense and fresh boysenberry aromas. The palate is all about freshness, with blackberry and black raspberry flavors lifted by anise, peppercorns and wild thyme. Great depth and verve throughout.

This is a structured, substantial wine, grippy on the palate, with firm-grained tannin and smoky oak. Mouth-filling with a juicy sophisticated core of cherry, blackberry and black currant, there's a defiant meatiness to the fruit, spiked in clove, black pepper and tobacco. Cellar through 2033.

Crisp acidity buoys sharp red fruit in this delectable winea blend of multiple sites across the appellation. Medium build, it shows youthful tannins and oak that supports without intrusion, allowing the crunch of cranberry, strawberry and pomegranate to speak forcefully.

The Serrano Mira family has been producing wine at this estate since 1667. The old-vines blend of four grapes (including Petit Verdot) is a rich testament to this legacya powerful wine that is impressively full, concentrated and dark. Despite its high alcohol, it is stylish, balancing swathes of ripe fruit with acidity and poised tannins. Drink this impressive wine from 2019.

Incredibly dark in the glass and potent on the nose, this bottling from west of Paso Robles shows dried blueberry, black currant, black pepper and asphalt aromas, proving thick but not sweet. The wine coats the palate with lavish tannins and bright acidity before delivering flavors of charred berry and peppercorn.

Alluring aromas of fragrant blue flower, woodland berry, forest floor and pipe tobacco slowly take shape in this compelling wine. Gorgeous and full-bodied, the palate delivers ripe morello cherry while licorice, cinnamon and crushed herb add depth. Polished tannins provide the elegant framework. Drink through 2026.

From the producer's Yountville estate, this blend of 88% Cabernet Sauvignon, 9% Petit Verdot and 3% Cabernet Franc offers thyme, stone and black pepper flavors within a leathery texture. Concentrated and structured, it further shines with black currant and tobacco notes that give it a distinct herbal edge.

This vineyard is in the West Oak Knoll area of the valley. The wine was left unfined and unfiltered by the winemakers, who employ native yeast for fermentation. Juicy stone fruit and zippy acidity strike a chord of balance and complexity that's low in oak and deliciously crisp in peach.

Strong aromas of mulberry syrup, exotic strawberry, allspice, cardamom and fresh cola combine for a deliciously rich nose on this attention-grabbing wine from Grenache-focused winemaker Mikael Sigouin. It's soft on the palate before the tannins tighten up, full of cherry mousse and strawberry-foam flavors that are leveled by bay leaf and garden herbs.

Very light in the glass, this fascinating exploration of the underripe side of Pinot Noir shows green olive and crushed cherry tomato aromas on the nose, with prevalent bay leaf, green peppercorn and pine resin. Those elements converge on the sip to make a cranberry, spicy herb and eucalyptus nut tea, which is tangy and complex.

This wine has rich, intense yellow fruit, orange marmalade and concentrated botrytis flavors. With all the elements in place, it is well poised to mature slowly and gently into a very fine wine. Its concentration is balanced by fresh fruit and and honey notes. Drink from 2023.
This wine is already balanced and developing quickly. It has fine acidity and crisp citrus and floral honey flavors. With its light touch, it's likely to be ready to enjoy. Drink now2021.

There is a strong pithy character to the nose of this wine, with aromas of Meyer lemon peel, grapefruit rind, Brie cheese wash, yogurt and wet rock. The palate is really tightly wound and also full of that tight pith character, with ethereal and wispy flavors of clean smoke, chalk and ash. The acidity is soft but penetrating.

Crushed sea shells and chalk meet with lemon blossoms, citrus rinds, baked pears and a touch of butter on the nose of this excellent bottling. Juicy lemon and brisk salinity drive the palate, with judicious acid cutting through the Gravenstein apple and lightly roasted macadamia nut flavors.

When it was planted with Bordeaux grapes in 1974, this vineyard was a first in Portugal. It continues to produce great wines, with this is the latest release. It is sophisticated and rich, while also finely structured. Its wood aging lifts the wine and adds spice and density. As with past vintages, this wine needs to age. Drink after 2020.

Named after the Fonseca estate in Alentejo, this wine is impressively rich and structured. It has firm tannins that are balanced by dense black fruits and crisp acidity. A blend of Grand Noir (the local name for Baga), Trincadeira and Aragons, it's a very complete wine, fermented in clay amphora and stone lagars. It's still maturing, so drink from 2019.

Showing Bardolino's more serious side, this delicious red opens on aromas of wild berry, pressed blue flower, spice and a balsamic note. With a blend of Corvina and Rondinella, the elegant, well-structured palate delivers morello cherry, black pepper and clove. Refined tannins provide the polished framework. Drink through 2019.

On the western edge of the appellation, in what locals call the Sebastopol Hills, this wine shows its provenance well, imparting wild, exotic aromas and flavors of crunchy red fruit and Asian spice. Silky, savory and inviting, it's also pretty, with impressive depth, persistent acidity and chunks of turned earth and pine.

With zero residual sugar, this winning white comes as advertised: dry and delightful in its floral, fresh and fleshy character, vibrantly supported in acidity. Peach, lime and pear flavors find length and purpose along a medium-bodied texture that's just the right amount of plush.

Extra dry in style, this sparkling blend of 68% Pinot Noir and 32% Chardonnay succeeds dramatically in its ability to be salty as a cracker and crisp as a bite of green apple, followed by a lemon chaser. Tart and lengthy, it has persistent acidity and purity that's hard to resist.

Tight aromas of Montmorency cherry, rhubarb and hibiscus are spiced by cinnamon stick and vanilla-laced brioche on the complex and delicious nose of this bottling by Edgar Torres. It's a very well-rounded Pinot Noir, with dark refreshing cranberry juice at the core and ample amounts of thyme, fennel, tarragon and black pepper throughout.

The nose on this bottling is very elegant and layered, offering well-integrated aromas of rose petals, clove, sharp hibiscus and rainbow peppercorns. Clove and allspice show strongly on the sip as do cinnamon and boysenberry, all framed by firm tannins and a bright powerful acidity.

Menthol, new leather, white pepper, fig and forest floor are just some of the aromas you'll find on this fantastic wine. Smooth and structured, the full-bodied palate evokes dried cherry, licorice, baking spice, raspberry compote and a salty mineral note. Firm polished tannins provide smooth seamless support. Drink through 2031.

There's intensely sharp fruit character on the nose of this bottling from a single clone and block in this historic vineyard, with candied raspberry and pomegranate aromas that are leveled by Early Grey tea and pressed purple flowers. The palate is extremely lively and tightly structured, with dark boysenberry and candied raspberry flavors that rise into a minty finish.

This single-vineyard wine is richly structured and seriously impressive, coming from a parcel planted with Syrah and Touriga Franca. Wood aging for 20 months has given the wine both spice and concentration. With the acidity and the firm tannins at the end, the wine will be ready to drink from 2019.

Broad, welcoming aromas of strawberry and baked red currant are lifted by mint leaf, star anise and white pepper on the nose. Pure raspberry flavors kick-start the palate, followed by waves of anise, bay leaf and juniper, proving this to be a dynamic and minty sip.

This latest vintage of this always impressive wine has great concentration while also having so much style and elegance. Its ripe tannins and juicy black fruits are just a part of this beautifully balanced wine. Coming from the Do region, it has that minerality that derives from the granite soil, giving structure. The wine is just ready to drink, although it will still mature further to be fully drinkable from 2019.

Very dark-purple fruit meet with crushed black rocks, dense purple flowers and roasted beef on the nose of this lush and delicious bottling, which is bolstered by bits of Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Malbec. Soft black cherry, caramel and vanilla flavors coat the palate, with slate, cocoa, espresso bean and graham cracker touches.

Blue and red fruit wrap around ample, tangy acidity in this medium-bodied, velvety textured wine, so classically styled for the appellation. Pomegranate, rhubarb and floral rose are all highlighted along its gradual evolution in the glass.

This is a remarkable, lovely wine, made from a site in the extremes of Annapolis. It is delightfully complex and layered, with a richly concentrated palate of dark cherry, blueberry and Asian five spice, with spikes of sea breeze and tea.

From architect Jos Perdgo's small quintaonly 17 acres on typically high-altitude merciless soilthis classic Do blend including Alfrocheiro and Jaen is ripe, still firmly tannic and mineral. It has weight and density, extra rich from the wood aging, and packed with solid tannins and balanced black fruits and acidity. The wine will be ready to drink from 2020.

This lovely, memorable wine from a fantastically farmed site is grippy in cherry and pomegranate with a backbone of integrated oak. Crunchy in texture, it shines in floral aromatics and a balanced body weight that's fruity and complex.

This rich and generous Grand Cru Class is full of dark fruit and tannins and is ready to drink. It has weight, juicy acidity and black plum and berry flavors. Ripe, with the perfume of Cabernet Franc, it's entering maturity now and should very drinkable until at least 2025.

Blackberry syrup, vanilla, mocha and a flash of mint are cut by a rocky edge on the nose of this blend of 58% Tempranillo, 21% Grenache and 21% Malbec. Extremely soft and welcoming tannins meet with solid acidity on the palate, where rich black fruit, hoisin sauce and Chinese five-spice flavors arise.

Headlining a most impressive debut lineup from this new boutique is this two-barrel reserve. Sourced from the Two Blondes (Andrew Will) vineyard, it's a thick and dense and delicious wine, packed with black cherry, chocolate and espresso. It belongs in the top ranks of all Washington Cab Francs. Yes, the alcohol is up there, but the smooth power of this wine more than justifies it.

Deep blackberry fruit and salt-and-pepper spice is brushed with warm washes of clove, cardamom and dried ginger on the savory nose of this bottling named after Ruben The Grape Whisperer Solorzano. The palate starts with a burnt coffee touch, set against fine-grained tannins that are structural but soft, and then come cassis, cola spice and black-cherry-liqueur flavors.

Spectacular aromas of sea salt, dried lemon peels, seared mandarins, chamomile, lemongrass, kaffir lime and plumeria make the mouth water simply upon smelling this savory wine. The sip is loaded with tension and judicious acidity, and yet the flavors are soft, from lemon meringue to crisp pluot and vanilla dust.

Ian Brand is a student of old vines, and it shows in this bottling from a century-old vineyard about 20 minutes south of San Jose. Rose petals, potpourri, dried strawberry and hibiscus-laced rooibos tea aromas transport one back to an old perfumery shop. Then the palate combines the woody tea spices with tart red berries, tarragon and dewy herbs. Fascinating stuff.

Fresh raspberry sorbet aromas meet with an herbal edge of pine oil, eucalyptus leaf, green peppercorn and dark sandalwood on the very compelling nose of this bottling by Edgar Torres. It's extremely lively on the palate, light in body but heavy in acid and tannic structure, with wild thyme, mint and sage decorating the mellow red-fruit flavors.

Forest floor, grilled herb, dark spice, eucalyptus and wild berry aromas fill the glass. The structured palate delivers dried black cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice, sage and pipe tobacco while taut noble tannins provide impressive support. It's savory and full bodied but also boasts an irresistible, almost weightless elegance. Drink 20202030.

A lovely appellation wine, this is dusty and spicy, as well as leathery in texture. Integrated oak and tannin make for a sharp, structured and on-point experience, with dense highlights of cassis, dark chocolate, clove and pencil shavings.

From a Barsac-based producer who prefers to use the Sauternes appellation, this rich, intense wine has weight, opulence and layers of honey and botrytis flavors. While still young, it shows impressive apricot and liquorous flavors. Drink from 2022.

Soft and layered, this perennially impressive vineyard-designate speaks highly of the variety, showing balanced offerings of plum, dark cherry, leather and spice. A smoky oak character lies beneath the fruit, complementing it well, while an expansive tannic presence supports the wine's overall breadth and depth. Big boned, this is built to age yet entirely enjoyable now.

This blend of 44% Malbec, 33% Petit Verdot and 23% Cabernet Franc shows lots of meaty notes on the nose, including both the charred edges and raw center of a prime rib slice, alongside blueberry and cedar oil. The blueberry core holds strong into the sip, where finely chiseled tannins provide a chalky mouthfeel and carry more flavors of black olive and charred wood.

Organically grown grapes go into this very fine wine. Its structure and balance confirm that it's still young, bursting with juicy ripe berry fruit and with firm background tannins. Its great fruitiness is contrasted with the strength of those tannins and with its concentration. Drink from 2020.

Tart cranberry, orange peel, cinnamon stick, rose petals and mulling spices show on the nose of this bottling from the historic vineyard by longtime regional winemaker Jeff Fink. It's invigorating on the palate, where ripe strawberry meets with rose hips and eucalyptus oil, proving mellow and subtle in structure yet engaging on all flavor fronts.

This is a very strong showing for a brand new brand, thanks, no doubt, to veteran winemaker Jeff Fink's involvement. Tight on the nose with Meyer lemon pith, savory salts and a waft of oak smoke, the palate explodes with chalky tension and rich yet bright complexity. Flavors of white lily, peach and sea salt ride atop melted butter, leading into a caramelized finish.

Enticing scents of iris, violet, menthol and exotic spice emerge in the glass. Elegant and fresh, the polished, delicious palate delivers juicy Marasca cherry, crushed raspberry and a potpourri of baking spices. It's beautifully balanced, with bright acidity and silky smooth tannins. While it's already accessible, it will also age for years. Drink 20182028.

Quite dark and viscous in the glass, this bottling shows very concentrated, deep and intense aromas of black currant, charred rosemary, roasted meat and a hint of incense. There's a coffee and chai spice component to the sip alongside the persistent dark fruit, charcoal, black pepper and uplifting flavors of violet and lilac. Strong tannins ensure a long lie. Drink now through 2030.

Romaneira's position on the north bank of the Douro above Pinhao always delivers rich, smooth and powerful wine. Its tannins, beautifully integrated into the ripe black fruits, are rounded, offering a dry core and a rich future. The wine, the top offering from this estate, is almost ready to drink. Just wait until at least 2018.

Pungent aromas of tight-grained oak meet with almonds, pecans and lemon sorbet on the opulent attention-grabbing nose. Woody flavors of sandalwood and cedar continue to the palate, which is crisp, clean and salty but not unctuous at all, with tangy citrus on the finish.

This red comes from one of the appellation's most important vineyards. Immense amounts of black peppercorn and raw beef show on the nose of this awesome bottling, which also offers soy-crusted meats that are gamy but not harsh. Rosemary oil, pine needle and peppercorns decorate the palate. It has a meaty lamb-roast richness at its core.

Iris, pressed rose, pine forest, woodland berry and a balsamic note are just some of the inviting aromas you'll find on this delicious wine. The smooth concentrated palate doles out layers of raspberry compote, juicy Marasca cherry, cinnamon and clove framed in velvety tannins. A salty mineral note lingers on the finish. Drink through 2027.

Earthy aromas of truffle, tilled soil, leather and forest berry merge with pressed rose petal and a whiff of game. Smooth, structured and savory, the poised palate delivers crushed strawberry, juicy Marasca cherry, clove and licorice. Firm polished tannins and fresh acidity provide support. Drink 20202030.

From older vines planted on the producer's estate Quail Hill Vineyard, this wine is thickly concentrated, with a generosity of oak. Creamy, intense and well made, it features complex layers of golden apple, butter and lemon bar.

This varietal wine is toasty in caramelized oak and richly interwoven with flavors and aromas of pencil shavings, plum and black currant. Grippy, with a velvety texture, it provides structure and power in equal parts.

Enticing and earthy, this opens with compelling aromas of truffle, tobacco, black-skinned fruit, menthol and a whiff of blue flower. The palate is both structured and elegant, delivering dried morello cherry, prune and pipe tobacco framed in taut fine-grained tannins that give it a firm velvety texture. It's still tightly wound and needs time. Drink 20222032.

This wine is intense in aromas of violet, rose, underbrush, dark-skinned berry and spice. Tightly wound and vibrant, the taut, elegantly structured palate delivers Marasca cherry, black raspberry, cinnamon and clove framed in firm fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. It's still youthfully austere, so give it time to fully develop. Drink 20132035.

This is the top wine from the Bairrada Quinta of Aveleda. It is hugely rich, concentrated and dark, with a solid structure. It has just arrived at maturity, giving the wine extra spice, black fruits and a dusty texture. It's a big wine in all senses, but is ready to drink now.

Floral, with a beautiful oak imprint, this wine is deep gold in color and sharply satisfying in complex layers of tangerine and grapefruit. Medium bodied and well integrated, it impresses from start to finish, ending in a bite of crunchy green apple dipped in honey.

This is a highly perfumed and floral wine from the famous site, which is tangy and slightly tart within a medium-bodied frame. Lemon and baked apple play off each other with ease, as a metallic edge of stony minerality persists and expands.

New management, farming and winemaking practices at this producer, including a focus on smaller production, are remarkably on display in this delicious white. Golden pear and crunchy apple provide an unctuous, delightfully balanced experience that's crisp in underlying acidity and subtle baking spice.

Fermented in all new French oak, this wine opens with an enchanting nose of floral beauty and freshness. Its sophistication follows through on the rich, balanced palate of caramel, papaya and crme brle, the lushness countered by a stony grit.

Exuberant in mousse, this wine is luxurious and rich, the perfect quaff for any occasion. Made from 75% Pinot Noir and 25% Chardonnay, and aged for three years, it's bright in bolts of green apple and strawberry.

Plenty of fresh purple flowers, from violets to lilacs, show on the nose of this bottling, as well as cola spice and a strong core of blueberry fruit. It's lightweight but well structured on the palate, where rose hips, lavender, fennel fronds and tarragon meet with boysenberry and light elderberry. This is still very fresh and young.

Made from a majority of Pinot Noir, this reserve-tier wine lives up to its label, showing a dry swath of wild strawberry and orange preserve among a creamy center of integrated acidity and depth. It's a delight with complexity and crispness working well together.

This Syrah, which is enhanced by 15% Petit Verdot, is one of the better wines from the region on the market for less than $25. Awesome aromas of pepper, blackberry and charred beef are intense and deep, while the palate is lifted by bountiful acidity and flavors of boysenberry, white, black and green peppercorns, incense and sagebrush.

This perennial favorite lives up to its word-of-mouth goodness, offering fistfuls of blueberry and huckleberry with a juicy length and throughput of acidity. Soft and strong, it's supple, floral and memorable in its deliciousness.

In the increasingly important Do region, Sobral's top-of-the-range is an impressively rich dense wine. With its great tannins and generous black fruits, it is full of potential. Produced by winemaker Carlos Lucas from a selection of grapes as well as parcels, the wine is concentrated, dark and firm. The acidity gives it great life as well as a juicy character that emphasizes the ripe fruit. The wine is still young, drink from 2019.

This is a wildly exotic wine, vibrantly abuzz in cranberry, pomegranate and rhubarb, a side note of barnyard-like earth and pretty rose petal. Tight-grained acidity remains firm in the glass and supportive of a grittiness of texture, notes of clove and black tea spiked throughout.

This blend of 70% Roussanne and 30% Viognier from one of the young appellation's newer vineyards is a white Rhne done right, balancing restraint with ripeness. Aromas of beeswax, daffodil, yellow rose and ambrosia melon rind lead into a fresh, tightly wound palate of lemon mousse, yellow apple skins and cherimoya, all framed by a chalky grip.

This wine is ripe in spicy black-currant aromas on the nose and intense in juicy black fruit on the dense palate. The rich, generous layers of fruit perfectly balance the tannins that build up to a harmonious whole. Still young, it will be best from 2019.

A blend of the favorite grapes of winemaker Edgar Torres (60% Grenache) and his wife, Erika (40% Syrah) from Kimsey Vineyard, this bottling shows bright and elegant aromas of boysenberry and elderberry with olive, wet river stone and pine forest. The chalky tannins still need time to evolve, but the black pepper, dark fruit, incense and myrrh flavors are well balanced.

Fresh and easy aromas of raspberry, plum candy, dark rose petals, boysenberry and allspice show on the nose of this clonal study. The palate blends big, joyous purple fruit and grippy tannic tension, also presenting lavender and Sichuan peppercorn tones.

A Napa Valley wine from the Central Coast folks at Fess Parker Winery, this Cab was aged for more than two years in 67% new French oak. Briary, it drips in brawny black fruit and highlights of tobacco, clove, leather and black pepper. An uplifting hit of acidity maintains a balance against the heft.

A gold color and honey aromas set the scene for this rich, opulent wine. It has a great layer of botrytis as well as plenty of spice and delicious apricot and orange fruit flavors, finishing with a tang of crisp acidity. Drink from 2020.

A smoky perfume marks this young wine immediately as Cabernet Franc. Its ripe blackberry and juicy black currant flavors give it richness, while tannins come through strongly. It's a powerful, solid wine, with great potential. Drink from 2020.

Get to know the local red grapes of Gaillac that make up this blend: Duras, Braucol and Prunelard. Together, they create impressive structure, concentration and intensity. Acidity balances the bold red fruit and ripe cherry flavors. It's a serious wine with good potential and will be best from 2020.

Rich, generous and packed with fruit, this is a field-blend wine that just bursts from the glass. With a fine balance between tannins and the rich blackberry fruits, the wine is ripe, warm and structured. It is a wine to age, so drink from 2020.

Light and crystalline in the glass, this snappy bottling shows ripe cranberry fruit, thyme and composting violets on the dynamic nose. Though very lightweight on the palate, it delivers waves of raspberry, hibiscus and spicy cinnamon flavors, revealing how layered and vivid that a fresh and bright expression of Grenache can be.

Enclave is Ventisquero Winemaker Felipe Tosso's collaboration with John Duval from Australia. The result is a smoky, oaky Cabernet, with subtle black cherry and cassis aromas that turn more earthy with air. A layered and structured palate is home to flavors of tobacco, chocolate, berry fruits and cassis. On the finish, oak remains out front. Drink through 2022.

This bottling from Santa Barbara County's oldest Syrah planting is always like tasting history. Aromas of roasted coffee beans and charred wood meet with pressed blackberry, vanilla and caramel on the nose. The palate combines tart black-plum skins with charred meat, more roasted coffee and lots of cocoa dust, with riper hints of fig and blueberry fruit arising toward the finish.

Fragrant and refined, this polished red opens with enticing scents of woodland berry, menthol, pressed violet and a whiff of dried herb. The creamy, luminous palate delivers strawberry, raspberry and cake spice alongside fresh acidity and refined tannins.

This wine comes from a selection of parcels on the plateau above the Lot river in Cahors. It's rich and firm, with great wood and spice notes as well as exuberant black plum and berry fruit. With its acidity, still-young tannins and firm texture, it will age. Drink from 2020.

This is a dreamy creamy white founded in stony mineral and juicy acidity that shows a mix of baked apple, pineapple and melon. A tease of green olive provides a briny, salty edge to its tense balance. A lingering hint of vanilla oak figures prominently on the lengthy floral finish.

From a high desert vineyard in the Cuyama Valley area, this bottling impresses with structure and earthy minerality. Aromas of black rocks, loamy soils and beef crust meet with shreds of elderberry and black plum on the nose. The palate's sticky tannins are persistent but pleasant, carrying flavors of dried blueberry, savory charred meats and a touch of lilac and rose petal.

A 100% varietal, site-specific wine from the heart of the appellation, this succeeds in a herbal persistence and lean nose. Red currant, cassis and anise wrap around thick tannins, with lingering notes of clove and cedar.

The blend of 55% Grenache, 25% Syrah, 16% Mourvdre and 4% Cinsaut offers subtle mulberry fruit on the nose, a spicy peppercorn kick and plenty of gamy meats. That funky meat quality, from raw to jerkied, is prominent and pure on the sip, surrounded by exotic plums and Middle Eastern spices.

There's a compellingly nutty warmth to the nose of this reserve blend of 66% Grenache Blanc and 34% Roussanne, with pecan and cashew aromas as well as more tart scents of key lime peels and lemon mousse. It lands heavily on the palate with roasted banana flavors and a buttery midpalate, but it is cut immediately by a kumquat tartness. Fascinating sipper.

This elegant bottling is named after the late actor-turned-vintner's daughter, who still runs the company. It features well-integrated aromas of cherry, rhubarb and smoke. That smoke also shows on the palate, where piquant raspberry, dried lavender, thyme, rosemary and allspice sizzle toward a lively finish.

This is one of a series of limited-production single-variety wines from this large Alentejo estate. Ripe spice and bold juicy flavors, both the hallmark of Alicante Bouschet, give this wine its richness and concentration. It is generous, opulent and just ready to drink.

This wine comes from the stony slopes above the river Tarn, 45 minutes northeast of Toulouse. That gives it its strongly mineral texture and powerful tannins. A blend of rare and local Duras, Braucol and Prunelard grapes, it's firm and structured while also full of great black fruit and potential. Drink from 2021.

Concentrated tannins and rich black plum and currant flavors distinguish this serious, dense wine. It has structure and dry tannins resulting from both the old vine fruit and the barrel aging. This is a wine that deserves some good aging. Drink from 2020.

This is a tip-top appellation blend from a winery based in the Lompoc Wine Ghetto, showing fresh-pressed raspberries, fennel pollen, dried rose petals and hibiscus on the nose. It's tightly wound on the spicy palate, with light cranberry, thyme, marjoram and Earl Grey tea flavors.

A richly spicy wine, showing its wood aging in the mint flavors as well as toast. Despite a dodgy harvest year, the wine has the dense, ripely fruity character that comes from winemakers Joo Menezes and Francisco Montenegro's use of foot treading and fermentation in open stone lagars and that gives great black fruits and soft tannins. This is a wine that is powerful and concentrated, ready to age for a few more years. Drink from 2020.

Rhubarb, cranberry and roasted plum aromas meet with gamy hints of grilled boar and toasted oak on the nose of this bottling. Light touches of fennel pollen, bay leaf and dried sage start the sip, followed by more roasted meat and rustic red fruits. It packs great energy and tremendous depth of flavors in a lightweight frame.

Richly layered red fruit accents an explosion of firm lengthy tannin, alongside dashes of clove and cinnamon, in this hearty full-bodied red. Robust and concentrated, it shows oaky bursts of vanilla and smoke on the finish.

Juicy and earthy, this lovely appellation wine is voluptuous with a spicy thread. Blueberry and huckleberry fruit meld seamlessly into savory bites of tree bark and forest as the whole offers length and breadth.

This wine combines elegance and power, complexity and drinkability. Orange rind, strawberry, flowers, Chinese Five Spice and a hint of raw meat all dance together on the pretty, lifted nose. The palate is satiny and leans more towards tart cranberry, with the spice character really shining, followed by superfine but sturdy tannins. Pair with roast duck, beef teriyaki, or a veggie stir fry.

This is a heck of a value for a wine that would shine no matter its price. Juicy in exuberant red fruit along the lines of cherry, plum and pomegranate, it shares deeper undertones of concentration and richness on the midpalate, with subtle accents of rose, cardamom and dried herb.

This is a wine for those who crave density and ripeness. Black currant, mint, fudge and burnt caramel aromas show powerfully on the nose, while the strong tannic frame leaps onto the palate to deliver caramel, milk chocolate and black cherry-syrup flavors. Roasted coffee and butterscotch touches lead into a long Cognac-like finish.

Reticent aromas of lemon peel, honeysuckle, meringue, tangerine, sea salt and chalk show on the nose of this top-end white from one of the region's pioneering properties. Rounded pear and apple show on the palate, but it's chalky and restrained, with a vein of grapefruit peel and lime pith.
